Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus is a Wolfenstein game with everything turned up to 11. If you'd like to see our hero B.J. Blazkowicsz's head separated from his body or a pregnant woman wielding dual machine guns then this is the game for you. The story is once again brilliant as is always the case with every entry in MachineGames Wolfenstein series with the game now more political than ever, but also more goofy for balance. The gunplay again excels with a new weapon introduced that seems to be an early version of the BFG from DOOM, known as the Ubergewehr. 

5/5
totally the best game ever
Crazy, bonkers game. Beyond weird. But that's make it good and memorable.

Wolfenstein II The New Colossus is the most disappointing 9.5/10 I‚Äôve ever played. It is a game that outshines its two predecessors in every single way. The gunplay is fluid and satisfying. The perk system is more fun to interact with. The stealth sections are balanced a lot better (and you are incentivized to ignore the stealth a lot more). The master-class game engine leads to a game that runs beautifully, looks amazing, and never once hitched stuttered or got in my way. The story and characters are a joy‚Ä¶. Until a certain point. Unfortunately, this games downfall for me came as death by a thousand cuts. The New Order was a game that was carried by its excellent story. The New Colossus is one of the best shooters I‚Äôve ever played but its goofy tone outstayed its welcome and soured the plot. As much as I thought the story squandered its potential, it doesn‚Äôt change the fact that this game was a 10/10 for 90% of my 13 hours with it. I am saddened by the fact that it doesn‚Äôt look like this world and characters won‚Äôt get a chance to redeem themselves in a third game.
Just wow.  You get a lot more than what you pay for with this title!!  Highly recommended after you complete the previous games.  Amazing game.

I'd recommend....with one big caveat and one smaller one....Am currently one level away from ending.  Haven't tried DLC yet.

+Great continuation of story.
+Good mix of bads; flesh soldiers and machines, and they are mixed up in battle areas pretty well.
+Well-designed environs that are varied.
+weapon mods


-This game and vram, I don't know what happened.  I've had to tool with settings so much to keep game running.  I don't have top of line system but I do have i5 11th gen, gtx 1650, 32 gb ram and am running game off of quality gen 4 nvme ssd (msi spatium 480).  I shouldn't have to play this game at ultra low with anti-aliasing off, and STILL get crashes and vram dump errors etc and non stop warnings about possible crashes.  When I play newer games with good graphics; Cyberpunk 2077, Doom eternal, Marvel's midnight suns, I have no issues, and some of those games I even play on medium settings!  Programmers here got lazy and didn't adequately program to make efficient use of vram, don't know why.  If you have gpu with at least 8gb vram you might not have issues at all but then again I've read stuff about better systems than mine having issues, so be forewarned...  

-a little improved over TNO is maneuverability, that is your ability to move around in combat, but this is still a significant issue in newest iterations of Wolfenstein generally.  You don't have ability to double-jump or grab onto ledges easily like in new Doom games.  Sometimes getting snagged on a piece of iron jutting out of ground can cost you a battle, pinning you down and making you a bullet sponge....


All that being said I'd still say it is more pleasure than pain, so try it out if you like great single player fps campaigns!

Overall: 8.5/10

Mediocre, at best. Become incredibly easy and boring if you pick the right enemies, and you can take down even the easiest enemies without effort. After the wheelchair scene at the beginning of the game, the entire thing is pretty easy.
This game absolutely falls flat however, in terms of the endgame and post-game. The "final boss" of both games are literally the same exact enemy, with no sort of build up or pay off, like in the first game. I would strongly recommend Old Blood and New Blood instead, if you're looking for a Wolfenstein to play.
Love it - 8/10

I'm playing this right after playing Old Blood and New Order, and this is the only game that I would consider "unfair at points". On the hardest difficulty in the previous games it was a tough but fair challenge, but this is the only game out of the three where there has been bullshit moments. Getting one-shot at full health and armor, autosaving at the worst possible times, and enemies with pinpoint accuracy. 

The UI is awful too. No specific key to open the map screen, a basic map much worse than the ones provided in the previous game, and the constant notifications telling me redundant information. I already know when I've picked up a collectable, I don't want instructions on how a one-time gameplay mechanic works, and I definitely don't want to be reminded that I have unread tutorials.

And the skills in the last two games when you unlocked a skill it gave you a new ability, like the ability to throw knives, and the ability to store the heavy laser weapon in your inventory. Sure, it had things that were just stat boosts, but in the New Colossus? It's all stat increases. You don't earn any new skills, you just get to do more damage, store more axes, etc. Contraptions were a good idea, but even they were implemented poorly when it was decided "hey, we'll just dump these in the one-off missions".

All in all I give this game a resounding "look how they butchered my boy".

Same thing as before in TOB and that ****ING COURTHOUSE MISSION. the enemies also have, I swear to god - EVEN the shotgunners mind you, dunno about the super soldier shotgunners tho - pinpoint accuracy on the 2nd hardest difficulty (I am Death Incarnate!)

NOTE: This is true, the Super Soldier Hammergewehr dudes have pinpoint accuracy too.

At this point ANY game that is like this and Doom Eternal (which is far worse) deserve to have trainers, which are godly saviours when it comes to crappy games like this as you get hit FAR too much.

Although after you get past that crapped up mission, you gain access to the Conwhateverthey're calleds which are massively useful, at least until you get to the last bit of the game.

Oh and William's grunt when he gets hit, especially way too much times, is one of the most annoying grunt sounds I've ever heard in a video game and this game has one of the worst flinch systems I've seen so far (worse than CoD's mind you) - instead of the flinching being based on the damage you take, it is based on how many times you get hit or both. So if you get hit by some machine gun dude too many times it will go all the way up, and if the flinch does affect aiming, your aiming will become worse.

This might be the last bit but anyways, the Ubergewehr cannot be obtained by ANY other means except from those Zerstorer ****ing "im gonna make you flinch 100 times" ***holes, the last level was the worst (although I think the Courtyard was allot worse) and I did not get the achievement for playing on the hardest difficulty. If this is because I picked Wyatt's timeline or used mods (I said MODS not TRAINERS) then that's honestly just BS.

Tthere is NO way I'm playing this game a 2nd time. As to people who got the Mein Leben achievement, they MUST've been cheating because going through like 12+ hours of a game is not possible. Lastly, which should've PROBABLY been an ability in previous games if you maxed out all your perks, you cannot carry - not at least ONE - heavy/super weapon.

Youngblood will DEFINITELY be an infinitely more worse game.

Fun, gory and chaotic. Dual-wielding assault rifles, setting Nazis on fire and fighting an entire army was incredible, and the characters are quite unique and lovable. 

Couple of issues, though. Kept getting invisible walls in doorways that I had to jump over, and you can't crouch through other doorways. Real pain in the neck when you're on a harder difficulty. And as someone who enjoys stealthing through levels, having the heavy exosuit enemies know where you are when they're not alerted is really irritating. They just stare at you and you have to kill them, which is overly noisy. Some aspects of the level design are questionable too. Other than that, pretty good game.

I really wanted to like this game. I really did. The concept is off the wall and I can definitely tell that there is a great story to be had somewhere in there, but after roughly 4 hours of opening gameplay, I just could not get into any of it at all.

Terrible shooting mechanics. Laughably absurd dialogue between other characters and with himself (feels like something I would have written in junior high with a stoner kid from my algebra class). Seriously, it's so cringe inducing I've had to occasionally skip the videos because it's so painful. The story and characters also got more wacky, stupid, and cartoonish which I think will turn off those looking for a thoughtful storyline instead of just a violent one.

Few maps, poor level desighn, stupid side quests, lot of bugs, nothing new at gameplay. This game falls short in so many ways, but it's biggest failure for me is the story.

Interesting Story And Gameplay

In the 27 hours that I played this game, I have loved every single second of it. Let me begin with the fact that Wolfenstein is my favorite game series of all time. I have played every game from Wolf 3D through to this one. The entire game encompasses what Wolfenstein is, sheer action, emotions, love, death, and fast-paced free for one. the story of this game was not as good as the New Order, simply because it was more futuristic in technology and a little more supernatural. But this does not take away from the game in my opinion, just adds to the growing lore. The interaction between BJ and Anya adds emotion and love to the character development. The ending could have been more "Wolfenstein," but the game as a whole gave enough twists and turns and emotion to make up for it. All in all, this game perfectly continues the Wolfenstein story. Strong recommend

Got it on sale for $6.00, it's probably worth that.  Shooting is kind of fun but nothing new. Story is disjointed and feels slapped together.  Cut scenes are too often, too long, and you can pause some and skip some, but not both.

Unfortunately the game play overall is just bad, glitched, unpolished.
You are always getting stuck on the environment in battles.  Heavy enemies powerslam you into walls making you a spectator until you reload the game.
Weapon selection is slow and often unresponsive and often leads to multi-tapping the key causing you to go through the agonizingly slow process of switching to dual wield.
There seem to be drastic swings in the difficulty.  One second enemies take 10 rounds, the next the same enemy takes 10 magazines.
You can get soft locked by trying to speed up tutorials when you follow the on screen instructions before the dialog explicitly tells you to do the action.

Overall this was a let down and seems like a rushed project with no real direction.

Gameplay is actually decent and even great for a casual shooter game. But for me, it's the game being "woke" that just makes this game bad. I'm not even American (I'm from the Philippines) and I still either feel bad / feel weird for some of the in-game dialog.

Just things like the story being suddenly convenient to make you weaker (literally start the game in a wheelchair) after you were able to take a tranquilizer shot that can take down an elephant (Wolfenstein: The New Order) and get up like it was nothing. Then, they make some random black woman suddenly start taking charge telling you what to do even though they didn't do sh!t until you literally showed up and rescued them.

I like this game a lot. I'm sold on its eclectic story-telling, swinging between a character study of Blaskowicz and a critique of the metastatic white-supremacy in America, when its not reveling in, bloody, Nazisploitation grindhouse pulp. It's all over the place. It switches between solemn and crass so earnestly that the tonal incongruity is something to admire.

I'm not smart enough to speak on the representation of all the characters portrayed. I can see nuanced arguments for both sides of it being empowering, but also bordering on harmful. But, from my POV, it's all in service to berate Nazis and fascists and racists. And that is a safe position to have overall.

There's technical issues with the game, for sure. I wonder if it's as optimized as it could be. I had to upgrade my computer to play it reliably, which I can understand. But even then, it complains about low memory when I play on the second-highest graphical settings. And I have a graphics card that should've been top-of-the-line for the year 2017.

To make an attempt at being succinct, I think you should play this game. It's an oddity, especially for a triple-A game. But to keep you informed, here's a list of other issues I had, in case any are a deal breaker for you:

[list]
    [*]I wish the "slow-mo" for the weapon wheel wasn't behind a specific upgrade and its tech tree.
    [*]Trying to peek corners has this weird jittery effect for me.
    [*]Stealthing towards commanders is precipitously more difficult than the previous game.
    [*]Level design is sometimes too obtuse for my caveman brain. The New York levels are disorienting and the "hint" button just tells me the objective, nothing informative.
    [*]While mixing dual-wield combos sounds cool on paper, I actually would prefer not. It breaks the flow of combat and I accidentally bring up my left-hand options constantly. Again, why is "weapon wheel slow-mo" locked behind a tech tree?
[/list]

I think that's it. Thanks for reading.

I love this game it is only second to new order but both are amazing games. like this one because of the flash backs i like the ones in new order but this on explores bj's past and his experience as a child and how he grew up in an abusive house hold because of his father but his mother comforted him.

pretty boring

I'll start with the three complaints I have.  The first is there is apparently a memory leak because it eventually maxes out my video memory.  The second is it tries to get me to buy dlc every time I launch it.  That's just tacky.  
Comparing to New Order/Old Blood: As far as gameplay goes, the only negative thing I can say (and this is arguable) is they changed what the mouse wheel does.  It no longer pops up a radial menu of weapons, and worse, the dual-wield options are not in there.  However this is because you can now wield different weapons in each hand.
The graphics are better, the gameplay is smoother, and you no longer have to cut shapes with the laser.  It's been "upgraded" to melt the entire thing you blast with it.
I don't want to give away any spoilers but this game's writing and plot are to say the least, phenomenal.  I've never had the pleasure in any other game of having my character in a gun fight from a wheelchair.  

This game is not for your children.  There are dismemberments and beheadings.  Oral sex pantomimes with victim heads, a whole lot of cursing, references to racism, etc.  How evil are the Germans?  They will send you to a camp if you're overweight and if you're gay, they will find out and "correct" you.  This game is an incredible FPS (apparently much better than its sequel) but it's not for anyone under the age of 21 in my opinion.  You'll be remembering this while you sleep.
Big downgrade from New Order, but it's still decent.

A pretty decent sequel to Wolfenstein: The New Order.

Pros:
More gore
More weapons
...better locations(?)

Cons:
The hub missions felt like even more of a slog, and it didn't help the new hub's even more of a maze than the previous one
Stealth is useless, and near impossible if you choose the ramming enhancement
[spoiler]Killing the main villain[/spoiler] didn't feel satisfying enough
Too many new characters getting introduced

Blaskowitz gotta be one of the worst modern videogame characters I've seen, along side the new Lara Croft. Really, he monologues al over the place and keeps dropping this cringe inducing f***** lines like "Caroline, lend me your wings" or other stupid s*** like that every single minute. The rest of the characters are equally terrible tho,

I gotta be honest, I didn't remember a single one of them from the previous game and they are back here so. Things happen to them. That's all I can say. Sometimes it matters, sometimes it just happens. One of them loses his arm, another gets hit, and really it never gets further than that, things happen, but not like you would care. Also they all talk loud, everybody is yelling all the time, and they all seem to have lost their minds. They are deranged and are so underdeveloped and monothematic that I just keep forgetting they even exist or even care about them. I specially love the part when they send a pregnant woman on a mission with your character, oh yeah you can expect so much more nonsense from this game that you'll be wondering what the hell whoever wrote this was thinking.

The story  has it moments. The bit where you meet H***** is really funny and kinda sorta gets close to the level of over the top comedy tone it should probably have had instead of still taking itself so seriously; I mean, whenever it's not interrupted with cloying cheesy sentimentality or nonsensical over the top developments that make little sense, specially if you undermine it with s***** over dramatic scenes. Blaskowitz keep flashbacking (yes they did) and the very first memory is one of his father, who happens to be a racist, antisemitic homophobic creep who, get this, forces you to shoot your own dog to prove a very silly point. It is so lazily written and on the nose that I kept asking myself what kind of awful trait would they come up with next. But breath easy, all other characters are equally cheap. And the gameplay, and this is my beef, feels like COD. So if you enjoyed COD or any other of the million tiring and unoriginal military shooters that have come out in the last 15 years then you're gonna have a blast I guess... or the previous installment in the series.

Honestly, I'm not a fan of this Machine Games version of the series. It's loud, it's stupid, it's annoying and it plays almost generically from time to time. The game looks great and it's well made to an extent but I can't go past the silly story, the awful writing, the terrible cardboard cutouts generic cliched nature of the characters. Thank f****** god this era of FPS is over. And Wolfenstein II might be the last of this kind, maybe an hybrid of sorts.

Alright, buckle up, my gaming comrades, because we're diving headfirst into the wild world of "Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus." Now, I don't know if the developers were on a diet of spicy sauerkraut and wacky juice while creating this, but it's definitely a rollercoaster through an alternate history funhouse.

Firstly, let me address our disappointed comrade from China, who probably expected the same level of epicness as "Wolfenstein: The New Order." Mate, this sequel is like the unexpected spin-off of your favorite TV show‚Äîsame universe, but with a questionable sense of humor.

Our Polish friend, ReVampiria, seems to have had a blast with BJ Blazkowicz's adventures, calling it a "mixture of explosive chaos and depressive storytelling." I mean, what more could you ask for in a game, right? And I'm totally with you on the ship obsession ‚Äì "M≈Çot Ewy"? Someone has a thing for nautical drama.

Now, we've got a diverse set of reviews. From MrGoodAim's enthusiastic discovery of unconventional activities with Nazis (weird flex, but okay) to Bot Marsh confessing their personal preferences (thanks for sharing?). Oh, and let's not forget about brutal advice from brutpenta ‚Äì don't be from Arizona. I wonder if that's the secret to surviving in this alternate history.

And then we have tubbz., who seems to think this sequel is like a DJ who can't follow up a banging first track. It's not terrible, just not the Nazi-thrashing party they were expecting. Sorry, tubbz., looks like the DJ dropped the beat.

To sum it up, "Wolfenstein II: The Quirky Revolution" is like a bag of mixed candies ‚Äì some sweet moments, some jaw-dropping oddities, and a couple of questionable flavors. The narrative's a rollercoaster, characters are more caricature than serious business, and stealth mechanics are like trying to tiptoe through a minefield without a map.

Rating: 7.5/10 - A wild ride through Nazi land, but the twists and turns might make you question if you're still playing the same game.

Obviously this sequel to the outstanding Wolfenstein: The New Order was supposed to be Sch√∂ner, gr√∂√üer, h√§rter (c). But apart from being more visually appealing, larger in scale and harder to beat, the game also became more annoying:

1. Unfortunately the dark nordic anti-utopian action thriller has transformed into a hollywood superhero farce with extremely annoying characters and ridiculous plot twists. 
2. The locations became larger, but harder to navigate and explore due to awful ingame map, which is small, doesn't have vertical layers and doesn't even have a hotkey like M. 
3. The collectible markers appear on the map randomly (instead of appearing after the silent officer elimination like it was in the New Order) and are completely not interesting to collect. 
4. The main storyline is rather short. Revisiting the locations for the side quests and ober-commando eliminations (kinda open-world feature) is too boring. 

What is still good:
1. Gameplay is still dynamic, bloody and fun overall. Though personally for me holding different gun types in different hands was highly inconvenient, we could have an option to set the same gun type for both hands by default.
2. Graphics are really good looking even after all these years. Though I didn't like that B.J. and Fergus looked younger, while being in their 50's.
3. The villains are still memorable nazi pigs, deserving every bullet shot in their limbs and every hatchet thrown in their faces. 
4. Mick Gordon's soundtrack still rocks.

In general I would give this game only 6.5/10, but still can recommend it for the franchise fans.

This game deserves a recommendation, but it's not perfect!

Firstly, there's the obligatory Disney Marvel influence on storytelling. I'm so done with the quippy superficial one-liner dialogues, it's funny when RDJ does it, but that's about it. Some characters are honestly repulsive. Grace for one; why are modern writers incapable of writing strong female characters? There's so many (black) women in cinema that were properly written; strong motherly figures, that nurture and cherish. Instead the trend these days is to insult everybody, pretend you're one of the boys, be rough and masculine, blow smoke in your baby's face, nice... Caroline wasn't bad, if you had to have a female leader, then fine. But she dies at the start of the game and instead of BJ or Fergus or hell even Anya taking over command, you pick up this "strong" racist black female revolutionary who simply takes over Caroline's cabin and command. What the hell? Diversity isn't enough of a reason to swap out a character, guys. At least make us believe that this character is a worthy successor/leader. Knowing what came after The New Colossus, I guess in retrospect one could have seen the signs. Possibly even worse is Grace's husband. What an annoying wimp, so glad he died... Another part of the story which I utterly thought was eye-rollingly bad, was the part from BJ's childhood. It was so terribly forced and heavy handed; modern writers can't write turmoil without going straight for racism or sexism and oooh BJ had a black girlfriend and his daddy was angry, give me a fuckn break. There's ways to write this, but not like this. The story is set in world where the Nazis have taken over the world. It's all about racism already, do we have more than one subject to pull from?

Apart from these annoying characters and story lines, my main problems were with game stability. I've gotten a save corruption during the Roswell level, luckily I had one more save game from before the level started, otherwise I would have had to restart the game entirely. I was considering quitting the game, as I didn't want to replay the level, but I'm glad I did because the second part of the game was much better than the first. 

The movement system is also really lacking in this game for some reason. I had this glitch that would make me get stuck behind every single step in the game. I figured out (out of necessity) during the last level that that was related to V-sync... But it was an annoyance during the entire game. On top of that, I had to often jump while sneaking to get over these ledges, which I would follow with a quick crouch, to get back to stealth asap, which rather resulted in doing a ground slam, alerting everybody to my position. Great. Peaking behind corners was clunky and during the constructor training course I got stuck behind an indestructible wooden dummy for some reason.

Another problem I had was with audio. I didn't get any proper immersion from the sounds in this game, very bad bullet hit reception, sometimes no audible footsteps, etc... overall very lacking. And for that matter so was the damage system, I'd have preferred a bit better indication of the damage level, playing at the second to hardest difficulty setting, I was often running around with 10 hp, without realizing I had gotten hit that badly.

This said, the game still has plenty of excellent stuff, a lot of the characters luckily are fun, BJ is a bit one note, but quite solid. He was too weak too often I think, there's ways to do this properly, but he felt a bit too spineless too often unfortunately. Anya was a bit underused in this game. Toward the end she became more interesting, but I think BJ and Anya's relationship could have received a lot more love instead of his iffy backstory or all the Grace crap. General Engel was a bit underused as well, but considering she was more prominent in previous games, it's understandable. Of course we don't usually play these games back to back, so I wouldn't have minded her presence in this one. Especially because there was no other main bad guy in this game, Engel could have played a bigger part I feel. Hitler's appearance was truly wonderful, that entire sequence with the audition and the other actors really was a blast, brava! Raw and ridiculous and funny! Fergus was solid throughout the game. Sigrun, General Engel's fat daughter and former Nazi, was a bit of a cheap character, but she had a few good moments, I particularly liked her standing up to Grace, but that was more because of my hatred for Grace than my approval for Sigrun... Max Hass has a few good moments in this one as well and so does Set, but nothing to write home about.

The game assets were fantastic as per usual, I really dig the art direction, especially the Nazi brutalist architecture, the hangars, the trains, the fortresses, etc... I wasn't too big of a fan of all the rubble locations in this game, but luckily there was a lot of good to mix things up. I prefer old-school over scifi, but it's still a wonderfully designed world.

The shooting and the weapons was again top notch, though the audio mixing would have helped out here as well.

Overall there's a lot of issues with this game, particularly in game stability and story/character development, but I still really like this game. I will skip Young Blood and hope for a solid Wolfenstein 3, with less woke bullshit. All hail Wolfenstein

I really enjoyed this game. It is kind of the perfect first person shooter in my opinion, giving lots of different ways to handle situations, such as stealthily taking out nazis with an axe, or you could take the opposite approach and dual wield one of the most damaging weapons in the game tearing the soldiers to shreds. The game also offers a lot of improvisation with the grenades and heavy weapons. You can't keep heavy weapons in your inventory, so during battle you can pick up a devastatingly powerful laser beam gun and cut through the nazis with ease and satisfaction, but they are scarce and can't be carried up ladders or through levels.

The story also offers a lot as well. (No spoilers) going into this I was mainly appealed by the shooting of nazis, but also mildly interested in the story and see how the game twists the events of the second world war, and I was positively surprised by how invested I got. By the end of the first mission I was thinking that the story would be bland and terrible with terrible characters that only speak in one liners, but as I progressed the more depth I saw in them.

The areas which you fight through were really good and imaginative. I enjoyed clearing out the nazis from the U boat we had occupied. I found that the above ground areas that weren't radioactive like the town areas to be the highlights of the game, but I wish they were used more because I prefer to see the towns that have been totally taken over by nazis and seeing the nazis interact with the real world than fighting through an underground millitary base. I mainly bought the game because of the few screenshots on the store page that show the nazis in the town, thinking that I would have more access to that kind of area, and I don't mind that it is more focused on combat inside buildings, I just hope to see more in the towns.

Great game.

First of all, I play FPS games in easy mode and single player, maybe the online and the hard challenges can improve the experience for the people interested in the game. There is like a ton of collectables that I didn't care for and extra missions to make this thing last longer.
I enjoyed the previous game, the writing was terrible but graphically it was impressive and the shooting was fun. So I decided to buy the second game and youngblood to have a brainless funny arcade experience in case I needed to release steam. 
Well, the art is gorgeous, full of detail, every nook and cranny beatifully detailed. Didn't have any crash or bug, collisions were ok, everything worked fine. Controls were intuitive. Sound was good, music wasn't great but worked  and the animation and acting was top notch. The gameplay is good but abuses the "find the general" mechanic, too much hide and seek, and the final boss was kind of lackluster compared to the first game. In easy mode the enemies were bullet sponges, even when they were only dreesed with jeans and a shirt and most of the time I was axing everybody. 
But the writing... There was little story in the first part, so the level of annoyance was little while you were enjoying your surroundings and the action. It was like a cheap 90's action movie, cheesy and unoriginal violent nonsense, but ok, you turned your brain off a few times and that's all. 
They decided that we needed very long cutscenes, real time interactions between your comrades, tons of boring memos and a big cast of characters. Everything is terribly written and themes like mental health, racism and diversity are introduced in a way so clumsy that kills any empathy you could have for the characters. You just want to kill the nazis and then all your comrades and finally suicide, so the new world could be a better place without this parade of violent terribly beings. Everybody acts like a teenage edgelord on drugs with little knowledge of reality, and sometimes it's difficult to realize who the fascists are in this game. It's sad how the good acting and visuals have been wasted with this terrible writing. Some people compares the game to the movie "The thin red line" because there is a cosmic junkie character(?), it was more "the teen ret**ded lines".  And next is Youngblood. I'll try an indie narrative game first to clean my mind.

50% of players finished the game. As for me i beat it on "i am death incarnate" but it wasn't fun.
Overall feel can be described as "If cringe was a game". Imagine 'New Order' but as if it was a song. 'The New Colossus' would be sh1ttyfluted version. You still recognize original but it's just "funny version" of it. But at least game's sort of entertaining after all. Non-brainer as most Netflix movies. I don't know how to describe the game more. A rollercoaster. I won't be surprised if at some point game will start playing "rapping for Jesus" mid-fight.

You still fight nazis but now story turns into some GTA5 sh1t sometimes with quirky and dumb characters, cliche stoner jokes and just inappropriate jokes. By inappropriate i mean that it's not the best timing for them. And the more you play the more ridiculous story gets just like in GTA San Andreas. It gets more and more cartoony. So if you just abstract from the fact that you're playing 'Wolfenstein: The New Order' sequel you even might have fun with it. I even caught myself thinking that if you switch BJ with Duke Nukem, adapt story and setting, you'll get perfect 'Duke Nukem Forever' game, actually...

As for gameplay itself. I found it really exhausting.
B in the B.J. initials stands for 'b1tch', i guess. First 4-5 hours your health is capped by 50 HP and you die from 4-5 bullets with or without having armor. And it would be okay if enemies sometimes wouldn't come at you like they randomly spawn around and you die often. But, hey, we have quick save/load feature now. So you get annoyed by loading every 5 seconds during big fights.
Also using guns themselves feel awkward. You still can wield guns in both hands but switching is so clunky, slow, non-intuitive (first 'Call of Juarez' did it better) that you just don't enjoy fights. BJ runs so f-king fast you clip into everything and it really is distracting you. So in the end you just kill bots in a good ol' boring "one by one" way. Sometimes simply camping them like a little b1tch.
But even when you can get 100 hp and even 200 hp you still die like a b1tch taking slightly more hits before you die.
Graphics are actually good. Probably it's the best looking game based on Id Tech. But lighting works against you. Like in real life your eyes have to adapt to brightness change so when you fight in dark rooms or simply at night, shooting enemies becomes pure chore and torture just like in Crysis 3. Night goggles would be nice.
Game is definitely not a 'git gud' case. Mostly it's luck and big amount of ammo.

Wasted potential. Give it a go on a sale

There are two games in Wolfenstein 2.  One of which is a modded version of Wolfenstein 3D, the other is Wolfenstein 2.  One of these games is an unfun slog that often disrespects player choice and has enemies react in often unpredictable ways.  The other is good, mindless fun.  Take a guess which one is the bad game.

[h1] Desktop / actual Review [/h1] 
the 2nd Entry of the Wolfenstein Reboot - the first one was already amazing, the 2nd one, i'd say, is basically more of the same, in a good way! although not as many cool POI's as in the first one, but that's kind of hard-to-top, the first one was very good afterall.

the Story is well-explained, eventhough many say the comedy doesn't fit very well, it does the job for me. the more serious scenes are hard-hitting aswell, gives you shivers in some scenes.

anything Gameplay related I don't have any complaints, great gunplay, music, weapon upgrades, etc.

the Performance is fantastic - a far-cry of what you see these days sadly, it runs on absoutely cranked settings on 3440x1440 Ultrawide like a champ, locked 144FPS, only a stutter when a new area loads, which is okay!

Horrible PC port, played for a few hours and it crashes right after the loading screen all of a sudden now, and it's not just me, there are many other players facing the same issue. I have tried everything to fix it, including updating graphics drivers, verifying integrity of the files, changing compatibility and display settings - basically everything listed on all support threads I could find. So disappointed, I don't even understand how this game is being sold to this day with the only option on the official support forum being "update the drivers". Uninstalled.

-Side missions are essentially just ‚Äùgo search for this thing‚Äù or ‚Äùkill this commander‚Äù

-the regular bethesda bugs are there, saves crashing, long load times and terrible performance.

In conclusion play The new order instead

In the game about fighting Nazis, a group of people who are bad because they are genocidal lunatics, guess which political faction the game makes you team up with. take a wild fucking guess. Here's a hint: it's the one group who killed more innocent people than the nazis.

I cannot begin to explain how obnoxious and preachy this game is. within the first hour, they kill of an enjoyable, "strong woman" character who still manages to fight despite her disability and replace her with the worlds bitchiest black woman, who spends the entire game (atleast, every single interaction I had in what I've played of this game) complaining about white people not solving her problems for her. whilst a group of white people do everything for her. To be fair, she does break this up with occasional one-liners so incredibly cringy it goes beyond funny or even ironic. although she never actually follows through on said one liners, preferring to stay in the safety of the sub moaning about white people.

furthermore, for the first half of the game, the main character is plagued with bad dreams about his father, who is quite possibly the worst written "bad dad" i've seen in any form of media. when you do finally kill the dad, it just feels like a self-insert fantasy from one of the devs who made the stand-in of their own irl dad comically evil as some absurd attempt to justify wanting to kill their own father. here's a list of some of the things the dad does:
-reports his jewish wife to the nazi occupiers because she bemoans him too much
-makes his son kill his own dog to get him to him "man up"
-beats his son for making friends with a black kid
-almost every lines he says is punctuated with slurs just so you know he's a bad guy.
-etc, etc
At first, I was absolutely positive the depiction of the father was just an exaggerated version created by JBs mind as it slowly falls apart, but no. that would be too nuanced. the father literally is just the worst dad in history. except the one time he makes a good call to deal with his sons night-terrors but it's played off as some right-wing gun nut crap.

The complete and utter lack of self-awareness from the devs is simply the cherry on top of this white-saviour fantasy.
here are some other examples of ridiculous crap:
-the main character, usually depicted as being constantly worried about his partner, barely even protests when she goes off to fight despite her being heavily pregnant.
-Frau Engel, the main villain, whilst busy cutting off the head of the resistance leader, starts making fun of her own daughter for being fat. because just in case being the former head of a concentration camp wasn't evil enough, she also bullies plus-sized people *gasp*.
-upon the death of the resistance leader, she is replaced within a few days by the black woman, who literally nobody in the resistance has ever met before, who has spent the past decade hiding in a tower, doing basically nothing. this is despite there being dozens of other members of the resistance who are both exponentially more qualififed, and established within the group. this is met with absolutely zero complaint, and every character immediately shows total subservience, including Fergus, a scotsman noted for his bad temper, who is repeatedly called an englishman by this new-comer. in a game known for exaggerated characters, something that would irl get you punched is met with slight grumbling.

I will admit that, in a vacuum, the gameplay itself isn't bad, but this can't even be considered a compliment because it plays basically the same as the last game. this entry brings nothing good to the table, whatsoever. it's not even worth the 6 AUD it costs on sale rn, as i could just play the first game and listen to an AI generated black woman voice read off critical race theory literature whenever a cutscene pops up.

Wolfenstein 2 is literally anti-white and anti-male propaganda.

Instead of following their signature gameplay of hard-hitting combat with Terror Billy like in New Order and Old Blood, Machine Games decided that it was a better idea to do a line of blow off a leftist college instructor's buttocks, then take a huge steaming dump on the Wolfenstein franchise.

The whole game is pointlessly racist with excrutiating cut-scene cringe that will land you in the hospital. There are no recognizable men in this game, BJ has been ruthlessly deconstructed from a Nazi slaying super commando into a weak wheelchair bound vegetable in the beginning then they constantly go into cut-scenes where he connects with his sensitive side with the females in his life and of course his dad is a racist charachiture of an abusive white father. This isn't BJ, it's a totally different character.

They should have stuck to making good gameplay consisting of shooting nazis, it's not that hard... instead they delivered absolute trash, the worst Wolfenstein I ever played, Machine Games have embraced mental illness.

The good

-Gunplay is very fun dual wielding firearms never gets old.
-Graphics look great on high settings 
-Pacing for missions feels right
-Killing Nazis from a wheel chair 10/10
-Level designs are well made and its fun to search for the hidden objects

The Bad
-Enemy AI doesn't seem to be that intelligent, they seem to just rush you and not utilize cover as much.
-The all white people are with the Nazis trope.
-Jabbing against male masculinity and pushing women as the saints for mankind. 

Overall I am enjoying the game and my playthrough regardless of the issues I listed above. The game is a steal when it is on sale but I wouldn't pay $59.99.

Alright, listen up, you digital warriors! In the crazy world of virtual mayhem, WTNC is your ticket to a strategic extravaganza that mimics real-world military shenanigans. We're not talking about your grandma's bingo night; this game's got more tactics than a chess grandmaster on steroids.

You want to be all sneaky and sly? Go for it. Prefer charging in like you've got a date with chaos? We got you covered, from shotguns to laser cannons ‚Äì whatever floats your boat or blows it up. And the best part? Your perks, they're like your personal sidekicks, tailoring themselves to your playstyle. It's like having a buddy who knows all your moves before you make 'em.

But wait, there's more! Side missions turn your resistance HQ into a hive of activity. It's like the bustling market of rebellion. Explore, find hidden gems, and soak in the lore like a sponge in a rainstorm. This game isn't just a game; it's an experience ‚Äì like going through a virtual boot camp for your senses. So grab your gear, get ready for battle ‚Äì the resistance needs you, and it's not gonna save itself from the pixelated oppressors!

This game is a worthy successor to the prior games. I really enjoyed the story and the wacky characters. Gunplay also is a lot of fun, especially how you can turn into a whirlwind of death in later stages of the game. Graphics are also quite good. Sometimes, the way forward is really poorly telegraphed and you trudge around the level until you find the correct way forward. 
I kinda miss the melancholic vibe and Blasko¬¥s monologues from the first game, the story vibe is often a little bit too over-the-top. Some characters could be described as flat-out caricatures. 
Apart from that, I got my money¬¥s worth. 

BUT: 
Sadly I encountered quite a lot of bugs including a broken quest that I could only circumvent with the help of Google. 
Enemies frequently spawn directly behind you, even if you just cleared that corridor to your six. 
How is this a thing, some years (!) after release? 

The √úbercommander missions on higher difficulty are frustrating trial-and-error nonsense. 
Also, whoever designed those chunky, constantly patrolling robodogs that explode on death, I don¬¥t like you.

Another great game in the series

I am seeming like the world's most cantankerous reviewer lately, but no.  I play games to enjoy experiencing other worlds, timelines, flights of fancy, whimsical chaos, moments of concentration interrupted by unexpected impossibilities of the sort you can only obtain via the astounding power of modern technology.

I do not play games to choose which innocent person to murder because the developers think that this Edgy Choice(tm) will get me more invested.

Normally I sure make it a lot farther into a game than I did here, though!  Once I finally got the cutscenes to stop crashing the game, I discovered the first choice you make in the game is "which of your old friends do you want to watch butchered?"  Haha.  Neither!  Oh, but of course neither is not an option, and even though he alludes to the idea that your stubbornness can outlast his patience, the scene is literally playing on a loop, and after 15 minutes of letting it loop I accepted this game was not going to be for me.

So Wolfenstein II: New Colossus proudly joins Prey (the 2006 one), Spec Ops: The Line, and Walking Dead: New Frontier in the "games I refuse to continue playing because I will not actively engage in the scripted murder of an innocent person" category!  Congratulations!

It's not great.

The gun variety is poor, worse than the previous game. Your arsenal is also poorly balanced. The (upgraded) assault rifle is the best weapon by a wide margin in the majority of situations, and when it is not the best, it is still the second best. It is also very ammo efficient on top of having plentiful ammo, and is found very early.
Meanwhile, the pistol is less lethal than a placebo, and all other standard weapons are highly situational, with only very specific circumstances in which they outperform the assault rifle, while the heavy weapons cannot be kept forever and slow you down to a crawl, which is a death sentence. On top of that, weapon swap speed is very slow, and the weapon wheel is janky and not very responsive (at least with keyboard and mouse, I heard it was better with a controller). So if you are using a different weapon in a situation where it shines (typically, the shotgun in tight corridors, as that's basically the only other weapon that is sort of effective - when you can get close to enemies), and then find yourself outside of the situation in question (say, stepping out of the corridors into a wide hall with enemies shooting at you from afar), you will get wrecked while you spend 4-5 seconds pulling out another weapon. So since the assault rifle is, as stated, at least second best at all times, you find yourself simply using it 90% of the time, with the remaining 10% being when you begrugingly switch to something else during prolonged engagements because you ran out of ammo for the rifle.

4-5 seconds of getting wrecked might not sound like much, but you are actually very fragile, and this is more than enough time to get killed. The game also has poor feedback for damage taken, and sometimes (often) you just plain don't notice.. There were multiple times where I started a fight at full health+armor, and then died suddenly despite thinking I hadn't even been hit yet.

For some reason, the auto-pickup range is pathetic, you basically don't pick up anything automatically unless you actively walk on it. You end up having to spam E to manually pickup everything that's dropped. Not fun at the best of time, but in the middle of a heated firefight it can mean missing a useful ammo or armor pickup that's hidden under debris, or accidentaly picking up a heavy weapon which will instantly get you killed because now you are slowed down and it'll take several additional seconds before you can throw it away.
Strangely, the manual pickup range is pretty generous on the other hand, there were multiple times where I picked up items I had no idea were there because the prompt appeared anyway.

Enemies are very bullet-spongy and take a long time to go down (unless, again, you are using the assault rifle), so fight end up taking longer than they feel they should.

So... yeah. Not great.

it was fun.   I'd never even looked at any of the games from this series until this one..  not disappointing.  

My one regret is that after the ending and the Nazi threat is "dealt with", I can't go through the submarine and "deal" with all the commie scum in the ranks of my own group.  a true patriot BJ would accept neither Fascism nor Communism.. and there are some... ohhh there ARE some. Only a complete idiot would want either of these systems in their country.  just sayin'

all in all, taking my own political feelings out of it, the game was very fun, highly(un-PC) offensive, which is perfect. I didn't encounter any bugs, crashes, lag or any of the other uncountable flaws common in most AAA games these days.

7/10  (1 point docked for not being able to "clean up" the submarine after the story.  lol)

Gonna give you the most honest review I can.

Story: The story of the first game (New Order), in my opinion, was better than this one. This one feels slightly forced and like the devs tried too hard to one-up the first game instead of letting it come naturally or building on it. It's still a good story - by no means is it bad - but don't expect it to top the first one.

Gameplay: The gameplay of this game takes what New Order had and massively improves on it. Graphics are a massive improvement, dual wielding is now mix and match (can have a shotgun in one hand and AR in the other, as opposed to only two ARs or two shotguns), new enemies types to take on, new gun types to use, ranged melee is more satisfying and can travel further, new armor upgrades allow for increased combat maneuverability in very interesting ways, takedowns are more variable and gruesome...just to name a few examples. Me personally, I love the way this one plays.

Now this is where the review takes a complete 180 degree turn (and don't let this dissuade you from playing, unless you're very intolerant/impatient or don't have a great pc)...the game is insanely buggy. I don't mean Skyrim buggy either, where most of the bugs are just funny or strange and can mostly be ignored. Every bug I have encountered in New Colossus has messed up the game in some way to where I had to restart from a previous checkpoint or restart the game entirely. At random points throughout the story, the game will just freeze, and the only way I have found to fix it is to ctrl + alt + del and end task. I've waited before for like 20 minutes and it never came back. I have an RTX 4070, i7 13th gen processor, and 32 GB RAM, so there shouldn't be any video/computing issues at all, but it happens at least once every half hour to an hour for me. Furthermore, assets in the game can become full-on obstacles, and you can't get over them unless you jump or change video settings. I'm talking like ridges on the floor that you can't step over or a tiny box that is impossible to walk, jump, or sneak over. It's almost like there are invisible barriers. Sometimes you can just jump them, but other times I've had to turn my video settings down a notch or two, or turn my FPS to 0 to get over them. Also, there are random chances through the story that an enemy (particularly the supersoldats) will become completely invincible; bullets go through them, explosive damage does nothing, and ramming into them with ramshackles is like throwing a feather at a concrete wall. The only way I have found to fix this issue is to reload a previous save or just run past them in parts where you can progress without killing all enemies, otherwise they'll just inevitably kill you. This last one has only happened once, but there was one instance where I was on an elevator moving to the next part of a level and all of a sudden my character just died while I was on full health. There were no enemies and I wasn't near anything that could cause damage, I was just standing in the open and my character all of a sudden dropped dead. I had to restart the previous part of the level I had just finished because of this.

I am able to look past the game-breaking bugs, as I really enjoy the series and the gameplay when it does work. However, I acknowledge that most people are completely turned off by issues like this, and that is why I left this review. If you are someone who can look past the bugs, I believe you will really enjoy the game as I have. If issues such as those I mentioned are deal-breakers for you or you think they will ruin your experience, don't waste your time, because there's no shortage of them at all.

Hot damn, I'm gonna break my pattern of writing shit posts for reviews

New Order was a dystopian thriller, horrifying and even a bit hopeless. It sent a message, it was great.

New Colossus is not a dystopian thriller, it's an action sci-fi movie. The tone has completely changed.
Now, you still kill Nazis and that's a big plus.
But after playing it I can absolutely see why so many people prefer New Order or even Old Blood.
I don't know what message this game was trying to send and it was kind of all over the place.

Neat, but good god, I am NOT a fan of such a brutal change of tone.
If only I wouldn't have the hindsight, otherwise I could've hoped that they'd pick up the pace in the next game.

Be the ultimate badass. Kill Nazis.
Either all guns blazing, or try being stealthy, it's your call.

And you even get to hang out on your submarine between missions, and chat to your fellow rebels. All of which are fleshed out proper characters which you will grow to love.

The story is actually must better than I was expecting, and you get to see some interesting, highly detailed places. There are some ridiculous twists, but the game... knows that it's ridiculous.

At the very start of the game (I won't spoil anything from later on), you're a paraplegic in a wheelchair with a machine gun. It's silly, but has some remarkably touching moments, courtesy of the great voice acting and motion capture.

It also has some replay value, from a choice you make when you start a new game. Which makes for quite a different playthrough.

If you're looking for a single player FPS with a story that'll make you care about your NPC friends whilst making you laugh and still featuring some best of genre gunplay, I can't think of many better recent examples.




To summarise: The gunplay is great, very tight. And there are a good variety of shooty things. The story is strangely enthralling whilst being totally preposterous. In a good way.

This sequel is not as good at The New Order, but I can't say it's a bad game. The story is way too Science Fiction even for my nerdy taste. There are a lot of scenes out of the place (for example the opening chapter where you fight in a wheelchair) and a lot of questionable game design choices different from the previous games (no chapter select, no pause during cutscenes, downgraded perk system). They also added new characters that don't really fit in the Wolfenstein universe, it feels more like a Netflix move more than anything. It is also a nightmare if you are a completionist and try to attempt the 100% for this game, that turned me down a lot and I just played the story without looking too much for collectibles/upgrades using a lower difficulty. I played the main story a few times. The first thing I always notice, is how annoying the unskippable cutscenes in the beginning are. I can see that it's important as a story introduction but after watching them a few times, being forced to watch the same thing over and over is just annoying.
The second problem with the cutscenes is, how much of the game is taken up by cutscenes instead of actual gameplay.
The gameplay looks impressive and is fun at first glance but feels unfinished. Combat is either jokingly easy or way too hard. 
The Enemy AI is really dumb and randomly looses track of you, even when using unsuppressed weapons. They only know duck and cover or run shoot.
Stealth is just as broken. Enemies spot you through walls and find bodies from halfway across the map. The Area 52 and Venus Oberkommando sections are very frustrating to play if you want to be stealthy.
The Story is kind of all over the place. Sometimes very dark and serious, sometimes so satirical and ridiculous that you can't take them serious. The scene with Blazkowicz and Anya arguing about how he is slowly dying and Super Spesh coming out of toilet and destroying the atmosphere is a perfect example of this.
I really tried to like this game but there are just too many annoying aspects.
If you want to kill Nazis with good combat and stealth mechanics, I'd play Sniper Elite 5 over Wolfenstein 2 any day.
Doom if there was humor and nazis instead of demons. The history is cool too and the games makes you want to play more.

The New Colossus is an absolute banger of a game, with a few minor issues.

It manages to do guns blazing, dual wielding and explosive combat alongside pretty good stealth, a bit of exploration and light RPG mechanics.

My only issues with the game are story and oddly enough, music related. I really like the story and characters, the cast introduced in The New Order is top notch to watch, but i do wish the story had a more satisfying ending. The one we have is very appropriate and not at all bad, but it's just a bit sudden and doesn't really end the game with a bang.

The OST is fantastic but the music volume is honestly too low, even when maxed out. Plus there's just 3 volume sliders, Master, Music and Dialogue, which is really stupid. You can either really enjoy the music and have everything else, SFX and voices, be deafened or vice versa. Maybe there's mods or guides online to change that, but the game doesn't revel as much in its music as DOOM does, which it absolutely should. Mick Gordon doesn't miss.

The side content is great, i like the collectibles and the readables really add to the world, but the assassination sidequests are too numerous and get kinda boring after a while.

And i don't recommend a very high difficulty if you're a guns blazing type of player, cuz you'll just get murdered before you even fully stand up out of cover. For that i'd recommend Medium difficulty and High difficulty for a more stealth based playthrough.
Game can annoy by crashing a lot but other than that I had fun with Wolfenstein 2

This review is mainly going to be how it runs on the Steam Deck I have played both on Steam Deck and regular Desktop and the game is Good on both.

For reference my Steam Deck has the normal GPU and CPU that it comes with the only thing Upgraded is the storage I have a 1TB SSD Storage Upgrade and Brand New Hall Effect Joysticks.


When playing Wolfenstein 2 The New Colossus on Steam Deck the game runs flawlessly at around 45 - 60 FPS up to Medium Settings there may be some dip in Quality if you set it to High or Very High but it should still run relatively well seeing as how it's a smaller aspect ratio.

The battery life on the Steam Deck when playing lasts usually 2.5 - 3.5 Hours depending on Settings used I typically set my settings to Medium and I have my Frame Limit set to 45 it doesn't make much difference at all setting it to 45 compared to 60 other than it just looks a little less smooth.

The default controller configuration for this game is perfect everything is easily accessible and easy to use it's a very familiar controller configuration that really any gamer can navigate.



The only downside I have with this game is that maybe I'm just inept with controllers but it does not feel smooth at all and I struggle with aiming sometimes so maybe it's just me but I feel like this game is BUILT to be played with ease on a regular desktop.



Overall this game is really good on both PC and the Steam Deck all I have issues with is using a controller cause I just suck with them but that's not really Steams fault at all.

[H1]Wolfenstein: The Colossal Cringefest[/h1]
I grew up with Return to Castle: Wolfenstein and Enemy Territory. RTCW remains one of my all-time favourites and It's not just nostalgia - I replay it quite often and consider it a timeless FPS. I can't say the same about the MachineGames's Wolfenstein. 

[b]The whole Nu-Wolfenstein saga is extremely mid and The New Colossus is a waste of time:[/b] 
- The majority of the game consists of cutscenes.
- New characters are infuriating.
- The villains are comically evil (which was not the case with past Wolfenstein titles and it feels completely out of place) and barely relevant to the flat plot. 
- Level design reeks of wasted potential. Some of the locations at first glance are stunning but soon you are put in the same grey corridors, bombed-out buildings, and warehouses we have seen so many.
- Side missions are a joke and shouldn't be here.
- Worst story pacing I have seen so far. The gameplay gets interrupted by cutscenes quite often. There is almost zero world-building or anything different than shooting (in the same galleries or corridors), watching cutscenes, and repeating. There are a couple of difficulty spikes that happen out of the blue in which on higher difficulties you need to cheese the (atrocious) AI to progress.
- Almost zero enemy and weapons variety. Atrocious AI which simply doesn't work.

I'm just glad I bought the Nu-Wolfenstein saga bundle for dirt cheap. At least the next instalment in the series is better... right?
I have completed The New Order with 100% and now i have played The New Colossus for 1 hour and it is just bad and disappointing.

I wish there was a 1-10 scale for Steam reviews. I personally think the combat is great and I like the story. But my biggest issue are the cut scenes. They were, in my opinion, long in The New Order, but I have replayed this game and during the cut scenes I wander off and feed the fish, play with the cat, eat, until the cut scene is finished. Anymore, I play up to a point and get bored and stop. If they gave me the option to wander around and explore while the  "story" is going on,  it would be ok. But, I am trapped. New Order was bad, but not quite as bad. The cut scenes are well done, and the voice acting is great. But if I want to watch a movie, I will either stream one or go to a theater.

When the game does let you play it is fun-although I felt like they recycled some of the ideas in New Order, particularly going to Venus instead of the Moon. You can stealth it or go in guns blazing. 

Overall, for an occasional or one or two time play through, great. I recommend getting it on sale. So I recommend it, I guess?

I was looking forward to playing this game as I have finished nearly every Wolfenstein game, except for YoungBlood. After starting with Wolfenstein the Old Blood, I liked the game. Good pace, story, visuals and destructive weapons. A 8/10 game. Then I jumped to the sequel Wolfenstein: The New Order, and to my surprise that game was less fun than its prequel. But regardless, it was a blast. 

But then when I tried Wolfenstein 2 I felt it lost everything I liked about the past two games. The first criticism is that in this game you don't really feel like Agent Blazkowicz. It's more like a normal soldier. Level design is disappointing as hell; you're thrown into these small environments where it's really difficult to move around during combat without a soldier coming from behind. The only exception was the courtroom where you had the freedom to take cover, reload, run to another place and ambush them without always worrying about receiving a bullet.

The story is really...off. First, it starts great, but then it feels off. And the way the game ends, it feels...rushed. Add to that the music isn't as great as its predecessors with no moment where I felt like a total badass. I always felt helpless in this game, unlike past games. But all in all, this sequel is a disappointment.

Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus ‚Äì A Bold Leap in Narrative-Driven Shooters
"Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus" stands as a testament to how video games can effectively blend gripping storytelling with exhilarating gameplay. Developed by MachineGames and published by Bethesda Softworks, this first-person shooter not only entertains but also provokes thought with its daring narrative.

Graphics and Audio:
The game boasts visually stunning graphics, with detailed environments and character models that bring its alternate-history 1960s America to life. Lighting and textures are employed masterfully, creating an immersive world that's both beautiful and haunting. The audio design is equally impressive, featuring a dynamic soundtrack that adapts to the action, and voice acting that delivers powerful performances, particularly Brian Bloom's portrayal of protagonist B.J. Blazkowicz.

Gameplay:
At its core, "Wolfenstein II" excels in its fast-paced, brutal combat. The gunplay is satisfying and varied, offering a wide range of weapons that can be upgraded to suit different playstyles. Stealth mechanics are also available, adding a layer of strategy for players who prefer a quieter approach. The game‚Äôs difficulty settings are well-tuned, catering to both newcomers and veterans of the genre.

Story and Characters:
Where "Wolfenstein II" truly shines is in its storytelling. The game tackles themes like fascism, resistance, and the human spirit with unexpected depth and nuance. The narrative is bold and often shocking, with moments that are both intensely personal and broadly political. The characters are well-developed, each with their own compelling backstories and motivations, making the player's journey through the game more engaging and emotional.

Performance and Technical Aspects:
On the technical front, "Wolfenstein II" runs smoothly on various platforms, with few reported issues regarding bugs or glitches. Load times are reasonable, and the game maintains a consistent frame rate, which is crucial for fast-paced action games.

Conclusion:
"Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus" is a remarkable achievement in the realm of narrative-driven shooters. It combines thrilling gameplay with a powerful story and well-crafted characters. While its unflinching portrayal of dark themes might not be for everyone, it‚Äôs a game that pushes the boundaries of the medium and offers a deeply satisfying experience for those who engage with it.

This is a rather mixed game. What the game does well, it does it really well. And what it doesn't do well, it really doesn't do well.

[u]Good:[/u]

-The graphics still look really good.

-Replacing the knife from the previous games with a hatchet was a brilliant choice.

-Weapon upgrade system is an outright improvement. (Although having locking the pistol silencer behind it was a really dumb idea.)

-Dual wielding is also an improvement over the previous games. Unlike the previous games, in this game you can actually aim your shots without the camera suddenly getting a need to focus on the ceiling like it did in the previous games.

[u]Bad:[/u]

-The story is overall worse and less engaging than The New Order. Not only that, but the tonal whiplash present in The New Order is even worse here. In one scene a guy is having a conversation about how he's dying and how he won't see his kids grow up. And then in the same scene a guy comes out of a toilet breaking the emotional involvement I had in that scene. (Not helped by the same guy literally praising the toilet like a deity a bit before that.)

-World building which was excellent in The New Order isn't really here. The world of The New Order truly felt like a realistic authoritarian nightmare. The world here just feels like you're going from level to level.

-Characters. Some are good. Some are awful. And others aren't memorable.
Here are some examples. Fergus, I like the dude. He's fun and has some interesting character moments between him and his robotic arm. But Super Spesh is a pure annoyance, comedy relief character done poorly. But Grace is where the character writing goes out the window. The moment you save her and her group she immediately starts calling Eva's Hammer as "Her boat." Immediately starts being hostile with some beloved characters from the first game, mainly Fergus. And just starts bossing around everyone like she's the queen of the world. In a scene when you meet her, the game tries to portray her as sympathetic by her saying that she loves her baby. Problem? In that same scene she lights a cigarette while breastfeeding. I've literally no idea what the writers were thinking when making her character.

-Character agency. All of the old characters quickly get sidelined when the new ones are introduced. In The New Order, while at times over the top, the characters felt like people. BJ, Anna, Fergus, Klaus and Caroline all felt like people with their own thoughts and reasons for fighting back. Here, they might as well be dogs doing what others tell them. 

-The gameplay is...not as good. Commanders are heavily overused meaning that a run and gun play style isn't as viable while they are alive. But the stealth is the same half baked excuse present in The New Order/Old Blood. 

-Variety is also lacking. Yet again, in a timeline where Nazis conquered the world with mechs and Jewish wizard technology, we still have "Dude with gun." and "Bigger dude with gun." There's some robots too, but other than the robot dogs, the only difference is the health bar. 
The gun variety also suffers. The guns aren't all that unique and don't feel quite as punchy as in the previous games.

-The game is also a buggy mess. The game crashed a few times, the frame rate was also dipping for no reason and the "The video driver has run out of dedicated memory. Your gameplay experience will be negatively affected" error annoyed me to hell and back. What helped with the crashing and frame dips was setting the game to the High graphics preset, even though I could go higher, the game just didn't seem to like it. The errors persisted throughout the whole game, every time you boot up, every time you start/finish a level. Just awful.

-Some scenes were a bit much. Either cringe-worthy or trying to be mature about touchy topics and failing miserably. 
Certain scenes at the start and end of the game just feel like too much/overindulgent.

-Lack of boss fights. The game doesn't really have any boss fights, the only thing that is sort of a boss fight happens on the second to last level. Not really a big deal, just disappointing.

[u]In conclusion:[/u]
Overall, this is a game with a lot of issues. I got it on a sale and feel like I got my money's worth, but I cannot deny than some of the issues above soured my enjoyment. The game has some really awful writing, gameplay with a lot of the same issues from the previous games which are now amplified in this one + some new ones.  
If you're a fan of the Machine Games Wolfenstein games, get it. At least to see where the story goes.
Overall, it's a 6/10. A lot of missed potential.

VERY VIOLENT - LIKE SERIOUSLY.  NOT FOR CHILDREN - PROBABLY NOT FOR ANYONE WHO HAS HAD RECENT TRAUMA OR THOSE CANT SEPARATE REALITY FROM FANTASY.

+
Carries on with New Orders story fluidly - shoot sneak, bossfight.  

-
Unbearably melodramatic and 'right on' in places.  We are talking 'younglings' territory here. 

I secretly loved New Order.  I have always loved the 'what if'  sort of fiction along the lines of books like Fatherland.   

The cold but familiar world conjured in these two games is remarkable - ruined by two things:

1 Melodrama.  Oh God the melodrama.  

2 Reality in the real world where dictators are making a bigly, heads bashed bloody and tea poisoning comeback.  

The last isn't the games creators fault - just that when fiction starts becoming reality with so called leaders abusing their people and even just talking about destroying their 'opponents' (never mind actually doing it) it becomes off putting.  

The game is very linear but so well paced that I did not really care.  If William suddenly took an open world type of twist where he supported the Nazis and KKK, that would probably end the game right there.

Expect a few surprises - but not that surprising.  

It also pulls of a good trick in that a lot of the mechanics are familiar from the last game but it doesn't grind or seem like a con - the action is so well paced over all it's familiarity is snug jumper sort of familiar rather than didn't I already pay for this familiar.  

Play for the action and chilling setting - grit your teeth through the melodrama.

W3D & Doom started the whole FPS bonaza.

FPP - First Person Perspective
FPS - First Person Shooter
Doom clone - term that was used from '92 to '96 (release of Quake) that means the same as FPS, just doom was so groundbreaking that every other fps game was compared to it.

All of FPS are FPP, but not all FPP are FPS.The alternative being third-person perspective -- or TPP -- which, technically speaking, should include any game where you're looking at the character you're controlling from the outside, but which, in practice, is usually used to describe games with an over-the-shoulder "follow cam" (as opposed to "isometric", top-down, side-view, and probably others).

The FPS term wasn't widely used before release of Quake, before that they were all called "Doom Clones" or FPP. Doom was actually the first game that brought recognition to the FPS genre as something distinct (even though there are games that fit FPS description and predate doom about 19 years, Id themselves released at least 3 FPS games before doom - Hovertank 3D, Catacomb 3-D and Wolfenstein 3D)

So if you want to be specific use FPS, if for example you want to talk about System Shock or Deus Ex use FPP as they're mix of FPS and RPG. And all games that came after doom and before quake can be called doom clones (heretic, hexen, duke nukem 3d, shadow warrior e.t.c.)

There's also a subgenre of FPP that contains vehicular combat (i.e. descent series) that some consider to be FPS and some do not so in this case it's safer to use FPP.

New Colossus has some good things going for it in 2023 and some bad.
Story line is interesting and the characters for the most part keep the story moving.
The alternate time line may be objectionable for some people. Humanity has a history of extreme bigotry and atrocities as well as a history of great accomplishments and altruism. 

The game play in Colossus is buggy at times. Crash Dumps and issues with video memory seem to be the issues most people notice on PC. There are many posts on these issues but fixes recommended depending on PC hardware don‚Äôt always resolve these issues. I would have thought that Colossus being a later developed game would not have these issues. The graphics in Colossus are very good and allow many options to tweak settings but the video out of memory bug is absurd.

I had no problems running New Order and enjoyed that game more because the game interface was easier to manage. Colossus at least let‚Äôs you manually save games and New Order did not.
The missions are fun with puzzles to solve and areas to explore. The perks for BJ and the weapon upgrades help to move the story along.

For all older players the enigma machine can be frustrating. Pattern recognition can be a stumbling block for older players especially with a timer involved. First always save your game before using the enigma machine. That way you can reload the game so you don‚Äôt lose your code or back out of the machine before time runs out.  This suggestion may help or not. I found out through trial and error once you solved the first pattern look ahead and identify the next pattern let the timer run down not out before locking down the first pattern key. Repeat for each pattern. That way you are always anticipating and ready to enter the next pattern and not letting the timer bother you. You still may have to try several times to get all seven patterns done. Just keep practicing and don‚Äôt let it frustrate you.

Overall, I enjoyed the game even though a little off the wall with Decapitations and attaching heads to different species. This is Wolfenstein love it or hate it. It is just a game and like all entertainment takes us away from our reality and transports us to another world.

Series topped with New Order / Old Blood and every entry since has been a massive disappointment.

If you have read my review of [i]Wolfenstein: The New Order[/i]-and if you haven't why not? It's quite funny-you'll know that one of two major beefs with the game is the way BJ goes all existential in the cut scenes. Weel if you're hoping for a change, forget it. In [i]The New Colossus[/i]  he gets even more existential and there's a lot of in the beginning THAT YOU CAN'T SKIP. We get to learn about BJ's abusive father (who really is quite the piece of work) and his gentle loving mother. It turns out that BJ is [spoiler]half Jewish on his mother's side[/spoiler]. No wonder he and the Nazis have such animosity towards each other. No, I'm pretty sure the Nazis hate BJ because at this point he's probably killed the equivalent of the population of Leipzig in Nazi soldiers. And BJ hates the Nazis because . . . well they're [i]Nazis[/i] for starters . . . do you really need any more than that?

So what's good about the game? Well as always. you get to kill a f__kton of Nazis-[b][i]always[/i][/b] a plus in my book. That alone makes the game worth buying if it's on deep discount (and I did). You get to travel to interesting places like the radioactive ruins of New York City (instead of the ordinary ruins you normally see when visiting), and the Nazi equivalent of Area 51. You also get to liberate the good old US of A from under the Nazi Jackboot (it's got nails in the soul . . . er, I mean sole-ouch!) and travel to exotic [spoiler] Venus to kill the wretched puling, drooling pants-s___ting carcass that Hitler[/spoiler] has become.

What's bad about the game? Well apart from the existentialism and the unskippable scenes, there are areas in the first chapter that you cannot access until you get to further down the autobahn, meaning that you have to go back and replay those levels if you want to fully complete the level. That's not just annoying, it's bad game design.
There's also not a whole lot of humor in the game-I mean okay, I get it, Nazi tyranny, nailed jackboot on the throat of my beloved country, et hoc genus omne. There wouldn't seem to be a whole lot of humor in that situation, but I disagree. There's always room for funny, especially when you're making fun of Nazis. It's like [spoiler] The Donald[/spoiler], they just can't stand being made fun of. And as a wise man once said, "If it can't stand being made fun of, it's probably not much good." I mean look at [i]Wolfenstein:  The Old Blood[/i]. It's not really a laugh a minute, but there are some really funny points. Google [spoiler] Wolfenstein grammar Nazi[/spoiler] if you want a great example.

You also can't toggle the iron sights which is kind of a pain when you're trying to lean out from cover to send another Nazi to an extremely gory end-and from there to Hades presumably.

Lastly, just about all the background scenery has kind of a washed out look to it which I find annoying.

So in conclusion (assuming anybody ever actually reads this), it's definitely worth buying. Most of the DLC seems to be Dodo doodoo from what I've read in the reviews and overpriced Dodo doodoo at that. Personally I'd wait for a really good sale, but I [i]am[/i] notoriously cheap.
