Lets get over it already. You are not funny. You can't meme. Stop bringing that shit here. 

And the reason why I still leave a positive review is because like I said before, most of the gameplay related stuff is actually amazing, and that's what I value the most. 

But please, stop it.

I don't have much to say about this game.

29 hours of this game was simply agonizing. The single biggest problem this game faces is the gameplay loop. That is just open section with commanders who can summon other soldiers if you don't kill them soon enough, bossfights, smaller linear stealth or shooting sections, and cutscenes. The gameplay loop was so annoying that by the time I was in the mission where you were supposed to get the atom bomb into the bunker, I was painfully aware that the gameplay loop would be the same.

Another thing are the difficulties. I've been playing on Call me Terror-Billy, and this must be one of the most painfully unbalanced games I've ever played. There was NEVER a single time where I ran out of bullets for all my guns and was forced to smack my enemies with my bare hands, never a time where I was forced into stealth, never a time when the resources were scarce. But, on the other side, there were a lot of BULLSH*T moments where I got killed from one or two shots, even on full armor and health. 

The positive things about this game? The game is simply stunning-looking, the music and sound design damn near made me BUST at certain points, the shooting feels SO GOOD, the weapons' punch matches their beefy look, the level design is simply masterful, and the game itself is so well optimized that even my potato PC can run this game at High settings preset. 

Still, it's hard for me to recommend this game to anyone besides fans of the Bethesda's Wolfenstein and Doom games. There is nothing even remotely appealing for people who don't play FPS games in here. This game suffers from bad gameplay loop and unbalanced resource to combat difficulty ratio, but it also benefits from it's graphical design, sound design, funny writing, great story, and great level design. Therefore, if you don't mind a repetitive gameplay loop for nearly 30 hours, then go ahead.

It really suffers from being the middle of what's probably going to be a trilogy (I [i]really[/i] hope it doesn't take [i]4[/i] games to get around to killing hitler), setting up several plot hooks that just aren't resolved and also calling back to things in the first game that aren't as impactful if it's been a few years since you played the first (which you should [i]definitely[/i] do before playing this one).

The sections where you're stuck playing hide-and-seek on the submarine trying to find whichever NPC the game wants you to talk to really slow the game down, and most of the cutscenes involving only your allied characters feel like filler.

Don't get me wrong, I had fun playing it. But the operative word here is [i]playing[/i]; it wasn't half as fun to [i]watch[/i].

Gunplay is weighty and satisfying, sound effects create a visceral experience when metal meets meat. And here's what I didn't expect: it's genuinely funny and emotionally/intellectually stimulating. Everyone involved in the production of this game is deserving of all the accolades.

I wish I could buy them all dinner and thank them for what has been a very enjoyable experience that moved and entertained me throughout. Again, very funny. Comedic timing, VO and animation department just crush it. I doubt any of the developers will ever read this, but sincerest thanks for what obviously required much skill, love and restraint (the most difficult of all creative qualities to master).

Oh and I saved the younger guy in the beginning and don't regret it for a moment. The artificially-induced existentialist madness (sanity?) was awesome. Every character was, really.

A Gritty Triumph of Resistance - "Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus" Review

Rating: 10/10

"Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus" is the second installment in the modern Wolfenstein series, developed by MachineGames and published by Bethesda Softworks. This first-person shooter is a direct follow-up to "The New Order," and it continues the epic journey of B.J. Blazkowicz in an alternative history filled with action, emotion, and unrelenting resistance.

Storyline: 10/10
The game picks up right where the previous installment left off, plunging players into an alternate history where the Nazis have seized control of America. B.J. Blazkowicz leads a small group of freedom fighters in a desperate battle against the oppressive regime. The storyline is an emotional rollercoaster, filled with memorable characters, impactful narrative choices, and a genuine exploration of humanity during times of extreme adversity.

Gameplay: 10/10
"Wolfenstein II" offers a thrilling blend of intense combat and strategic gunplay. The game builds upon its predecessor, delivering an even more satisfying arsenal of weapons, abilities, and combat mechanics. Players can approach battles with different tactics, from stealthy takedowns to all-out mayhem. The gameplay remains consistently engaging and is a hallmark of the series.

Graphics and Atmosphere: 10/10
Visually, "The New Colossus" is a masterpiece. The attention to detail in crafting a Nazi-controlled America is astounding, offering a dark and gritty environment filled with both the familiar and the bizarre. The atmosphere is enhanced by a superb soundtrack and voice acting that immerses players in a world of oppression and resistance.

Characters: 10/10
The characters in the game are exceptionally well-written and developed. B.J. Blazkowicz's personal journey continues, showcasing his vulnerability, determination, and growth as a character. The supporting cast is equally impressive, each with their own stories and motivations that enrich the overall narrative.

Conclusion: 10/10
"Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus" is a tour de force in the first-person shooter genre, offering players a thrilling, emotional, and challenging experience. The storyline is a standout, driven by well-crafted characters and thought-provoking themes. The gameplay is nothing short of excellent, keeping players engaged from start to finish. Visually and atmospherically, the game excels, providing a rich and immersive setting.

This is not just a game about fighting Nazis; it's a deeply personal and profound exploration of resistance, freedom, and the human spirit. "The New Colossus" continues to raise the bar for storytelling in gaming while delivering intense action. For fans of first-person shooters and those who appreciate strong narratives, this game is a must-play. MachineGames has once again delivered a triumph of a gaming experience, leaving players eager for the next chapter in B.J. Blazkowicz's journey.

I can't believe this is the sequel to The New order. What a missed opportunity. just played both for the first time, and The New Order completely blew me away and was just as good as I was hoping it would be when i first saw gameplay as a young lad. So hot off the tail of the previous game I hop into this one. Downgrade from two previous installments. Movement is clunky, my character got stuck a few times in door frames, and levels quickly become repetitive. Overall the game feels unpolished.

For some reason, like the first game, The New Colossus decides to start with its worst bit: fighting Nazis in a wheelchair. In an FPS. Hmm. Oh well, at least it turns out to be a fun shooter once you've got past that section. However, there is a caveat to this: for the first five or six hours you can only fight with a maximum of 50 health, and can only increase this temporarily with extra medkits and wait for a critical story section to recover the rest of your health. Prepare for a lot of scavenging, and in my case, quicksaving. 

Speaking of the story, the characters are still great, but the overarching plot has to be one of the most "gamey", implausible, and bombastic I've ever seen. Wait for your disbelief to peak when [spoiler]you encounter Hitler on Venus (a planet hot enough to melt lead) in the guise of a prospective actor[/spoiler]. 

It's still a brutal, entertaining shooter nonetheless, if one where the stealth is not so satisfying as in The New Order, because the more linear level design sometimes makes it very hard to eliminate the commanders first before getting past the common troops. Still, melee takedowns are very gleeful thanks to Blazkowicz viciously hacking them to death with a hatchet. 

I think I prefer The New Order, but if you like that game you can't really miss this one, especially if you find it in a sale like I did.

Developed by Machine Games, Wolfenstein 2 takes the Wolfenstein trilogy to new heights. After the success of The New Order,  many fans were wondering how a sequel can possibly live up to the excellent story and gameplay of the original. I myself had these fears going into playing The New Colossus. While the story is more goofy this time around, Wolfenstein 2 improves the gameplay of both The Old Blood and The New Order. It takes what fans loved about the first two, and kicks it up a few notches. I absolutely loved my time spent playing the game, and it was one of the most fun story-driven FPS games I've played. Is it over the top and too unrealistic at times? Yes. Does it constantly poke jokes and sometimes resorts to using toilet humor? Yes. But that's the entire point. It's both satire and parody, and Wolfenstein 2 delivers both in an astonishing and epic fashion. We get to explore more about the background of "Terror Billy", and how he faced many instances of physical and emotional abuse by his father. These aspects help us feel empathy and compassion for William, and better helps us understand his motives. While I preferred the more serious and gritty tone of The New Order, I can't help but feel Wolfenstein 2 is just as good. They are both vastly different, but in unique and interesting ways. Both hold a special place in my heart, and I recommend everyone to play all three of the modern Wolfenstein games. All three were absolutely amazing and worth every penny I spent on them. If you're looking to kick some nazi ass with a compelling and dark story, this game certainly delivers.

OVERALL RATING: 9.5 / 10

A total downgrade for previous entries. The gameplay starts good but after a quick 1 or 2 hours you start to see all the problems the game has. 


[h3]1[/h3]Terrible lazy level design (go from A to B and abrupt fade to black level transition). 

[h1]2[/h1]The game doesn't know if to focus on stealth or action, and let me tell you, if you go guns blazing (I mean you have this amazing akimbo guns in your power) you're gonna get melted really fast.
So you spent most of your time crouching spamming the "grab" key for health and pieces of armor from the level. You pump those numbers and for what? Some well placed shots and you are seeing red all over. Rinse and repeat.

[h1]3[/h1]Talking about level design, the art and presentation of some levels is really nice, you probably watched them they are all over the place on Youtube gameplays and Showcases. The very first level inside the Ubot, The Roswell: Downtown District, The confrontation with Mustache' piss boy aaaaand... what else? The very last level maybe? When you go outside the flying fortress to the big showdown and boss fight of the game. That get this. You can just skip all of it if you just run and grab the ladder at the other side. YUP.

[b]Note:[/b] It's not the only "boss" fight that you can do this, when you go to the "occult" facilities to steal some tech or whatever, this huge Mech appears and you go "aaaww shiet, this it!". All for what? Just hide a bit and run to the other end. My god, what a piece of vomit and terrible game design is that?. And before you start saying anything, imagine if Half-life, Doom (2016) or Eternal or whatever it's up your valley, had this mechanic in boss fights. "Oh, no need to worry son. Boss too difficult? Just run over there to end this fight". Abysmal. 

Going back to topic, the level design most of the time are short and uninspired. And when they do get your attention it's for brief very short moments. 

[h1]4[/h1]The story. Oh god, where to start. First of all if you played The New Order you will know that at the end of the game, Blazko' simple put, just dies. Finito. Finish. And all in all, it's was a well done send away for the character. Also, the way it's presented there's no way he will come out of that situation. 
But in here, (I guess the money making machine had to continue) you get the laziest bamboozle moment in cartoon story, when they strip all away and he gets rescued anyway, you know, because yeah. I get it, the show must go on, right? But at least do it in a way that it's believable and coherent. And not this BS that was made in 4 seconds in the lamest way possible.

[i]Anyway, that it's just the start. The story from there continues decent enough but soon enough you realize that the characters are always over the top (to try to get your attention: some "Decapito"! Executions! Some shouting & Drama! Some old dude pissing himself and general morbid but lazy stuff) like Irene Engel that never captures the vibe of Wilhelm Strasse "Deathshead" -from The New Order- that with "less" he got under your skin really quick. [/i]

Loved characters from the Original get destroyed, have no depth or any character growth except for some cringe one liners. I could go on and on, but in general there's nothing but except one or two cool moments that at this moment you all saw them in Youtube, probably in a cinematic or a direct moment from the game. I wanted more of that but the game died on me at the 10 hour with nothing more to see or watch in terms of more story development. 
The game just doesn't know what to do with old and new characters, it's just in a rush mode jumping for A to D all the time.

[h3]5[/h3]Bad design choices. Not only you take more damage than previous entries, but you start and need to endure 60% of the game with a handicapped health. Yeah, I can hear you scream "oh, but Aguila, that's because of the Lore/Presentation of the story and then you get a suit that fixes that a-and.." WELL, FUCK THAT I SAY! Who thought that going around with your nose in the ground spamming the use key reaching for extra health constantly was a good idea? It could had worked for a level or 2, but not for more than half of the game!

Yeah, then you get your head in mode "fly me to the moon" and get a cool armor suit (lore) but things don't get better -well just a little bit- because like I said, that armor goes down really fast when getting shot. And you know? When you do get to that point the game just ends. Haha! Yeah, maybe 3 or 4 levels and abrupt ending. And what a shit ending that was, I better don't go deep in that one.

[h3]6[/h3] This actually a good and bad point. There were some -very few- cool acting and voice actors too, like the dude who Acted the Father of Blazkowicz. Even if I don't like the script or what they did to the characters the performance was solid. I hated that dude more than Irene! Haha! 
Oh, and big Mustache Vomit Boy and Art Director Girl did great in that scene, we all know it by now, really adding a tense atmosphere. But that's about it, it's just that scene, they appear and they are all gone. A shame really. 

[h3]7[/h3] Enemy variation and cool designs. Where are they? Where are the new and cool fantasy/tech armor from the previous titles? Well to be honest, the Dogo in armor firing fire was cool -but not entirely new- you get a really few extras I believe but not memorable and nothing more.
So get ready to kill the usual grunts because none of them stuck in my mind to be worth mentioning. 


[i]Anyway, as you can see I left all the "Politics & Agenda" moments in the game outside of my review. Why? Because the game it's just that: a bad game. All of the other noise and political aspects of the game I couldn't care less. If anything, it's just juvenile or in your face writing to get a reaction out of you or directed at some groups of people. You take that out and the game it's still poorly made.[/i]

Sadly, B.J Blazko' and Max Hass (my favorite characters from before) don't go out with a bang, but rather in a messy game that didn't know in what direction to go and ended in a short Convoluted Mess. 

[u]Warning:[/u] There's a demo for you to try, but it's not by any means the quality of what you will get in the rest of the game. I bought it in a big sale and I still got disappointed.

The story is OK for the most part, but a bit heavy on cinematics.

Okay I have to admit.  I hated this game when I first played it.  I just got done with New Order and I was looking for a similar experience.  I played through New Order first time on I am Death Incarnate because I'm a vet at FPS games and the original Wolfenstein, Spear of Destiny, and Doom games.  That game was a fantastic experience.  When I started this game I was extremely frustrated by the difference of the game.  I set it also to I am Death Incarnate hoping to struggle but ultimately beat the game.  The game at times seemed impossible early on.  Then I realized one crucial part of this game.   PERKS.  This game expects you to either die and slowly level or to repeat missions to level.  If you look at perks you get ranked levels based on how you kill things.  For example, every 50 people you kill dual wielding you get a larger ammo capacity.  Knowing this you can grow your character over repeat deaths and eventually reach the point the game is easy.  It just sucks because you will die lots of times in the process.  The game literally is like a Dark Souls in difficult, which I typically love.  Having gotten way further now I would definitely recommend this game, but be mindful of what I said above.  You will find yourself leveling a lot at the harder difficulties because you NEED to survive.  If you have that patience of dying and repeating to level, you'll be into this game.  If that seems like a grind you will hate this game.

Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus begins directly where The New Order Ended. After General Deathshead was killed, it was time to start the Revolution and finally kill the Commando and General Engel. The Characters get a lot of Development in this game and it really shapes in. In contrast to TNO the Game never felt like it was too long, even if the Game itself is longer. Thats mostly because of the brilliant Level design and funnier story and improved Gameplay and Graphics.

At the beginning of the game you'll get a short rewind of TNO and you have to decide (again) if you save Wyatt or Fergus. Instead of TNO and TOB, its actually worth to play through both timelines because Wyatt and Fergus get a lot more character depth and its really funny to hear their bullshit (seriously, it's awesome).

At around half of the game you can also choose between one of three "skills" you earn because of an well "serious injury". Which also adds a lot to the awesome Gameplay. 

The Game is brilliant and adds a lot to The series. I really liked that funnier approach of a story instead of the total serious settings of TNO and TOB. I mean you literally ride a pig in this Game after you drank a lot of liqour.

Even if General Deathshead was a better opponent than Frau Engel, this game really offered a lot more than TNO and its absolutely worth it to play through both timelines.

"Mother trucker dude, that hurt like a buttcheek on a stick!" that's exactly how I felt when completing this freaking game, it's unbelievable, graphics are amazing, a real upgrade to previous Wolfenstein games, gameplay feels fresh and at the same time familiar. You've got several weapons at your fingertips to mix and match to kill tons and tons of nazis on many different and creative ways.

I had already heard many good things about The New Colossus, but boy, this thing is perfect, I had high expectations and I was amazed by what I found, graphics-wise looks great, full of details and high definition environments. The gameplay is fluid and fast, the story is catchy and interesting, an amazing conclusion to Blazko's story. A very satisfying ending, gory as hell. 

Regarding my journey to completion, it was the most challenging thing I've ever done, most of the achievements are your normal kill number, collectible, etc. But damn, once you go for Mein Leben, it's gonna be real though, but at the end it is doable and once that little thing pops you'll feel amazing.

In conclusion, great game, beautiful graphics, excellent gameplay, intriguing story, extra challenging achievements. Get it as soon as you can along with the other two Wolfenstein.

In Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus you play as a relentless resistance fighter battling against the oppressive Nazi regime in an alternate version of history. 
The game offers a action filled single-player campaign with fast-paced gunplay, satisfying stealth mechanics, and strategic combat encounters, every moment is filled with excitement and adrenaline.

Works great on a steam deck too: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qBkzyJSHYeo

In addition to the single-player campaign, the game offers replayability through its various difficulty levels and multiple paths to explore. 
There are also additional challenges and collectibles scattered throughout the levels, rewarding exploration and providing extra depth to the overall experience.
With its gripping storyline, intense gameplay, stunning visuals, and thought-provoking themes, Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus is a must-play for any fan of this cult first-person shooter franchise.

A pretty good game overall. Funnily enough I stopped playing when I realized you don't have a flashlight. Such a silly, silly thing. But just this one huge oversight makes me unable to recommend this game. It's beyond stupid and breaks immersion bad enough (why wouldn't the character carry one, most places he goes it would be expected) to break the game for me.

First of all, I want to say that you would enjoy this game if you found the previous games fun. There is clearly an improvement since the last game, which is not surprising because of the generational differences. Overall, the game is pretty average, it is not boring but neither fun.

My biggest problem is that I feel the like the game has an identity issue, you can go stealth in most levels, yet the systems are not deep enough to support that kind of gameplay.

When you want to play fast, the mechanics of the game hold you back. Changing weapons is a pain in the ass. Wolfenstein wants you to take cover and slowly change your weapon instead of going all in and feeling powerful. I played the game below on the second hardest difficulty, which I never normally do.

In the end, Wolfenstein feels like a cool MVP demo and has some really great potential. Sadly, it fails to reach that potential. I would recommend playing DOOM if you want to experience a well-designed shooter instead of Wolfenstein.

Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus is an astonishing continuation of the new and rebooted Wolfenstein franchise. It retains most of the qualities from Wolfenstein: The New Order and cranks it up a little. There is some awesome weapons at disposal with some cool new mechanics to come with them. Being able to have two separate guns in each hand makes for some innovative game play. The whole idea of killing Nazis is perfect for a game like this, as everyone hates the Nazis and what they did to society. We are enraged at them and being able to go rampant on them in this game just makes you feel good. It was a clever enemy choice. The graphics are very impressive too. Certainly the best in the series so far. The game play is quite fast and you always need to be on the move, but you can also take a stealthy approach which can be more a little more rewarding. Some new abilities were included too, especially when you can choose between three new contraptions. Also, there is an abundance of collectables to obtain which makes for some major replay ability. On the topic of replay ability, there is now seven different difficulties that can be played from. That is sure to get hours up high. Though, on any difficulty the game is still pretty challenging. There are three additional DLC's that you can purchase. Each of them follow a new character that is resisting the Nazis. Much like the main campaign. They all have some interesting motivations and stories but they all have one problem. The game play is the exact same. Nothing new is added at all. The only new thing is the story and the moon environment that you travel to in the second DLC. Furthermore, each DLC ends with you going to assassinate someone in the final mission. There was wasted potential with this DLC. However, the main campaign makes up for this substantially. The antagonist of the main campaign, Frau Engel, is developed really well and we love to hate her. Characters from the previous game make their returns and the usual Wyatt or Fergus choice is available. Each path develops either Wyatt or Fergus, and they both have some tragic problems they need to deal with. Not only that, but some brand new characters were introduced and they are confidentially a warm welcome to the series. Each character has their own personality and traits that make the story all the better. Though, the real highlight of this journey is William Joseph Blazkowicz. He has very intriguing chemistry with a lot of the main characters. The entire backstory for him is so tragic yet it really makes for some great entertainment. We love diving into B.J's past, especially his dad which is another great character. B.J is developed extremely well in this entry and really drives the story forward. There are so many great moments in this game. It all cranks up towards the second half after many great twists and turns in the story. With jam packed Nazi killing action, Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus solidifies itself as the greatest entry in the series to date. 9.5/10

Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus is a very difficult game to review. It gets so much right, and so much wrong that I wish there was a neither recommend or not recommend option, lol.

As a sequel to the great Wolfenstein: The New Order, The New Colossus in my opinion, is a huge flop in terms of story and tone. The New Order had its moments of comedy, however largely it remained a gritty, dark alt history with futuristic Nazis winning world war II, which was interesting. In Wolfenstein II however, its like a marvel movie. The humour is too often and too out of place, and feels vastly inconsistent in tone. Sometimes, it shares the exact same dark grittiness of The New Order, before quickly jumping back to dumb marvel humour the next scene.

The story also is just... not as interesting here in my opinion. In The New Order, your goal was clear - form a resistance and assassinate General Deathshead. Here, the plot is so jumpy, it's wild. You'll go from starring in a movie for a retired Adolf Hitler on venus, to detonating nukes, to killing BJs dad, to going undercover in a texas town watching Nazis scold KKK members on their German. While it is indeed entertaining, there is clearly a lack of identity and focus on what story The New Colossus wants to tell.

Now, onto the positives.

I know some people have issues with it, but in my opinion, the gameplay in The New Colossus is incredibly fun. It is very fast paced and a lot more DOOM-like compared to The New Order. Very fast paced, brutal takedowns etc. It's very entertaining. While there are a lot of balancing issues, especially with difficulty and ammo running out fast, the gameplay is largely polished and well done.

The game visually is very done too. The environments, regardless of how well they fit into the story are very beautiful and detailed. The enemy designs too, are very detailed. 

Speaking of enemies, while I wish the devs kept the original designs from The New Order like the Panzerhund and guard robots, the new enemies such as the Zitadelles, and Zerstorers are very interesting to fight and offer a good, fresh variety.

Overall, if you play The New Colossus off the back of The New Order, and are coming for story, I don't massively recommend it, due to the issues. However, if you're not interested in the story and want to fuck up some nazi's day, then it can be pretty fun.

An absolute blast, with fun gun play and great sound design. I mean who wouldn't enjoy killing nazis while dual wielding any weapon you like ( you can combine 2 different types of weapon too). You are in a battlefield killing some nazis and what happens ? BOOM the game randomly crashes literally for no reason at all ( happened to me twice ) Half the way into the game it gets a little bit repetitive because the game gives you some side quests which are all about revisiting the previous places that you were fighting to complete them, you get back to the same places to kill "important oberkommandos" nothing more. Do you want to achieve all 3 of the contraptions ? Well good for you go back to the places that you have already been, kill the oberkommando and find the contraption. Oh by the way the last contraption is literally located on the last place that you visit on story so you will have absolutely no chance to try it on story missions. Well you can still try it by revisiting the places and doing some side missions but it is not for me. Anyways overall as i said the game itself is good, very enjoyable you will have a really good time that's for sure. But i would recommend you to wait for sale and then purchase it.

Having recently played The New Order, I had somewhat high expectations from this one as TNO was amazing. The story and characters only got crazier and more fun from TNO, and had some really insane moments, but unfortunately, New Colossus suffers from difficulty balancing and overall slightly inferior gunplay quality imo. 

To elaborate on the gameplay issues, first major problem is the difficulty setting of the game. I started off on I Am Death Incarnate (same as my TNO playthrough) and soon found myself struggling to survive. Enemies sometimes would randomly hit me from the back when I had made sure to clear the rear before moving, enemies overall felt spongier, and the bullet hit feedback was absolutely terrible, whether it was while taking or dealing damage. Often times I'd hit an enemy hard enough to know that the amount of hits would surely take him out, but they'd apparently get invincibility frames during their "stumbling after being hit" animation, making them much more tedious and annoying to deal with. Another issue was that even on lower difficulties, you can get destroyed from full health and armor to zero in a matter of 2 seconds, which is where I wish the balancing had been done better. This I think resulted from the fact that the game does not give you enough feedback when you're getting hit, and by the time you realize you're in danger, its too late. On top of all this, the "lean from cover" system was a lot more finnicky and inconsistent unlike TNO, contributing to the gunplay issues even further. Now if you're going into this game after a long time after TNO, or without having played TNO, then don't get your hopes down, as most of these issues are noticable only if you have TNO as a frame of reference, which I did.

On an absolute scale, I'd definitely give this game an 8/10, which is what I gave TNO. However, as I mentioned, since TNO did a lot of things better, I feel like this was a bit of a step down for me, so a 7/10 seems more accurate.

Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus starts off with an awesome intro that immediately puts you right back into all the action you‚Äôve come to expect as the legendary B.J. Blazkowicz. I have been playing Wolfenstein since 1992 and have many fond memories of it, Quake, and of course, DOOM. I was so happy to see them continue this from the two previous games in this new era of the franchise.

Jumping into this game, I felt the graphics looked great and the story was once again a solid one where it captures a lot of different emotions. I enjoyed that it still kept that serious undertone to everything but also had some lighthearted and even hilarious moments. I also loved that there is a Manhattan level since I‚Äôm a New Yorker and all.

As I kept playing, the story was definitely a memorable one as I thought all the characters added a nice touch to everything. It was a very immersive experience from beginning to end, especially getting to see the backstory of Blazkowicz which helped fill in a lot of gaps. Not just from these newer Wolfenstein video games but from the originals decades ago.

I truly loved the fast-paced action of Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus with all the great new weapons, instant kills, and the option to go in full Rambo mode or stealth depending on the situation. All the levels looked great and the destruction elements in them from pillars, fire extinguishers, computers, walls, etc. added another great layer of realism. All in all, this is a pretty fun and short game with yet another killer soundtrack that goes perfectly with all the sheer violence and gore.

Now, the only thing I have to complain about are the annoying bugs I found while playing. There are still some potentially game-breaking bugs where you get stuck because of invisible walls or things that block you from normally walking. Basic things like going up a few steps or crouch-walking underneath bleachers to advance through a level can get you stuck permanently and you can‚Äôt go through for whatever reason.

The only way I was able to overcome this in certain levels that needed me to obviously move to progress was to save your game, quit, and restart Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus in Safe mode. That worked like a charm and if you ever encounter that issue, please do that as it worked for me at least. I also had to do that when guns didn‚Äôt work at all against enemies as it glitched out for whatever reason. I had to save, quit, and restart in Safe mode for it to work as it should.

As I mentioned earlier, it‚Äôs a pretty short game that I breezed right through. I was excited for the DLC but honestly, it was a bit of a letdown. The DLC was okay but nothing new or original. Just different characters replaying levels and maps I‚Äôve already completed in the main campaign. This was definitely lackluster especially since you‚Äôre playing with characters you‚Äôve never heard about until the DLC.

It would have been significantly better if they did this with the actual characters you‚Äôve met along the way. Imagine doing a level as Sigrun Engel, Max Hass, or even Zofia Blazkowicz instead of these random people? That was a missed opportunity for sure as the DLC was pretty boring and pretty easy to get through since they‚Äôre all just short missions using special abilities.

I give Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus a 4/5 as it‚Äôs definitely worth playing if you also grew up with the Wolfenstein franchise or want a fun, quick, awesome single-player FPS game to play. The weapons are incredible, the story is great, and it has some pretty funny moments that I genuinely laughed out loud to. The only thing is you will find a few bugs here and there, especially one that looks like you‚Äôre blocked by an invisible wall that can get frustrating since it messes up the natural flow of the game. Either way, I‚Äôd highly recommend this game as it‚Äôs such a fun rollercoaster of a ride.

The New Order and The Old Blood were really really good FPS games, at a time where great FPS games were rare, but the sequel is really bad in every way.

The guns sound and feel weak. They just make little clicky sounds. They sound broken and unsatisfying.
 
The head bobbing and movement is so janky and bouncy. This issue was in TNO and TOB too, but it was probably around ~75% better and more tolerable than in W2:TNC. The amount of camera shake makes it hard to see what you're doing when it really matters. Usually some head bob is done less severely in good shooters and doesn't affect me, but this game just makes me constantly disoriented. The sprint animation is truly awful and shaky. Add on top of that, BJ gets stuck on geometry constantly, making controlling him a miserable experience.

The writing is obnoxiously edgy. It forces a constant stream of mind numbing, over the top interactions, one after another that drag on way too long. It also has a really annoying leftist slant to everything. I don't care about this extremely unlikable feminist's dislike of men nor her monologue on testicles, is this really dialogue in a game? The Nazi killing an old comrade from TNO and simulating cunnilingus on your other alive friend with its decapitated head while laughing is not funny, or a good device to make you want to defeat her. Really I don't know what reaction that scene wanted from me, it was just off-putting, trying so hard to shock. Really it was just the writer badly overestimating their ability to write a shocking, irreverent scene. 

This game really is just a fundamental misunderstanding of why W:TNO and W:TOB were good games, and totally Flanderized the whole thing. Its really just TNO again, with every aspect of it done poorly, or flat out ruined.

Continuing the story from The New Order, BJ has awoken from a coma to his besieged U-Boat. Killing Nazis while piloting a wheelchair is an intriguing and fun concept but the game quickly advances to an upgradeable exo-suit of sorts to make up for the fact BJ is now disabled. 

Story-wise, the game is excellent, if a bit poorly paced. BJ remains the stoic hand of the Resistance while having a strong internal reflection. Continuing his relationship with his pregnant wife, Anya Oliwa, BJ fears a death he knows is imminent and laments leaving his wife and unborn children behind, never being able to achieve his vision from the first game and also leaving them in a world ruled by the Nazis. Most of the Resistance characters from the New Order, including Fergus or Wyatt (you're given a choice of timeline in the beginning) return with a few new faces. Some players will object to the overt political messaging regarding racial discrimination, but I personally believe that not only is it still necessary for many to hear, but also in my opinion, its tastefully done to not intrude on the experience. Cutscenes and other story moments do tend to drag on a bit but not too long.

Gameplay is basically the same as The New Order with some new weapons, a new weapon upgrade system, some new abilities/perks, and a few shakeups, particularly the first level in a wheelchair. Its a LOT harder than the first one so be pragmatic and do an easier difficulty.

graphically, the game easily matches most modern games, has new takedown animations, more blood and gore, and is generally better than TNO in every way while matching the style. sounds, Mick Gordon's soundtrack, and the VO quality are  all also universally excellent.

[b]Overall: [/b] 8/10

Kill Nazis in a high-octane shooter where we follow a, practically, immortal soldier accompanied by witty dialogues, action-packed and fun scenes, plus some amazing music.

[b]Music: [/b] 8/10

Top-notch. Manages to immerse you in the story, from the ambient sounds, to sound effects from weapons and voices from different characters.

[b]Visuals: [/b] 8/10

Just as solid, if not better than the last entry. The only downside that I will include is that when being shot at, there is no longer a visual cue from the direction.

[b]Gameplay: [/b] 8/10

It‚Äôs harder than the previous entry, that‚Äôs for starters, so be ready for a hell of a ride. Besides that, the game remains pretty much the same with some changes to perks and weapons. Personally, perk systems work fine, but some perk options to improve them (looking at you, return to sender perk), are simply too tiresome or marginally useful to use.

[b]Story: [/b] 8/10

The story is much darker, less hopeful than the previous game. At least through 3/4 of it. Missions seem less about killing Nazis and liberating the world, and more about just staying ahead and trying to make things work. The ending was a bit abrupt for my taste, but we‚Äôll-deserved. For at least a little while, it seems Blazkowicz will be able to relax and smile.

I just can't fathom how this game has so many good reviews. The gameplay is okay, but nothing outstanding. If you get it for the gameplay, I guess you are fine. Or if you really just want to spill Nazi blood, you are also fine I guess.

Where the New Colossus goes off the rails for me is the writing. Seriously? What a mess. And not a hot one. A stupid one. Every Nazi leader is complete lunatic from the unhinged blond girl to the bed-wetter Hitler. Really? These are the leaders of this formidable and evil empire that took over the world? Please. Just stop.

Even with all the bogus robotics and the woo woo occultism in the previous games, those games were believable because of the way the characters acted. They acted like real people in a surreal world. Here, everything is surreal to the point where if you pay even a tiny bit of attention to the story or the characters, you just end up rolling your eyes constantly to the point where they fall out of their socket.

I could write a lot more on this, but it wold just be a waste of time. Just like the game was. Do yourself a favor if you liked the New Order and the Old Blood and just skip it.

I much prefer Wolfenstein: The New Order and The Old Blood to this game. With that being said, the story in Wolfenstein II is much more gripping and captivating. 

The Nazi killing is also amped up, however I played all these games on hard difficulty, and Wolfenstein II was much much easier. mostly because the enemies aren't total bullet sponges and actually die when you pelt them with a full clip. It felt really good but didn't give as much of a challenge. The movement feels VERY VERY SQUIRRELY. If you sprint at all you just run at 90 mph zipping past everything. Even adjusting your FOV to 100 doesn't make it feel any better. Overall, I preferred not to sprint. Very squirrely movement. Maybe this game is meant to be played on a gamepad idk.

I didn't even bother with any of the side content, which I usually go out of my way to do in most games. I just flat out didn't care about any upgrades besides what I was finding throughout the regular levels.
Also, the levels can be extremely short. Straight up.

With all that said, I would recommend playing this once if you even remotely enjoy a compelling story, Wolfenstein, or Nazi killing of any variety.

One of my favorite games of all time.

The gunplay is highly enjoyable. Pretty much every level has multiple routes and ways to succeed. Stealth is challenging without being punishing, (and also entirely optional.) The graphics, even in 2023, are superb.

The story is where the game really shines, however. The usual suspects object to this game being ‚Äúpolitical,‚Äù as if it could be anything but. The premise of fighting Nazis who‚Äôve taken over the United States is, in and of itself, inherently political. The writers, to their credit, don‚Äôt shy away from that. They‚Äôve built a resistance full of heroic, flawed, interesting characters, who will do anything to defeat the most evil force the world has ever known.

If I have one complaint, it‚Äôs that the game is too short.

The New Colossus is plain badass ridiculous fun.  There are very few negative things that I can say about this game.  Here's a quick list of my thoughts:

Pros:
 - Great graphics.  Some parts of this game were awe-inspiring in how pretty and cool they looked.
 - Fun as hell gun-play.
 - Cool levels and environments.
 - Interesting characters.
 - A ridiculous but fun story.
 - "I'm from Arizona."
 - Really stable performance.  Some negative reviews of this game say that the game crashes constantly.  I never once had it crash.  At worst, the FPS dropped because too many particle effects were on screen for a moment, but other than that, I'd say this is the most stable AAA game I've played in a while.

Cons:
 - Weird difficulty spike near the end of the game.  The game has a fairly standard difficulty curve, but then it seems to spike for no reason near the end.  It goes from challenging but fun arenas to arenas that felt difficult for the sake of being difficult.  There was one where I could only maybe pick off one or two enemies stealthily before a Laserhund would track me down, no matter where I hid.
 - Unsatisfying ending from a gameplay perspective.  The final sequence of the game just feels like any other level, except it adds in a new enemy type that'll wreck your shit.
 - Annoying VRAM bug.  There's been a bug since some update years ago that throws an error up saying that you have run out of VRAM, and recommends restarting the game on a lower graphics preset.  This is just a bug, though, as pretty much any halfway decent card has more than enough VRAM to run this game.  You can mute the message, but it only lasts for that play session, so you have to deal with it again when you close and reopen the game.

Overall though, the game is more than worth playing, especially if you want a game where you can kill Nazis.

I like the new characters, the revolution story, the longer campaign with optional side missions, and the new U-boat hub that's way bigger than the hideout in TNO and you can play what appears to be the entirety of Wolfenstein 3D on an arcade machine within the game. I've also played for 23 hours at the time of this review and the game has never crashed even once.

This game is definitely harder than TNO, I completed the game on "Call me Terror Billy!" difficulty after dying about a million times and there's no way I would ever play it on a higher difficulty setting. Whereas in TNO I completed it on the second hardest difficulty without much trouble.

The downfall of the whole trilogy from technological perspective.
- Perks system was an utter garbage comparing to previous games. Nothing memorable or worth taking notes of.
- Playing this game on "I am death incarnate" is just a whole next level of shitshow. Sponge enemies, enemies scripted to spawn behind you. One shot of a normal soldaten can take up to 75 armor, in a late game armor is not even worth being a damage buffer - everything just kills you in one shot effectively. No buff perks that allows to expand health/armor. Playing with weak Billy's body that has 50HP for 50% of the game is just atrocious game design. Courtyard fight level was probably the finishing line when game turned from good to being a complete garbage combat wise. 
- Movement system is complete trash - you can get stuck crouching, running away can get you stuck on invisible walls, you cannot jump down or crawl through spaces because of some collision issues. Some of the storyline objectives get softlocked in inaccessible states, etc.
- Enemies AI quality severly degraded comparing to previous games. They are detecting you through the walls, shoot through the walls, they can hear silenced weapons and read your inputs. Since level design was rushed and was not made in mind of having cover spots for AI, they compensated AI by making them mobile and feed of ESP features and teleports - enemies will literally track you down through the walls as they walk and will occasionally teleport to you when out of line of sight.

Hopefully next game will be given in a hands of more competent developers.

TLDR: Great game, just as good if not better than the first two, but with some annoying glitches/crashes. Mostly manageable. 

Incredible game, just like the first two, but with some caveats. A few annoying glitches kept bothering me throughout the game, like the game constantly claiming I'm out of VRAM when I'm not (could be a memory leak but it doesn't seem to matter if I keep playing after this), the game sometimes blacking out for a second during some cutscenes (not sure what the deal was it seems to happen randomly), and very infrequent but still present crashes. Because of this I have a difficult time saying it's outright *better* than the first two, but the ambition and fun is absolutely still there. Shootin' Nazis is as fun as ever. There's a few balance issues I noticed (some enemies do *way* too much damage), but its not that bad. 

Writing and story wise, it's a home run IMO. People mad that a game about shooting Nazis in America has even slightly less than hard right wing politics is extremely funny. Characters are written as well if not better than the first games. You do spend the entire game chasing after a single main villain though, which is a little disappointing after the first game's multiple main bad guys, but she's such a great villain that it's fine.

All in all, a great game with a few annoying glitches that shouldn't ruin your ability to enjoy it. 

Yep, I still love shooting Nazis.

[h1]The Positives[/h1]
[list]
[*]The art team did a fantastic job with creating the environments. Each location is very detailed and you can tell care was put into each level.
[*]Voice acting is top notch and care was put into voicing the protagonist's thoughts and feelings throughout the game.
[/list]
[h1]The Negatives[/h1]
[list]
[*]The writing is shallow and predictable. Plot points are unbelievable and often achieved through deus ex machina.
[*]The strong white female character of the prior entry is promptly killed off and replaced with a strong black female character. This character is new to the game's crew and yet nobody questions her suddenly taking over complete command over all strategic decisions making it feel forced and created for the sake of diversity rather than being a well written plot point. It's so on the nose that she even takes over the prior character's bedroom.
[*]Character development is shallow. In my opinion the character with the most development and best writing is the protagonist's father who isn't even key to the game's plot and is only present in a few flashback sequences.
[*]Game play is serviceable but tries to appeal to multiple audiences without fully committing to any of them. There are RPG elements but a talent tree is lacking and is instead just a series of perks which are upgraded by performing X number of actions. Stealth is presented as viable but the levels generally don't seem to be designed well for it. Quick character movement and the option to dual wield firearms makes it seem like running and gunning would be viable but enemies very quickly take down your health without strategic use of cover. Despite this there's a mechanic called commanders who call in constant reinforcements until eliminated and they're usually placed at the end of a level which encourages the player to make their way to them as quickly as possible. All of these design contradictions make it feel like it's impossible to play optimally as each play style falls short.
[*]Weapon design is imbalanced where certain weapons are massively better than others. This along with plentiful ammo makes it so there's never a reason to use more than the same 1 or 2 best options.
[/list]
[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
While although the game has its moments it's difficult to recommend this to anyone who isn't a die-hard fan of the Wolfenstein series. Every aspect of the game is done better by other titles out there.

Immersive sims are some of my favourite games - The Dishonoured series being one of the best in my opinion. The environments are dense and complex with a lot to take in BUT the action is slow and methodical allowing the time to plan and investigate your surroundings. Wolfenstein 2 has the same approach...meshed within a First Person Shooter setup. For me, they do not work well together. It affects your enjoyment during the action and only serves to slow down the pace confusing the player.

The previous Woflenstein games balanced the world/action very well. Just enough story but the focus was on the shooting whilst providing a few options on approaching the enemy. This sequel feels like a movie with a bit of game-play woven into it. If they had made an animated movie then there's a chance it could have won awards as the script and characters are very, very good BUT this is an FPS...is it needed?? Add to that very complicated map layouts and star cards, art, letters, postcards, diaries, newspapers, weapon upgrades, 10+ ammo types, health pickups and armour pickups...I can't help but think Machine Games have "over cooked" their game. Progress and growth are great but there is a limit...

I find myself pressing "E" to pickup items more than I do "LMB" to shoot!! And trying to pickup items off the floor amongst a pile of guns and bodies just feels stupid...edging forwards and backwards until you get the icon on screen you're looking for...and that's when things are quiet. Doing this in the midst of a battle is pure stress fuel!! Need a grenade?...sure, run around and have a look but are you going to notice the grenade in a bucket down besides the cupboard?? Or how about the armour folded neatly stashed on the bottom of a book shelf??? Cute and intelligent but does it work in a gun fight...NO!!!

When playing this game I find myself moaning more than I'm enjoying...if you just run through the levels shooting everything that moves then you're missing a lot of detail. On the other hand, take time to enjoy the detail and the shooting gets in the way. The two do not mix very well at all. You need simpler environments to allow the player to concentrate on the shooting (Doom 2016 achieved this quite easily in how it managed pickups/ammo/story telling.) This Wolfenstein game feels like Doom set on a Dishonoured map....

5/10 - Forgets it's FPS roots and tries to be an immersive sim which over complicates the game-play. The guns just aren't good enough for most battles making upgrades absolutely essential (they all suffer from small clips and bad accuracy!) Gun fights are over too quickly on easy and near impossible on hard. Environments are way too busy and complicated making navigating them an absolute pain the ass!! Item management gives you a headache and stresses you out as it's just not accessible in a gun fight. And an un-skipable intro which makes playing on UBER a complete waste of time!!! Something that has haunted Machine Game's games for a while now...

Wolfenstein 2 is a good game, but just like The Fractured But Whole it feels overstuffed and a little bit worse than the first game. It is still great to plough through enemies dual wielding shotguns or assault rifles, and the 3 short stories of the Freedom Chronicles - while being very unspectacular storywise - are very much worth playing, especially "Gunslinger Joe" and "Agent Silent Death". But overall, there are too many mechanics cramped into this. You can get three different contraptions that alter your playstyle, two different signature weapons (like in the first game of the series) and there are so many different collectibles which needlessly stretch the playing time. You also have to revisit every sector to kill √úbercommanders and collect secrets to get the game to 100%.
But I love the action of the game. Apart from the Agent Silent Death DLC I did not use stealth at all, because the gunplay is so great and over the top. Another aspect that really makes Wolfenstein 2 work is the setting. There are so many hateable and evil antagonists and the vision of a 1960s USA that is ruled by the nazis that somehow won WWII is shockingly good. There are so many ridculously fanatic ideas of how the world might look like in such a scenario.
As an action game I can fully recommend Wolfenstein 2, but if you don't like collecting stuff and doing the same quests over and over again just to complete the game, you might get through this in just 5 hours or even less.
Additional note on the difficulty: for me, the 2nd highest difficulty, "death incarnate", is already too much, but "mein Leben" is only for insane people. It is way more difficult than the highest difficulty in The New Order, and that one was already way too much for me.

Whilst I thoroughly enjoyed Wolfenstein The New Order and Old Blood, The New Colossus felt like a step back in the series. The gameplay loop is incredibly repetitive, revolving around killing commanders to stop reinforcements spawning; whilst this is a good idea it is over used and the game feels like a game of hide and seek with Nazi Commanders, nearly every section in this game involves this mechanic, meaning you're forced into stealth or frantically sprinting past all the enemies to kill the commander as quickly as possible.

The story is mediocre at best, with some of the writing foreshadowing what was to come with Wolfenstein Youngblood.
Grace is the biggest offender of the story; You come across her after a few hours into the game and she joins the Resistance. However from the first moment she is in the Resistance she becomes the leader, without any vote or acknowledgement from anyone. This makes no sense, why would she be the leader after being there for 5 minutes over people such as BJ Blazkowicz, Anya or Seth Roth.

This franchise went from tense, gritty nightmare fuel and transitioned into a Girlboss comedy. 

Gun play is an improvement and the customisation has been expanded but this seems pointless when you have to stealth everywhere to kill commanders unless you're playing on the easier difficulties.

The majority of achievements didn't work for me as well, including simple ones such as complete the dlc's which take about 20 minutes

Just go play New Order and Old Blood.

I am in my second run of the game and I would really recommend it, it's absolutely great. It feels a bit different than the prior games, but I really love some of the new ideas and mechanics. This may be my favourite game in the series.
What I can't recommend necessarily are the higher difficulties, not because they are more difficult, but because I have the feeling that the games mechanics like enemy spawns and weapon balance are just a bit off and feel more like you're always gambling (especially enemy spawns seem to be pretty random and occure quite often at a place behind you where you just stood) than actually playing a harder game mode.

There is also a huge problem with some of the other mechanics like reloading or picking up items that just sometimes refuse to work which is quite annoying, especially the picking up items one is extremely frustrating in combat situations.

Some story elements are of course pretty ridiculous and there is plot hole after plot hole, but it's still a piece of fiction and otherwise the story can be very fun and interesting. The enviroments are awesome (you come around a lot), the gun handling still feels pretty good, the style of the game is very unique, the new mechanics are pretty cool and I had a blast trying them out and leveling guns and perks.

This game is great. It has its problems, but the main draw for me are the settings/environments and scenarios Billy finds himself in. The game is filled with action-packed sequences, and nearly each mission is varied enough for it to feel like a great sequel. 

Gameplay wise, its a bit of a bore-fest. Yeah, the gun play is incredible and smooth, but its very much just shoot everything that moves and get to the end of the level. Not very exciting, but serviceable. The meat of this game comes from the story, specifically the plot, and the different locations you go to; they have a good amount of variation to them. However, the actual writing of the dialogue is... questionable in some areas. However, this didn't detract much from the overall feel the story was trying to provide. 

There is a specific scene in a Nazi occupied Washington D.C that just had me gawking at the screen the whole time. Overall, a very beautiful game with satisfying story beats, but falls a bit short in the gameplay department.

Note to future self: never install it again.

Some of the good things:

- Some great unique "gimmick" gameplay moments, like the wheelchair and panzerhund gameplay widely shown in the trailers. I knew they were coming but enjoyed them all the same.
- Contraptions - a mechanic unlocked for the latter half of the game - can add a variety of spice and replay-ability to the game.  
- Cutscenes are very good and cinematic; I sometimes felt like I was watching an animated film because it was done so well.
- Most of the guns are useful and feel powerful, especially as you unlock some of the upgrades. But not as interesting as TNO - see in "some of the bad things" below...
- You can dual wield with any weapon in either hand, rather than just the same weapon in both hands like the previous game. This can create some great combos; like silenced pistol with (louder) silenced sub machinegun for stealth levels (pistol for general usage, sub machinegun if you need to spray), or assault rifle with a heavy hitter like the LaserKraftWerk or Kampfpistol (rocket launcher). It's quite fun to play around with the combinations. This system has it's downsides though...  - see in "some of the bad things" below...
- The game is much prettier than TNO.
- There are bonus missions where you go back into previous levels to complete optional objectives. They are quite fun but also fairly bland as there is none of the tight scripting that exists in the core levels.

Some of the bad things:

- The game does not always communicate it's mechanics well - for example, when you select the Contraptions, it explains them in terms of offering different ways to manoeuvre around the environment; and you choose based on that. What is doesn't tell you is that you also get a few bonus perks. Some of these are extremely useful and I ended up regretting my decision for a while. It wasn't until later when I discovered that two of the "bonus missions" can give you the two contraptions that you didn't select - again, this is not explained (or if it is, I totally missed it!)
- The story has a moment which throws all stakes out of the window and which ruined my suspension of disbelief more than some of the moments from the previous game. I don't care that they put some lore in the explain it, it had me raising my eyebrows.
- The hub world feels much more dull and dead than Kreisau Circle did in TNO
- The unlocks for weapons are just numbers upgrades for the most part. In TNO, upgrades gave the weapon different abilities, like an underslung rocket-launcher, or turning your sniper rifle into a plasma rifle. There's nothing like that in this game, and I think you're expected to meet those needs with the new any-weapon-in-any-hand-dual-wielding system.
- The new dual wielding system - and weapon selection in general - is incredibly fiddly to use, at least on mouse and keyboard. In TNO, I dynamically switched between weapons on-the-fly to respond to the needs of the battle. In TNC, I found the UI too cumbersome, and generally picked the weapons I would be using before starting the engagement. Sometimes this meant I had a heavy hitter weapon in my offhand going unused "just in case".... which is a shame considering in TNO I could have had increased firepower until I needed the heavy hitter. I have to imagine this system was designed for consoles because it does not control well at all on PC.
- My biggest complaint about this game is that you die too quickly. I have played and completed TNO, TOB, and TNC on the hardest difficulty for each game. In TNO and TOB, I found it generally quite fair to play and I usually knew what was hurting me and had time to react and put them down. In TNC, it was incredibly common for something to kill me but I have no idea what it was. To put it in context, I can start a fight with the maximum possible health and armour and still be dead in less than a second. This makes some sections of the game - particularly the stealth ones - quite frustrating, as "going loud" accidentally can become a death sentence, whereas in TNO and TOB, you adapt and have a great fight. In TNC, this lead to me playing in more of a "campy" style rather than engaging in "push-forward" gameplay.
- The enemy variety felt much smaller in this game than TNO, which is a real shame. TNO's roster was diverse and fairly challenging. TNC's roster is quite pathetic; even the ultra-heavy robot Zitadelle can go down with one well-placed fully-charged shot from the LaserKraftWerk to it's very obvious weak spot. I missed the Guard Robots and Heavy Robots from TNO.
- There is a lack of unique boss fights in this game. TNO had some really memorable ones. I would say that there is only one true boss fight in this game, and that it's not very cinematic...
- The plot jumps all over the place. I always understood why I was where I was, but it took a few leaps and felt like it skipped a few steps along the way. There is one part of the story in particular where essentially a whole mission happens "off camera", and I would have liked to play it.

I never played the first one so I had nothing to care about during the very first scene when the game demanded I make a choice. My choice, after waiting to see what the game would do, was to exit it and uninstall it. The game hit one of the few pet peeves I have for shitty writing and that's tell me I have a choice when I do not. Maybe the rest of the game is good but I'm already installing something else and moving on.

Great shooter. Surprisingly good presentation that hits a mark between heroic, over-the-top action with some light-hearted humour, and more serious topics with uncomfortable moments of gruesome gore that are well-placed within scenes dominated by some very good (voice) acting. Sometimes absurd, sometimes horrific, it's often hard to balance out - but the writers did it well and created some interesting and iconic characters, especially with the antagonist Frau Engel.

On the gameplay side, you can expect rewarding shootouts with heavy, and dual-wielding weapons that actually feel heavy when they penetrate the Nazis. It's a good mix of modern and old-school shooting mechanics. My only gripe would be that compared to The New Order, there are little to no real bosses like in the first game. Also, the ending could've been a bit more epic and overall, and overall, the game felt a bit shorter than its predecessor.

The side missions are nothing to talk about but let you squeeze a bit more playtime out of it. The collectibles are fun - at least the records, as you can actually listen to the songs that were produced for the game. And there are some really catchy tunes, most of all "Changeover Day" by Die K√§fer, the Nazi-German version of The Beatles.
Perfect sequel to an excellent game. Story is incredibly immersive, gameplay and writing is excellent. A must play for FPS and single player game enthusiasts

Review:

Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus is a brutal and action-packed first-person shooter that delivers an adrenaline-fueled experience set in an alternate history where Nazis have taken over the world. As the iconic resistance fighter William "BJ" Blazkowicz, you'll embark on a gripping and emotionally charged journey filled with intense gunfights, jaw-dropping set pieces, and a thought-provoking narrative.

The game picks up where its predecessor, Wolfenstein: The New Order, left off, immersing players in a world oppressed by the Nazi regime. The story is dark and gritty, tackling mature themes such as fascism, oppression, and sacrifice. It offers a well-crafted narrative that explores the depths of human resilience and the consequences of standing up against overwhelming odds.

One of the highlights of Wolfenstein II is its immersive and expertly designed gameplay. The gunplay is fast-paced and satisfying, allowing you to wield an arsenal of powerful weapons against hordes of Nazi soldiers and high-tech monstrosities. The level design offers a good mix of open-ended exploration and linear action sequences, keeping the gameplay fresh and engaging.

The game's difficulty can be quite challenging, even on lower settings, which may deter some players seeking a more casual experience. However, for those seeking a true test of their skills, the higher difficulty levels offer a demanding and rewarding gameplay experience.

The characters in Wolfenstein II are memorable and well-developed, with strong voice performances that breathe life into them. BJ Blazkowicz is a charismatic and determined protagonist, surrounded by a diverse cast of allies who each have their own motivations and struggles. The writing is sharp, blending moments of intense action with heartfelt and emotional storytelling that will keep you invested in their journey.

Visually, the game is a treat. The detailed environments and atmospheric lighting contribute to the overall immersive experience. From the grim streets of occupied America to the twisted laboratories of the Nazis, each location is meticulously crafted, further enhancing the game's dark and oppressive atmosphere.

While the game excels in many areas, it does have a few minor flaws. The pacing occasionally feels uneven, with moments of intense action followed by slower narrative-driven segments. Additionally, some players may find the story's alternate history elements to be polarizing, as it takes liberties with historical events for the sake of its fictional narrative.

Overall, Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus is a thrilling and intense ride that delivers a compelling story, exhilarating gameplay, and a well-realized alternate history setting. It offers a solid challenge for first-person shooter enthusiasts and provides a memorable and thought-provoking narrative experience. If you're looking for a game that combines fast-paced action, a gripping story, and a healthy dose of Nazi-killing, Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus is a title worth adding to your library.

The level design is awful in this game. Every single level is painfully repetitive (I can't state this enough). You‚Äôll navigate an area that gives you the option to stealthily take out the commanding officers or go in guns blazing, only to enter the next area and be slapped with the exact same scenario.

Story : I preferred the darker tone of new order. New Colossus has a very over the top tone but it isn't too far from crazed cult or mecha hitler from earlier games. Some chracters can be a bit cringe but still had enough emotional moments in the story for me. B.J trying to audition infront of Hitler is one of the finest moment of gaming.

Gameplay : It's quite different from the first game. You may like it or hate it. I loved it. B.J is a lot less tanky , you can go down pretty easily in higher difficulties , it's a lot less like rehashed nazi doom game and the focus is much more on positioning and choosing covers and right moments to be aggressive. 

Stealth is harder than the first game. In new order you almost always has a very obvious secondary route that will get you to the commander alone. Secondary routes are much less obvious in this game and commanders are placed deeper into the levels. 

Gunplay is crunchy . Dual shotguns or marksman assasult rifle , take your pick. 

Gore is ramped up.

PC PORT : Runs like a dream. .No stutters , no hitches. Makes me miss ID tech games. Played on rx6700xt. 

Inshort : Gameplay and tone has changed over from the first game . Your enjoyment will depend how you will react to them. Apparently game had pc issues at launch. But it's a fine game imo. A lot of hate on steam from members of a particular political mindset along the line of "Not ALL NAZI ", ridiculous for this series.

mannnnn.... I bought this game because it was on sale and I've played the other Wolfenstein games in the past (which I loved!). Maybe I'm blinded by nostalgia from the previous games and I'm being a boomer, but it just didn't seem that good and wasn't that fun. There is ALOT of level design reuse which I didn't really like. And the levels themselves weren't as cool as they could be. They had a massive opportunity to show us an alternate reality of America where the nazis won WWII and we really didn't get to see it (except for the Roswell mission). It just kinda seems like you're doing missions through either ruins or bland nazi bases the entire game. I guess I just wanted to see more with it. I'm writing this right after I completed it. 

I'm not upset,  I don't really feel like it was a waste of time, but it just had so much more potential.

The messages of the game will always be strong and apply to any moment in history, making it a really timeless game. Gameplay brought some new novelties and it's fun, but what makes this a good game is the charming characters, the powerful plot and the details in each scene. A great game that will certainly leave anyone satisfied with the experience. As of now, the game runs flawlessly on PC.

PROS:

1) The game is surprisingly well-optimised. I can't really recall any moments except for maybe 2 where I experienced visible stutters and this was even in situations where my screen was drowning in bodies and bullets.

2) The visual design is pretty good and the shooting is fairly satisfying. Enemies aren't bullet-sponge chores to mow down and doming a trooper or vaporising one with a laser looks appropriately cool and entertaining.

IT'S NICE I GUESS:

1) The game has a slightly larger weapon variety than its predecessors and they are somewhat more unique. I do not put this in the pros column because it's still a somewhat boring arsenal. You've got a melee weapon that can be thrown, a pistol, a machine gun, a machine gun that also functions as a sniper rifle with the appropriate upgrades, a shotgun, a laser gun (or a sticky bomb launcher) and a handheld rocket launcher. With the exception of the handheld rocket launcher this is basically the exact same load-out as The New Order (that one had the machine gun with an under-barrel rocket launcher instead). You also have 4 disposable heavy weapons to play with - a machine-shotgun which won't hit shit unless you're standing literally right next to an enemy, a laser which fires a continuous beam, a flamethrower which shoots fireballs instead of a stream of flames and what I can only describe as the BFG from Doom except completely useless and taking so goddamn long to fire that you're better off using something else (it's also only available in the second half of the final level of the game).

2) Fergus once again is the only character worth a damn in the entire story because he's at the very least funny instead of being cringy or outright boring to listen to. He's also the only character whose cutscenes I wasn't tempted to skip through. Still, Machine Games seem to have learned their lesson in that picking Wyatt actually gives you a brand new weapon to play with (the sticky bomb launcher) so there is at least SOME reason to pick his dopey ass in this game.

CONS:

1) The level design is fucking atrocious. Not only are the levels painfully short but they can all be summed up as the following - shooting arena -> corridor to next arena -> shooting arena -> corridor to next arena -> shooting arena, ad nauseam. Each arena has either one or two commanders that will raise the alarm and call down waves upon waves of goons on your ass the moment you so much as breathe which might be tense the first time it happens but gets tedious very soon after.

2) The boss fights are virtually nonexistent. For all that I think The New Order was a piece of crap, it did at least have one good boss fight (the London Monitor) and realised the importance of having a final boss to close off the story. The New Colossus has no such epic finale and the best way I can describe how it ends is to say "it just ends".

3) The story is insanely stupid and unlike The New Order, which at least stuck with its retarded attempt to make a "deep and serious" story out of fucking Wolfenstein, it seems to be incapable of deciding if it wants to be serious or goofy. You have BJ's voice actor delivering painfully pretentious dumbfuckery in a grating whispery voice for the first half of the game and then it devolves into some wacky-ass crap once BJ gets resurrected from literally being beheaded. The story choices with BJ's stereotypical southern hick father are truly bizarre (dude is supposedly a mega racist but married a Jewish woman? Huh?) and seem to exist for no other reason than poking fun at the kind of people Hollywood liberals imagine conservatives to be...I'm guessing because it's incredibly jarring at doesn't contribute to the plot in any meaningful way whatsoever.

The characters are basically all uninteresting stereotypes except for Fergus who is at the very least a fun stereotype, you've got the angry black woman who says "motherfucker" so often she may as well be auditioning for a Samuel L. Jackson biopic, you've got the fat Nazi girl whom we're supposed to sympathise with because her Nazi mother bullied her...for being a lardass, you've got the completely forgettable bearded dude from Louisiana, you've got the magic Jew Set Roth who is basically a walking plot device machine, you've got Anya whom I can't even understand why the fuck she keeps getting shoved into dangerous situations by the team when she's supposedly pregnant with twins and you've got a bunch of other idiots scattered across the U-boat that you make into your base of operations.

4) The DLCs are a complete waste of time. Not only do they recycle some levels from the base game as well as the weapons but they are also insanely short and serve no other purpose except to setup what I'm guessing is plot lines for a sequel.

I played through the game once in the Fergus timeline. I started over for the Wyatt timeline sorely so I could try out the sticky bomb launcher. After about 15 minutes, I realised I had absolutely no desire to revisit this gruelling shitshow again and stopped.
