TLDR - A step back in some areas in terms of level design, story writing and questionable design choices but ultimately still a fun time held up by extremely satisfying gunplay and gameplay mechanics. A solid game, yet weak sequel to the previous titles.

Pro's:

- Wolfenstein's strong gunplay/gameplay mechanics from The New Order (TNO) and The Old Blood (TOB) returns and is still as satisfying as it was before
- Levels present a horrifying 'what if' the Nazi's occupied the U.S
- Characters are all likeable and entertaining.
- Story immediately picks up from the end of TNO. You're also allowed to choose which 'timeline' you wish to follow (based on a decision made in TNO, here it is presented in a flashback). The story can be altered slightly based on this so multiple playthroughs are encouraged.
- A lot of previous characters and villains return from TNO
- An interesting look at B.J's backstory is shown 

Con's:

- For some reason, Machine Games decided to handicap you with lower health (you start with 50 instead of 100). This can lead you to getting melted far too easily early in the game, making it feel more difficult than a lot of late game sections.
- Some humour and writing is out of place. There will be times where the serious nature of some scenes is pointlessly interrupted for a quick gag to lighten the mood. These light hearted elements would have served better elsewhere. Wolfenstein The Old Blood pulls the humour aspect off much better and TNO has a better balance.
- Sometimes you can spend far too much time on the Eva's Hammer (Submarine, TNC's 'Hub world'). It's supposed to make you connect with some of the characters you meet and whilst you can interact with some of them, it overstays its welcome by the end of the game.
- The story on its own can feel a little weak. It holds up better if you've played TOB and TNO because it very much picks up where they left off. As a standalone, it falls short and a handful of plot threads are left open with little explanation.
Proper FPS with an outstanding story and great presentation. Easy recommend.

This game is a sequel to [i]Wolfenstein: The New Order[/i] and differs quite a bit from its predecessors. The atmosphere in this game is far less serious and more morbidly humorous, especially during the cutscenes (which felt like they took up a bigger portion of the game). I personally did not feel that the new characters they introduced in this game were as likeable as the first game's characters. Graphics are a huge step up from the previous games, with textures and effects looking way better. While level design is not too different from before, with some levels feeling like they were rehashing or putting a new coat of paint over old concepts (Venus level), these levels seemed more enjoyable and/or memorable in comparison. Player choice exists in this game to a somewhat greater degree, more so in gameplay rather than story as you can choose between three contraptions that allow unique play styles and abilities. The perk system has been replaced by a weapon upgrade system that requires you to find upgrade kits hidden around each level. The achievement grind in this game was brutal, culminating in the frustratingly difficult Mein Leben run (you have to complete the campaign in one life). The DLCs really didn't offer anything new, and ultimately felt very uninspired.

So I'll preface this by saying I enjoyed both The New Order and The Old Blood, not as much as Return To Castle Wolfenstein, but I thought they were fairly solid games. I put off playing this game for a long time, because I remember being very put off with how this game was marketed and the gaming journalism dicksucking it was getting with Vice calling it "one of the most important games of the year" (give me a fucking break.) For those reasons I suspected the game was going to have incredibly cringey writing dripping with the Trump derangement syndrome that was so characteristic of pretty much every piece of media in 2017. Unfortunately this turned out to be the case and the writing and cutscenes are so bad that it's honestly embarrassing. They honestly made killing Nazi super soldiers lame, how do you do that? Now if the the core gameplay was good I could have forgiven this to a degree, but sadly this is not the case as you'll see and this game takes a big step back from the previous two games.

This was an incredibly low effort game for starters. I think they only added one or two new enemies in this game that weren't in either of the previous two and the nearly 3/4ths of the game takes place in a horrible boring sewer levels and bombed out ruined buildings. It honestly might be some of the worst and most uninspired level design I've ever seen in an FPS. The funny thing is despite all the buzz and marketing about the Nazis and KKK running the streets of America they do almost nothing with those ideas, outside of one boring walking sim part, instead the entirety of the game takes place in sewers, destroyed buildings, and generic military bases. The sad thing is you could have actually done cool stuff with a Nazi occupation of America, but outside of marketing hype for the game, based on cynically manipulating the current political landscape at the time, they really did nothing with it.

Also the stealth in this game is completely broken and there's basically no reason to attempt it. Enemies will mysteriously spot you through walls randomly. It's a shame because the stealth actually works well in the first two games. Most of the guns are pretty shitty too. There's literally no reason to use anything other than assault rifle and laser gun. The tried to pad out the game with extra side content like hunting down √úbercommanders, but the enigma code breaking minigame is god awful, and all the assassinations missions are just reused levels from the campaign, which as previously mentioned has pretty bad levels.

All in all disappointing, and it makes me wonder how terrible Youngbloods must be to be as universally panned as it is, when this all in all mediocre game got such praise.
A real triple A game as it should be.

I liked but didn't love Wolfenstein: The New Order and this feels like a lesser version of that. As for the good, you get a fun, absurd story and you get to absolutely obliterate some nazis with weapons straight out of a sci-fi movie. For the bad, you're constantly tripping over the bizarre lack of consistent proximity pickups, wrestling with a lean system that seemingly has a mind of its own, trudging through the ham-fisted writing that reeks of 2017, and dealing with Grace just kind of endlessly being super rude to characters you actually like with no redeeming character arc. 

Flaws and all, it's still worth checking out to do what the Terror-Billy does best.

I enjoyed the past two modern entries in the Wolfenstein series and was looking forward to seeing how the story progressed. Finally being able to play this was exciting and refreshing to see the cast return and some newcomers to the story.

The story continues where the first game ended. William finishes his mission and while it was implied that he doesn't make it at the end of the first game, in this story, his friends and comrades save him. Frau Engel is back and she is more determined than ever to stop him and his revolution. It's up to William to gather other survivors and rise up to fight against the Nazis once more and take back the world from their oppression.

For starters, I love that the game still continues the two-timeline story like in the first game. So for those wondering, I did the Wyatt timeline just like I did in the first game. This changes story scenes depending on which timeline you choose. Graphically, the game still looks amazing. It was so cool seeing all the technology and machinery in all the levels. I feel this game definitely upped the gore and violence though, so be aware of that going in.

The gameplay is more or less the same just like previous entries. Once again, they adopted the perk system in where depending on how you play, you will get passive buffs. Perform a lot of stealth kills? Now you have increased crouch speed. Do a lot of heavy weapon kills? Well, now heavy weapons have a larger capacity. I love how this system is implemented, although, I wish they told you about your perks like in the first game instead of having to research them in the menus.

One of the biggest strengths in the Wolfenstein games is the characters and story and this game did not disappoint. I loved seeing the cast return and the new people William recruits are memorable as well. There were plenty of times while walking around the home base when I would stop and just watch the characters interact with each other. Sometimes you could do lil side missions for them too. Seeing characters develop throughout the campaign was great too. Heck, my favorite chapter in the game was when you go through William's hometown and see his memories.

Lastly, the gameplay expands halfway through the game when you get to choose a new special ability. One is good for stealth, the other for combat, and the last for exploration. It stays with the "tailor to your playstyle" type of feel and I commend the developers for the fun system.

Now for the gripes. I think my biggest gripe is just getting lost. I counted 3-4 stages where I had no idea where to go and I would spend 5-10 minutes wandering around trying to find out where I was supposed to go. The map helped somewhat, but it was still slightly frustrating. Make sure you manually save often, especially if you want to play stealthy. Next, the stealth upgrade that you select halfway through the game was sometimes hard to know where it could be used. Lastly, make sure to up your brightness, this game gets really dark, and hard to see enemies at certain points so be mindful of that.

Final verdict? This game was still a fun ride from beginning to end! There are plenty of extra missions you can tackle after you beat the main campaign. Three DLC chapters as well as an arena mode where you just kill as many enemies as you can. There's plenty to enjoy as well as the great story so I highly recommend this game, just be sure to at least finish the first one so you can enjoy the characters and story bits more. Now to see what happens in Youngblood. Can't be that bad, right? Thanks for reading!

At least 50% of the game is composed of cutscenes with badly written dialogues (with uninspiring attempts of rally or phrases of effect) and annoying characters. 
Yup, this is definitely a game that I won't be playing again.

Perhaps Wolfenstein II was the hallmark beginning the tendency of increasingly crappier wolfenstein games? 
Remains to be seen...
 
P.S.: Short example (obviously not the only issue): I've noticed a bad implementation in the game likely related to the rendering pipeline not allowing the GPU to operate at capacity as I'm getting an aprox. 60% GPU usage (with even lower CPU usage) but staying around 135 fps and not reaching the 165fps to equal the 165hz monitor. I have around 8gb of ddr5 ram not being used as well (this part is fine). I've searched around in forums and apparently this game was rushed, which might explain this (and other) technical flaws.

I'm at a weird spot with this game, it's a step up from Wolfenstein but in a lot of ways a step down as well. For starters, I think the story is one of if not the best in all of the games (maybe the ending is a little meh but who cares). The combat and feeling in the weapons are fun as hell and being able to upgrade them only makes them get better as the game continues, and rewards you for exploring and finding these upgrade kits which I frankly enjoy. Making a beefy and cooler weapon towards the game climax and showing I have managed to survive everything the game has thrown at you makes you feel like you will obtain victory. this game is about depression in a lot of ways, you've been fighting this battle for who knows how long and things aren't always rainbows and sunshine. tackling the problems of racism the way they do I love it (who would've guessed racism in a game about killing Nazis wow). the KKK just walking around casually, black people being treated less than just as everyone else. you face something that is nothing short of a monster maybe not some creature but they are mentally sick and you can understand that pain and anger, maybe even a bit of sadness our mc feels. This game has always hit hard and home with its touchy subjects. the next thing I want to bring up is the gameplay did this game take a step down from difficulty or am I just better at the game, this game genuinely felt super easy, aside from maybe the game's final boss if you call it a boss fight, I had fun with it though. the side quest is boring as HELL, the enigmatic code hunt I probably will not do since it's just replaying old levels over and over and over and over. the after game content is pretty pointless even though I understand the purpose maybe there is a secret ending tied to it after beating the game maybe not, I do not care.
Constant crashes for modern hardware sadly. Seems like a good game by the time it was made. Previous Wolfensteins were amazing.

[h1][b]Short review of Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus[/b][/h1]

[h2][b]+[/b][/h2]
[b] ‚Ä¢ Beautiful graphics that are still pleasing to the eye.
‚Ä¢ Interesting atmosphere and environment.
‚Ä¢ Shooting and pumping weapons.
‚Ä¢ Ability to take different weapons in both hands.
‚Ä¢ Action.
‚Ä¢ Many opponents.
‚Ä¢ Soundtrack[/b]

[h2][b]-[/b][/h2]
[b]‚Ä¢ Boring and uninteresting plot.
‚Ä¢ Russian dubbing in this game is terrible.
‚Ä¢ Lack of bosses.
‚Ä¢ Unlike the previous part (Wolfenstein: The New Order), opponents have become lighter, and heavily armored soldiers scatter from a pair of cartridges.
‚Ä¢ The game is too short.[/b]

[h2][b]Result[/b][/h2]
[b]Overall, I would recommend playing Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus. Behind the boring plot is addictive and meaty gameplay.[/b]

You know what to do.

If not, take one orange you love. Start by setting the orange on your kitchen counter. Use the palm of your hand to press the orange down and roll it around. This gently begins the process of loosening the orange from the peel without making a mess in your kitchen. Because the peel is still closed, juice and bits of pulp will stay contained.

Next, lay down a plate or a paper towel to protect your counter. With your thumb, press your nail into the top of the orange near the stem. There‚Äôs more likely to be a small gap between the peel and the fruit at the top or bottom of an orange. [spoiler]This gives you enough room to maneuver[/spoiler]. 

Start from the top where you‚Äôve made the puncture with your thumb, and pull directly down. Aim to pull a large strip of the rind at first. The bigger your initial tear was, the easier it will be to peel the rest of the orange. 

Hold the orange firmly in your hand and use your thumb to continue to puncture and peel downward until you‚Äôve removed the entire orange from the peel.

I'm a fan of the first one, but this one I mostly ignored for years and for good reason. Takes too long to get started. Lots of fluff, lots of cut-scenes that feel like they're getting in the way. BJ is way less likable, I don't care about the cast and most of them are crass stereotypes. The missions feel short and poorly designed and just feel like they're there to get you to the next cut-scene. Weapons are a mixed bag. Some feel relatively okay after you upgrade and some feel like you're shooting airsoft guns. The heavy weapons are awesome and plentiful but are so overpowered the only way the game can stop you is constant knockdown attacks. Stealth is there, but nothing really to say about it. Knockdowns are super annoying and will likely result in death. Most of the side content is pixel hunting random items and doing missions where you have to track down an enemy with a weapon that is insurmountable if they get the first shot (because you get knocked down and they just stun lock you until death) and you have to re-do the entire mission if you don't know exactly where the enemy is and do a manual save. The story and tone were all over the place and anytime anything cool happened something cringe would happen right after. I don't hate this game. I just felt like I had to finish it in spite of itself. I uninstalled it immediately after credits roll and did not do any cleanup.
Had a lot of fun. Nothing like a diesel-punk setting where you kill Nazis

This time it took a while to get into the game, but after about three hours of playing, it was already hard to quit. So far, MachineGames' developed [i]Wolfenstein[/i] is doing very well, at least in my opinion. To put it briefly, [i]The New Colossus[/i] is a good oldschool FPS in a modern form. In terms of playability, the game worked well from a technical point of view, the gameplay was smooth, the graphics were very good and the story offers drama, a couple of very humorous scenes as well as some surprising moments. In other words: decent entertainment.
Anyway, who wants a fast-paced shooting game, it's a very good choice as the main story can be completed in 10-15 hours. However, for those who want to peck for longer, the side tasks and all kinds of collecting add tens of hours of playing time.

Long unskippable cutscenes, can't reload checkpoints because manual saves, no mission select, they redesigned many of the characters giving them softer features and baby smooth skin for no reason. Swapping weapons is now a pain if dual wielding because it just swaps out one of the equipped guns not both. Many of the environments are dark and washed out, with enemies being difficult to see as they blend in. A terribly uninspired story that ends on a cliffhanger.

[h1]The franchise at its best.[/h1]

Let me start this one by saying I have no fu**ing idea what all these negative reviews are about.
To me The New Colossus completely overshadows its predecessors, doing a better job at arguably everything.

[b]- Graphics[/b]
Wolfenstein II obviously looks better than ever and to be honest, it aged magnificently.
The New Order horrid OOF system is gone and things three feet from your face are not out of focus and Blazko is officially not myopic anymore.

[b]- Audio[/b]
Sound department is top-notch. Voice acting is majestic.
Generic 30 seconds long hard rock music sequences have been replaced by a full OST matching the action perfectly, pressing the shooting sequences and fading down to an ominous hum for the stealth sections masterfully.
Dialogues are great, voice acting is spotless, especially BJ.
"Caroline. I'm hurting. Will you lend me your wings?". Pure beauty.

[b]- Story[/b]
Character development and writing in general are not a strong side in Wolfenstein, we know that.
No exception here, everybody is a vague, shapeless and stereotypical two-dimensional cartboard figure but Anya, Fergus and particularly Wyatt, are at least granted an arc this time, changing dramatically during the game.

Hundreds of details including side quests and everyday moments and dialogues between crew members are always interesting and hilarious or just plain depressing but always capable of drawing us into the world of Wolfenstein to a degree no game in the series could achieve before.
It feels like the Resistance is truly a family. I feel overall way more invested in what's going on.

People complaining about The New Colossus "not having a true ending" should remember that the last two games had HORRIBLE endings, especially The New Order and its fade to black Soprano's style cliffhanger.

[b]- Controls[/b]
Faster and better with more freedom, simply put.
You can crawl, rush, tackle, run through walls, extend your legs six feet from the ground, stomp and more than everything really, your favourite nazi-killing sodlier can now successfully leap over a damn 20 inches tall handrail. Unbelievable, I know.

[b]- Performance[/b]
The only true tender spot here. Performance issues with most GPUs and drivers settings.
Thankfully, easily fixed with a 60 seconds tweak to the register file, google can and will help.
It solved 99% of the issues I had. Now it's just...a Bethesda game. You know.

[b]- Content[/b]
Way longer game, bigger areas, more variety, more turret sections and vehicles and overall more interesting missions.
Not much to say here, there's just way more content in this one, even without the DLC.

So why the hate? 
Well. Turns out only 0,8% here on Steam could actually beat the game on Uber, compared to more than 6% for the last game and 10% for the first, this alone tells us a story, I think.
This game is HARD.
Even at hard difficulty you will die, a lot, that until you learn the game mechanics.
You get maybe 1/10 of the medkits and armor you got in New Order, enemies actually take cover instead of running towards their demise, you're not a God behind cover anymore, no suggested/mandatory path for stealth segments, no 200 HP all the time, no cheesing your way out, no bulls*it.
Uber is absolutely insane, as it should be. One death game over is tough. You'll have to fully master the game to even stand a chance.
The courthouse shootout alone is more difficult than the other two title combined, including Deatshead on "Uber".


[b]TL:DR Verdict.[/b]
Technically and qualitatively, this is hands down the best Wolfenstein game ever made, sadly also thanks to the direction that horrendous abomination "Young Blood" steered the franchise towards.
Ignore people who don't have the patience or will to master the game's mechanics, great game, safe buy.

There is the VRAM issue and that it pop up a notification, but I had no crashes, but other people have and it was not fixed by the devs. The only problem I had was with physics and some edges you had to walk up or over.Physics were bad for nades and the throwing weapon. I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.Thank you

Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus is an incredible end to the soft reboot series that began with Wolfenstein: The New Order. From start to finish, this game is a thrilling and intense experience that will keep you on the edge of your seat.The game picks up right where the first one left off, with protagonist B.J. Blazkowicz in a dire situation. As you progress through the game, you'll encounter a variety of new enemies, weapons, and environments. The level design is superb, with each location feeling unique and memorable.One of the standout features of Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus is the story. The game explores themes such as resistance, sacrifice, and family, and does so in a way that is both thought-provoking and emotionally impactful. The voice acting and character development are top-notch, making you care about the characters and their struggles.The gameplay is also excellent, with a variety of weapons and upgrades to choose from. The game offers a good balance of stealth and action, allowing you to play the way you want. The boss battles are particularly memorable, offering unique challenges and satisfying victories.Overall, Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus is a great game that does justice to the series. The game offers a compelling story, thrilling gameplay, and memorable characters, making it a must-play for fans of the series and anyone who enjoys first-person shooters.

I LOVED the first one and dived right into this afterwards but so many things about the second disappointed me.

[b]Gameplay[/b]: I think my game was bugged.

[b]Inconsistent auto-ammo-pickup[/b]
Sometimes I automatically pick up ammo, sometimes I have to press a button. I tried everything, including making sure there was room in my carry capacity. No consistency. In intense firefights, it almost always forced me to manually pick up, which was so frustrating.
[b]Broken stealth[/b]
W1 had great stealth. Enemies would need a second or two upon spotting you to realize what they're looking at, which lets you shoot or duck away and is also pretty realistic. Here, a lot of enemies had zero reaction time. The moment they appear on screen, sometimes on the other side of the map, they start to raise the alarm. A couple times they "saw" me through a wall (not a grate), and other times, they literally spun 110 degrees while I'm silently crouching behind cover. 
[b]Schizoprenic "lean" mechanic[/b]
I can't believe they somehow messed this up from the first game. Here the lean can't make up its mind as to whether to do it or not, flipping back and forth between cover multiple times a second, whether I use the lean button or the sights. It was more a hindrance than a benefit
[b]Misc[/b]
Experienced a couple of game crashes. Also some weird messages about my video card running out of memory upon loading a save that seemed to have no actual impact. Had a couple other bugs like textures, character, gun models and lighting not loading properly that weren't always fixed upon starting the game again.

All this leads to a LOT of save scumming because you can't trust the game mechanics to work as expected.


[b]Story: *spoilers*[/b]
Man, I loved the story in W1 and W2's didn't come close. W2 makes the mistake that some movie sequels do which is, rather than explore the characters you know and love more deeply, it does away with them partially, figuratively, or literally, replacing them with new characters that are supposed to be "cool" but are actually annoying AF. 

The romance between BJ and Anya was the driving force in the first game. In this one it's non-existent. Anya, an intelligent and multilingual medic that helped take down Deathshead is [spoiler]relegated to being a horny lackey that is ordered around and literally sent off on armed missions while being pregnant with twins. WTF. I get that they wanted to raise the stakes and make things dire for Kreisau by killing off Caroline, another great character from W1 but for sadboi BJ to forget Anya, who took care of him for 14 years and carries his children because of this is insane. It would have worked if they really explored his debilitating grief to the end, gave him catharsis, allowing him to reconcile with Anya. But no, they both magically get over it the moment he gets a new body, which is so ridiculous I won't even get into it. For a game that's trying so hard to show it knows emotions, i.e. BJ's father arc, this cop out on grief was an utter waste.[/spoiler]

Fergus was a cynical but charming Scotsman in the first but in this game he's just angry, all day every day, but doesn't have a backbone when it counts [spoiler](standing up to Grace)[/spoiler]. A literal caricature. Wyatt is slightly better but so many characters' dialogue involves them being worked up about something and almost yelling at each other. But either way, the characters never fight alongside you, which doesn't make sense considering they're the few real soldiers in the team, and that choice from W1 was supposed to be weighty. They don't appear much other than in some casual interactions. The uberannoying new character Super Spesh gets more screentime than characters from the first game. [spoiler]Thank god he dies shortly after.[/spoiler]

Grace is alright, in the end. But again, the way she interacts with the team is ridiculous. [spoiler]She literally walks in and plops herself in Caroline's room right after she dies and starts giving orders. To people that took down Deathshead and liberated and saved her. Sigrun giving her a smackdown was my favourite moment in the story.[/spoiler] 

Sigrun was probably the only new character I genuinely liked that had a proper character arc.

All in all, the game was playable and had some enjoyable moments, but other than look very pretty, it didn't scratch my itch for a grounded character-driven story with solid gameplay.

Pros: Wolfenstein II has everything you could expect from a AAA fps release.
Cons: Wolfenstein II has everything you could expect from a AAA fps release.

It's got the graphics, it's well optimised, I didn't have technical issues even running 4K on older hardware on the highest settings. It was just a completely forgettable experience - I didn't dislike it, but I didn't enjoy it either: one of those games that's just going through the motions, completely unremarkable in every conceivable way: I've essentially played it a million times before. The only real take away I had was thinking about the promotional "controversy" when the game came (that I only recall vaguely) and thinking it was funny playing a game where Nazis were the villians, but *what* the Nazi's were doing was seldom brought up in the game. Meanwhile the writers of Wolfenstein II populated it's cast with essentially nothing but racial/cultural stereotypes.

Sooo Ive played through all modern Wolfenstein games now and finally finished Wolfenstein II.
Honestly it's the best of the series, taking what they did right in New Order and Old Blood and enhancing them while also adding way more content.
 The writing of the story is much more intriguing and less predictable. I really liked William's character development, it has ups and downs and questioning yourself.
Most guns feel great and responsive. Most enemies feel real and not just like stupid AI, its  not perfect but I'll get to that soon. 
The main story levels all offer different play styles with a lot of variation and I assume replayability. You know where to go the level design is very intentional. They also look great, if youre not inside of a german facility, which youre a lot of the time, because theyre just grey and nuts and bolts and crates and stairs. It feels bland but I suppose its realistic. 
I really like the commander system but it has a few flaws in addition to the whacky stealthing.
They also reduced the amount of bosses which was a welcomed change.. most of them were boring, slow and 100% gimmicks that added nothing to your game play experience.
Visually this game is impressive, from character models, maps, assets, gore and visual effects and it doesn't hide it, very American. I also really like most of the cutscenes.
I very much appreciated the attention to detail. Little items, documents or quest items found are to be found again in your hub. NPCs in the hub interact with each other and uhh while I dont really care about it personally it still is a nice touch and it feels much more alive.
There's also just soooo much to collect, gold, "readables", songs, toys and what not. I dont know if anyone still likes going through every inch of a level while reading some awfully written article or video about how to find all 500 weird quirky items. Just not for me, I like to collect the toys for Max but thats it.
I am German myself and obviously had a very easy time understanding NPCs, reading random texts or laugh at some of the proper german humour, I wonder what it's like for people not understanding this magnificant language. So much to do in this game, from the Main Story of course, collecting items, doing side quests in your hub, shooting range, challenges, playing retro wolfenstein- so much more content.

I did come across some issues though and I will list them now.
The Ubercommando missions were a horrbile mess. Youre dropped off at a smaller level part of the main story ( which I just complimented) but at a different point, you basically play through them in another way. Sadly this directly destroys the great level design. It feels almost random where you have to go.
They were also very difficult at some points, either swarms of enemies and no way to stealth it or just the worst types of enemies back to back to back. Luckily you can cheese them- once you killed that levels Ubercommando you can exit the mission but you'll miss out on the collectable.
I played through this game in the I am Death Incarnate difficulty which is the second highest difficulty and as someone whos played most shooters on the on the highest difficulty I stil had major problems. Some tank enemies are just impossible to beat, theyll shoot rockets at you and shoot fire if youre too close. They blast your ear drums while disorienting you and basically erasing half your HP with a single blow. I dont know how many rockets, grenades and shotgun shells they eat because I only ever beat one of them and just completely ignored EVERY one of them afterwards. It just is not worth it- doesnt grant you an achievement, doesnt make it easier to progress- in fact its such terrible enemy it doesnt feel good to fight them its a waste of time. Same with other big german things you encounter but the big robots are the worst. There are also meatier soldiers that dont drop with a single headshot. They are quite beefy but have huge weakpoints, sadly you can only really attack those weakpoints from behind and its not easy to get there. They either shoot lasers that do tons of damage or shoot slow spread rocket shotgun shells that deplete easily 75% of your MAX fully MAXED OUT HP.
Often you're almost done with a wave of enemies but then you get one shot and wanna smash your head 30 times against your wall. Its unsatisfying because these shells are very weird and super inaccurate- which sounds fine but in reality it felt bad due to the difficulty of predicitng the bullets.
And this is where I come to my main critique of the game. It's unreliable.
Some enemies will stagger when shot and sometimes they don't. Enemies when out of your line of sight will shout so you know they are gonna attack you from behind, sometimes they dont and just shoot you down instantly. Grenades thrown by enemies are marked with a symbol and sometimes theyre not and you jsut blow up because you didnt hear you were busy shooting. Enemies sometimes do little to no damage with each hit and sometimes the same enemies deplete half your hp and armor in a few shots. Most enemy troops have a certain range they need to be in to shoot William but not every one follows that rule. On some levels you just get sniped ( not by an actual sniper, just some guy with a rifle) or even random rocket fired and hit you or the insane amount of explosive barrels stationed around you. Breaking boxes with your melee feels fun but sometimes William throws his melee instead and the hatchet disappears because?? who knows. Stealth works great, unless it doesnt. Once enemies are aware of your presence they will spot you instantly and being well hidden in the dark or mostly obstructed, doesnt matter if they spot Williams huge ess model youre fcked. So? you think then do it loud and I would agree if that didnt mean you instantly die because every single guy is firing at you. the commandos are instantly alarmed although it has been established not all enemies on the map can hear your gunshots, but the commandos dont care once an enemy is alarmed and not instantly taken out- alarm goes off and everyone's after you. But you cant take out most enemies with a few shots so you have to completely stand out of the bigger enemies sights which is difficult as there are many of them in every level.

To me its a missed opportunity to make one of the greatest shooters. First Person Shooters, especially on high difficulty, need reliablity. You have skill, awareness and experience but the game can just f you over and it feels terrible. It made me actual rage quit a few times.
Due to this I will not complete this 100% and will just maybe come back to it later, sadly.
This is game is 95% cutscene and 10% gameplay. My math might not be entirely accurate, but then again neither are the iron sights.

Good game.

Fast paced and near non-stop action, with a solid story, memorable characters, and overall an awesome sequel to this rebooted franchise.

I played this entirely on Steam Deck and, completed the campaign, and have approximately 43% of total game completion (collectibles, side missions, etc.).

The game picks up immediately after the last game and the story didn't just feel like a rehash of it. It stands on it's own and tries some new things. The levels all felt unique and added to the story and world building this franchise has done. I really enjoyed it from start to finish. The cut-scenes were all well done and I never felt the need to skip them.

The game is pretty non-stop. You go through certain sections of a level and have to kill the enemies. If you alert a "commander" then swarms of enemies come for a while but is not never ending. You do get a bit of a breather between these sections though which is nice. There is health and armor throughout the levels so you never feel too under prepared. I only got stuck on a couple parts, and it didn't feel overwhelming most of the time. You just had to change up your tactics and move more in most instances. I did appreciate the game tried to keep you moving.

There are collectibles throughout most levels/locations. If you find a map in the level it will reveal where all areas in that level, and if you kill a commander in an area then it will show you the location of collectibles, but they are sometimes further into a level. I felt this made exploring a bit more rewarding, and it encourages you to go back to levels later so you can collect what you missed. One of the collectibles are weapon upgrade kits, and it was nice to be able to pick and choose what to upgrade and when. You can even William at a certain point in the game.

All of the characters had their own personalities and were acted pretty well. Nobody really felt flat or 1 dimensional which was nice.

Overall I had a blast with this game. It was fun and challenging at times, but it really did keep me engaged. Highly recommend.

The story is godamn awful, all the new characters are extremely annoying, and the pre-existing ones that were actually interesting and well written before now have the depth of a puddle. Gameplay-wise, the combat is not too dissimilar to The new Order but suffers from absolutely terrible level design disguised by the admittedly very beautiful looking areas. Levels are often frustrating to traverse, particularly if you attempt to stealth your way through. 

I get the feeling the devs were perhaps trying to partially emulate the modern doom design philosophy in a way. Giving the player large arenas stocked with ammo and then filling them with enemies. It simply does not work in tandem with wolfenstein's much slower pace in combat. You cannot jump through open areas, gunning down enemies left and right like in doom, you will die.

Now, I don't think the wolfenstein series should be taken seriously, the concept itself is inherently ridiculous. This game however, takes the occasionally goofiness of the previous games and turns itself into a whole ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• circus. There are so many "lol XD random!!!111!!!11" moments in this game which feel completely out of place and elicit no other reaction from my body other than pure, primal cringe. I can't take any part of this game seriously because there's awful marvel movie tier dialogue every 5 minutes reminding me that the writers (who somehow are the same ones who worked on The new Order) just decided they didn't give a flying ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• about this franchise anymore.

A lot of people complained about this game being overly political or "the wokeification of wolfenstein". THEY ARE RIGHT..... Its an assault on Men, the Army, Capitalism, those who gave up their live against actual Nazism amd socialism... Its a blatant socialist propaganda piece, and its egriegeous.....Men bad, America is racist, and putting emphasis on race instead of merit, EXACTLY WHAT THE NAZI DID....the Woke Cult is just a religious outbreak of socialism, with the primary tennet being that instead of the bourgeoisie, its the White male that is the source of everything Evil in society.....Never forget that Nazi mean National Socialist..... dont belive me, go check the definiton in a dictionaire..... you deny hitler socialism, you deny the Holocaust... you anti-semite POC......Fucking Pathetic and genocidal marxist .... Ideology before common sense....

So yeah, ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• this game. Only buy it if you want to cringe at your monitor for approximately 10 hours. And if you played TNO and just want to see where they decided to go with the story, wait for a sale. A big sale. This game is not even worth ¬£10, let alone 25.

Finished the game. My experience was:

- Port giving me technical issues. Not great, getting crashes etc.

- Managed to finish the main game eventually.

- The story in previous game (New Order) was more enjoyable. I found this sequel to have it's moments, but ultimately fall well short of what was set up in the previous game.

- Some scenes tried to bring more depth and meaning to the story, but ultimately felt more like a cheap shock value (like the early game cut scene-ish stuff) and the auditioning/movie thing. It might have worked better had it been done differently, I would say it's much too blunt and feels quite disconnected from the rest of the game.

- I've seen this game get a huge amount of praise, and in a lot of cases more so than the previous game. This game has imo a definitely lower quality story whereas in the previous game it was a lot more interesting, nuanced and emotional highs and lows felt a lot more "earned" in terms of how it was written and played out.

- I would still say for the game itself it's still worth playing regardless, the combat is still great like the previous game, though there have been some minor changes which I found not to be an improvement and ultimately could be done differently (how weapon types work).

- Music and sound is great, also visually it's modern wolfenstein and it's pretty great.

Bottom line: quite disappointed with the port and the underwhelming story/writing, not a great result in my opinion. If you've played the new order it's natural to also play this. If you haven't played any of them I would probably still recommend to play them both in order: though remember, don't expect too much from this one. The new order is quite a ways ahead of this, in my opinion.

Here are some reasons to play Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus with a bit of humor:

You get to kick some Nazi butt. Who doesn't love a good Nazi-kicking? In this game, you get to take on the Third Reich and their robot dogs, all while feeling like a total badass.

The weapons. From a grenade-launching shotgun to a laser gun, the weapons in this game are all unique and satisfying to use. Plus, you get to dual-wield pretty much everything.

The story. While it may not be for everyone, the story of BJ Blazkowicz and his fight against the Nazis is both ridiculous and heartwarming. It's like a Quentin Tarantino movie, but with more Nazis.

The alternate history. In this game, the Nazis won World War II and have taken over America. It's both terrifying and fascinating to see how different the world could have been.

The humor. Despite the serious subject matter, this game has some genuinely funny moments. From the ridiculous character names to the over-the-top violence, you'll find yourself laughing more than you expect.

The characters. The cast of characters in this game is diverse and interesting, from the tough-as-nails Grace to the lovable giant Sigrun. You'll find yourself rooting for them all.

It's challenging. If you're looking for a game that's easy to beat, this isn't it. Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus will make you work for your victories, but that just makes them all the more satisfying.

Overall, Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus is a fun, challenging, and entertaining game with a lot of heart. And did we mention the Nazi-kicking?

Wolfenstein 2: The New Colossus is an outstanding game that delivers a thrilling and action-packed experience. While some encounters on the "I am death incarnate!" difficulty may feel unbalanced, the overall gameplay is fantastic.

The game's message is clear - f*ck Nazis, fascism, and racism - and it is delivered in a bold and powerful way. The story is engaging and immersive, with well-developed characters and a satisfyingly intense plot.

The gameplay mechanics are well-polished, and the game offers a variety of weapons and upgrades to keep things interesting. The visuals and sound design are also top-notch, adding to the overall immersive experience.

Overall, Wolfenstein 2: The New Colossus is a must-play for any gamer looking for a thrilling and meaningful gaming experience.

After beating this game and the last 2 all on the hardest difficulty, I can confidently say these are good games. Good, mindless fun that can be somewhat of a challenge sometimes.

Would I recommend this game? Absolutely, but there are important things to keep in mind before you play:
First of all, the gunplay is really satisfying and the stealth sections do the job well enough, I really like the fact that the weapons are HUGE (really, even the pistol is oversized), running and shooting has never felt better.
It's important to keep in mind though, this game will KICK YOUR ASS in the higher difficulties, so if you also enjoy that, welcome in.
The part I didn't really enjoy, like most people, is the needless political propaganda in the story, however, I don't think it merits skipping all cutscenes. Sure, some will have you rolling your eyes but I feel some other parts have genuinely made me chuckle or get serious, I really love some of the characters, I feel Blazkowicz is a great main character who is just DONE with everything.
All in all, I feel this game was a fun experience and you should give it a try.
yes

Depravity and immorality masquerading as deep, profound and meaningfully provocative. 

This game is so confused, and is, quite frankly, repulsive.
It's trying to be dark and serious, using extreme violence and gore to shock the player, but then the next second it's using violence as a punch-line.
A game where I blow up nazis with glee, fight robotic dogs and shoot people's heads off in a wheelchair is not a game that should also try to deal with the real-world issues of homophobia, racism, domestic abuse or the incredible tragedy of the holocaust... especially not in the same fucking scene. This game is a joke, and not a funny one. I love dark humour, but there's a time and place and a general tone about it that this game has no understanding of.

You're really going to make fat jokes with a girl crying about having her diary full of sexual fantasies being read by her mother while you show a main character get their head sliced off in gruesome detail as the mother then goes to pick up the decapitated head and mimic sexual acts with it? And you expect us to believe you have any sort of moral decency or maturity? Is there even a message behind it, or are you just taking joy in the depravity of it all?

The writers severely lack maturity and self-awareness. I would, without exaggeration, seriously expect more from children. This is pathetic.
Wolfenstein shouldn't be an outlet for your own little insecurities. It's a game where the entertainment value comes out of blowing people apart for fuck's sake. Don't you think there's a slight clash in tone there? You're not goofy, you're not insightful, you're just, as I said, [b]repulsive[/b], by any definition of the word.

I don't usually take video games seriously. No-one should... unless, in the ultra rare case like this, they're actually trying to make a statement, in which case I'll treat your product like it was made by adults for adults approaching topics worthy of serious discussion. The thing is, this is so pathetically childish that it's a little hard to fathom that anyone in their right mind actually made this. 

As for the gameplay? Hard to judge from 37 minutes, of course, but my first (and last) impressions as I tried to just enjoy the game, trying to look past the negatives I'd heard about its story, was pretty unenjoyable. I was playing on the second hardest difficulty and enemies went down like bricks with stupid AI and unimpactful combat. I was bewildered by how well this game ran, though. 80FPS max settings at 4K on an RTX2060 with visuals this good? How in the fuck did they do that???

Even if the combat (again, based on very little playtime) was actually enjoyable or unique, given how much the legitimately fucked up narrative is forced down your throat, this game is impossible to enjoy to anything close to a worthwhile extent.

This game isn't worthy of anyone's time or money. Don't waste a minute on it. Don't waste a dollar on it. It's vile.

[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/201810/Wolfenstein_The_New_Order/]Previous[/url] [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/350080/Wolfenstein_The_Old_Blood/]entries[/url] in the series got stellar gunplay fort sure, but this one's topping those hands down. Heterogeneous dual-wielding rocks! To exactly nobody's surprise, settling on a combination of assault shotgun & rifle as my workhorse didn't take me long and this pair is a banger! To compensate for that, I suppose, the combat got notably more brutal. I don't even know what armor in this game is even supposed to do, it's gone entirely in 1-2 hits anyway which makes sense, given how weapons became more deadly than armor became protective during the course of the 20th century. It's all fair play though, your weapons rip through nazis just as well (I can write a whole essay on the shotgun alone). Oftentimes, you're all but forced to play tactically, with the leaning mechanic working ever-damn nicely. Otherwise, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/548570/RAGE_2/]applying constant pressure is a survival strategy as satisfying as it is effective.[/url]

And you often have to constantly apply pressure, i.e. because there's another commandant sequence, the one with 2 pricks calling for reinforcements unless you kill them quietly. They really overdid those, to be honest. This suff works well when it's sprinkled in to vary up the pacing but here, it's a constant level design element and they get annoying quickly. You still can blast you way through though.

I've ended up doing the moral equivalent of blasting my way through cutscenes, that is skipping them. [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/201810/Wolfenstein_The_New_Order/]Previously[/url], the writing was a nice mixture of over-the-top alt-history fiction with BJ's pseudo-philosophical, heavy monologue working great with that zany backdrop. Occasionally delving into serious stuff to set up the finale and viola, you got a well-crafted story arc. Here, the thick drama ruins everything, the sprinkles of bathos don't help either. There's some really good stuff (pretty much every time Irene Engel's on the stage) but most of it begs for the skip key. They should've gone for "less is more", same goes for the grindy upgrade mechanics.

My point is, it could be better, but it's still a solid FPS.

PS: interesting how the word "nazi" is a curse in of itself. Playing the German version, BJ whispers "I can think of a thing or two to do with a hatchet and a regime asshole". Here, "regime asshole" is just "nazi" because, y'know, it's an insult way worse than "asshole". Makes sense, the historical nazis surely tried their best being as inhumane as humanly possible.

This is a strange game. 

First of all, it's gore and violence are over the top and the guys definitely took quips from Tarantino both with story and presentation. Sometimes it works, more often it's cringe or disgusting. 

Second, addition of the HUB, shitloads of collectibles, mini-games and small talks with your crew. It can be fun if you into such things but also it really messes up the vibe and flow of the game.

Third, the main gameplay is slick and simple, but it's too repetitive for such a long game (maybe that's why they added so much stuff that doesn't involve killing things).

Fourth, the story. Devs really tried to send some kind of message but I am afraid even they didn't know what was the message exactly. You can see some pro LGBT, BLM, body positivism and other modern social justice stuff clumsily melded with anti-nazi/fascist narrative, all of it is set in 1960 in a world conquered by Third Reich. I gotta say it looks ridiculous and the message (if there ever was one) doesn't get across at all. Very cautiosly I have to wonder if the devs tried to appeal to some market/social group who would love such narratives?

Fifth, the whole Wolfenstein story once again moves nowhere and after finishing the game there is a feeling that BJ once again achieved nothing.

In general, I enjoyed this game and there are definitely a lot of love and work poured into The New Colossus. But it could've been better if devs didn't try to put so much stuff and shallow narrative into the game.

Terror Billy comes again, the one who can kill Nazis even from a hospital gurney and has found armor that makes him superhuman (even more), and this time he looks all the way to Venus and the F√ºhrer himself in the face. In short, a bombastic sequel, as it should be.

After reading the first paragraph, players who didn't like the first part will probably say that it looks like a nice Hollywood fool. But veterans of the latest iteration of Wolfenstein already know that it won't be that simple. The story component of New Colossus is actually one of the game's greatest strengths - it manages to be sensitive, funny, epic, moving, terrifying, absurd and disgusting all at once, and rarely does the mishmash come out with an unpleasant incongruity.

This time, Blazkowicz moves across the big puddle from Europe back home, to the occupied America of the 1960s. The New Order rules there. Guys in Ku Klux Klan costumes are walking the streets, there is a total Germanization of American culture, the Jews are gone and the blacks will soon follow. And Manhattan is a radioactive hell after being hit by a nuclear bomb. But the rebels are not going to leave it at that, so they set out on a bloody journey, the end result of which should be an all-American uprising.
The harsh tyranny of the Third Reich is visible at every turn, so it's no wonder that most Americans prefer to sit quietly at home or even collaborate with a white hood on their heads instead of trying to do something about the situation.

At the same time, the tone of the story spills over from side to side. For a while, you listen to the protagonist's genuinely touching, depressing, philosophical monologue, only to be ambushed by the comically evil main villain in no time. Into a serious dialogue about the terrible state of the whole mission, a character loudly praises how she had a nice emptying after a long time. At one point, you even find yourself going to the set of a Nazi propaganda film about BJ Blazkowicz and auditioning for the role of BJ Blazkowicz, the real BJ Blazkowicz taking the whole thing very seriously as another serious part of his quest to save the world.
I dare say it's one of the funniest scenarios I've seen in the game.

Nazi propaganda constantly labels you a terrorist and portrays you as a complete amoral lunatic, which, let's face it, isn't all that incomprehensible considering the number of your victims. And it's a fact that you cause more than one atomic explosion during the game. But in the end, there's seriously no doubt that you're doing the right thing. Because you are freeing the world from the most horrible regime in human history. And because you're playing one of the best single-player shooters of recent times.
In short, it's honest hectic shooting peppered with some stealth and tactics, served with a quality story brought to life by great characters. Gutten Appetit, Terror-Billy! [b] 80% [/b]

Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus is a disappointing follow-up to the critically acclaimed Wolfenstein: The New Order. While The New Order effectively portrayed the darkness of war through its intense and emotionally charged storyline, The New Colossus falls short in comparison. The narrative is convoluted and lacks the impactful moments that made its predecessor so memorable. The gameplay is also lackluster, with repetitive missions and uninspired enemy design. Overall, Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus fails to live up to the high standards set by The New Order and is a step back for the franchise.

Until the developers get off their ass and create a patch so everyone can play this game, I need to leave a negative review. I was so incredibly excited for this game and for its release, but the day of I couldn't run the game and no matter what patch I tried for my GPU or game, nothing worked. I finally found my own solution by disabling my integrated graphics card, but that's another story.

Speaking of story, this game's story leaves a bit to be desired. There will be spoilers ahead, so read at your own risk.

The entire driving force of this game is to start a "revolution in America", a phrase heard so often in this game, you would think you would actually build up a revolution in the game, and watch the Nazi regime crumble throughout the storyline. Wrong. The game is left at what I believe to be a purposeful cliffhanger for a sequel, and it's very disappointing.

However, the gameplay is rather enjoyable, despite the lack of boss diversity. Giant walkers everywhere? Check.

All in all, this game won't hold up to The New Order, which I highly recommend, but it's still a good way to pass the time.

This game was a huge disappointment for me. It was boring, it fel like a chore. In this linear shooter, too many times I had no idea what the game wanted from me - where to go, which door to break, and how to "solve" another mob of enemies. The stealth sections were a joke, they would punish me for going stealth. The "hint" button is useless (why even advertise it on load screens?), maps are pointless, the motivation for too many missions was too vague, the crafting felt a last minute patch. Most importantly - BUGS! After all these years! I would constantly get stuck waling over changing floor surfaces, especially doors in the last few missions. And - I got STUCK AT THE EPILOGUE trying to climb under those benches. Turned out I had to turn on VSYNC to finish the last mission. But that was after the game totally broke the immersion of revenge on the very last mission. No, I do not recommend this to anyone.

TL;DR A great downgrade from TNO in narrative, some unnecessary things added to the game, and everything else was done just as well if not better in The New Order. Added together I dropped the game. I just couldn't take it seriously and since the narrative is treated as something of importance in this game I therefore need to pay attention to it unlike in something like Doom 2016 or even Eternal where you were given the bare essentials and had to find the details if you cared enough.

Firstly, the story is a mess. I'm not going to say TNO's story was "realistic" but it at least treated itself seriously, this one does not. Your helicopters (forget what the game called them) are painted with peace signs, rainbows, and flowers. I know the game takes place in the 60s and in our world the hippie movement was in full swing at the time but that isn't the case in this game. You are under the heel of literal nazis and are fighting a guerrilla war for freedom and you decide to ride in guns blazing while also having peace signs and flowers painted on your helicopter? That kind of clashes let's be honest. And remember how the Nazis were evil in TNO in that iron fist authoritarian way where you got the sense that so long as you followed their rules, you were good? Yea, not now. They feel more like Joker's brand of evil, set to go off at any point, kill and massacre just alleviate boredom, and diabolically laughing while doing so. Mispronounce a German word? Oh boy better correct that or get ready to meet the business end of a luger. Remember when death was a definite end in TNO? Well in this game (spoilers) someone is actually decapitated medieval style but don't worry, they managed to survive and get a literal head transplant. I know we're playing fast and loose with biology in these games I mean, we were fighting basically fighting souped up super soldiers and mechs in TNO and actual zombies in Old Blood, but surviving a decapitation is just a step too far for me. And even the super soldiers didn't come out of their experiments with full functionality, they could really only follow orders and kill. Far as I know, we never hear one talk as I'm pretty sure they can't. But the decapitated guy? Perfectly fine, better actually thanks to his new body. And in Old Blood that was more or less a retelling of Return to Castle Wolfenstein so I guess I just separated it in terms of it being canon.

I felt like the weapon upgrade system was unnecessary. It feels like Doom 2016's upgrade system but to me it was just missing something. In Doom each upgrade you got would change the weapon in a substantial way. The shotgun would get a grenade launcher or a burst fire (in eternal it would be fully automatic) and could be switched out. Rocket launcher got a lock-on or you could manually detonate the rocket in the air, and so on. In this game, at least the ones I remember were more or less basic upgrades. Armor piercing bullets for the rifle, a scope, and a taped magazine for faster reloads. A silencer for the machinepistol or a drum mag, or even different ammunition that increases damage. Nothing really changes the weapons to make them more interesting just upgrades that give more ammo or do more damage at maybe a slight cost to velocity. 

You also start the game (and play a decent amount) with reduced health, I think you're stuck at 50 for several hours until a story thing happens and you are given the full 100 health to play with. The game is still functional but I felt like I couldn't run and gun like I could in TNO due to the reduced health.

And this is more of a pet peeve but with the transition to a new engine, they changed BJ's face just a little bit,  and honestly, it just looks ridiculous to me. I can't really point out as to why.

I will say that the gameplay is just as good as it was in TNO. The unadulterated violence is just next level and is why I love these types of games. Leaving a fight with a room looking like a slasher movie or a Tarantino film never gets old. Perks are more or less implemented the same and I enjoyed it in TNO and they work just as well here. But both of these were just as good in TNO so they just kept what worked. The new characters were fine, no real complaints about them. Most I can say is that they were very "meh" but I felt the same about TNO's characters save a few standouts like Anya, Set, and Fergus and some others but the majority were just...there and many are the same here. I did notice some performance issues stutters, fps drops, and a few crashes but reducing the graphics helped. it was odd since the problems only became apparent like 5 hours in. Prior to that, almost no issues except the occasional stutter.

Anyways that's it. I could talk about some other stuff but that's delving into spoiler territory and I didn't really get to experience it as I dropped the game shortly after getting basically a major upgrade to your character. This upgrades lets you do a few new things dependent on your choice but it also lets you now have 100 health. But by this point, I was already tuned out and dropped the game and just didn't go back.

Straight up one of the worst games I've ever played. Came back to it recently to see if it's as bad as I remember and it's even worse. Such a shame considering how good The new Order and Old Blood were.

The story is awful, all the new characters are extremely annoying and the pre-existing ones that were actually interesting and well written before now have the depth of a puddle.

Not to mention B.J. himself has the awful side plot regarding his abusive father, something that has never been referenced in previous games. It feels extremely jarring and shoehorned in an unnecessary attempt to flesh out B.J. as a character.

Gameplay-wise, the combat is not too dissimilar to The new Order but suffers from absolutely terrible level design disguised by the admittedly very beautiful looking areas. Levels are often frustrating to traverse, particularly if you attempt to stealth your way through. There are also a few incredibly tedious sections where you have to fend of waves of enemies single-handedly. The courthouse battle is an especially egregious example of this. It's so difficult and lasts so long that I thought I was doing something wrong when I first played the game.

I get the feeling the devs were perhaps trying to partially emulate the modern doom design philosophy in a way. Giving the player large arenas stocked with ammo and then filling them with enemies. It simply does not work in tandem with wolfenstein's much slower pace in combat. You cannot jump through open areas, gunning down enemies left and right like in doom, you will die.

Now, I don't think the wolfenstein series should be taken seriously, the concept itself is inherently ridiculous. This game however, takes the occasionally goofiness of the previous games and turns itself into a whole fucking circus. There are so many "lol XD random!!!111!!!11" moments in this game which feel completely out of place and elicit no other reaction from my body other than pure, primal cringe. I can't take any part of this game seriously because there's awful marvel movie tier dialogue every 5 minutes reminding me that the writers (who somehow are the same ones who worked on The new Order) just decided they didn't give a flying fuck about this franchise anymore.

A lot of people complained about this game being overly political or "the wokeification of wolfenstein". I personally don't really care. It is kind of weird how they tried to do some genuine political commentary about the current state of the world, but it doesn't really hit. I actually think it would be quite interesting to explore other political factions in a setting like this if it was actually done well. There's the communist guy who really doesn't have much dialogue outside of his introduction and the wolfenstein universe equivalent black panther lady who is one of the more annoying characters. They had the potential to actually pose some interesting questions about B.J.'s beliefs but the writers really put no effort into fleshing them out or even giving them remotely serious or believable personalities. Just cardboard cutouts who occasionally say some dumb shit.

So yeah, fuck this game. Only buy it if you want to cringe at your monitor for approximately 10 hours. And if you played TNO and just want to see where they decided to go with the story, wait for a sale. A big sale. This game is not even worth ¬£10, let alone 25. Fingers crossed the devs and writers actually pull their weight for the next game although that's unlikely considering how youngblood turned out.

And on a side note, the DLCs are lazy cashgrabs. No new content, no story, just glorified level packs.

Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus is an absolute blast to play. The gameplay is fast-paced and intense, with a wide variety of weapons and enemies to fight against. The story is well-written and engaging, with memorable characters and a compelling narrative that keeps you invested in the action. The graphics and sound design are top-notch, immersing you in this alternate history where the Nazi regime won World War II and now controls the United States.

As BJ Blazkowicz, you'll lead the resistance and fight back against the oppressive regime, taking on powerful bosses and challenging missions. The gameplay is challenging but rewarding, and there are plenty of collectibles and secrets to discover as you make your way through the campaign.

Overall, Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus is a must-play for fans of the first-person shooter genre. It's a well-crafted game that delivers on its promises and offers a thrilling and satisfying experience from start to finish.

Overall this is a good game... BUT, and this is a HUGE but.

The gameplay is generally good, almost identical to TNO, (which isn't a bad thing) However the difficulty is scaled a little bit weirdly. For me playing in "Bring 'em on" difficulty (standard) some levels felt incredibly easy with practically no difficulty to speak of, whereas others were incredibly difficult. This however didn't bother me that much.

I did however have one MAJOR issue with this game. The game ends where it should have started. Without spoiling anything I'll just say it was really disappointing. The ending was so jarringly out of place I thought I had just played a really long prologue until an achievement informed me that was the end credits. [spoiler] I found personally the fact that your actual effect on the world is never shown. Do people uprise? do people riot? what happened in the relationships between all these characters? [/spoiler] A lot of the game's ending is a big question mark, and not in a good way... It all seemed like a huge set up for a big third game, which as of now a (proper) third wolfenstein game hasn't happened, so it all feels very unfinished in truth.

I also took issue with the fact that when you finish the main story, the game never makes it clear to you whether that was actually the end or not. I actually had to go and google it to make sure. Honestly to me the most disappointing part, is the lack of recognizable landmarks in the game.

But I will say even through all that crap, it's still not a half-bad game. It has some pretty neat gameplay elements, and some damn cool characters (even if they were almost all crazily underdeveloped), and some story moments which in the moment are really amazing to play. It's hard to say it's a bad game, however, don't go in to this game expecting another New Order. It's a different beast, in some positive ways, and sadly, in some incredibly negative ways.

I only got in to wolfenstein for the story, which I understand for most people isn't the case. For me personally I'd say this game is one I have mixed feelings about. For anybody who liked wolfenstein for just the gameplay, or just liked the story as some side stuff to get in to, absolutely buy this game, however if you're like me, you may also leave disappointed

TL;DR: Story felt vastly unfinished and underdeveloped and left me craving more (in a bad way). The gameplay and core loop are just as fun as TNO, I give this game a solid 7/10, not bad at all, but compared to TNO, it's nothing to write home about.

[h1]Introduction:[/h1]
Wolfenstein: The New Colossus is a first-person shooter developed by MachineGames and released in 2017. As a fan of the series, I was excited to see what the newest installment had to offer. Plus, as a communist, there's little I find more satisfying than killing fascists, so I was definitely looking forward to that as well.

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
The gameplay in Wolfenstein: The New Colossus is fast-paced and intense, with a variety of weapons and abilities at your disposal. The controls are responsive and easy to use, making it a breeze to take out waves of enemies. One of the standout features of the gameplay is the ability to dual wield weapons, which adds an extra layer of strategy to combat. During my time playing, I didn't encounter any major bugs or glitches.

[h1]Story:[/h1]
The story of Wolfenstein: The New Colossus takes place in an alternate history where the Nazis won World War II and have taken over the United States. You play as B.J. Blazkowicz, a resistance fighter fighting to take down the Nazi regime. The story is well-written and full of twists and turns, and the characters are well-developed and interesting. The pacing of the story is excellent, with just the right balance of action and exposition.

[h1]Graphics and Sound:[/h1]
The graphics in Wolfenstein: The New Colossus are top-notch, with detailed environments and character models. The frame rate was smooth and stable throughout my playthrough. The sound design is also impressive, with a great soundtrack and excellent voice acting.

[h1]Replay Value:[/h1]
Wolfenstein: The New Colossus has a good amount of replay value, with multiple difficulty levels and unlockable content. There are also collectibles scattered throughout the levels, which give you a deeper understanding of the game's world and characters. The multiplayer modes are also a lot of fun and add an extra layer of replayability.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
Overall, I highly recommend Wolfenstein: The New Colossus to fans of first-person shooters and anyone looking for an engaging story with great gameplay and graphics. The game's intense action, well-written story, and excellent replay value make it well worth the price of admission. It's always satisfying to take out a bunch of fascists.

Gameplay/gunplay -wise: It's pretty much the same as "New Order" and "Old Blood"; dual-wielding, solid feel to the shooting, decent weapon variety, optional stealth, commander killing, perks based on kills/tactics done repeatedly, variety of maps to go through, etc. All similar. Though it doesn't have the ridiculous lock-picking mini-game BS from TNO (thank GOD!) and it doesn't really have a "branching story" depending on who you picked for a companion (Death's Head survivor), that person just... IS THERE, and ... DOES STUFF.

Mechanically, it's got some rough spots. Lots of points where you get snagged on world geometry, lots of spots where the stealth system breaks itself, lots of places where your mobility skills won't activate properly, some shoddy optimization, some GPU/memory leakage, some bugged out texture loading and lighting. Mostly minor stuff, really, but it detracts from the overall package.

YES, the cutscenes are mostly throw-away and told very ham-fisted-ly, but you can skip them if you want, so, (shrug). The story overall is pretty garbage, but the "story" in a Wolfenstein game probably isn't why most of us are here. (more shrugging).

Overall, it's probably worth a look, especially if you've enjoyed the prior reboot titles. I'd still opt for getting it on sale though. This is definitely the weakest of the three.

This game seems to have a very common issue with video memory leakage, it's just a matter of time when the game tells you that the "video driver has run out of dedicated memory".

Storywise also kinda disappointing and once you recruit Grace it feels like she was supposed to replace BJ at one point but Bethesda changed their mind. And her insulting crew members is not very cool considering the circumstances

Just like the other Wolfenstein games, The New Colossus is well paced. The combat switches instantly from slowly sneaking and taking out guards to running guns blazing through hallways guns akimbo mowing down enemy after enemy. The story is interesting enough but its the characters that sell this game. The voice actors always go above and beyond to create a cast of characters that is wacky but endearing. There are countless scenes in which their mannerisms add a layer of levity but also depth to their characters. Even walking around the world, dialogue and small scenes spring to life and you only have to stand and wait for their lives to play out around you. If you are interested in a FPS that boasts not only satisfying gun-play but also a captivating story, then this is the perfect game to pickup.

I played Wolfenstein: The New Order a few years ago, even though the sequel wasn't a big step up I enjoyed it. 

It still kept its great visual style and art design, some of the maps and set locations looked really great, especially if you collect some of the art concept collectibles to see the early drawings. 

The level design offers you a few but limited paths to deal with foes but most of the map layouts are really confusing. The enemies are varied and some new ones are added to the game offering new challenges. 

The plot/cut scenes felt like they came straight out of a movie and new characters are just as memorable and vibrant as the old crew from the first game. I know some didn't like the plot but I enjoyed quite a number of the scenes. 

The game play was mostly untouched from the first game, which actually could have needed some upgrades with respects to the shooting mechanics and stealth system.

My biggest gripe though was how short the game was, When it ended I was like "Wait that's it? That only felt like the appetiser to the main meal."

All in all this game, although not as revolutionary as TNO, was really fun so no regrets purchasing it.
