[b] tl;dr [/b] game very good. Fast paced, weapons satisfying, level design flows. Lighting sucks, dual wielding made too inconvenient, side content dips in quality. Big recommend overall.

[h1] Ramble: [/h1]

This is a great game. It takes all the things that made New Order interesting and pushes them further. You're faster, aggression is rewarded, stealth is nerfed to being very situational, and you depend less on cover. It does a lot of QoL things better, too - automatically picking up ammo and armour from fallen enemies, and having a less limiting (but still important) ammo economy, are very welcome changes. It's also a very pretty game.

Interestingly, I found that you get punished for stealth in this game. Unlike in New Order, enemies usually have enough armour to mean you can't just one-shot them with the pistol or a thrown hatchet. You have to get close to reliably take them out without setting off an alarm, but then you're out of position for if you do get caught. Since patrolling enemies are a lot smarter than in NO, this will happen if you try to stealth an entire encounter, and you'll get rekt for it. Therefore, stealth is more about putting yourself in a favourable position to begin a fight, e.g. with good sight lines, being near health/armour, or getting the jump on harder enemies. This may sound like a bad thing, but it's actually great imo - it means stealth makes up a much smaller proportion of gameplay whilst still being a strategic part of combat. (For context, I played on "Call Me Terror-Billy" difficulty for my first playthrough).

It is held back by a few small things though. Most importantly: the lighting. What the heck? I've never played a game where I thought much about the lighting, to be honest. But NC totally fumbles it by having so many areas (especially later in the game) filled with unrealistically blinding lights, thick fog, or a weird miasma that obscures everything. Not only does it break immersion, but it adds a frustrating aspect to the difficulty because you get killed by stuff you can't see. 

Weirdly, this does seem intentional from the devs. This is obvious when you do the side content because quite a few levels have encounters designed around these lights or fog obscuring distant enemies. One level is even in total darkness, meaning you rely on a very small flashlight. I like that they experimented with this, but in practice it's annoying.

Also: dual wielding. Because they give you so many configurations, it's hard to quickly/easily get to the combos you actually want. If you rely on pressing Q to toggle to your last used weapon, you can't do that between dual weapons and a single different weapon. Moreover, if you scroll or use the weapon wheel to switch weapons while dual wielding you won't go back to a different single weapon like in NO, you'll cycle your right hand gun and keep the left hand gun the same, or vice versa. Since time doesn't slow in the weapon wheel until you get a late game perk, this means you'll get rekt for being picky about weapon combos.
This *could* be fixed with having dedicated hotkeys for each weapon, but I don't think it's reasonable to expect players to do that on a first playthrough.

Finally: the story. This is the least important part of the game really, but they gave it much more love and care this time. Even if you ignore the plot itself, the hub is full of heartfelt interactions between different Kreisau fighters which make it feel like a real place, full of real people, with real hopes and tragic pasts. Even the random Nazi dudes have interesting conversations, causing you to pause and listen to their random personal drama before swiftly relieving them of it. Same goes for the documents you find. In most games I ignore these things, but here they're witty and loaded with emotion.

It's not without issues though. Fergus, one of the only interesting characters in the previous games, is sidelined to being an angry twat most of the time. BJ becomes way too melodramatic for the first half of the game - they definitely should've toned that down a bit. And the story-laden intro is unskippable, making Mein Leben playthroughs too much of a chore. Otherwise, I really like the way they use new characters and develop old ones. It manages to be both very silly and surprisingly sincere - it has hilariously unreasonable bombast alongside heartfelt character interactions. A very nice balance of tone, imo.  (Side-note: "Terror-Billy" is a stupid nickname and I hate it.)

[h1] Wolfenstein reboots in a nutshell: [/h1]

New Order: 7/10. Strikes a truly unique balance between being cover based and retro style. Stealth is OP, and often incentivises you to avoid fights, but it does allow you to go ham with dual weapons when the time is right. Map design is generally open and allows you to flow between aggression and cover, though some levels (especially the final one) are all about sightline/choke abuse. Starting each mission with limited weapons, usually just the pistol, feels needlessly limiting and further encourages stealth to avoid fights.

Old Blood: 4/10. An often frustrating experience due to its over-use of tedious stealth, limiting map design that punishes aggression and encourages abusing sightlines by leaning, and one of the most mind numbing final bosses imaginable. It has its moments, but generally it takes the foundations laid by NO but puts you in maps which make most of the interesting things about NO unviable.

New Colossus: 8.5/10. Takes almost all emphasis away from cover and stealth, maps and mechanics are conducive to playing aggressively, and has a more interesting array of weapons and upgrades. Story and characters are good but a bit melodramatic at times. Held back by some small things, but very solid overall.

This is meant to take place in the United states and there's only really one part that manages to show Nazi occupied America, New York city is just a boring wasteland (and yes, I know it was nuked, but they still could have made NYC look a bit more like NYC).  

I have a lot of issues with this game, like the difficulty balancing is horrible among other things. If you really wanna play this because you liked the previous games I'd lower my expectations and only get this on a good sale for 8 bucks like I did, and I still feel kinda ripped off with that. I would suggest buying Doom 2016 or Doom eternal instead, those games are made for fans, by fans, and it really makes the games shine.

Also If you thought BJ's monologues in the previous games were melodramatic and kinda angsty, they turned that up about 100% for The new colossus. Another thing worth mentioning Is this game is strangely taxing on my computer, despite me being able to run Doom Eternal on Ultra without any problems.

PROS:

- Acting is incredible
- The dystopian world is amazingly made

- We can finally get to explore and fight into the nazi dominated cities or the post nuclear ruins, instead of having only a quick glance (I.E. as seen in London, Berlin or the Moon surface in TNO. Yes, they still taste extremely bitter)

- The duration of the game is finally reasonable

CONS:

- Checkpoint system is sometimes messed up

- AI has definitely improved since last chapter, but is still not great

Wolfenstein TNC may not be a bad game, per se, but it certainly isn't what I'd call a FUN game. The grit, grime, and weight of TNO's combat and story is gone, and in its place are myriad frustrations. Getting stuck on small bits of level geometry, extremely dissonant difficulty spikes, and some of the worst player character damage feedback I've ever seen are just a few of my gripes. Starting from about 1/4 of the game onward, there were far too many arenas that were just brutally unfair, making it impossible to persevere if you hadn't already memorized the layout. Adding on to that, the cutscenes. Sheesh. I thought everyone was exaggerating, but after the first couple of hours they really start wearing on you. 

All in all, if you see this game on sale for 5 dollars, by all means grab it to round out your Wolfenstein collection. Otherwise, hard pass.

OVERALL RATING: 7/10

What fascinated me the most was the idea of Nazis accelerating technology by atleast a century, their space traveling tech is something we dont even have now or portal lethal laser guns yet the game is set in 1961. This is evidence by the familiar architecture and the protagonist‚Äôs, B.J Blazkowicz, mid-western accent however i'm confused by this choose, are they implying that technology would have advanced to level never seen before if the third reich won WW2, I might be reaching it is a video game after all, just fantasy making. This version of Hitler is amusing to say the least, he won the war but is still highly paranoid and just as ambitious to eradicate his enemies prewar and obviously is a pill popping addict, he should of had more screen time they barely touched the surface of exploring this character,albeit I didn't get to kill him (only became aware of that option when I sought out the steam achievement list to see what i missed after completing the game).

The game begins with Blazkowicz kicking ass and killing Nazis on a wheelchair, the tone of the game is established early and Im loving it , just like every other fps or games with fps elements incorporated I was not sure which approach to take : go gun blasting like in Doom Eternal Or stealth approach; the game presents both methods. In some chapters of New Colossus it made sense to be stealthy to avoid dying countless times, obviously depending on what difficulty you were playing. I was playing on ‚ÄúBring Em On‚Äù, it was all smooth sailing until I reached the  infamous ‚Äúcourtroom‚Äù (those who have played know what i'm referring to). It was brutal, I was confused and frustrated, I raged quit after 30 minutes looked up on youtube, ashamedly, to find that some people managed to play it on the utmost difficulty setting with pristine accuracy, their movement was fast and erratic like a ADHD person on amphetamine; it resemble the gameplay of pro COD players I've occasionally seen online. At that point I asked myself am I capable as a casual hobbyist to play like that, obviously for fun, it takes me too long to finish games in general however I enjoy delving into the lore that the development team created but for once I want to feel like a gun sling badass. So I set a timer for 30 minutes and tried to channel my inner ADHD to imitate those pro COD players you see on random TikTok/Youtube clips, I progressively improved with each death but because of human error and feeling out of my element I would eventually catch a bullet to the head. I think that style of gameplay requires hours of practice,it is insane, sooo I lowered the difficulty setting but using the same approach and survived, only for that surprise plot twist (WTF). Note: at one point I tried it on the highest difficulty, conclusion: not fun, maybe I need what Hitler was popping to reach those speeds.

The gun animation is very satisfying and the stealth takedowns are on point with numerous variations each with flesh debris splattered on your face and nearby surfaces. In terms of the story it's actually pretty good, I can see it being a short Netflix series with Tim Miller at the helm. The dialogue cutscenes in the submarine sometimes strangely reminded me of Cowboy Bebop‚Äôs scenes when the characters were chilled and mellow and having casual dialogue. The dialogue between the NPC was basic, nothing special. The graphics were on par with most high graphics games of 2017 but the visual effects stood out for me. I definitely recommend this game to FPS players who are also looking for a good cinematic story.

Overall, this is a pretty good game; however, there are multiple aspects in it that were extremely frustrating and seemed like a downgrade from the original. Some minor spoilers for mainly gameplay/weapon related things below.

Gameplay-
Dual wielding different weapons at the same time is awesome in theory- however, the dual weapon select screen is terrible. When trying to select a weapon (with mouse), pushing your mouse straight forward/up will almost never select the topmost weapon (assault rifle), and this hold true for most parts of the wheel. This necessitates taking your eyes off combat, and slowly selecting a weapon in real-time while you are getting shot at. Some slow-down and a more precise wheel would have fixed this (it probably works fine on console/controller).
Weapon variety is pretty poor; I like the additions of the new heavy weapons and diesel/electricity refueling, but half of the main weapons are pretty obsolete. for stealth, the Pistol far outclasses the SMG, and the rifle outclasses it in open combat; making the SMG obsolete from basically the start. The little grenade-launcher pistol is also straight up terrible, and is also far outclassed by the Dieselkraftwerk-thing (which you can also dual wield!). I miss the option for a high-powered rifle like in TNO that was useful for far-off enemies. Plus points for bringing back the amazing shotgun/s though.
Contraptions were a neat addition, but the fact that you can ONLY obtain the final 2 right before the last mission (which you dont even know will be the last mission when you start) is pretty disappointing. I chose Ram-Shackles, which I now feel like is the most useless of all of them. It forces you into an aggressive playstyle (yes, I know that was the point- but players should have the freedom to experiment with different ways of entering firefights even if their "build" is skewed towards one end of the spectrum) by making a loud entry into new areas that are only accessible via a contraption route. The game really should have offered the chance to get these contraptions earlier, or should have added another mission or two to the main story so that you have a chance to get and test out these contraptions.
Clipping and invisible walls make it so that BJ can often get caught on the bottom parts of doorframes and other little obstacles that in most modern games would not hinder you. Trying to crawl/fall through vents is equally annoying, and some other tight areas are near-gamebreaking as you need to find the exact angle and positioning to pass through.
The melee key being double bound to the throwing axe is also very annoying. So many times did I try to stab a guard/break a box at point blank, and the axe is thrown and often lost or even alerts nearby guards. On the topic of the throwing axe- there are many instances in which it was thrown, and just dissipated into thin air; it did not hit a wall or even go through the air, it just disappears after being thrown and does nothing.

Story-
Overall, story is not bad. The main story missions are well varied and paced for the most part, and there are a lot of interesting characters, dialogue, and collectibles to be found. There are also some extremely annoying characters (yes, you know who I'm talking about) that come into the story and take very odd commanding roles and give BJ condescending orders and things of the nature. There are also a host of new characters that seem like they would be a major part of the story, but contribute almost nothing in gameplay or cutscene time. Remember in TNO when your bunker gets wiped out by the Nazis and so many of your people die? I remember that being a quite sad moment and motivation towards the final fights; meanwhile, if the ship had been raided towards the end of this game, I would have felt very little sadness for most of the crew (besides those who survived TNO) since there is very little development created. Searching around the bunker in TNO was also far more engaging and satisfying than trying to explore the ship (which has an extremely confusing layout). 

Overall, this game is not BAD by any means; it is quite good in fact, but I am leaving this as a negative review due to the extremely frustrating choices made, mainly pertaining to gameplay. I got it on sale for about $6; for that price, I am extremely satisfied. If I had paid $60 for this game brand new, with only about 8 hours of main story and some very disappointing side missions, I would have been pretty unhappy.

If you liked the first game, you probably will like this game too. If you didn¬¥t played the first game, then play it, before playing this one.

If this game's predecessor The New Order was made by Machine Games' A-team, then The New Colossus was made by their C-team at best. While TNC inherits TNO's extremely capable shooter DNA, without the latter's set-pieces that were interspersed to keep things interesting, the former ends up being just another shooter.

The story is also nothing to write home about. Again it builds on its predecessor's, but doesn't really expand on it. This makes it a little difficult to care when certain characters are killed off, or when new ones join the party. There are no particularly noteworthy twists of any sort, it's just a case of go to a location, kill enemies, retrieve something/destroy something, wash rinse repeat. There's a sub-plot about mortality which tries to evoke pathos, but you know they're never gonna die anyway because they're a main character and therefore have plot armour, so said character's crying about it just ends up being annoying.

Environments are serviceable but small, nothing special. I was also able to get my character stuck into the level geometry at least once, which at least confirms this is indeed a Bethesda game. Weapons are nice and punchy but some of their upgrade choices are confusing. For example there's one that has a silencer, but no scope; while another has no silencer, but a scope... WHY? Then there's the shotgun, which as per traditional videogame weapon balancing is capable of doing damage only when it's close enough to an enemy to be inserted into one of their bodily orifices.

Alternative history Nazi-controlled America is less contentious and therefore less shocking at the time of this review in 2022, compared to half a decade ago when the game was released, thanks to a certain tangerine president and his supporters. Granted there are far too many Americans who need a basic history lesson in the horrors of Nazism is and why it's something to be abhorred not embraced, but I don't feel a videogame is the optimal vehicle for delivering that message. At least, not this one.

All in all it feels like a game that was created not as the result of a bold vision for how to move the series forward, but simply to tick the box "Wolfenstein reboot sequel" off a list. And that's a downright shame for such a time-honoured franchise.

Wolfenstein ‚Äì The new colossus is a FPS set in an alternative retro-future. The second world-war was won by the germans, and now the US is under german occupation. It is up to the weakened protagonist, who just regained consciousness after a long coma to fight back against the germans.

At the start of the game you will have to choose between saving one comrade out of two. The result however will not be only slightly changed cutscenes down the line. Depending on who you saved, you will unlock a unique weapon. As such, saving Fergus will unlock the laser rifle, by far the better choice. The other one would be a large-scatter close/medium range combat gun. 

The graphics of the game are detailed, as expected from a AAA franchise. There are tons of assets used in the game, like various vehicles, ruined buildings. The german soldiers will have a wide variety of outfits, and there will be a lot of semi-futuristic weapons. There will be a few problems with the graphics too. One is the notorious ‚ÄúThe video driver has run out of dedicated resources ‚Äì accept and mute further warnings‚Äù warning, which will just keep popping up randomly during playing. For me there was a slow item loading, resulting a delayed pop-in of items at the edge of the screen when turning suddenly. Also the game imitates the delay of eye adaptation when entering a dark zone, where for a few seconds everything will be very dark, then brightening up sightly.

The level design is good. There will be various environments, but the most emphasizes will be given to retro futuristic german environments, a combination of industrial and military settings. The stealth approach felt more natural on some levels than others, still, on normal difficulty triggering the alarms won‚Äôt be fatal, merely more harder for a short time. The enemies arriving piecemeal if you stay far away from their base after an alarm can be abused in a pinch.

Surprisingly the story, specifically the cutscenes are the weakest part of the game by far. AAA games shouldn‚Äôt have issues in that regard, yet this game manages to present ridiculous / jarring scenarios. It doesn‚Äôt help that the allies to be sought for the revolution are irresponsible anarchists. While one shouldn‚Äôt expect realism in this setup, the events / characters are just way over the top, entering a bad caricature level.

The voice acting of the game is great, too bad it is wasted on a weird story. The music stayed in the background, generally I just didn‚Äôt notice it.

The weapons will be mostly the standard types expected in an FPS. A welcome option is the heavy weapon class. There will be 3 types of them. They can only be picked on the map, and have to be abandoned either as you progress through choke points, or when their ammo runs out. The best one is the heavy laser, it is basically the I win option. The diesel thrower is more of a mid/close range weapon, and there is an autocannon too. If I got access to them, I always preferred them to any of my other weapons. The catch with them is that you will move more slowly, and cannot dual wield. But on normal difficulty I never found a situation that mandated dual wielding. As for the standard weapons, there will be a pistol and a submachine gun, both of which can be silenced, so using them won‚Äôt trigger an alarm (but if the enemy gets the chance to fire back, that will trigger the alarm). The standard assault gun is good for any situation, the shotgun is only till medium ranges. I already mentioned the special weapon depending on your choice at the beginning. A mini grenade launcher will be available too, though I barely used that, even after upgrading it to a RPG. You can use throwing axes too, but I rarely relied on them, they are mostly an alternative for stealthy approaches. Grenades can be used too, but I had varied success in throwing them to the intended places, so I don‚Äôt really relied on them. After the electric discharge upgrade I saved them mostly to disable monster mechas for a brief period.

The skill tree can be unlocked by performing certain gimmicks. Some of them happened naturally, like for heavy gun use. Others were more obscure, and I didn‚Äôt really progressed with them. On normal difficulty the game was forgiving enough to proceed without much progress in most of them. Eventually you can unlock one of three personal upgrades. By far the best for a casual gamer is the leg extension. Not because of its way of handling, but because it will unlock the secret bonus of health stabilization. By doing its somewhat hidden upgrade quest, it will allow to overcharge your health to 200 without it decaying, as it would happen otherwise. It also grants the adrenaline rush, which adds 3 health to you after a kill. It doesn‚Äôt seem much, however under 100 your health will grows to the next multiple of ten if no damage is taken. Kill someone when your health is 40, it will change to 43 then increases to 50 with no damage. The other two contraptions can be obtained too through their enigma mission, but there was an in game hint as to which enigma mission is that only towards the very end of the game. If chosen, the ram shackle upgrade supposedly can be upgraded to regen armor, probably similar to the adrenaline rush mechanics.

By collecting the commander cards, eventually the option for enigma missions will open up. They offer a chance to replay previous maps of the game. Most of the times the map will be the same as for the campaign, but not always. For example, Blazkowicz‚Äôs home will be a very different map, and Roswel downtown will have quite a different setup too. Playing through these maps you get a chance to collect all the collectibles, though a guide will probably be required for that. Starting with the New Orleans ones, I just ignored them, but did all the collectibles before them - which was the cause of me burning out for this part of the game. Running around aimlessly for the remaining collectibles just wasn‚Äôt fun, neither was checking out a youtube guide for them.

There is a quicksave function, but the game does its best to hide it from you. Nevertheless, with F5 you can quicksave freely. There are autosave points, the save icon is displayed clearly in the upper left corner for them, and you can save manually from the menu.

I played with the keyboard and mouse, for FPS games they are the natural choice. There was a weird bug with the game for me, if I left the gamepad attached to the computer, the game refused to use the keyboard input and shown only gamepad prompts. I just had to unplug the gamepad while I played this game.

At the start of a few levels I got the pistol equipped. That was a subtle hint by the game makers that a part with recommended stealth approach will come. Even if you don‚Äôt want to use stealth, your first weapon upgrade should be the silencer either for the pistol or the submachine-gun, opening up the possibility to take down enemies without triggering an alarm right away. There will be such hints throughout the game. For example if you encounter a lot of shotguns on a rack it is a hint that a close quarter approach is a suggested way to proceed.

The game has DLC missions too, with new protagonists. They aren‚Äôt exactly cheap, and are quite short. If all three would have been available for 5‚Ç¨ when I was playing, I would have bought them mostly to unlock the achievements, but alas that didn‚Äôt happen. As such I ended up skipping on them, and probably for the better.

While the game was reasonably entertaining, its sequels didn‚Äôt catch my interest. The VR one was limited in length, and seemingly a mediocre game too. Youngblood was a coop game, which, if played with an AI companion, was deemed very tedious. As such this game seems to be the proper end of the single player part of franchise for the time being.

Unfortunately, the game crashed to the desktop a few times. After a few such incidents, I just started to quicksave after finding a collectible, or after an inner segment.

Alternate history stories where Nazi won the WW2 is not rare, though Wolfenstein is one of the few game series which makes a fascinating story out of it. Wolfenstein TNC brought the story to 1960s United States, and successfully rendered a chilling Nazi-occupied nation.

Still, there are some problems with this game. For example, the annoying ‚Äòout of VRAM‚Äô bug, which would appear even if it just use half the VRAM available; the Steam achievements not registering bug, which is especially annoying since even some basic storyline achievements cannot be completed.

[b]Spoiler Alert[/b]
Also, the gameplay is a bit empty after completing campaign. [spoiler]After killing the main antagonist, the only thing you can do except for grinding components, is killing the Ubercommanders, which still doesn‚Äôt give you anything besides a hidden assassin mission. You can‚Äôt even see the main characters in the U-Boat! [/spoiler] In my opinion this is a real waste of the game mechanics.

For context, I've played the new Wolfenstein series - The New Order, The Old Blood, and most recently, The New Colossus.

The first two were nice. Fairly enjoyable action gameplay, well thought level design. The characters have been interesting so far, but the story around them wasn't something to write home about. The alternate history *setting* and lore, however, are really interesting. Yes, I liked The Man in the High Castle. How did you know? Yet, the first two games didn't draw me in all that much. The graphics were fine, and something about the visual design felt noisy and cluttered. They didn't come close to being my favorite games of the last few years.

All this made me hesitate to start The New Colossus.

Wow am I glad I did. This game is a *massive* glow up for the new Wolfenstein series. 

It not only addresses my complaint about visual clarity; it's a hands down handsome looking game! 

The story remains just as interesting. Characters, old and new, are more fun than ever. Something about the cinematography and music in the cutscenes elevates them, and their performances pack a punch in this one. Grace Walker, a new addition to the squad, was solid all around. Another thing I enjoy about this game's narrative is the tone. It seems like a totally serious action-thriller on the surface. Yet, it's not afraid to delve into the weird and ridiculous from time to time. I think this was true for the previous iterations as well, but The New Colossus dials it up a notch. While I enjoyed it, I don't know if everyone would.

I enjoyed the gameplay loop in this one a bit more. If I remember right, the first two games "chained" their set pieces, with the character moving from scene to scene. I didn't complain about that, but I prefer how The New Colossus lays everything out. The game has been restructured to follow a home base and missions model (after the first mission or so). This gives an in-universe excuse for the game to take you to familiar locations, reusing maps with slight modifications for special assassination missions and collectible hunting. The New Colossus remains a gameplay-first game, offering a good amount of replay value and bonus "levels" to players who value those things.

Finally, one of the most standout aspects of this title for me was the FEEL of everything. I don't have a single word to distill this into. Everything from the menus, to the sound effects in the menus, to how the weapons looked and felt, movement controls, and overall UX is remarkably crisp. It's not easy to balance the fluidity of first-person character animations with how responsive the controls feel while managing to not look janky. I think it was mainly the UI respecting the player over unnecessary animations, delays, fade-ins for aesthetics. During gameplay, almost every voluntarily triggered animation (such as reload) can immediately be cancelled with reasonable consequences. I never found myself waiting for a menu to fade or slide into place, or for my character to finish reloading or switching weapons as an enemy guns me down. I'd love to see other games learn from The New Colossus how to make an experience that *feels* fun while looking nice.

All in all, I recommend this game. It's great. Please play The New Order first. Knowing all the characters was a big part of my enjoyment. Skip the prequel unless you're a huge fan of the first one. It's non-essential. It's very much a gameplay-first game with good replay value, bonus objectives, fantastic level design, fun collectibles, good humor, all packaged in UX that respects the player.

As a bonus, The New Colossus has a satisfying ending that could spark a sequel, but it won't be necessary. Netflix original series writers should learn from this franchise.

Highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys modern Doom-like shooters. There are a few downsides to the game though. Running and gunning is definitely an option for the more seasoned Wolfenstein/Doom aficionados but for those players looking for a casual experience expect to take the stealthy route and die a lot during intense gun fights. And not to the difficulty either, more so fixed things in the environment killing the fluidity of your movement, random explosions caused by an over abundance of gas containers and explosive objects jam packed around each setting, getting dropped by an enemy or explosion and not being able to bounce quick enough, and the slow reload rates when overwhelmed by enemies.

For the upsides I'd say New Colossus' biggest draws are the characters, extremely satisfying gunplay, enemy variation, and story (some would disagree with this point). The story itself is nothing amazing or groundbreaking but its a good story none the less. The characters each have their story arcs that flesh out both their flaws, and their best qualities (to an extent  with some). The gunplay is my favorite aspect; the shooting mechanics, bullet impact, weapon design, and variety and choice when it comes to killing enemies is where this game shines. There are some moments that are more predictable when it comes to the gunfights but the replay value is high. I've caught myself wondering how I can go about killing an entire squad of elite nazis on my second campaign playthrough with a different set of weapons and using the environment to my advantage. Sure does getting killed by a random explosive ammo container get frustrating after the third or fourth time: absolutely, did I still have an amazing time: Ya mein fuhrer. Last thing I wanted to mention was the graphical improvements over the previous games. The art style really stands out and the smoothness, textures , and lighting give this game an aspect of eye candiness I haven't seen in very many video games trying to achieve a similar art style.

Overall highly recommend this game for anyone looking for high replay value, great fast paced gunplay, good story and characters, as well something beautiful to look at. Best Wolfenstein in my opinion.

I do like this game a lot, and it does improve on some of the aspects of the previous game, The New Order. The graphics are better, there is more extra stuff for you to do in this game than just getting collectibles as there are side missions and also assassinating the commanders, and the amount of weapon upgrades and how you collect them also felt better. However I have to say that I still found The New Order to be better. The levels are good but not as good as The New Order in my opinion, The New Order also felt like it had more tension because the situation was a lot more dire but in The New Colossus the resistance is doing much better and as such there is less tension throughout most of the story. However don't let any of that dissuade you from the game, I still think it's very good, however if this is your first time playing the new wolfenstein games, I would recommend playing the new order first. Overall, 8.5/10

This game barely passes as a good game. Buy only if on sale. I liked the first Wolfenstein: First order. This is a soup cooked from the leftovers. This is one of that modern games that has some elements only because its cool to have them. Movies are too long, they start to tell you things you are not interested in. I am very patient in this and am watching them in games. Here I had to skip, it was too much. The sound is sometimes so overwhelming that you can not hear your surroundings and I had to turn it off completely in the last section of the game. It should be possible to cancel some animations, like when you are picking up some big weapon, you have to wait for the picking up to finish only then you can throw it down. You start story where you ended, on the big submarine. Then there is the old bat, frau Engels, she will be your nemesis throughout the game. You will face some serious self actualization told with inner voice of the main character. WTF. Just let me on them and keep this stuff to genre that is for it. Oh I forgot to tell that it is so cheese, it hurts. Like a play from high school. But weapons are good. Pistol, SMG, Sturmgewehr, modern shotgun,grenade launcher. And trusty hatchet for a melee. Can be thrown as well. You can upgrade your weapons, in a really good way and can even switch between mods. You can get up to 3 gadgets of war. One is walker, imagine 2 meters high polesthat jump out of your boots. Just double jump and up you are. Has some tactical usage. The other is armor that allows you to ram down things. Last is sneaky/snaky, harness that allow you to shrink a bit, get into small air ducks and such. Later in game you need to use them to progress further. You are getting also skills, this time to acquire them is more about using them then before. AI is nothing out of ordinary. You get officers that if alerted and not finished of quickly will summon allies. When killed he drops enigma ticket. You can use them in enigma engine to decode locations of commanders on map. It only adds flavor to the game, nothing else. It is so hard to pick something from the ground. I had to backtrack quite often because of that. Like missing enigma ticket when you pressed E during shoot out. Who likes that? And best thing as last ‚Äì you get to play the conversion of original Caste Wolfenstein. Modded a bit. There are 6 episodes each with 9levels. I enjoyed it a lot and play it all thru.
All in all I can recommend the game. You will have fun. But there are so many more better then this one. The cheesiness was too much. Like you get to fly to Venus, to audience with Hitler to play role of B.J. Blazskovic in a movie. You do not get to shoot him, but the things they show you are too much.

the bad : bogged down by it's own bad design choices, game crashes a lot, armor and weapon pickups tend to fly into hard to reach little spots throughout levels,little crevice's between debris, you can and will be shot during melee glory kills and dismounting vehicle states, stealth is nearly pointless, not entirely, it's only generally useful for starting fights, too many cutscenes and the mundane tasks in the hub between levels. honestly, just leave all that to a cutscene.. that's skippable. I'm playing wolfenstein, I'm here to kill nazis, not be an office assistant. the story... the whole power armor, and artificial BJ suit... it's awful. the weapon wheel can be really moody if you play on a controller, weapon swaps are slow, and if you need to change weapons during a fight, the wheel may or may not work at times. the autosave points... i can't tell you how many times it saves the game while you're being shot. so die, load auto save and you're taking damage instantly. 

the good: when stupid things aren't happening and you're shooting nazis, it's good at that. AR is OP, shotgun is still my preference because AR's are boring and overdone. stick to shooting, don't try to run and melee/ mix up the action during a fight too much if you have to reload or swap weapons because the wheel may not work, you'll be shot/killed for doing it, what sucks is it's so close to playing like you're in an 80s action film, and when it does play to that potential, it's fun, it's challenging and the a.i isn't entirely stupid on death incarnate, they're accurate, will flank and change positions a lot. the action is great only to be bogged down by it's crap. Old Blood is still better. Just play that.

Far and away the best out of the reboot trilogy. Almost every complaint I had about the combat in the previous two games has been fixed here. You can now reload while sprinting, and most pickups (with the exception of health overcharge) you can snag by simply running over them, rather than having to mash E all over the place. While there's some familiar faces in the weapons roster, they all have a spin to make them new again, along with upgrades to increase their usefulness. For example: the magnum upgrade for the pistol actually makes it viable throughout the rest of the campaign, as opposed to that weird burst-fire thing from New Order. The perk trees are better conveyed, meaning I actually went to seek out certain types of kills as opposed to simply accidentally getting perks. While there's still more cutscenes than I would like, the dialogue and characters are way better for the most part, making them more engaging as opposed to a slog.

Not recommended. 

1. On principle. 
I don't like this Nazi-obsessed shit. All the guns are German-styled. None are Allied-style. There are swastikas fucking everywhere. The team's pig is named "Rosa" - clearly a racist dev was referring to Rosa Parks, the African-American civil rights activist. Though we are shooting at Germans, I don't believe this game is anti-Nazi. I think it's just the only allowable way to make a game that is about "what if the Germans won WW2?". 

2. Bethesda cannot do FPS. 
I've played Dooms and Fallouts enough to know this. They try hard, but they are RPG guys; their style doesn't translate over. The gameplay is in some aspects pretty good early on, but overall it is just boring and poorly designed, and I can't bring myself to finish the campaign. The few weapons on offer grow tiresome, the enemies are boring, the gameplay, the whole game actually, is just childish. 

3. The characters and story are cringe, and often crossing a line. 
Again - they tried real hard, but what they produced is crap. Every character, every scene, is a cliche. Lots of it doesn't make sense and is anachronistic. It gets worse though. There are many moments in the game where I am just honestly questioning the mental health of the devs. Scenes of domestic violence, animal abuse, child abuse, a pregnant woman smoking, the main character rambling to himself on and off during the campaign, you have to choose which of your comrades dies and which lives, every parent-child relationship is just abusive and you're watching the abuse. The game just isn't right. What do you expect when the whole thing is about Nazis.

Positives:
The graphics and engine are slick. There have been moments I was really enjoying gameplay, but they don't last. 

I've played Wolf 3D, RTCW, this. This is a shit attempt. I was offered the game along with Doom Eternal for $5 or something, so I just added it. Having played enough of it, I can't recommend it. 

The devs need therapy, or something stronger than that.

I'm not usually a fan of FPS games and after reading reviews my expectations were not high, however I think I was wrong. I am quite impressed with the game design because it allowed me to play most of the way through with stealth which is my preference. I was also surprised to find that the game did not force me to endure "mini-boss" fights because there always seemed to have been an alternative option (stealth, sniping or running away). Regular saving and changing difficulty is enabled too. I did find that the format of finding and killing officers did get a bit tiring, so I was disappointed to discover that after the main game ended there was a series of uberkommander killings to be done. Nevertheless I did them all but my enjoyment level was dwindling. I bought the game in a sale and got the dlcs which I mostly enjoyed, apart from Joe which often felt like a vanilla FPS. The other two are more fun because of the stealth, but by the end I had definitely had enough. I wouldn't recomment the dlcs unless they were almost free, as they were for me.

You know out of the whole series even though my first gameplay was on TNO I think I preferred this one more than TNO. I did hate the grinding though to complete the game nearly 100%. I think I have like 97% so no I didn't get that completion because there's a few things I don't care for when grinding. But story wise the game is the shit and I felt was more edge of your seat than prior. Highly recommend when on sale if your into the series and if you like WW2 FPS games.

Having just played "The old Blood" and seeing the great improvements Machine Games made over "The New Order" I was expecting a lot from "The New Colossus".
Whilst Machine Games did manage to fix a few of the issues I found In "The Old Blood" sadly some well working mechanics seem to have regressed.
The New Colossus is definitely still a Wolfenstein game, however, whilst I enjoyed playing "The Old Blood", this game was a bit of a nuisance to play.

So, a list of the bad:
*With generational game and engine improvements, The New Colossus now has terrain that is not even, which is great for the looks of the games but terrible for actual gameplay purposes when the game isn't tested well enough. I ended up getting stuck in multiple areas that I couldn't get out of. I also had multiple situations where the platform I wanted to get onto was 1mm higher than the one I'm on and I couldn't walk onto it and had to jump. Its not a huge problem but over hours of gameplay gets annoying.
*The lean mechanic is broken. A mechanic that worked well on both the original and the prequel has somehow managed to break on the new game. The leaning would frequently glitch and it got so bothersome that I avoided using it
*The SJW plot point seems forced and unnatural. This seems to be a trend in plenty of new games. Just so its clear im not against such ideas being popularised in video games, but it feels like an afterthought rather than something natural that fits into the game.
*Extra Uberkomander missions were a nice addition to the game for more gameplay, however they just reused all of the same maps and made it feel like gameplay padding.
*The fog in some of the maps is terrible and makes you not able to see any enemies, whilst they see you clear as day.
*The shadow of BJ running is hilarious.
*The DLC ad that I get every time I launch the game is annoying
*I usually suspend my disbelief for the Wolfenstein games since they are a little out there, but not too far out (in terms of what is possible/impossible and/or liekly/unlikely to happen in the real world), however I got blown right out after a key point in this game and it killed my immersion.
*I ran into a game breaking bug that has been reported by multiple people but was never fixed (during the looking for Wyatt scene if you do an Uberkomander mission, all major NPCs disappear)
*Video RAM constantly "running out"

The good:
*The game is finally no longer capped at 60fps, thank you Machine Games.
*The game looks amazing. For something released  in 2017, this game has no business looking this good.
*The difficulty settings have finally been fixed (which is a complaint I had for both of the older games) and higher difficulties are actually more challenging.
*For better or worse, the game is longer so you get more for your money
*The core gameplay is still the same Wolfenstein, so if you liked the old games you will likely like the new ones too.

Overall, its just another game in the Wolfenstein series. Nothing spectacular, some old issues fixed and some new ones created.
If you liked the old games and can get this one for cheap I'd say its worth a play, but just don't expect much of it. For everyone else I'd say its probably better to leave this one alone...

It's a great game for sure, but gameplay-wise it falls behind The New Order. Technologically speaking, it's a leap forward in terms of the unlocked FPS and graphically it's a beautiful game. The story picks up where the first game left off and it's more or less what you would expect from a sequel such as this.  With all that said, I still think The New Order is a superior game.

The pacing in The New Order was brilliant with some areas welcoming/encouraging stealth while others saw you blasting your way out once shit had canonically hit the fan.  However, The New Colossus did away with this narrative-based pacing in favor of a more generic stealth game feel.  Each mission is separated into a number of big rooms in which you enter silently with the choice to go loud or sneak through.  Many will love this "play your way" style and that's respectable, but personally I liked the mixed-encounters approach better in the first game.  Walking into a room, coming face to face with 10 guards who are looking at you like a deer in the headlights added to the intensity and realism.  On the other hand, this almost "sandbox" approach in the sequel slows the gameplay down too much for my liking.

All in all, it's still a fun game.  It's basically stealth-optional Doom 2016 and that's not necessarily a bad thing - it's just that no one played Doom 2016 and said to themselves "man, I'd love to be sneaking through these maps right now".

The New Colossus is a worthy successor to The New Order. The story continues and the world is really fleshed out for a 10 hour FPS game. The characters are interesting and there are a few very memorable scenes that are enjoyable while others are a bit horrifying. 

The gameplay wasn't the strong point for me, but admittedly as a former console gamer I used a controller. The controller settings felt stiff and aiming felt awkward. Because of this issue I turned down the difficulty and used more stealth and melee when possible. I'm sure mouse and keyboard are fine as no other review I skimmed over mentioned this. Overall it was a blast to go back into the Wolfenstein world and kill a ton of Nazis!

Not quite as good as The New Order or The Old Blood due to weaker level design, but still a brutally entertaining slaughterhouse from start to finish. The story is certainly the darkest it's ever been, even if the comedy can feel forced at times. The game is relatively short but you can go back to districts to assassinate commanders and pick up any collectables you missed.

It's often incredibly difficult as well, if you're playing on Do or Die or higher, enemies will shred your armour and health in seconds. Be that as it may, if you're looking for another action-packed thrill ride with crunchy weapons and ferocious violence, this one will certainly deliver.

The New Colossus is, without a doubt, an amazing game a living proof that single player linear experiences are fun and recommendable. But surely if you have played the past entries on Wolfenstein series that was already expected.

The game an amazing linear adventure and continues where New Order ended, following the amazing and bloody story of BJ Blazkowicz an unstoppable Nazi-killing-machine that is trying to free the world on this dystopian alternative past. 
The game is not-stop-action, more action than ever, more blood than ever, more carnage than ever, killing Nazis never felt so good. But the best of all is, if you wanna take a more slow approach, go stealth you can do it and it can be very rewarding since the melee finishers are bloody and super fun.
Visually the game is pretty good as well, it is very detailed, with great visuals and amazing light shadow effects, even for the 2022 standards it is really good experience, graphically speaking.
But as always the gameplay is the cherry on top of the cake. Yes you have a good story, yes you have good graphics (and even a very nice soundtrack), but if the gameplay was not so fun, fast paced and intuitive the game would not be the amazing game that it is. 

So, and to not extend myself much more, The New Colossus is a really fun game to play.
I get it in a pack with other Wolfenstein's but even at normal price it is fair enough for the game that it is. Fully recommend it!

First playthrough review :

The games picks up exactly where the last one ended (so i would strongly to play the previous one). 

Along the way (around 10-15 hours), you'll meet a colorful cast of characters (some new, some returning).

There are two playthrough min to finish the game and taking to various locations across America.

The short playtime makes it so the pace remains up the God damned roof the whole time.

Upgrading from an old laptop to an RTX3060 12Go GDDR6 vram, 16Go DDR4... I ran it maxed aside from adaptive resolution at 60fps, biggest drop was 58 for two seconds (while that was active).

It looks gorgeous.

Every weapon feels great (there was one i didn't use after a while but it's just down to my preference).

Story is really good (especially for the genre).

My only regret is that i bought the Alt.history bundle and didn't know there are some DLCs.

Edit :
I finished my second playthrough (got the collectibles) and played the post credit content (some of the collectibles were hidden there by the way).
It's good content but hyper repetitive. It feels like a "do that thing again until the sequel".
Tried to beat the Mein Leben difficulty in order to complete the game... 4 tries and no luck. It's really cool to put a permadeath but it's really hard. That takes a lot of skill which i seem to lack. I'm not giving up and will try again from time to time but then again i'm not all that good at fps...
Tough but fair.

In full i'd say it's very good for the genre, not too bad if i consider other genres i play most of the time.

Edit #2 : I finally finished it (forgot to update the then). Mein Leben was really tough especially in some sections. As it's a permadeath mode if you loose you restart... Usually what most games would do is you die, you restart the whole playthrough. Not here though. Die and you'll have to redo a whole playthrough before being able to have another shot at Mein Leben because dying there means save erased. I wasn't a big fan of that - at all.

Wait... i must finish the campain in Mein Leben again to get a shot at finishing the DLCs ? To Start them i must finish the campaing AGAIN ?

Just to get this out of the way: this game looks AMAZING.
I'm not saying The New Order looked bad, but The New Colossus takes it to a whole new level.

On the gameplay side, it mostly plays like The New Order, with a few additions to make it feel fresh.
I really liked the Killboard as a way to revisit previous levels; it felt way better than just replaying the same level like you did in The New Order. It took me a total 37 hrs to 100% the game on I AM DEATH INCARNATE, which didn't feel all that long simply because of said Killboard feature. 100%ing The New Order felt way more tedious, even though it took me 14 hrs LESS to complete.

From a technical POV, The New Colossus is a huge improvement over its predecessor; the switch from OpenGL to Vulkan makes it run as smooth as DOOM 2016 while looking even better. There's also no more physics bugs when playing at 120+ FPS; in The New Order, you couldn't go over 60 FPS without e. g. Nazi drones moving ridiculously fast and water pushing you back so hard you couldn't take a step forward.
I also noticed no stutters while playing with Intel's Alder Lake E-Cores enabled, which I had to disable for The New Order (and also, The Old Blood).

All in all, The New Colossus is a general improvement over The New Order, at least in every way that matters to me - and The New Order already was a great game. So yes, I think you should give it a try!

Of course, the story and characters are definitely not the most realistic or deep, but, for a first-person shooter game, it's good.

The difficulty levels are... VERY unbalanced and there are too many of them. The New Order had five (Can I Play Daddy?, Don't Hurt Me, Bring 'em On, I am Death Incarnate and √úber), this one has seven (Can I play Daddy?, Don't Hurt Me, Bring 'em On, Do or Die!, Call me Terror Billy!, I am Death Incarnate and Mein Leben) and it feels like there shouldn't be so many since Bring 'em On, which is the medium difficulty, already feels like I am Death Incarnate from the previous game; and anything from Do or Die! and above feels like you die from two or three shots. I absolutely do not recommend you play on anything above Bring 'em On unless you're a fan of stealth or have the reflexes of a cat, 'cause you can and will die dozens of times in the same spot from two or three stray shots.

The gameplay itself feels really satisfying to me. I love the weapon selection of this game, even if the upgrades are nothing special, the weapons themselves are very satifying to use.

I have mixed feelings about the story. It's not terrible, but it does feels like they went full "Whatever, just write something to kiss some american ass, write the word 'freedom' a bunch of times and be done with it, you know they'll swallow anything. We still need to finish some other things and this is supposed to launch next week" on a meeting. An effect from that is that some characters' personalities seem a little off, specially Set's who plays a large comic relief role pretty much all the time. On the other hand, Irene's psychopathic personality is awesome and I find the new characters very likeable.

All in all I do think it's pretty good and satisfying gameplay wise and the story is not bad enough for me to not recommend playing it. It's still the nazi-murdering simulator we all know and love.

A lore-building, Nazi-slaughtering, gorgeous first-person shooter full of bells and whistles. This game really looks good, and its improvements over the New Order are mostly incremental and change the game-play to suit different play-styles. I found it a lot easier to play a stealth-based approach with this sequel, but it's just as fun to play a tactical or run-and-gun/tank style. The perks have been revamped, and the weapons upgrades and customization system offer more options than the preceding game (in New Order,  weapon upgrades were linear and tied to the plot, some of them entirely automatic). One change that I didn't welcome so readily is that of the character models for BJ, Set, and Anya-- I supposed they are graphical improvements but they look like entirely difference characters, and BJ in particular looks as though his eyes are a bit too close together (perhaps that's just his near-death gauntness, but the look is carried through the entire game). 

Definitely worth a buy!

I'm not sure what is going on with this franchise but the story in this game was incredibly bad, at times it was so bad i couldn't help but laugh at what was going on on the screen.

Story Issues:

The story is just so bad right away from the very beginning that i had to force myself to keep playing in hopes that it would get better, however it did not and i feel like this was one big gimmick. 

1. I didn't play the previous game but from the preview it seems they left you off with a cliffhanger that you were badly injured. So to start the game off in this state was really jarring, considering i didn't play the previous game. With that the wheelchair was pretty slow and your first introduction to this game is incredibly limited gameplay with a literal handicap applied.

2. The fact that the main character goes back to his home / the farm makes sense but was incredibly stupid on the characters part, as that would be one of the major places the nazis would be watching. Considering he knew how his father was, it should have been very apparent that he would have snitched on him the moment he showed up.

In effect he causes his own capture / death / beheading which was just really dumb.

3. Once you get to the point of the main character being beheaded, the story just gets out there and makes very little sense past this point, making you question if any of it is actually real or just a figment of his imagination as his head is dying lol

Like they just so happened to find a new body for him right after he was beheaded, where was that when he was literally dying in his own body? Would have saved him from being captured at the farm lol

4. The gold "key" that you collect is never actually explained or used in any way whatsoever, even though they show it and talk about it quiet a few times, as if it's supposed to play some important role but never actually does.

5. Your wife, being super prego, makes very little sense for her to constantly be the one on the front lines fighting nazis and jumping from helicopters, at some point her kids would have sustained so much damage from her constant erratic movement, gun blasts and explosions, that they probably would have died lol

6. The whole new orleans recruitment scene when you talk to the group stationed there, was so hectic and nonsensical, for no apparent reason, just made it really hard to keep up with what was going on. Constant gun shots going off, can't even hear what they are saying, both guys screaming at each other nonsensical nonsense that didn't even pertain to the issue at hand and then you allow yourself to get so drunk you pass out? lol in enemy territory? was just really dumb and way too hectic. 

7. The last time you see your wife fight, is when she strips for no apparent reason and then blasts away at nazis fully topless lol which was just like "why?" XD Being pregnant shouldn't it have been you that protected her from the blast, not the other way around? and why did she need to strip? she wasn't on fire or anything... it was just incredibly odd.

8. The final scene in the game was very disappointing, considering your going to kill the person who killed your leader, you'd figure it would be much more dramatic or at least offer some sort of challenge to do, yet you simply walk up to her and axe her once lol done deal. 

It was a huge letdown, considering all that she's put you and everyone you know through, to have her die in such a meaningless way and for it to be so simple / easy. As if she never actually was a big deal in the first place, which kind of makes you wonder why did everything happen if she was such a push over? lol

9. During the final "speech" which wasn't even that motivational or rousing, you / the main character just stand there in the background like a dope, with a blank expression on your face and don't even really react to the "speech" that's going on, in fact you barely move at all or acknowledge anything around you.

At this moment, it should have been the main character making the speech, considering he was the one doing most of the important missions and killing lol and the fact that he was the one who just killed their supreme leader, why is he just standing in the background? Just a perfect moment to really get players pumped completely missed and made the ending way less of an impact than it should have been.

9. After the main story is over, none of the main characters reside on the boat anymore, you are left with nothing but side characters / people you picked up along the way and have zero attachment to any of them. It made the entire after main story experience empty and made me wonder "where are my friends?" lol after all you've been through, they are just gone? 

10. The main characters notable talking point is "i have kids on the way" lol which was laughable, like, dude why did you get her prego during the middle of a war? Then try and hold it as some candle to light your way... as if you weren't the cause of that lol 

As such, thousands, upon thousands of lives were depending on the success of his missions, yet his main concern is "i got kids on the way" XD lol like dude how self centered can a hero be? Was just super cringe.
 
Mechanics Issues: 

1. Collectibles do nothing / accomplish nothing (wasted time)
2. Killing all the leaders from the war map does nothing / accomplishes nothing
3. Completing side quests does nothing / accomplishes nothing 
4. Getting lost easily - I found in certain areas / levels i was not able to find which way to go or i was not able to find paths
that lead out of a building, which made me run around looking for the correct way until i simply gave up and re-loaded or
searched every single nook and cranny (which was a waste of time really)

5. Complete lack of indicators - Certain games like the latest Tomb Raider games do a great job at indicating action points while blending in those indicators to the world, i found that in this game there is nothing of that sort and i easily walked past action points (i.e breakable walls, vents, etc.) without noticing them at all.

6. When talking to someone, if you happen to run past another person or a few people, they just automatically launch into a long discussion and then you can't even hear the person you are actually talking to, doesn't make sense that they wouldn't stop the previous discussions or at least lower their volume while you are interacting with or talking to someone else.

7. Odin Codes - I found that a bunch of times during the war map missions, odin codes do not collect properly and sometimes i'd lose 1-3 odin codes due to them not collecting even though it showed a prompt saying i collected them, this lead to me having do re-do areas / levels just to collect them again, in specific spots that i knew properly worked.

8. SAS mission - doing these seems to do nothing at all or provide you with nothing even if you clear them of clear a bunch of them, on various difficulties. Seems like a total waste of time unless you simply want to replay those missions.

Summary:
In short there were simply way too many issues with the story and out of combat gameplay to make this an enjoyable experience, i kept having to ask myself if this was going to be worth it and unfortunately the answer is, it was not worth the time i spent playing it.

As stated, the combat mechanics are awesome but that's the only reason why i finished the game, which isn't saying much since the story is what is driving the entire experience lol

This game is now nearly 5 years old at the time of this writing but is still ridiculously bug-filled.

I had originally bought this game a few years ago and then refunded it because I could not get past the first level due to the game either freezing or crashing upon trying to exit the level.

With it being on sale recently and it being a few years later, I thought I'd give the game another shot. I was able to finish the first level BUT a different issue has occurred. Upon exiting any level, the game gets stuck on whatever the last thing you were looking at while loading the next level. After a little while, I am able to progress to the next level at the expense of "skipping" the current cutscene that is not actually playing. 

With that said, in order to understand what is going on, I have to go to YouTube to watch the cutscene I had just "skipped".  While highly inconvenient, I could live with it... if it were not for the other issues that have also appeared.

NPCs are often missing their dialogue despite doing all the animations. In at least two levels, I've experienced missing or screwed up textures. Another error, one that I see often mentioned by others, is the memory leak error. And the worst of all, I am now unable to further progress in the game because when trying to exit the start of the Roswell mission, I get an "str_online_connection_error_03" message that sends me back to the main menu.

My computer meets all specifications for this game. My drivers are up to date. I've already verified the game files a few times. Again, this game is nearly 5 years old. This is unacceptable. 

I guess I shouldn't be surprised with it being a Bugthesda title. I've also had issues with a previous Wolfenstein title which I left a similar review for before it was unrightfully removed from Steam for apparently "violating the Steam ToS" when it was just complaining about poor performance.

Anyway, I'd say I'd revise this review once the game is fixed, but with how long its been and with Bugthesda's track record, I'm not expecting anything. If you were able to enjoy this game without any issues, good on you, but clearly I am not the only one who is disappointed with this game due to absurd errors. 

If any of you reading have any useful comments, feel free to leave them. Maybe one of you can help fix what the devs cannot.

There are a lot of shooter out there. Most of them try to be original or trying to innovate. In this case, the sum of everything makes a great experience.

First of all, the history, even though, it tells something that is difficult to be believed, it is like more like a sci-fi history based on actual event. I mean, what would have happened if Nazi would have won the war... Some parts are extremely exaggerated. I mean, even winning the war, they would have been broken to address fund to develop advance technology and even having the resources, some of the technologies showed in this game would have taken several decades to develop instead of few years. Anyway, despite all of these, I think it was a great experience and great story to follow. Acting of each characters were top notch. Seeing Hitler was very interesting. All were well thought through.

Graphics are ok for today standards. Good sound, good effect. In overall, the some of the parts make a great experience and place this game as one of the most rewarding game to be beaten.

This game in normal difficulty is playable. Like previous installment, any part was ridiculously hard to go through. I do not recommend to play it on easy because you will loss most of the fun trying to choose proper weapons and strategy to past on.

TL;DR at the bottom. I got this game on sale, and it's a big part of the reason I had a good time with it. If you just want to shoot the absolute fuck out of some nazis, then this game is perfect. If you're like me and hoping for an improvement on the first game's story, setting, and gameplay, you miiiight be a little disappointed.

Right off the bat, I [b]loved[/b] the first Wolfenstein game in the reboot. The New Order had somewhat compelling characters, a thoughtful narrative, fun gameplay, and a couple of exciting boss fights (although the final boss was impossible on the hardest difficulty). This installment is [i]fine[/i], but it misses a lot of the things that really made the first game great. 

The upgrades feel kinda milquetoast, and save for a few, don't add much to the gameplay loop. I really enjoyed the stealth gameplay in the first, and I felt that this installment did little to build upon it meaningfully. You get an SMG that can be suppressed, and there's an upgrade you can get that allows you to walk silently and squeeze under tight spaces, but they do little to actually service the gameplay itself. 

The story is really where I was hoping to love this game, and I'll try to keep this spoiler free so you can experience the little details for yourself. I personally was really fascinated by the first game's world-building, and the alternate history and its focus on America was tantalizing. I like the small details here and there, such as the KKK's rise to power in the US as allies of the Nazis. But the storyline itself feels pretty rushed and shallow. I was hoping for some more of the gritty, emotional choices that had to be made in the first game, which helped that game's story feel weightier and more personal. The missions you went on followed directly after one another, which meant that they narratively flowed together without many seams to pick at. This game opts for a hub world instead, which is [i]fine[/i], although there are extraordinarily few games in which the hub world actually feels like anything other than busywork or a portal to make the missions make sense. The linearity of the first game's gameplay was not only a fun return to the retro style of the original Wolfenstein 3-D, but also helped the storyline in a way that I failed to appreciate until this game. New Colossus' story feels very scattered and unfocused at times, and while I like the animated, vibrant characters, the rapid introduction of them leaves little room to develop them in a terribly meaningful way. They're not an inch deep, but your feet will still touch the bottom of the pool. 

[b]TL;DR[/b] I had fun with this game, but it didn't feel quite as inspired as the first game. The story suffers from lack of grim, gritty choice, overabundance of characters, and unfocused storyline that webs out from a hub world rather than moving in a straight line. The gameplay loop felt pretty identical to the first game, but is missing the spectacle of the first game's set pieces and boss fights. By the end the story feels like it's sprinting to its conclusion.

Overall: 6.5/10. Fun, but lacks the inspiration of its predecessor.

Loved Wolfenstein New Order. I mostly played for the storyline and the alternative universe theme. Loved the personal relationships in that game and felt completely immersed.

This game however, better graphics, better gameplay. But the storyline wasnt quite there and it impacted my immersion. The news articles and written notes werent as good. Got to new york and I thought yeah this is it excellent map. But then Grace.. Oh god Grace..

It began to dawn on me that storyline wasnt going to be a strong suit in this game..

I quickly got tired of poor character responses and unrealistic arguements between grace and other crew. The main character seemed to become completely helpless and stop asserting any kind of lead role as soon as she appeared, if not before then. Missions on the boat were boring and irritating "go here and get this".

Then it became worse It felt like I was no longer the main character and im forced to witness a this side character who I rescued, take over the entire crew, the submarine and the main storyline without any buildup or reason as to why my character is listening to her. She literally walked into the sub and took the captains cabin without any complaints from anyone. Given that the last captain had died not a few days earlier, you'd think they would tell her to do one, but no. What made it yet worse was how obnoxious she was, anything but a leader completely unlikeable, the former captain wasnt amazing but atleast she had the character and personal struggles to back it up.

The main character going from a patriotic soldier of the good ole USA, to an a an apathetic dogs body who wont even step up for his friends, completely ruined the story for me. Watching Grace bully the scotsman whilst he stood aside doing nothing, then watching the scotsman completely forgive her for her bullish behaviour was wierd. Sadly for me as im not massively into FPS action games, this killed the immersion, and ultimately the game..

Before anyone makes it about Race, you can p**** off. Its nothing to do with that its plain bad writing.. Were there some back story, some build up before grace takes over, some give and take in her arguements, and maybe some missions where you work with her. I might have built up a mutual respect and acceptance for her edgy attitude and understanding why she takes over. but the character behaves like an absolute cow.

As I say, I didnt play this for the FPS action, I played it for the story, everything else, ill be honest was great.. but as soon as I realised this character was in it for the long haul, i uninstalled.

Wolfenstein II keeps the tight gunplay and immersive environments from earlier installments. It interweaves a bombastic narrative style with the necessary amount of grace and tact for the intense subject matter. I‚Äôd recommend it to anybody who enjoys FPS games or alternate history.

Nazism is disgusting and makes monsters out of human beings. Animal abusers and narcissists, addicted to power and hatred, petty, jealous, aggressive, cruel. A bigotry so powerful it overrules rationality. It is the irredeemable ideology, one of humanity‚Äôs greatest shames, and so insidious that strains of it survive into the modern era despite the catastrophic cost of such ideals.

As a result, Nazis make fantastic video game enemies for anyone with the slightest moral compass. Killing them is uniquely satisfying. Nothing of value is lost when you kill a Nazi. Even the most pacifist gamer is going to want to pull the trigger. 

Wolfenstein II understands this, and presents you with an exceptionally rich and disquieting cast of ‚Äòubermensch‚Äô to eviscerate. Mothers who torture their children, husbands who beat their wives, murderous stormtroopers and eugenicist scientists - even the KKK make an appearance at the end of your gun.

Wolfenstein clothes them in success and finery that seem like a skinhead‚Äôs wildest fantasy  - a Supreme Nazi Court gilded with gold, a base on Venus, mechanized military and a stranglehold on the planet. But all of this does them no good. All it does is place these horrible people on a gilded throne that they never earned - and then it lets you tear them from it.

The standout moment of repugnancy (and there are a lot) has to be a withered Hitler, ranting and spitting with hatred as he fails at urinating in a bucket, humored by people who hate and fear him. The scene is a devastatingly effective critique. It sums up the real Nazi endgame most elegantly; total power, no control.

Wolfenstein remembers that Nazis live base, hate-filled lives. Their dreams amount to nothing but greed and petty tyrannies, all change negotiated from the barrel of a gun, all relationships irredeemably ruined by power and irresponsibility. This isn‚Äôt a story about Nazis ruling the world - it‚Äôs a story of them ruining it, and that can‚Äôt help but remind you that they ruined our world, too.

Heartily recommended.

This is game is like The Last of Us Part 2 when it comes to it's presentation.

(Comparing to TLOU2)
*Both games overhauled their predecessors' overall gameplay mechanics into a much better experience. Probably the selling point for me to recommend because of the gameplay and the shooting mechanics. Get it just for Nazi killing.
*Both games had a step-up transition from their respective game engine to an improved one. Enhanced graphics and details tailored for next-gen consoles.
*Both games had a slight to heavy redesign of known characters in their own respective franchise.
*Both games had a great improvements to it's audio and sound design. Can't say which are those specifically.
*Both games had great soundtracks.
*Both games introduced permadeath feature.
*Both games had a step-down to it's storytelling. Inconsistencies to it's tone, it's pacing, and the poorly written new characters that makes you want to gouge your eyeball and shoot them with a fully-upgraded shotgun.
*Both games had unnecessary story expeditions. Leading to some poor pacing issues and lengthy cutscenes.
*Both games had injections of forced politics and wokeness in it (aside from Wolfenstein's Nazi ideology and the imagery because that's pretty obvious)

Sunk a good few hours into this trying to crack a Mein Leben run. No joy. The games good though, really good, and the gun play and action are on point for a Wolfenstien game.

The story's not great though, and there's a lot of cinematics and cut scenes used to tell it. There are some great moments in the story, don't get me wrong, but overall it's just messy, and I get a sense that they just flung stuff at a wall to see what would stick. 

The gun play is awesome though, and there's a good balance between needing to be stealthy and go for the silent kills, and then letting loose, guns blazing and tearing the place up. - The latter is my favourite way to play it.

Just 2 things to mention if you're picking this up now, I kept getting a crash dump error which forced a restart a few times, and I kept a graphics "dedicated memory" error despite having a 3090 and not going too extreme on the graphics. Both seem to be common issues, and while annoying, were not really game breakers.

Overall, if you're looking for a Wolfenstien fix and need a break from the New World Order, then give this a spin.
