Remember in the old days when the reward for sitting through a tedious mediocre cutscene was the next cool level of play? W2 flips this formula on its head by making the reward for completing tedious mediocre levels some excellent cutscenes.

I was quite hesitant to play this game given that the previous game in the series ended on such a perfect, melancholy note (quite exceptional in games of this ilk), but I have to say I was pleased with where they took the story from there.  But while I loved the movie/story side of this sequel, it was rare that I found myself truly enjoying the actual gameplay.  And, sadly, even when I did my enjoyment was marred by a host of small annoyances in design.

There‚Äôs also a host of what is almost shovelware piled on top of what would otherwise be an adequate game.  It seems as though the final product was presented to some Suits who demanded that the game length be doubled ‚Äì so the devs just piled on assassination missions where you go back to the same level maps you‚Äôve already completed, and a bunch of pointless collectibles (some of which you can get only on the replay missions).

I recommend this mostly for the story, which is outstandingly written, acted, and shot. The levels themselves are ok, as long as you can resist the urge to find every hidden collectible.  I completed the main game and played a few of the replay missions, but got bored and decided that was enough.

THE GOOD:
‚Ä¢	Story/cutscenes
‚Ä¢	Environment/concept
‚Ä¢	Decent selection of weapons and useful upgrades

THE BAD:
‚Ä¢	No quick save.
‚Ä¢	No walk (probably the usual lazy console port issue, assuming PC players will use controllers rather than the more precise keyboard & mouse). This also caused problems selecting codes on the Enigma machine, as the arrow keys repeatedly overshot entries.
‚Ä¢	Can‚Äôt remap some keys (most notably escaping from map/inventory screens)
‚Ä¢	The weird ability to overcharge health, resulting in a cacophony of useless glowing health packs begging you to click them even though you‚Äôre already at 100%.
‚Ä¢	When trying to smash crates, your axe throws if you are not right smack up against the box.
‚Ä¢	Speaking of axes, sometimes they disappear after a thrown enemy kill.  At other times it‚Äôs a pixel hunt to recover them.
‚Ä¢	Combat sounds, such as gunfire, are weak compared to explosions and voiceovers.
‚Ä¢	There are a couple points where you can make a choice, but it doesn‚Äôt make that much of a difference.  For instance, you can choose one of three gadgets, but every time there‚Äôs a place to use one gadget, you can clearly see how you‚Äôd proceed from this exact same point using the other two.
‚Ä¢	Pointless collectibles that have no in-game effect.  
‚Ä¢	Collecting enigma codes from commanders is supposed to reveal collectibles on the map, but this worked inconsistently.
‚Ä¢	Dropped items like armour and ammo can be very tricky to pick up. Sometimes running over them collects them, but sometimes you have to specifically click on them.
‚Ä¢	The mechanic to enter small spaces with a gadget is very picky, often resulting in your staring at the wall just above the space you wanted to crawl into.
‚Ä¢	The hint function was almost useless. (Not at all the helpful sort of nav guide in games like Dead Space.)
‚Ä¢	Can‚Äôt change the level when looking at the map ‚Äì you actually have to go to another level to see that part of the map.

THE UGLY:
‚Ä¢	Many poorly explained concepts/mechanics ‚Äì most notably the Enigma decoder, which is both timed and can use up resources if you fail.  Oh and it doesn't autosave before you use it the first time.
‚Ä¢	Arena fights (the laziest form of level design).  Luckily only a handful of these.
‚Ä¢	A couple points where it‚Äôs not clear at all how you are meant to proceed.
‚Ä¢	The terrible cover of ‚ÄòWe‚Äôre Not Gonna Take It‚Äô during the end credits. At least now I know what happens if you remove all traces of melody from a song and turn the volume up to 11.

P.S. I still have no idea what the significance of the Star Card collectibles was supposed to be.

Definitely not for kids, a more "mature" ish... game. Not straight up nudity or violence (though there is both), but more so in the idea of torture, physcological issues, drugs, racism, and other more serious issues being taken (semi) seriously. Also yes, it does get gruesome, and not just blood splattery gruesome, sometimes a fair bit more graphic and well rendered.
Overall it's a refreshing change of pace from most stories or stuff that can't get too far into nitty gritty or realistic issues or social problems for fear of not being able to sell enough copies or alienating some players. Most that do this stuff barely touch surface level and keep it simple, here, they'll go down into the nasty bits and details, though often each area is still covered more quickly do to the limited length of the game. But for the length it is solid more often than not.

Now, gameplay, pretty good, decent action, though also has some issues and areas that get frusterating they could have polished or tweaked. Some inconsistencies like firing the heavy beam gun hits targets right on the crosshair, even if to get to them the beam travels through the edge of a wall or crate from the gun. On the other hand your tossed axes and grenades seem to originate someplace far off to the right side of your character, even further right than the hand the visibly throws them, so those seem to love getting stuck on cover or obstacles next to you in tight areas even when visually it seems they shouldn't have. The part the game is inconsistent between weapons and mechanics with things like this mean you keep randomly having problems and annoying moments that keep you from reliably falling into a gameplay groove where everything flows... since some always break the rules of others. It's not too bad... but still something often enough that hurts the gameplay experience. When it is working, combat can be pretty good, though there are also general issues like visibility. They like extreme lighting, but night time or evening with bright sun and shadows in buildings on the streets of an old city... where you can easily see in reality thanks to a nice high danmic range of lighting our eyes provide this game does not. Areas not the brightest are frankly... just dark, so dark the one thing I wanted the most in this whole game as a bloody flashlight since my characters eyes are just terrible. Even if you stare at the enemy in the shadow of a building in the evening, the games camera doesn't exposure adjust so you can see there, it's constant, you just can't see guys beyond general outlines or moving shapes far too often. On the other hand, most levels to look great and the lighting is very atmospheric... if you take a screenshot or aren't trying to actually see into the shadows or such while fighting. But you are so ya it's an issue.

So overall, a pretty good game, one I'll recommend to many (not everyone), but also one that's definitely not perfect. Still, better than the last Wolfenstein game and that one was fairly good already. You'll probably know yourself if you'll want it or not already, but overall I'll still recommend it. Gameplay while not perfect was overall fun and enjoyable more often than not (just make sure to use F5 for quick saves often), and the story was pretty decent and refreshing in how it's told and doesn't hold back or shy away from parts most games or media would. And while being somewhat serious, it also never stops being over the top so don't worry, you're not going to get depressed or overly downered feeling playing it, there's always enough guns and explosions and cursing to keep you from having to think too hard if you don't want to about the stuff, and to keep most of it feeling more... heroic? Actiony? Eh, the pacing and mood keeps you in a good most of the time feeling. Yes you can argue about freedome, slavery, and stuff with characters but while throwing a back and forth fight of punches, alchahol, or bullets, there's some action or dynamic fighting going on with strong music and a nicely set up pacing, not just sitting and talking 90% of the time. And many of the characters you have issues with, get what's coming to them eventually, gotta love the characters (or hate them) as they are all very well done here. VERY WELL DONE.

Still a solid game, though I prefer The New Order more I think. Looking forward to Wolfenstein 3.

Were is Wolfenstein?

It's fun, it's punchy, it's very cinematic. Lots of great moments, and a pretty smooth blend of cutscenes and gameplay that feels (mostly) natural. Overall, if you like action/adventure shooters, this is a good time. 

The main campaign was fleshed out and pretty long, and at the end I was just wanting more. Played through the first time on "Bring It On" difficulty, and I think it was fairly well-tuned to be challenging without being annoying. Got kind of stuck a few times, but felt driven to keep trying. Having finished it and gotten more familiar with the mechanics, weapons, etc. I think I'm going to try playing on a harder difficulty. 

One thing I strongly recommend is to start doing the Ubercommander side missions as soon as you get access to the enigma decoder, and prioritize them over the main plot progression. These side quests will feel more natural if you do them as you go, and you will get more experience, perks, etc. to help you through the final stages of the campaign. They account for a lot of the actual play time you can sink into the game, and it's going to feel more fun and rewarding if you're doing it along side the main story.

The alternative is - like me - you save up the maximum stack of enigma codes so you start wasting officer kills not being able to pick up more, you finish the main story, then you have a whole bunch of side content that doesn't feel like it's happening in the correct context. You go out and do these side quests (which are fun enough, but fairly basic) - but it never actually amounts to anything. It feels like maybe there is going to be a payoff at the end, but you just unlock things that you won't actually use in the campaign. To make it worse, after you complete the story, the vast majority of the main characters just vanish from Eva's Hammer for no apparent reason, leaving it feeling kind of weird and lifeless. Don't set yourself up for this endgame limbo like I did.

I am a 51 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

The gameplay is actually good, but the whole story behind this sequel has deep roots in bad writing, which leads to cringe moments.

We get in Blazko, your life fucking sucks: You're a crippled fuck for half the game with nearly suicidal instints, but you still go on for your love, but there's no real need to burdening people with your depression.
This continues until [spoiler]He gets captured and executed. His heads falls down but PlotArmor stuff kicks in and he gets emergency transplanted into a vacant supersoldat body. Remember Mars Attacks? that's the same fucked up stuff.[/spoiler]

Anyway, even the Nazi go full cringe here. They were brutal and such but there's no need to force the player to watch a mother-daughter body shaming moment (haha she's fat!).
Or even [spoiler]The fucking Hitler, now a full crazy old fart, that pukes around and takes a leak in fucking champagne bucket. CRINGE.[/spoiler]

One last thing, on the cringe. Max Hass.
They got the genius idea (no) to give further depth to a character that is borderline worthless. By following the general writing, they could've written a moment where Max Hass has to play a quiz game, and choose between some real answers.
Well, he then would the say his line ("Max Hass") and would instatly win the big prize.

Thank fucking god they didn't do that.
Ewww, do gamers really love this stuff now??? Seriously???

Games today have gotten way too "fancy" as game devs try to find some new formula or idea that will make them famous. I'm looking at Hideo here!

I love this for the fun ride. This game makes me angry at the antagonists. They piss me off so I want to fight back and kill them.

There are no difficult secrets to figure out. There are no "gotchas" that will ruin the game if you don't know about them. It is just good clean nazi-killing fun!  Throw in a little steam-punk-esque  body armor and leg and arm transplants here and there and you have the formula for a fun romp through an alternative reality where Hitler got the Atomic bomb first and used it on us and we folded like a guy playing poker with a pair of nothing and leave it to Mad Max to save the day from these evil, twisted 1/2 dimensional cardboard cutouts who are all sociopathic psychopaths who are a little crazy to boot, and you have a comfortable formula for a fun game where you spend hours upon hours of your time running around killing dirty nasty nazis who deserve to die without question.

Also, Blastoffovich is just like before, same voice, same overly dramatic "Caroline can you lend me your wings since your head has been cut off and you can't see to fly anywhere anyway, I'll see you soon cause I know I'm dying (somehow) and I'm ready (sort of) but that's cool because my gf is preggers with twins and while I'm sure that I can handle this Nazi-nonsense, I don't think that I can handle twins!!!

Not gonna lie, I love this series. 

REAL WORLD COMPLAINTS.  Ammo is both too available and too difficult to find. Seems like you have TONS of it when you don't need it and not enough when you do.  And since enemies are bullet sponges, it takes a lot of ammo to kill them. I wish the game awarded marksmanship more with headshots being instakills (often they are, but sometimes I don't think so) and maybe I will get a subsonic silencer to allow me to be a more gun oriented professional sniper/stealth killer.

STILL, I highly recommend this whole series.

ONE FINAL PROBLEM, the video programming in this game is plagued with bugs, but they haven't been deal breaking of game busting. Just mildly annoying. The game itself runs ROCK SOLID AT ULTRA SETTINGS and 144 FPS on my several years-old Alienware, M17 R2 laptop with some nice specs. It has a 2070-MaxQ video card and i9 intel processor with 16Gb of ram.  The game looks and runs beautifully, so Iwould get this even if you are worried about graphics. My experience has been that the graphics actually work well, even when they say they aren't going to...

RECOMMEND HIGHLY if you are looking for a fun FPS with no real thought depth and just want to kill NAZIS.

A really REALLY FUN game! I beat it on the second Highest Difficulty - I am Death Incarnate. It's brutal but it was absolutely mayhem and badassery. Overall I found the narrative and serious tone of The New Order better, but that doesn't mean the story is The New Colossus is bad. I found it to be really fun. 
Overall the gameplay is absolutely amazing, batshit insane and BJ Blaskowicz stays to be a true badass to his very core, but also a deeply emotional person caring for his friends and his loved one. I do miss his extensive monologues from the first game though. 
Highly recommend playing through this one and do share with me how your experience was with the game. Now we wait for the Third Wolfenstein to come out where we can wreak havoc as Blasko again.

YAY FOR THIS STUFF:

- The story is fantastic. There is excellent character development here, and not just with Blazkowicz. Some of the scenes really impact the player at a deep psychological level. The developers actually make you care about the characters.

- Awesome graphics that still hold up by today's standards. Even facial animations are lifelike.

- The weapons are nice, and there's now an upgrading system so you can add cool gizmos to your collection of bang-bangs. 

BOO ON THIS STUFF:

- The mapping system REALLY stinks. Many of the levels are multi-level and the map doesn't show you where the objective is until you're actually pretty close to it. I found myself backtracking a lot and wandering around aimlessly simply because I missed some small detail in a room, like a covered hatch, for example.  There is a "hint button", but it unfortunately shows points of interest possibly along with your objective, so it's fairly worthless.

-  During some of the levels, Blazkowicz keeps whispering to himself about his relationships with several characters (his mom, his dad, Anya, Caroline, etc. etc.), and that gets old REALLY quick. Shut up, you hammerhead!

- The heavy laser is sweet, but it has a very annoying metallic buzzing sound to it. This also gets old REAL fast.

- Way too many developer logos before the menu boots up.

I am still recommending it; it's well worth the money.

It's not such a good 1st person shooter as you'd hope. The levels are fairly complex in their layout but often you won't know where to go and you have to seek your path out too often. Including in home-base where it's just tedious to walk around until you find 'that room' or 'that exit'.
In normal levels it's just so odd that you can't climb up a perfectly low ledge where other ledges are fine because they've been designated for this. 1st person shooters have been around for so long it's like the designers aren't playing their own game with open eyes to see what's weird about it. (edit: there's more game play oddities but the killer issue is below)

The worst thing, though, is the notorious crash/error "str-online-connection-error-03" and the follow-up 'Could not write Crash dump". In my case it happened for all my saves in the Roswell level and I could not fix the issue. It's been around for years but no suitable fix can be found. Safe Mode, Verify integrity of game, delete config, reinstall drivers etc etc etc.Its a game breaker. Nothing works and that's the end of my time with this piece of sh*t game. So many people have been let down by this issue. Thanks for nothing Zenimax, Bethesda and Machine Games. I can load old saves again but I know the same thing will happen again later on. 

Edit: Spent 2 weeks with Bethesda support on this but it was a waste of time because they just give you suggestions like reinstall or 'change that gfx setting in the config file' which couldn't possibly have an effect on the issue described.

Do not waste your time with this because there is a high chance you will lose all progress. I symbolically asked for a refund, although i am not eligible for it.

Edit:
Pros - not that many :(
The voice acting can be excellent and the characters and story really funny, but the game does let them down by completely mistiming NPS responses to each other

I thoroughly enjoyed the story. It was easily the best part of the game. I was invested enough to really despise some of the antagonists in the game. Characters are borderline caricatures sometimes but I think it adds to the games flavor. It's both serious and ridiculous. I enjoyed pretty much all of the cut scenes.

Weapon variation was acceptable. There are light upgrade mechanics that also keep the weapons fresh. I found taking out Nazis to be quite satisfying. Unfortunately, you can be forced into a situation where you don't even get to use the most OP weapon in the game. Also for anyone else who doesn't know, there are also movement/navigation upgrades half-way through the game. Ex: Leg extensions that give you height, the ability to plow through walls, and fit into smaller crawlspaces.

The DLC is 100% a waste. I didn't buy it and I'm only referring to reviews that anyone can read. That's how bad it is.

Overall I give it an 8/10. I'll gladly answer any questions anyone has.

Finished 4 of the tiny and short "missions" in 1.5 hours, and as stated in my refund request:
This game is so boring that even running and gunning while blasting Rammstein couldn't save it.
Buy Nightmare Reaper instead.
Wolfenstein... what more is there to say.
It's fun. What's better than killing Nazi? Not much.

Do we really need three missions in a row which start with a "heist-planning montage" cutscene?
The "stealth the radio officers" sequences aren't fun because of cock-up-cascade.  They aren't a great fit for Wolfenstein.  If you want to be Dishonored, be Dishonored all the way.
The worldbuilding and character design are still excellent, but I kinda feel like they should just be a movie.
B.J. has way too much voice-over monologue about his internal thoughts in a "tell don't show" way.
I hate the gun design.  Like Antoine de St. Expury said, a design is good not when there's nothing to add, but when there's nothing to remove.  Stop bolting pipework onto the barrel.
The submarine is WAY too big and mazelike.  Submarines are super fucking cramped.  There should not be a bottomless pit in the middle of a submarine, even if it is the "world's biggest".  It should feel like a being stuck in a phone booth or a classic Mini Minor with three wrestlers.  The downtime between missions felt like a tedious easter-egg-hunt rather than an actual relaxing way to get some character development (though that happened, at least).  Metro 3's train was much better at this, because the map was just a straight line.
Why the hell are we liberating America anyway?  Fuck America.  I'm sure there must be more useful places to liberate from the Nazis.  Kazakhstan, for example, has a shitload of uranium, and is ripe for Seven Pillars of Wisdom-style guerilla raids.  Where is China and Japan in this world anyway?  If you're going to copy The Man in the High Castle, at least *mention* what happened to the rest of the world.  It's not just "America" and then a giant blank until you hit the Rhine.
PS: BJ's dad was way too one-dimensional.  We get it, Americans are anti-semitic racist dickheads, too.  We all know about Tuskegee!  Stop pretending systemic racism in USA is due to a couple of moustache-twirling Captain Planet baddies from the Deep South.

Killing Nazis has never been so tedious or so unsatisfying. It's actually shocking how bad this game is, considering how much I liked the previous ones. 

The guns feel bad. The firefights are just enemies flooding toward you until you kill them all. There's no AI to speak of. Trying to actually run and gun through areas just gets you killed - better to sit in a hallway and let all the enemies file one-by-one to their death. The levels are short, and never build towards an exciting climax. The level design is often confusing. There's a couple super harsh spikes in difficulty that come out of nowhere. It's incredibly annoying having to spam "E" everywhere to pick up health and armor, and the hitbox for actually grabbing the items sometimes seems bizarrely small.  The game mimics real difficulty by constantly just spawning enemies in behind you out of nowhere. I literally watched enemies appear out of thin air many times. 

I eventually got so bored I dropped the difficulty all the way down to the easiest setting just so I could sprint through and finish the game as fast as possible. 

The only thing I loved about this game was the characters. I see a lot of people complaining they're too wacky or too over the top, but I liked that. The writing for their dialogue is all solid, the lip synch is pretty good. I wish these characters were in a better game. Also the visuals were pretty nice.

I don't give many games an unambiguous thumbs down, usually there's some caveat. But in this case, I can confidently recommend skipping this game entirely.

Do not give Bethesda money for a problematic product like this. I bought it full price when it was released because I'm a fan of the series. In my old pc (i5-6600k, GTX970, 32GB ram) it used to crash every five minutes rendering it unplayable. I thought maybe my GPU memory is too low and that's what causes the problem. When I got my new pc (3080, 16GB ram, Ryzen 7 5800H) the first thing I did was trying to launch it. I got the 'Could not write crash dump' error and I've tried all the fixes I found online with no success. This was my experience with this game and I'm all out of ideas on how to make it work.

I saw a review calling this game 'Woke', I guess some people arnt comfortable with the idea that Nazis and the KKK should rightfully be labeled 'The bad guys'.
I also saw a review criticizing the game as too short with no boss battles like the old blood and the new order. Those two games had awful boss fights...Good games, bad boss fights. That shouldn't be a criticism. This game is also just as long if not longer than the new order (I'm on my second play-through of the entire rebooted series so the lengths are pretty fresh in my head).
I honestly think this game is drastically better than the new order and slightly better than the old blood. The new order had a great story but the gameplay way incredibly punishing...almost to an unfair degree. They would throw enemies at you in constant waves and it just would make several sections no fun (the bridge being one major example). It would prevent stealth from working effectively too. The old blood improved on that and this game improved on it even further.
Stealth actually works. Weapon upgrades actually feel like they are effective. The new engine improves the look, movement, and the shooting. All around this is the best of the main line wolfenstein games.

A buggy mess of a console port.

-Frequent crashes
-Invisible walls in door ways blocking progress
-Running out of video memory on cards with 8-12 GB or more
-Horrible UI, especially the menu
-Low res textures blurred out with excessive post-processing
-Short story filled in with repetitive and boring "open world" side missions
-No HDR in PC release. Windows auto-HDR causes the game to crash.
-DLC comes with buggy hitboxes where your hits won't register until you reload the game.

Get it when its dirt cheap. Otherwise you're not missing much.

I just love when a sequel to an already great game is even better and improves on everything the first game had! Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus improves gameplay, guns, characters, presentation and story!

Let's talk gameplay first: this game's guns are infinitely better than the previous game's guns. They have better handling, clear purpose (strengths and weaknesses), and look better. Each weapon of your arsenal will be useful in one situation or another, and suits each playstyle (stealth or run-and-gun). The enemy variety is also there, with clearer markings of what each enemy is and does. Without too many spoilers, later on you get a choice of, let's say, contraption, that lets you lean further into your preferred playstyle.

Another section where the game truly shines is its story and presentation. The characters you already know get more fleshed out, as well as new characters that are introduced; they all have their humor and their personality, which makes them feel real. BJ is still the good ol' badass we love, and he gets a more fleshed out backstory, which I enjoyed. There are various points of the story where BJ will feel differently, or he's in a different headspace then before and he talks about it. Every bit of monologue and dialogue is enjoyable and I commend the voice-actors for doing an amazing job!
The atmosphere is top-notch! Same with the first game, Nazis have occupied the world and you get to see different parts of the world, but mostly America, as this game it about liberating the USA.
There are many twists and turns in the game, elevated that much more by the AMAZING cutscenes that are longer this time, as well as well-shot and well-paced!

There are numerous collectibles to find should you so desire, as well as news articles etc. which flesh out the world. You get a feeling of how much Hitler was actually idolized by the Nazis - reminded me of The Emperor from the Warhammer 40k universe.

On the technical side, the game's graphics are simply amazing! Never underestimate how much good lighting helps graphically, and you will see this both as you're peacefully exploring the levels as well as frantically shooting your guns. If you're in a darker corridor or room, the muzzle flash from the guns simply lights up the area you're in, and it looks amazing, not to mention the explosions and the particle effects.

You may encounter an error saying your video card is out of memory after some time of playing, but this is a bug that has been left in the game, so don't worry!

All in all, I recommend this game to everyone, especially if you love shooters like Doom and have played and enjoyed Wolfenstein: The New Order!

Vintage chocolate chip cookies

Ingredients
150g salted butter, softened
80g light brown muscovado sugar
80g granulated sugar
2 tsp vanilla extract
1 large egg
225g plain flour
¬Ω tsp bicarbonate of soda
¬º tsp salt
200g plain chocolate chips or chunks
Method
STEP 1
Heat the oven to 190C/fan170C/gas 5 and line two baking sheets with non-stick baking paper.

STEP 2
Put 150g softened salted butter, 80g light brown muscovado sugar and 80g granulated sugar into a bowl and beat until creamy.

STEP 3
Beat in 2 tsp vanilla extract and 1 large egg.

STEP 4
Sift 225g plain flour, ¬Ω tsp bicarbonate of soda and ¬º tsp salt into the bowl and mix it in with a wooden spoon.

STEP 5
Add 200g plain chocolate chips or chunks and stir well.

STEP 6
Use a teaspoon to make small scoops of the mixture, spacing them well apart on the baking trays. This mixture should make about 30 cookies.

STEP 7
Bake for 8‚Äì10 mins until they are light brown on the edges and still slightly soft in the centre if you press them.

STEP 8
Leave on the tray for a couple of mins to set and then lift onto a cooling rack.

RECIPE TIPS
FREEZING THE BISCUITS
If you‚Äôve frozen the biscuits, take them out and arrange them on a lined baking sheet. Once defrosted, pop them in a medium oven 190C/170 fan/gas mark 5 and heat for 2-3 mins to crisp up. Don‚Äôt leave them too long or they‚Äôll dry out.
STORING DOUGH
You can keep the uncooked dough in a sealed container in the fridge for up to two weeks. Simply take some out, dollop on a lined baking tray and allow to come up to room temperature for 5 mins before baking

Overall I enjoyed this game. The gunplay was good, the environments were interesting, all the music and sound design was fantastic. The characters were a high point. The plot was serviceable. In my opinion the new order was better, but this game was a good continuation.

My biggest annoyance with this game was that they redid every characters model in this game, so pretty much every returning character falls into the uncanny valley where you don't quite recognize them (this includes BJ, although his model is nearly the same so it's not as much of a distraction). Anya and Private Wyatt have completely different models. Unlike the other characters where they still look like themselves pretty much, Anya and Wyatt are literally just different people. If they hadn't told me who they were I might not have recognized them.

The fights were pretty annoying at times, where there's a room full of baddies and commanders so you're clearly supposed to stealth it, but there's so many people that you keep getting spotted. At times i beat rooms not because of my skill but because of memory because I had died so many times. Unlike TNO, there are 0 bossfights in this game. Some of the most fun times I had in the previous game was [spoiler]The London Monitor and Deathshead[/spoiler]. There's none of that in this game.

Buy this game on sale. Overall its a fun time, but don't expect TNO.

Decent shooter filled with terrible hamfisted writing and flawed pacing.

Pros: 
-Passable gunplay.
-Occasionally funny scenes.

Cons:
-Nazis are bad, if you haven't caught on to the whole premise of the series by now, yet the writers seem to want to shove this down your throat at every single possible opportunity. Its like the writers never went through 2nd year high school English and completely fail to grasp the concept of 'show not tell.' 
-Overblown but underdeveloped characters. The main characters you interact with are all cardboard cutouts of political /cultural /racial stereotypes and never seem to have any further character development beyond your initial meeting. After certain cut scenes I feel like I understand why the Nazis would want to conquer and kill everyone (not say I agree, just that I understand).
-BJ doesn't feel relatable anymore. He spent close to half the game moping about his impending demise I almost stopped playing 3 times. All that was missing was him cutting himself on the wrist while Linkin Park blares in the background. Give me back the grim but sympathetic soldier who has witty one liners. I get that the writers were trying to show more of BJ's thoughts and develop his backstory, but the more he speaks, the less I am able to self insert.
-Graphics feel like a downgrade, also it will remind you that your video memory is full until you mute it.
-Stealth isn't always possible, sometimes the commanders are located in odd positions, sometimes the enemies seem to be prescient.
-AI is dumber than two sacks of bricks. Once your location is know, all the enemies will attempt to swarm you. It took me one fight to figure out that you can pop one soldier, retreat down a long corridor, and pick off the enemies as they come to you.
-Upgrade system for perks is a chore. You can easily max out 2/3 of all perks before you leave the airship.
-Contraptions are neat, but I feel like they come too little too late into the game and realistically won't affect your gameplay loop unless you are a completionist.
-Upgrade system for guns is.... passable. Upgrade the silencer for pistol, armor piercing and scope for the assault rifle, charge up and ammo capacity for laserkraftwerk and you've basically won the game.

Final Thoughts:
Wait for a sale if you really really REALLY want this game. If you don't want to end up disappointed, just pretend Anya and Caroline rescued BJ at the end of New Order and they all lived happily ever after.

Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus is an action adventure FPS, released in 2017 and was the third instalment in the recently rebooted Wolfenstein trilogy. It was developed by Machine Games and published by Bethesda Softworks. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2825023598
Wolfenstein II features incredibly entertaining combat and great villains that were carried through the previous games, afterall, who doesn‚Äôt want to kill Nazis? The gameplay was incredibly smooth, featured more weapons and new mechanics. 
The game was very optimised and can easily run on medium end computers. The new weapons were certainly a refresh from the previous games and being able to dual-wield any two weapons was a great addition. 
The quick fast paced action made the game incredibly entertaining and I never felt bored when I was playing, the story was always there and while it did help the experience it was certainly being carried by the gameplay. Additionally, the campaign was quite short (around 10 hours) however I do not believe there is a content problem as there is much to do after completion with 80 achievements, DLC and combat simulations. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2825443563
The Wolfenstein games are all very well made and I can recommend all of them to almost anyone, however this was certainly the weakest of them all. This is mainly due to the lacking story despite the fact it isn‚Äôt the focus of the Wolfenstein games, it was certainly very entertaining in TNO and set the standard. 
Additionally, Wolfenstein II featured extra content through the Freedom Chronicles DLC which is an entirely different mess of weak, nonsense and extremely expensive for the little extra content it provides. The price I would put on this expansion is around $10  (AUD) and honestly wouldn‚Äôt pay a cent more as there was probably close to 4 ish hours of content. They also featured 'static pictures' as the cut scenes which definitely made the whole experience more 'underwhelming' in general. Like the other wolfenstein games there were a lot of easter eggs and collectables which to me are always fun.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2834161774
In the end I would say Wolfenstien is definitely worth the price and anyone who is on the fence should stop sleeping on the decision. If you don‚Äôt know, the Wolfenstein games are credited with being the first FPS and the games have been running consistently for around 30 years making it one of the longest running franchises. I firmly believe anyone can pick up the Wolfenstein games and very easily enjoy them. As a franchise (Wolfenstein: The Old Blood, Wolfenstein: The New Order and Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus.) 9/10. Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus 7/10.

This game is one of the best shooting game in my life. The plot is straightforward but full of contents, secrets, and connections for each character. I adore how this game's major story twist occurred while the story was still proceeded. Almost every character in this game has a unique background and a significant connection to the main character, I strongly suggest you guys to complete Wolfenstein: The New Order before playing this game. The game was well designed, making it the greatest shooting game, and playing with the AI in this game is a lot of fun.

The enjoyment of this game could be impacted by its difficulty. I finished the game on the toughest difficulty, so there was no longer "run-and-gun". Moreover, in this difficulty, you can hardly clear all of your enemies by only standing behind the wall in the same place since the AI will keep approaching toward you. You must use extreme caution because with only two or three shots might return you to the Lord.

The gunplay is still awesome, courtesy of ID tech. But goddamn, what happened in character writing between this and The New Order? Grace Walker is without a doubt the most unlikeable character ever written and absolutely unbearable to the point where she almost made me stop playing. Most of the new characters are annoying at best, the only exception is Sigrun Engel, who is actually pretty well written and sympathetic.

So, all in all, the great gunplay saves this game, - but in all other aspects, especially characters, The New Order was far superior.

Shallow. Painfully cringe-worthy shallow. 
I forced myself to watch the cutscenes, I really like Horton, and the scene when Sigrun slaps the shit out of Grace is good. Auditioning to play yourself on venus was excellent. The other 99% of cutscene in the game made me dry heave it was so cringy.

I never liked Caroline, but Grace is so much worse, I hate her so much. A bad rendition of the stereotypes they were intentionally drumming up to 11. Her husband too to a lesser degree, though he was the fine kind of normal flat bad. Just regular bad character writing. The scientist thirdly too also only got under my skin a little, they absolutely did not need to make him so insanely over the top stereotype. Or I guess, to summarize my whole annoyance with the game: They did it all intentionally. They made everything bad as like a statement. An ode to the most boiled down concentration of everything the genre stands for, and then they essentially forgot to put their /s. They made me sit through hours of cutscene instead of a tastefully short and sweet serenade. I was dragged over the hot coals of a tone deaf opera-ballad-epic. Anya and William are not characters, they are blank slate cardboard cutouts, and forcing me to listen to his inner monologue made me physically ill. The whole plot main A plot is literally the subplot from gears of war where you help your buddy dom find his wife.

The themes are the opposite of subtle. The bad guys are so... cartoonishly-over-the-top evil. Caricatures of bad guys in media. Not a tasteful dollop of trope-y. Full on, in-your-face shock value for shock value's sake. The game lurches from one bombastic shark-jumping scene to the next. Some of it works. But not once its all stitched together like the soul of a little girl shoved into twisted demented body of her childhood dog.

The game-play is all below average drivel. Of the 9(seriously, is there only 9?) guns, 3 were so bad I would never use them under any circumstance. I was playing on hard, and I never found the shotgun, heavy gatling shotgun, or the BFG to be useable. I would only ever use the SMG when I was out of STG and beam rifle ammo. I would only use the pistol when I was out of ammo for all three. The enemies are all bullet spongy af. On paper, trying to disincentive headshots and reward skillfully landing your body shots in the same place with the armor system sounds good. But in practice it never helped. 3 headshots or 3 bodyshots is still three bullets ttk and often 1 bullet too many, an unlucky dropped stagger and every other or every third enemy will trade one bullet on your health bad.

When every third enemy gets to shoot you once for free because they have laser perfect accuracy and great damage at any range, it can be rough to get a good auto save. For the courthouse sequence I literally ran out of patience and dropped from hard to medium, just so I could kill every enemy before I ran out of ammo with all the guns worth using. There is gatling shotguns galore to tickle enemies across the room with as they 3-shot you with their STGs and then drop 6 rounds of ammo for them.

Rapid fire nitpicks that add up: Grenades and tomahawks are scarce/floaty/hard to aim. Entering and exiting vents and doors should not have me getting stuck on them. I should personally not be able to climb or swim faster than a gods damn super soldier in a video game. Mantling makes no intuitive sense. The ground slam attack is worthless. Why do I have to (waste time)hold E to pick up inspectible collectables but not other collectables. Why do half of my E to pick up and R to reload presses get eaten by animations taking priority. Speaking of animations taking priority, why does it take so ffff long to change weapons, they chose this aspect of all things in the game that they wanted to make realistic? You're getting shot at man, stop messing with the collapsing stock and shoot the thing already!

I found myself hoping that William's pondering that maybe the rest of the game is also a day dream was true.

I just played the game; 7 hours on file between today and yesterday. I already can't remember a single line of the music. I already can't remember if I might be forgetting the existence of a 10th gun. Weak shallow game, imo.

everything is great for me in this game, but as an english native speaker fluent in german, I just can't believe how amazing the game is when you know both languages. I played through the German editions of previous titles while living there too and this is just a whole new level. I remember wolfenstein coming out as a kid too and have played the whole series up to this point. There is no parallel. I can't believe the depth. I mean, when I was on exchange to Germany as an 18 yr old I got into jazz rock and cosmic music through my host dad who was a post war german kid growing up, and have this great album Kosmische Laeufe which is feaux DDR music in that vein but when I found this nazi psych rock record in new york in the game I wasn't expecting the sheer amaaaaazingness of that experience after clicking play. The lyrics, the sound, seriously mindblowing!!!!!!!. I went back to Germany later in life to do a doctorate in music so I'm difficult to impress with this stuff. I could go on for ages about the quality of the game. Best game of the 21st century so far, god I love killing nazis. Bring em on.

I have a 8th gen i7, 12GB of memory, and a GeForce GTX 1050 Ti. From what I can gather is that my setup no longer works due to an update that was intended to allow higher settings, through the lowering of settings and increasing the GPU pooling size I have managed to get 7 FPS constantly and occasionally up to 10 or 11 FPS.

So, there was I, playing the game, I thought to myself:
-hey, how my PC is doing?
I activated stats in options and returned to the game. Played it for a bit. Finished the level. Decided to take a break. Closed the game.
Oh, the look on my face when I realised, the stats are still on my screen, faded. I hastily tried to restart my PC. Nope. Still there. 
-maybe stats are in-driver thing, it's just for some reason not disabled itself after closing the game?
Opened the game, disabled stats. Nope. Still there.
Driver update. Still there.
Disabling screen for an hour. It's gone, dodged a bullet.
And don't tell me my screen is old, or bad. I had a lot things that stayed on my screen for a long time. None of them are burned in. But somehow stats of this game managed to do that. I'm puzzled.
Yes, it's gone now, but how about I'll hit your car with a hammer? Hmm? It's just a little dent, you can buff it out, don't you?

Did you like the other new Wolfenstein? You'll like this. If you hated the other one, you'll probably hate this. And if you aren't sure which one to get... I personally would recommend start with Wolfenstein 1, and then do this. (1) The story in Wolf 2 is probably better if you played the first game. (Wolf 2 does start with a flashback, but it is more of a reminder than a complete retelling). (2) The games are very similar, so you might as well start with the cheaper game. 

Wolfenstein 2 is a great game, but it is not perfect. 
[list]
[*][b] The Value! [/b] It's a single player game, with no microtransactions. They even gave away a "free sample," of the DLC. The DLC hasn't been released yet, it looks like they are setting up to do the best type of DLC. Three new characters in three new missions, on new levels.
[*] [b] It's very cinematic [/b] It is a story driven FPS. Most of the story is told in cut scene, not during gameplay. Watching a 10 minute cut scene (even if the graphics are top notch), is annoying to some, and you could make the argument for YouTubing the game.
[*] [b] The signposting is poor [/b] You can push "g" anytime in game to display a waypoint, but the levels don't naturally lead you to where you should go as well as you'd like. Midway, you'll get to choose one of three abilities: Break walls, crawl through narrow tubes, and extendable stilt legs. I found myself getting stuck, where I could not find the way to use my ability to get past an obsticle more than once.
[*][b] The game play [/b] is a real matter of personal preference. There are roughly three styles the game leads you to - stealth assasination, cover based shooter, and dual wielding mayhem, but none of the three styles are good enough to play the entire game that way. You can stealth for awhile, but you can't see enemies through walls, or hide bodies, and if you are seen or a body is found it will trigger every enemy in the level. There are enough enemies with explosive weapons that you can't just use cover, and your character is squishy. If you go mayhem and get flanked, you will probably die before you can react. There are a handful of times that the game forces you into a mayhem scenario, and always felt lucky when I beat the area, not skilled.
[*] [b] The story [/b] On the one hand, the story is the highlight of the game... on the other hand.... It is really over the top. I think the safest example is (not really a spoiler, but tagged anyway) [spoiler] that you will go to Venus. Not the moon, not Mars, not one of Jupitor's moons, Venus. You will have gun battles outside on Venus. [/spoiler] So you need to approach the story with a sense of humor. But it also has a unique world, where Nazis have conquered America, and a lot of Americans are OK with that. You'll see Klansmen, walking around opening in their robes. It's a world where respectable Americans have made peace with the Nazis, and only outcasts and weirdos are willing to fight.
[/list]

Again, Wolfenstein 2 is a great game - I love the humor/over the top storytelling. Watching a cutscene and thinking, "Are they going to... oh my God.... I can't believe that happened." I love sneaking around and murdering Nazis with an axe. I love the characters, even if they are sometimes flat or cliche.

Update: I replayed this game in July 2022: It's still so much fun... killing nazis is still great. It's not the best gameplay out there, and you really have to be down for a rididulous story, but it holds up.

As far as the DLC: I thoroughly enjoyed it, all of the DLC are the "good type" of DLC - each on focuses on a different character with one of the three abilities from the game, in a stage with gameplay focuses on that ability. They are short, and worthwhile if you enjoy the base game.

Fantastic sequel. It hits all the notes that should be struck, as well as giving you a solid amount of gameplay even after the completion of the story. 


The story itself creates a strong amount of compelling cliffhangers to make you say " Just one more level..." before bedtime.I can not stress enough how well the soundtrack is timed and the general joy this series continues to bring me. I would recommend this to any fans of singleplayer FPS fans.

Presentation (5/5) - high production values using the latest technology at the time and violence against Nazis is displayed in a satisfying way. Sound is of the highest level (including weapons, sci-fi ones in particular), voice actors are all great, music is outstanding, and you start in a wheelchair dual-wielding guns. This game has a ridiculous style that I like.

Story/Dialogue (3.5/5) - great voice acting aside, I have mixed feelings about the story because it can be a bit confusing on what it tries to be: a 'Doom' with nazis instead of demons that doesn't take itself seriously, a gritty and sadly too accurate observation on an American society what-if. There are plenty of absurd moments on the former (enjoyable and all) that can clash with the other elements of the story. The dialogue, character choices, and some of the chemistry between the characters don't always work and some jokes fall flat. That being said, the hilarious Hitler cameo has to be seen - such a great mocking portrayal.

Gameplay (4/5) - This game is clearly well designed. You have satisfying weapons, challenging biological and mechanical opponents that can have good AI, optional but helpful stealth approach, and doesn't get too repetitive. There's light RPG elements to develop your character or weapons as well. Nothing too innovative, but the game is well-rounded utilizing good mechanics

I don‚Äôt think ive ever been so annoyed with modern FPS in my life. It really beggars belief that not one of them is able to get a single solitary thing right.

For example, why do games insist on forcing iron sights on every weapon imaginable? What does it achieve other than obscure 80 percent of your screen and artificially slow down the action to an absolute crawl? 

Why do guns have so much recoil and particle effects that obscure what little is left of your view after the gun models take up most of the screen anyway? Yes, it's more realistic that way but honestly, who gives a rat‚Äôs ass. This isn‚Äôt a hyper realistic military simulator, it's bloody Wolfenstein. It‚Äôs a game where you shoot Hitler in a mech suit, for the love of god. Why is it so brown, gray and uninspired? Why is there so much melodrama and hours upon hours of terrible cutscenes and story being crammed down my throat?

Why is my character so pathetically slow?

Why does every modern FPS insist on having a BFG-type weapon that slows you down even more and takes an hour to rev up and is therefore rendered completely useless? 

If you find yourself asking the same questions then my best advice is to go and download Return to Castle Wolfenstein instead of this one. It's old and it looks like ass by today‚Äôs standards but it is by far the closest thing you will ever get to a good Wolfenstein game. The story is simple and unobtrusive and there‚Äôs lots of nazis to kill, as well as zombies and zombie nazis. What more could you possibly want?

Overall I don't think this one is better than the first, but it is still very much worth playing if you enjoyed the new order. 

 New colossus is a vast improvement in gameplay, the guns feel great and the upgrade system is an improvement. The level design and general atmosphere of the missions is great, from a bombed out NYC to Venus, there are a variety of missions that keep it interesting. 

My main issue is with the writing, especially at the beginning of the game. For some reason BJ is super emo at points and it just doesn't seem fitting to his character. I think it gets better as it goes on but there are still a lot of incredibly cringey moments throughout the whole thing. Not as tightly put together as the first, but still has a lot of equally as cool moments.

As someone who liked the first one (The New Order), this game was very disappointing. It was worse than bad; it was boring and embarrassing. 

The gameplay mechanics are above average but extremely repetitive. There are no special or unique weapons; just your standard assault, submachine gun, shotgun, pistol, and, for some reason, two grenade launchers (I chose the Wyatt path). There less than 10 different enemy types; 3 different types of humans and maybe 5 types of robots. 

But the gameplay isn't what I came to this game for. It was the story and characters, which were annoying, goofy, unlikeable, and written extremely poorly. There were scenes of dialogue in this game that made me embarrassed while playing it. Also, there are character subplots that come up and made to seem like they're going to be major issues but then are resolved almost immediately in the next scene. 

As for the main plot, I keep being told by the characters that big things are happening but I never get to see or feel that. You kill the main antagonist at the end of the game and when I got back to my home base, not a single NPC commented that we had killed the big bad of the game (with only one exception). 

I haven't played Youngblood (nor am I going to) but I watched a couple of reviews that talk about how bad the writing is and how cringe-worthy the main characters are. After playing this game, I can definitely how the studio that made Wolfenstein II can make a game as bad as Youngblood.

I can recommend it, but if you played other games, than it's a abomnination.

1. Keybinding between the three games are all around, fuck you keymaping dude.
2. Perks give "+% to something" rather than some new effect like in previous games
3. There is no highlighting of hidden items, like in previous two games, and killing commanders in stealth gives you fuck all. You need to use online resources to find them
4. After BlowJob Blaskowicz gets his new body, suddenly I get those alerts that I need to calm on my graphic settings, and in Vulkan Performance info I can see sudden spike from just 3.5GB in VRAM and 70MB in heap2 to 3.7GB in VRAM, 3GB in heap1 (I can assume ram or swap) and 200MB in heap2. 
5. The detection of enemies is wonky, just like it started to be in Old Blood (in New Order if you killed someone before they shouted it was chill, now if they just see you it's instant alarm). 
6. I like the "choose what you want to upgrade" style, but it makes exploration unrewarding, since you will get what you want. Oh and you almost can't skip them, they are in most places just where you would be headed eitherway.

Starting with the negatives: 
Gameplay is fun for the most part - my only major gripe being at the epilogue when you have to hunt down the last of the oberkommando, you don't have enough enigma codes to unlock all their locations so you have to replay levels you've already completed.
In addition to this the bosses are pretty tame, being only bigger versions of regular enemies that have way more hp and more damage - though not any worse than previous entries in the series.
The Positives:
The story is really compelling - comparable to the Metro series. It starts off pretty lame with a total Deus Ex Machina, but after the ending of New Order they totally wrote themselves into a corner - so they get a pass.

Faithful sequel to the New order, I have things I prefer and dislike about it. The removal of the ability to strip enemies of their armor post-humously has impacted my gameplay in a positive way, and forced me to get better at headshots and aiming, but it is also extremely annoying to deal with. In the new order combat really lagged with unrelated out-of combat tasks, but the stealth in the new colossus is also rather irritating at times. You can see a similar lagging when it comes to stealth, whenever a body is discovered it will take up to two minutes for units to stop searching for you, and in some sections (like Agent silent death DLC) they never stop searching. I still think the game has a lot of potential, and while being a step down from the genius of the old blood, it still has a place in my library as a very competant first person shooter.
For the best experience possible, I recommend playing this game on the Volkscomputer while listening to Die K√§fer and drinking Erdbeermilch.

Hoo boy, Wolfenstein 2. 

An improvement over the previous two MachineGames titles in every way... except the storyline but I guess that's a bit subjective. Don't get me wrong, I loved Wolf2's campaign but some story beats and a few freshly introduced characters really rubbed me the wrong way. The usual argument is that it goes too over-the-top for its own good and I can frankly see that but I really like stories that don't take themselves seriously, so this one hit the mark for me. The issue is that it follows two games that do take themselves seriously and directly set up the plotline. Nonetheless, I didn't mind it as much as other people did.

Still, the gameplay, weapons (good lord the shotgun and hatchet!), engine and performance, sound design, direction, voice acting and soundtrack (Mick Gordon's actual magnum opus, no one can convince me otherwise) are all exemplary. The level design took a slight hit as commanders are encountered a bit too often and too close together which can detract from the enjoyment for some people. 
However, "could not write crash dump" was the bane of my existence. A very common complaint I see in forums and discussions is the constant crashing. Even the developers have addressed this with a list of proposed solutions. None of them worked for me despite playing on an AMD system, the one Wolf2 was advertized to be most optimized for and slated to offer the best gaming experience on. Although I was able to bypass the crashes since I was able to point out exactly what causes crashing. Namely, trying to preview collectibles straight after picking them up - most of the time. 

Overall, Wolfenstein 2 is an incredible package with a few blemishes that should absolutely be experienced first-hand. I'm not denying its controversial status; everyone has their opinions and stances towards the game. I suggest playing it for yourself and forming your own view on it because there sure is a lot to talk about here, and many hours of straight fun. Killing Nazis has never been this satisfying.

SPOILERS ALERT!

Amazing shooter with a preposterous, juvenile story.

How to enjoy this game: SKIP EVERY CUT SCENE (seriously, hit ESCAPE as fast as you can). Figuring out what you are supposed to accomplish at the beginning of each level is WAY MORE FUN than sitting through each ridiculous, lengthy, addle-minded cut scene.

At the beginning of a level you may be in a massive submarine, or on the roof of a terrible flying war machine, or riding a fire breathing mechanical beast! Why are you there? What are you trying to accomplish? Figure it out! Just shoot, loot, and explore.

Is the game worth it? Not really. But if you have some money to burn and want to shoot stuff with your brain turned off, this is the game for you.

It's a really good game. Honestly, I thought it was the best of them.

[b] Story [/b]
It's surprisingly good. We are talking about a game where the main appeal is blasting up some Nazis. Yet, I really enjoyed the story itself. Especially the start. The way Blazkowicz feels and talks is so good, that you can actually feel how sad and defeated he is. His interactions with the rest of the crew is really human. The story was pretty good.

[b] Gameplay [/b]
It's mostly the same as the previous games. You got guns, you shoot some Germans or [spoiler] Klan's members[/spoiler]. The guns are fun, but they are not all good. Like the lazer beam blaster thingie is fantastic, the pistol isn't that great, the shotgun is good, but I didn't really use it. Dual-wielding is veru fun. The new abilities are alright, they are not a gamechanger, I thought they would be more useful. The skills are underwhelming, that was the only disappointing thing for me.

The only complaint I have is that the game will randomly save in the middle of a fight, so sometimes I had very low health and the game would quicksave with 3 enemies infront of me and a dog after me. So remember to save the game yourself every once in a while, so that you have a backup to go to.

It's. Just. Awful.
So I'll start with coming up with anything positive.
1. It pretty
2. Gunplay solid.
That's absolutely it. It looks and plays just like the first one. Everything else is just bleh.

Negative:
Every character is insufferable. Not even Blazkowicz is likable in this game. They make terrible decisions which I get to a degree, cause you know its a game. However, NONE of these people are likable and I would say are almost as morally corrupt as the villains. I'm convinced the leaders of the "good" guys would cause just as much suffering as possible if they were in control. I forced myself to sit through every cut scene hoping for some redeeming qualities, but alas it just made me hate them more.
The story itself feels pointless. Just like the previous game there's one main villain  (should've died in previous title) that is introduced in a cut scene and you don't interact with them for the rest of them game. You fight the same enemies in uninspired levels all across the states and again you go to space. All the maps aren't bad but none of them stand out and the story and characters are so weak I can't remember why I was there half the time. It just feels like a carbon copy of the first game, but misses all the marks.
I would not buy this game again. Even if it was free its just not worth your time. I only put in 9 hours and i'm sure you could get at least 20 if you did all the side stuff and end game content, which is literally just running back through the mission areas and killing the "high profile target"...... It's just a regular officer unit with a special location. This game is just feels so lazy every step of the way and loses all the wolfenstein charm very early on. Seriously ya'll don't support AAA junk when we know ,and they have done better.

This game makes me wish that Bethesda would allow Machine Games to continue making proper Wolfenstein sequels -- story based ones like #1 and #2 in the series. There's so much to do after this one wraps up but then they jump to the 80's with the 3rd sequel (if you can call it a sequel). This game features the odd cringe moment and questionable music choice, but it is otherwise a superb action shooter with really tight gunplay and great settings to fight in. Any cringe is also countered by some insanely hilarious and out-of-the-box turn of events that make for great surprises and outlandish moments. For the completionists out there there is a whole ton of things to do when you finish the main story, too.
Game is challenging and has alot of nostalgia to it.  Recommend to anyone that likes fps games

Wolfeinstein 2 lives up to the first game and prequel game in the reboot series with its levels utter batshittery and hilarious nonsense, that in reality makes perfect sense in the world, I throughly enjoy this game and would recomeend getting it for anyone who wants an insanely fun nazi killing shooter with great humour and writing, just the irony in what the nazis say alone is hilarious, like "There is never an excuse for violence." and then like two seconds later, "Do you think we'll be assigned to the same death squad?" absoulute perfection.

1. Leaning mechanic is broken - twitches aggressively when looking around or when too close to a wall. 

2. Weapons are too weak and feel awful to use - you have to shoot way too much into enemies unless it's a perfect headshot, and the ammo capacity upgrades don't help because it still wastes time how much you have to shoot into them. They don't have oomph and any sense of power to them, and the pistol is entirely unviable unless you're going stealth, which the game actively discourages. 

3. Bad story with cutscenes that just make you uncomfortable with characters that have unlikable traits

4. Game is anti-stealth despite the fact that it has skills dedicated toward stealth play. Enemies will shoot instantaneously upon sight of the player which was never a thing in the past two games (you had a second to kill them beforehand which made it manageable), and commanders suddenly get alerted that you're around when nothing even happened (no one saw you, no gunfire, etc), yet sometimes even the exact opposite happens, commanders don't get alerted when explosions when off and you chopped the limbs off a big guy.

To add to this, there are levels that are impossible to do stealthily. It's simply not an option. 

5. Has one of the worst final bosses in any game I've ever seen. Again, stealth is impossible, and there are so many nazis literally everywhere that I'm not surprised if they're set to infinitely respawn. It makes it extremely difficult to focus on the final bosses (of whom instantaneously kill you in 1 shot), and it doesn't feel challenging, it just feels like you're being f*cked over on purpose, it's not at all satisfying, it gives the feeling of "thank god this is fucking over". 

To add to this, the exit to the level is in the area the final bosses come out of, allowing you to completely skip them entirely if you're fast enough and they aren't looking in that direction. 

6. If you don't have armor, assume you have 1 HP. If you have full 100 armor, assume you have 50 armor, because you take so much damage that you die just being breathed on. The game also does very bad at communicating to the player WHERE they got shot from. I can't react to getting shot at when someone is outside of my general vision, one because the game doesn't let you know which direction, and two, BECAUSE YOU'RE SO FRAIL THAT BJ WOULD PROBABLY FALL DEAD IF A NAZI BREATHED ON HIM!

7. The New Colossus decided NOT to learn from The Old Blood, and doesn't reward the player with anything whatsoever for getting all gold collectibles, or any collectible at all for that matter. I'm sick of games doing this. I don't want to get collectibles if all I get in return is a stupid achievement. I want a genuine reason to unlock them.

8. Wyatt is barely utilized in the story and feels more like a background character, while remaining incredibly uninteresting the whole way through the game. Fergus is objectively a better character which feels like a kick in the balls to anyone who chose to save Wyatt - which I did because it felt like the morally correct choice and initially I was more interested in him. 

9. Wyatt also gives you a Dieselkraftwerk, which is objectively a worse weapon than the Laserkraftwerk Fergus upgrades for you to be more powerful. The Dieselkrafterk has extremely limited practical use, and its upgraded fireballs have tiny hitboxes that make it impossible to hit anything that isn't a large target. And even then, it's too hard somehow.

10. The Ubergewehr is the worst weapon in the entire game. It has a small blast radius and heavy armored enemies can literally just walk outside of the blast even if they were directly hit by it, nothing paralyzes or sucks them into it, they just walk out and they're fine. The same thing can happen with the robots because they're decently powerful and have speed. 

Overall, it's a massive step backwards in gameplay compared to The Old Blood and a massive step backwards in story quality compared to both New Order and Old Blood. I don't recommend it at all. I'm even willing to say New Order's extremely bad final boss is better than New Colossus' final boss. What is wrong with these developers? They have no idea what they're doing.
Awesome action

The addition of contraptions was an interesting device to attempt gameplay diversity, however regardless of which you chose the routes all lead to the same place and you end up collecting the other devices anyway. Heavy weapons mostly served to slow down combat, as the Laserkraftwerk does equitable damage anyway. However, the story was more satisfying than The Old Blood, and the ending felt like the resolution to a good book.

This wasn‚Äôt a good game for me sadly. Gameplay aspects are good for the most part but the story is too cheesy. Other games of the series are cheesy too but this at another level. Unfortunately, there are a lot cutscenes to make it even worse. Although, there is some meaning to the story at the beginning of the game with BJ‚Äôs dilemma, the game loses it very quickly. And honestly, I find the Nazi murdering part a bit over the top. I can say it is almost racist for some parts.
