Wish I could give this a "meh", but I'm err'ing closer to a downvote than an upvote.

1) only supports vulkan-capable cards.

So, regardless of how capable your old gfx card is, if it can't support vulkan you get an error msg that's basically saying "go buy a new gfx card, scrub"


2) Once you do get a gfx card that can play it, the game eats your cards ram like popcorn.

I got a RTX3060 w/ 12gb GDDR6... I would consistently get warning messages saying my card's ram was used up. Give me a break.


3) Someone decided to go nuts with Volumetric Lighting / Fog

Many levels have fog so thick you can't see where you're going, or if there's enemies there. But, enemies can see perfectly in the fog, so while you're wandering around like an idiot, they're keeping easy track of you and lighting you up. And, you try to see who's shooting at you, and you barely see a flicker of light in the foggy haze from their gun.


4) Game tries to mix action and stealth like The New Order did in a "play your way" style, but it feels like they sacrificed the action to try to bolster the lackluster stealth, so now both are  lackluster.

Stealth is still "crouch to sneak / d**k-eye view of the world" which I'm sick of. I'm tired of games making you crouch to sneak. It's unrealistic, and I wish this stupid trope would die already.

Enemies still spot you easily, because even on the easiest difficulties they can spot you through thick fog, or spot you from a mile away while they're up on a catwalk. Or, they hear you walking, b/c you decided to stop crouch-sneaking.

They give you a hatchet to silent-kill enemies via slash or throwing it. And, it's ok for a bit, until you throw the hatchet at one enemy and it bounces off their back armor while they stumble forward, yell, and now the alarm is going off. So, the tool you're supposed to use for stealth killing is unreliable as a ranged stealth killing too... YOU HAVE ONE JOB, HATCHET, AND YOU'RE FAILING AT IT!

Anyways, the action starts, b/c of course it does since stealth sucks...

Now you can-run-gun to avoid getting hit.

But, someone made the ham-fisted decision to make you have to practically be right on top of ammo and armor for BJ to auto-pickup.

So, levels usually devolve into this Keystone Cops BS:

* you try to stealth a bit
* you get caught, b/c, of course you do
* you start blazing
* every enemy in the map comes at you at once, and commanders call for reinforcements to constantly spam more enemies at you. So, you go from no action to suddenly an arena-style boat load of it.
* you're running around shooting them all, but run out of ammo. Why? Because you're not picking up most of the ammo from the enemies
* eventually you kill everyone
* now you get to spend the next 5-10 minutes walking around like a glorified janitor manually clicking the "use" key to pick up all the ammo, health, armor, etc that BJ decided to waltz on by during the combat

It's not fun.

It kills the pacing of the game, and becomes boring.

And, it actually becomes deadly when ....


5) The game randomly & DRAMATICALLY spikes in difficulty here and there.

I'm not trying to prove my man-hood on a video game. I just want a fun experience. I'm a seasoned FPS gamer. So, decided to go with "Bring it On" (normal mode). I was tearing through things, and thought about turning the difficulty up until I came to one area where they just spam enemies at you constantly in a place that has no cover, and where enemies can flank you from multiple sides.

I was running around getting my rear shot off, b/c couldn't find cover. And, I was running out of ammo, b/c all the ammo and stuff is on shelves that BJ won't pick up.

So, you know what's really fun in the middle of an intense fight?

Having to STOP FIGHTING, mouse-over to target an item on a shelf, and then click the "use" key to pick it up. AND THEN REPEAT THAT OVER AND OVER to get more stuff.

So, you get your rear shot off b/c you're having to stop and pray to god Fitts' Law kicks in and lets you target the pickup quickly.

After you die continuosly, you figure it's just bad level design. Ok, get through it, set difficulty back up.. until you keep running into the same situation OVER and OVER again in many other levels.

I gave up and just played on easy mode, b/c I got tired of bipolar game play that can't decide if it wants to be a cakewalk or a suicide mission on the same difficulty mode.

Of course, killing enemies is a pain, because...


7) Enemies are bullet sponges

You have an armor-piercing assault rifle. You have to waste 1/2 your clip to take a guy down. You stop shooting.. he stumbles and you sigh, b/c he should be dead, but he's going to get back up.

You have an auto-shotgun that you run up on enemies with. It takes 3-4 SHOTS to take them down.

It boggles the mind how much damage these guys can absorb. But, then again, BJ is made of some kind of self-healing steel, so I guess it's just the nature of this fantasy universe.

But, it's annoying going through on the easiest difficulty, and enemies still take many shots to go down. That's just lazy programming to pad the diffuclty.

"Should we make the enemies smarter?"
"No, just add more health to them."

smh


~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Was there anything good?

Sure, the story was good.

But, I got irritated at how several characters on BJ's team were just complete jerks for no reason.

In The New Order, folks acted like adults, and were focused on solving problems while respecting each other.

In this game, most folks are acting like high-schoolers ... like some 12yo boy wrote what they think someone "cool" would act like.. which means bullying and name-calling folks that are supposed to be their friends and allies. Because apparently being a jerk to others while expecting to be respected in return is "cool".

And the bigger annoyance is BJ just stands there and lets it happen.

BJ was acting like a moral compass of The New Order, but here he just lets members of the team bully each other right in front of him without stepping in.

smh

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

The more I think about this game, the more it teeters towards a down-vote.

The story is interesting, but has ham-fisted, contrived drama
The stealth is better, but that's like saying cold garbage is better than hot garbage
The action is ham-fisted, so the pacing of levels is awful
They pad the game by re-using previous levels for "commander hunts" that "liberate america", but they don't explain what that means or unlocks


It's an interesting alternative "what if" universe that tackles some tough social issues. But, it has too many bad design decisions.
tbh u rlly need a good graphics card for this game but otherwise its good

The New Colossus is overall weaker than The New Order, but despite that its still a pretty good game.

For the most its the same really great game play and characters I loved from the previous game. Sometimes though, the game does make some questionable choices with its story and level design.

The story is pretty great most of the time, however there were a few times throughout where an out of place scene or line would make me flat out roll my eyes. The same kind of rule applies for the game play as well. Most of the time I was enjoying myself and getting the most out of the refined mechanics. Sometimes however, I'd be reminded of some of the more negative changes.

The best way I can describe the game play changes, is that the game feels a lot more punishing, but not always in a fun and fair way. The best parts of the previous titles took place in these linear sections where the game would allow you to take on tons of enemies in these close quarter battles with fun weapons. These sections do exist here, however they're certainly not as common. The game instead decides to place you in a lot more of these open levels with commanders. This combined with the new special enemies and how insanely fast you die this time around, going loud and proud is a lot more difficult for the most part. Playing this game on hard just like the previous games, I died a helluva lot more than I used to and it didn't always feel fair.

All in all I don't have a ton to say in all honesty. It's another good entry but just with some minor improvements and minor annoyances. It took me about 7 hours to beat on hard and without doing much in the way of the side content. I'd recommend it if you're a fan of the series. Could've been better, but it also could've been far worse.
Overall pretty fun. Typical shooter story line but I've loved this series since we played it on 14" CRT monitors back when systems had a max speed of 33mhz
its a good game

Wouldn't recommend buying for full price. I played on Call me Terror-Billy! (very hard, *I think*) difficulty and still finished the game in 9.5 hours. Granted I only did a handful of side activities but they didn't really seem worth doing unless you just want to experience more of the game. Even then the side stuff only consists of going back to previous areas you've already played through to kill some named general and get collectables you might have missed. The overall tone is a bit everywhere too, goes from comedy to dramatic to action packed in one cutscene at times.
TL:DR The gameplay is fun and over the top like you would want from a Wolfenstein game, just feels lacking in areas and very short.

I like the game, it has solid shooting mechanics and most importantly for an FPS it's fun to shoot the things you are shooting, but I can't stand the head bobbing. It's like BJ's a toddler with guns and at any moment he could tip over. I'm not sure if I can keep playing since I haven't found a way to get rid yet.
Part 2 kicks shit up to 11 and it's sooooo good. kill all the nazi's :>
very cool nazi kill
Over all its a great game! But i would recommend playing the rest of the series before this one
guffy ahh walk
The humor doesn't always land but its always fun killing nazis and immersing yourself in an alternative timeline.

I wish I could leave a "mixed" review. I'm glad I bought this on sale and not full price. Overall, I think Wolfenstein: TNO was a superior game in terms of story, presentation and atmosphere. In TNC, every potentially emotional cutscene gets abruptly cut short by cringey jokes or crude humor that don't stick the landing. It's hard to tell what exact kind of tone Machine Games was going for when they developed this. Character motivations are all over the place. The first and second half of the game have markedly different tones. BJ himself feels like a completely different character by the end of the game, and it's not due to earned character development whatsoever. In fact, it almost seems like Machine Games themselves were conflicted as to whether BJ should be a silent protagonist or not. There were many in-game moments where characters would ask him a question or interact with him directly, and there is absolutely no option to respond.

The combat and visuals have been bumped up, but it still feels a bit like "Doom-lite". The map and objectives list need serious work. Collectibles and hidden items are heavily obfuscated in the environments to the point where I would blindly spam the action button in hopes that I'd pick something up. Also why is armor and ammo not automatically picked up like in Doom? Although I realize the developers are different, it's impossible not to compare Wolfenstein to Doom since they have so much shared DNA, not to mention the same publisher and engine. The levels are extremely short and rarely have any branching paths. Much like my issues with the first game, the developers clearly created the levels with stealth in mind, but the enemy AI keeps switching between brain-dead and omnipotent seemingly at random. 

I think it IS worth playing, albeit at a severely reduced price. If I were giving it a score, it would probably be 5/10.

[b]The rebellion begins...[/b]

Set back in alternate 1961, when the Nazis won World War II and took over much of the world, B.J, affectionately known as Terror-Billy, plots an uprising against the regime with rebel troops.

[b]If you haven't played the first part, Wolfenstein: The New Order, you should do so before playing this game, as the story flows seamlessly and there are some familiar faces to see.[/b]

In Wolfenstein 2, MachineGames puts a whole load of crazy ideas on top of it and throws the logic completely overboard. But that doesn't matter at all and it's actually a good thing because it's not about a history lesson on World War II but about an intense, emotional and profound story.
And this is exactly what is told with the quite long but complex intermediate scenes and with a lot of depth and also shows our Terror-Billy from his somewhat softer side. The characters, including those who are new on board, work and convince with their stories. Toilet jokes included.

The stolen submarine "Hammerfaust" serves as the starting point and rallying point for the rebellion. And this thing is just huge. It really takes a while until you know all the routes between e.g. the operations center, hangar, canteen. Although there is an in-game map, it is still easy to get lost. Aside from the story missions, optional side tasks can also be completed on the Hammerfist. In addition to the individual character quests, this also includes the district assassinations. As soon as you have the punch card from a killed commander you can decode it on the Hammerfist and unlock the corresponding district. Here it is then only necessary to locate and eliminate the officer. As a reward, for example, improvements for weapons or combat modifications waving. Unfortunately, these district assassinations are all very similar and there is nothing worth mentioning as the locations are just variants of the locations already visited in the story and after a short time they become more tiring than fun.
However, for those who want to get all the achievements, the districts are a must, because that's where the missing collectibles are and you can't get them through the story.

[b]Sneaking or just shooting away, you can do that however you want[/b], but Wolfenstein 2 is definitely a bit more difficult than The New Order and the opponents act, depending on the level of difficulty, sometimes really cleverly by enclosing you, sounding the alarm or using a grenade the other throw. Eliminating the commanders early is just as important here again, because otherwise they'll call in a lot of reinforcements very quickly and then the only thing left is to shoot yourself free.
Also this time countless weapons are available which can also be modified with up to 3 stages. From the ax to submachine guns, assault rifles and rocket launchers, everything is included.
The Akimbo mode also now offers the possibility to carry two different weapons.

[b]Visually, Wolfenstein 2 is absolutely great. The engine convinces with extremely good light and particle effects and also metal surfaces or the armor look extremely good.[/b] The game can be played, presumably on most computers, with maximum graphic details and without major performance problems.

[b]Is the game worth buying?

Yes, in any case. I think Wolfenstein 2: The New Colossus is just brutally good.[/b]

While it wasn't as viscerally satisfying as I had hoped, it was still a very fun experience, although it does get a little stale after a while. Admittedly, the game could codify more of one style or another of combat (stealth or loud, most missions end up as a shootout) and it badly needs some bug fixes (shots passing through enemies sometimes)
One thing I think this game does great is actually the 'soft cutscenes', the ones where you cant move and are just an observer, without the ability to skip. In this, and much of bioshock 1 & 2, they serve a narrative purpose- in Bioshock, important twists and details are revealed using them.
Here, the soft cutscenes serve the importance of making you HATE the enemies, so you really FEEL the rage felt by Blaskowicz as you hack them to pieces, blast them apart, or disintegrate them with an energy weapon.

(Edit: oh right, theres very little replay value unless you're a masochist; its another case of higher difficulties just hiking up enemy health and making their guns do more damage.)

I waited with the review till the end of the game. I got it on a discount for around 19‚Ç¨. Here is my verdict: I was afraid to try it out as not all the Wolfenstein games were great, they were always good but not always great. This one is a blast! Graphics are wonderful - I have never seen such face animations in other games.  The scenario is one of the main advantages, nowadays, scenarios are not always great. Some turns of the story are sick! Others give you shivers, other touch emotionally! Rarity! The world is not fully open but the game is not linear - you can choose how to finish the missions and though where you want to go. Moreover, you travel from place to place... Did you EVER played on Venus? Well... The combat, weapons etc are really good, you have more choice than you can think of. I can only recommend!

The main campaign is pretty fun. The finishers and new guns feel satisfying. The combat is more fun than in New Order however it still sometimes feels very unfair. The side missions are horrible, like really horrible. No check points, unfair enemies and bad hiding spots. Stealth is impossible in side missions. Only play this game for the campaign, the rest won't be fun, it will be tedious and time consuming.

I have played both of the previous games in the Wolfenstein series, and I simply cannot recommend this game. The movement and gunplay is jerky and almost unplayable. I have put over 2 hours into the game and haven't enjoyed a single second of it. Everything about this game is 10X worse than the previous games, if you're looking to play Wolfenstein, play the previous games, the story, gameplay, and everything about them were so much better.

So I will be honest and say this is the first installment of the Wolfenstein series that I have ever played. I really enjoy the story thus far and wanted this to be the bridge that would get me to play the rest of the series. 

I want to start with the negative in this instance as it is game breaking. Throughout the game, a video memory issue would pop up, however, it would go away and not be so much of an issue. At about 9 hours into the game the memory issue came back with a vengeance. I looked up several online solutions and none have worked for me, be it updating my drivers, verifying the integrity of the cache, starting in Safe Mode, or adjusting my graphics settings. I am relatively disappointed as I hit a point in the story where I am able to freely roam around and hunt down various Nazi Leaders without having to progress further in the main story. Based on this issue alone, I would not recommend this game. If I can find a solution, I will update my review accordingly. 

The game still looks great despite being as old as it is, the game play is balanced and for the most part very smooth. Controls are simple and for the most part, everything is fairly self explanatory. The world is semi open in a sense that you can travel to locations and approach the objective the way you want, kind of like Splinter Cell Blacklist or Metro 2033 and Last Light. 

The story is pretty solid and there are a lot of collectibles to search for within the world that will keep the game going on for some time.
Cannot pause cutscenes and cannot watch cutscenes you missed from within the game.

THIS GAME IS INCREDIBLE BUT 10e FOR ONE DLC THAT SUCKS SO MUCH IS NICE !!! XD MAKE THEM FREE OR AT LEAST LOWER THE PRICE FFS

If you liked The New Order go play that one again and if you didnt like it you will definitely not like this one. Either way dont bother

Oh and btw: the game runs terrible. You will randomly get 10 fps, if you have vsync turned off you're constantly looking at 2 different pictures, if you have it turned on your game lags a whole second behind... 
And even with a high-end graphics card and playing on low video settings you will constantly get notifications that you ran out of memory. Graphics look both on low and on Mein Leben! like crap, the only thing that noticeably changes is the lighning from randomly glowing objects to Minecraft still has more complex lighting...
Loading also either takes ages or is acceptable but auto saves are also made randomly in the middle of a battle and you cant restart the chapter.
10 hours of gameplay and you've seen it all

So get it when its on sale, at least 50% one.

shoot good

Excellent gun play if you like to go in guns a blazing. Stealth is possible for some things but you can never get a roll going. Story seems cohesive is you only play once a week. Story writing seems random at times. You can play through each level fairly quickly which makes it great for people who don't have much time on their hands.

However, despite having a brand new rig with well over the recommended requirements the game likes to freeze and throw random error messages. Sometimes I can play for hours with no issues. Other times, its a matter of minutes. I do not have issues with countless other AAA titles. Must just be a Bethesda thing.

For the ridiculously low price i bought it for I can deal with things. If i bought it for full retail at launch I would of been grabbing my pitchfork. 

TL:DR If you can get it on sale it is worth what you paid for it.

Do you enjoy single player games? Play this.
Do you enjoy alternate history fiction? Play this.
Do you enjoy shooting Nazis with regard for little else? Play this.

The art in this game is incredible, and while there are some obnoxious aspects to this game (the very immersion-breaking 3-5 second interactions that you have to do any time you interact with something other than a gun, for instance) its still a lot of fun. Think "DOOM" but with the action set to a narrative instead of just a soundtrack.
Great game, people should get it

This game is fine at best. Hits the same positives as The New Order and Old Blood though the game feels very stealth focused on almost every moment, as going in guns blazing feels like the enemies do WAY too much damage no matter the difficulty which makes stealth almost necessary the entire game. The games cutscenes kinda last abit too long, like around 30 seconds - 1 min which really shouldn't be the case as i'm here to play a game not watch a movie, sure i can skip it but my point still stands, compared to The New Order for examples the cutscenes were short, simple and explained enough to the player to understand why everything is happening. The game has alot of iconic moments though such as the strawberry milkshake scene and that same level having alot of great lore to read and playthrough even if it's just a walking mission stuff like that is always welcome and much prefer that over watching a cutscene as having the player playing the game is the right way to do it. Also the Hitler scene too is greatly done which is probably the most iconic scene in this game next to the Strawberry Milkshake one. 

The engine too i much prefer over the older one, the shooting, cutscenes, levels, everything all feels so much better than The New Order as with that you had moments where something as simple as papers and pencils were 2D and that goes for alot of the environments in The New Order where everything here is 3D, looks and feels so much more atmospheric and gorgeous at times. It runs on ID Tech 6 so same engine as DOOM 2016 and works perfectly here.

I still enjoy the game though as it's continuing off The New Order and does enough that makes it passable to me but i understand this game being very 50/50 to others but i say give it a try atleast and see if you enjoy it or not as everyones different.

The New Colossus is a good game, but it has many flaws. If you've played New Order before, it can feel like a bit of a downgrade. I don't game often, so I do not have alot of expience, but I can say that this game is just plain chaotic. Most of the time I'm getting shot and I dont even know from which side I'm being attacked, the dual weild controls are difficult and I often end up shooting with the wrong weapon. That ends up being frustrating. Also the difficulty seems to vary alot, the courtroom was the hardest part of the game even though its in the middle, the last bossfight couldnt even compare. The story is alright, but it felt like sometimes the writers didnt know when to time the serious parts and when to time the humor. However, the flashbacks from BJ are amazing and give so much more depth to his character and the story. I was overwhelmed at some points. Also the character Sigrun was an amazing addition to the cast, I love her so much. Unfortunately this game has also made me cringe a couple of times, and it was unbearable, especially the part where BJ yells "White-ass fascist nazi pigs", I get what he was going for, but no. Grace is a character I can't seem to form an opinion on, she's a strong woman and I like that alot about her, but her dialogue often feels off and too over the top, but maybe that's because I'm not familliar with Americans (lmao). This game doesnt shy away from being batshit crazy, and that honestly is one of its charms, but the story ends up becoming bland; you have to unite with a resistance group TWICE?? You go to the same spot TWICE??? The Eva's Hammer is so huge that I often spend more than half an hour wandering around, and that becomes tiring. Alot of the levels look gray, gloomy and alike. The scene on Venus holds a special place in my heart, and it is definatly the best part of the entire game. Even though this game sometimes gets on my nerves, and even though its not as good as New Order or Old Blood, I do recommend it. It's still cool as fuck to murder a bunch of nazis in cold blood.

honestly this entire series is one of my all time favorites. it is just so nice and satisfying. pure happiness, peace and calmness of this game could bring even most angry man to Buddha level of inner peace. It is amazing how calm you can become playing this in perma death mode and not being able to leave this fucking submarine:)

This is a really good game, but it's not without it's flaws... 

So let's start with the good things: combat is really satisfying, guns, sound, graphics and gameplay are really top notch, it's really a lot of fun being able to run at full speed through the enemies while double wielding any gun combo shooting around at averything that moves. Everything about gameplay just feels great, I don't really care about stealth, I mean... It's a Wolfenstein game, I don't wanna be skulking around, I just wanna shoot Nazis and that's it, though if you like Stealth gameplay I bet you could go through the game playing most encounters like that.

So, for the cons: my gripes with the game are what most people might dislike, there's just soooo muuuuch exposition, why? whyyyyyy is there so many moments in the game that you loose control and just have to sit and watch cutscenes to deliver the story?, just: WHY?... There are moments that made me feel like the intermission was longer than the actual map I had just gone trhrough, it's baffling, I mean IF the story was really good, I'd be ok with it, but it's just a mess of a story that doesn't know what it wants to be: A serious story about loss, and a group of people trying to live through an oppresing regime? Is it trying to be a kind of love story of two people facing parenthood? Is it trying to be a lighthearted story that's just "for laughs"? Is it trying to be an action packed type of story?, I felt it was trying to be all of them, and in the end it's just messy. Also, there's a thing about difficulty, It's a hard game in the way that maybe a couple of shots will get the player dead, so: on higher difficulties you'll have to play slow, and carefully, I really don't care for that, so I lowered it enough for the game to become "fun" for me, and allow me to have that really great "Run n' Gun" type of combat.

In conclusion: Should you play this game? If you really like fast and agile combat scenarios, yes! just be patient with the storytelling, and for god's sake, turn down the difficulty so you won't be frustrated with how fast BJ can be killed.

There isn't much to say other than that it's a Wolfenstein game. You get duel wielding guns, optional stealth routes, and a story that doesn't hold back on the gruesomeness. 

One thing I think this game does better than the previous two in the series is the story. The ending is sort of mediocre, but its the middle section that exceeded my expectations the most. If you enjoyed the previous two games, I'd recommend to stop reading the reviews already and just jump into the game instead so you don't spoil yourself by accident.

The game also does a really nice job between balancing high adrenaline action with relaxing game play. After each mission, you get to return to "Home base", where you can explore around and check out what your crew is doing. It's a nice change of pace but also not necessary, as you can start the next mission immediately if you want to.

A note though, make sure your graphic drivers are updated. This game will keep crashing if the drivers are not absolutely up to date. I also got random "graphic memory full" alerts, which would sometimes lead to a crash. The game does auto save a lot, so crashes don't set you back that much at least, but its still something to look out for.

If you could describe The New Colossus in two words, it would be "disappointing" and "forced".

I'll start with the few positives this game has. Gunplay is still fun enough, as they mostly just ported over The New Order's weapons. The game also looks nice, even if it lacks unique environments save for things like the courtroom scene.

Now... the rest. Like I said at the start of this review, The New Colossus is disappointing and feels incredibly forced, especially from a story and level design standpoint. Without spoiling too much, it feels like the writers got cornered by the studio/publishers to just... undo the ending of the first game. Not only that, but halfway through the game, the story also undoes the protagonist's entire arc he's had throughout the first half. It's an extremely bizarre and unnatural shift in the mood, and stays with you for the rest of the story. Characters get killed off but replaced with carbon copies of themselves, other characters just have no impact after being introduced, they keep throwing shit at the wall but nothing sticks. The semi-serious, dry, sarcastic, almost parody tone that The New Order navigated so well is nowhere to be found in The New Colossus, and is replaced by awkward dialogue and cringy interactions.

The levels and gameplay are similarly dour and feel uninspired. It is carried hard by the gunplay, but lack of enemy variety (and generally boring enemies in general) is the downfall of TNC. For example, the Panzerhounds that were absolute MENACES and generally extremely scary due to their speed in TNO are just lumbering around, being shitty mobile flamethrowers that can't turn very fast? Wtf happened? Why is this game a downgrade to the previous one?

[b]*SPOILERS FOR THE FINAL BOSS [/b]

[spoiler] THERE IS NO FINAL BOSS, ARE YOU KIDDING ME MACHINEGAMES? WHY ARE TWO RANDOM SLIGHTLY BIGGER ENEMIES THAT WE'VE FOUGHT FOR THE ENTIRE GAME THE FINAL BOSS?  And then the game just... ENDS. Wow. Even of the rest of the game was better, that ending is downright criminal. [/spoiler]

Anyways yeah. This game pretty poopoo. If you want more of TNO's gunplay it's fine on sale I guess but otherwise just avoid this one.

Actual details:
Well spoilers aside, I'll just lay this out in a way that sums up why I think most people *truly* hate parts of this game. Firstly, I bought this in order to experience a top shelf nazi killing ride. I didn't expect it to have a coherent story (which it struggles at even that).

What you get is a mess of awesome fps action, and pro-commie undertones slowly making their way in more and more as if it's some creeper cuck trying to open the closet door without making enough noise to alert you havin sexy time with big lasers.

Next section will get political, but I tried very hard to supply real value to the conversation, so give it a chance. If not, skip to "The game - ..."

That's not even close to being all. The anti-white sentiment in the game is clever, subtle, and sick. Simply put, this game insinuates that America isn't actually a group of freedom loving fuckers from all backgrounds, but rather a country ruled by the evil white man who would've happily kneeled down, had the Nazis dropped atom bombs on the eastern seaboard, ya know, because white man has that pure instinct to be racist. 
Fuck Machine Games for this one. As if there wasn't enough media in the world right now that straight encourages my own fellow Americans to believe this sentiment. I'd be thankful that this game "went broke", but it doesn't matter either way. Whatever forces are pushing the mentioned propaganda, are successful at it. Companies worth billions all echoing the same things, so this issue with the game hit close to home. And yes it is an issue. I shouldn't even need to explain why but to anyone ignorant of how the Nazis propagated anti-jewish hatred, I encourage some light reading on the subject.

There is one particularly nasty scene which shows exactly how aware the dev/publisher is of what they are doing. You are sneaking through a section and two high ranking officers are discussing the finer nuances of the violence. The game uses them to make a line for line parody of how victims of antifa attacks have discussed real life violence. We are talking about victims, that were minorly right of faaaaar left - disabled veterans, blue collar workers, etc. who just in the last few years were protesting just for conservative values and suffered bloody violence for it. Words like "We are all people", or "Violence against someone just because their beliefs don't match your own, is terrible".. When those words were spoken by American protestors just who happened to be conservative, they were just protesting... In this game those SAME words (I swear to fucking christ the dev did this on purpose), were spoken by men who promote authoritarian nazism and kill men, women, and children.

I won't give a class in manipulation here, but I'll state that the dev accomplished two things.

1. They draw a strong comparison between evil killer nazis, and joe shmoe American conservatives from the 2010s.

2. They make the rational of "We are all people" devalued, and laughable from a certain angle, especially if you are already deluded enough to support violence against someone who's conservative, liberal, whatever, simply for being those things.

The game - it is most parts pure action, and it's fun. There are a lot of cutscenes and without them, it just feels like your average current gen shooter. There really isn't much to say about it. Everything is really well done, even the sound design has gotten so much love.
I think if I could get this game on sale for less than $15, it's worth it. I really have a problem with the narrative they're trying to spin here though. "White America", "Black America", just enough. This garbage, divisive, dangerous propaganda (let's start calling it what it is, rather than "mindset", "agenda", or "narrative") is getting old and tired. I do believe most people are getting wise to it, but just barely. Here at the end of 2021, it really does feel like we're just barely coming out ahead of all the manipulative tricks these large companies are throwing at us. And I do feel like that comes before another average shooter. I'd only recommend it to people who aren't impressionable towards the mind games this plays on the player. I got so tired of it, I sometimes skipped cut scenes. It doesn't bring anything new to the genre, but it is fun. I don't know what else to tell ya.

At time of writing, I had bought the game after *passively* watch youtubers play through it. That's why it only shows 2.5 hours at the time of the review. I'd regret the hell out of this purchase if I didn't get it on sale
Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus is a very good solo FPS (which is already a rarity in the current game market) with a good story and a great sense of humor peppered by intense gunfights.
Good shit, better than the last one, and graphics hold up. Good game play.
its nice gameplay is nice
"eh fuckin' terror billey"

Pretty standard gameplay. Meh story. They got some liberal agenda on it, so it's more of a meh. Not exactly bad, but meh. Played cause I played the New Order. If you enjoy generic FPS with meh story, then it's a go. If not, I think there are problably better games. At least for the main story and main gameplay. I'm not familiar with the DLCs.
Blood
nice game

***EDIT AFTER RECENT RE-VISIT***

Honestly, this game isn't as bad as I remember it being, but it's still a monumental dissapointment. And it baffles me to this day that this game is by the same people who made New Order.

Pros:
-Presentation is super good visually and musically. MG put idtech6 to it's absolute limits and it shows, these environments genuinely hold up 5 years on. Mick Gordon's composition is also incredible as always, even if I enjoy his stuff on KI and Doom Eternal more.
-Gunplay is punchy, impactful, and just damn fun. A lot of the arenas have super nice design too.
-Stealth is... not as non-viable as I remember. There's still a few points where it flat out forces you to go loud and auto-triggers a commander which sucks, but you can still absolutely stealth if you want to. The perks assigned with the constrictor harness help a ton too.
-The contraptions are a fun addition, even IF they come in too late to have any sort of meaningful impact. Channeling my inner scalebarer main and trampling over a nazi into a pile of bloody chunks never gets old.
-Brian Bloom as BJ never gets old. Even with a worse story he has some damn great moments in this, and specifically the stuff with his mom is genuinely some good stuff. It's just a shame the whole situation with his dad is as one-dimensional as it is (racist father is racist, he bad).

Cons:
-Lack of combat innovation. Aside from some new toys and a more streamlined upgrade system, this game plays about as the same as TNO and Old blood. At least Doom Eternal tried to make itself play different from 2016.
-The tone and story. I'm not gonna harp super hard on this as many others have said the same thing I do but this game's writing is such a downgrade from TNO and Old Blood. I don't know how they turned a alt-history story with the overarching themes of war and how it fucks people over from both sides into a generic "fuck nazis" story just for the sake of pandering. A lot of the new characters like Grace and Sigrun are not only genuinely unbearable, but also contridict the previous game (Dealing with one's post-nazi relations was already a theme dealt with between Klaus and BJ. Why do it again here?) Some of the lines too from others are absolutely cringe-worthy, and you could absolutely tell near the end somebody on the team had a prego fetish for anya. It's sickening. 
-A lot of this game too uses violence just for the sake of it or for shock value, unlike TNO and Old Blood. In those games, the violence was used as a way to show how bad the situation was, and to give presence to your enemy as a threat and how fucked they were. In this game it's just there for the sake of telling us how bad nazis are. Which we know already. It's redundant and honestly uncomfortable at points.
-Frau Engel's presence as a villain is absolutely a downgrade comapred to deathshead. Whenever you saw Deathshead in TNO, you knew something fucked was about to happen, and you were in for pain. His smile and demeanor helped drive in the threat of him as a villain. Yet in this game you see Frau Engel only a couple of times and doesn't have as much as a presence despite being THE MAIN VILLAIN.
-Area reuse. I'm not gonna apply that to the post-game, but even near the end of the game it loves to reuse areas and it's lame. Look, we're back on the ausmerser like at the beginning of the game! Look, we're back in manhattan! BUT IT'S AT NIGHT SO IT'S DIFFERENT! It gets tiresome.
-The final "Boss". Remember Deathshead in that mech in the first game and how memorable that was? How about 2 generic robots that are introduced as normal enemies. That's the final boss. [spoiler] Oh, and you just kill frau engel with 1 mouse click. Absolutely no buildup or satisfaction, it's so flaccid. [/spoiler]

It's a 6/10 if I were to give it anything. A fun game, but an absolute dissapointment in reguards to the story, which is a shame considering just how good New Order's was. I know people are still hoping for a wolfenstein 3 at some point to close everything out, and in a way I can't blame them, but at the same time I can't say I'd be super excited if they're just gonna retrace their steps again in terms of design with this game and it's writing. I don't want to play the same game again. And I want to actually enjoy and be invested with the story too, and not be frustrated with it.

It's... interesting i guess.

The story? It changes tone way to often,sometimes trying to be dark and focusing on themes like abuse, racism, and murder, and sometimes just downright weird, using some crude humor and violence as a joke. Not too sure what they were going with. Fortunately you can just double-press escape. Still not a good story by any stretch of the imagination. 0/2

The combat is enjoyable and that is what earns TNC a positive rating from me. All the weapons feel great and are impactful. Playing this on "Call me Terror-Billy!" mode for my first playthrough felt pretty unbalanced, with me dying 5 times in the first level. Playing more carefully is really important, especially in the beginning where you only have 50 health. Once I got the hang of it the combat was satisfying and challenging, but not unfair. Halfway through the game, you get 100 health instead of 50, and in the words of BJ, you "feel like a fucking tank" in comparison to the beginning. You can play more aggressively, but still have to be pretty careful. The fully upgraded StGs were awesome to use dual-wielded, melting super soldiers in a few hits. There are a few cheap sections, but overall the combat is fun when you get to know the  tactics you should use. 7/8

I would rate this 7.1/10 as I don't care as much about the story and only allocated 2 points to it. The combat gets one point deducted for being slightly cheap in terms of death. Bonus 0.1 point for a naked, pregnant woman killing 2 nazis and getting covered in blood in a cowgirl position at the end.

This one plays significantly worse than new order. enemies raise the alarm within 0.1 seconds of seeing you out of the corner of their eye. It's quite ridiculous to witness, and frustrating to play since the game rewards stealth. When you sneak behind some enemies, they will start yelling at you before they even fully turn their head towards you, like they have eyeballs growing out of their ears. These are enemies wearing goggles in radiation suits that obstruct their vision, by the way. 

A cool weapon from the previous game is locked behind a timeline decision now. You won't even know unless you search online for it because the game doesn't tell you that you get only one of 2 weapons depending on that choice. One weapon is significantly better than the other in combat situations, and the other one can cheese some parts of the game.

Sometimes, enemies will have no clue where you are, and other times, they start shooting in your direction to hit solid walls before they can see you. Drones will hover on the opposite side of walls or doors even before they see you, and will leave when you walk away. 

The level design is also significantly worse. The manhantan level is full of invisible walls and forced linearity. Rubble that look like it should be climbable are not.

I also can't figure out how to make collectibles reliably appear on the map. It's very inconsistent. Stealth takedown of commanders don't do it. Picking up maps don't do it. Sometimes they're there, sometimes not.

Wolfenstein : The New Colossus is an exceptionally polished game however the shallow nature of it's gameplay ultimately make it a weaker entry than New Order and Old Blood.  I've played through this game twice, once on steam and once not on steam when it was released.

TNC is a hard one for me to review, it feels so right in so many places at times. When TNC feels good, it feels exceptionally good. However those moments are a far cry from the previous two games in the series continuity. The gameplay systems underlying the game itself are ultimately a much shallower suitor than the admitably flawed perk system of old. While obtaining upgrades within TNO and missing them felt bad, it kept you always searching for something fun and unique to use and knew how to pace them better. The endgame upgrades which branch into 3 different trees feel incredibly hemogeneous. By the time you get them, you're unstoppable with the exception of some really really annoying enemies. The poor execution of upgrade systems means that weapon progression feels so much shallower as a result. There are so many blind spots in combat that are so unfun could have been mitigated with a perk or an upgrade even that just.. don't exist. Instead we have a version where you level up random stats. Insanely boring. Doom got this right! Come on!

Combat sometimes can feel less like picking a weapon for the right job but whatever is going to serve as the right bullet hose at the time, shotguns are not the beasts that they were in TNO or TOB. They hurt a lot but so does pretty much nearly every other weapon on the game, at least on the "expert" difficulty. You die incredibly fast in TNC, so much faster than TNO and TOB's equal difficulty. Sometimes you can be staggered which leads to your immediate death, if you don't see it coming then you're likely already too late because a lot of the arenas take place in corridors or tight spaces. Most enemies forgo taking cover or even trying to flank you like in TNO and instead beelining it straight for your location, meaning that sometimes it's as i said. Use bullet hose weapon. Use your heavy weapons for the slow supersoldats to save on ammo. It very rarely steps outside of that rhythm except in stealth. Stealth feels like a much more annoying cousin of TNO's stealth but does not innovate and infact regresses from the original system. It feels like it exists because it existed in TNO, it feels very stagnant. In terms of difficulty, the game definitely feels easier than it did on launch. It was insanely difficult back then. Even so, it does feel good. Feedback is still somewhat decent. Just not as fun as TNO or TOB.

I've just utterly destroyed this game's gameplay portion but i just wanna say that this game looks fantastic. Even in 2022. It's much less an objective a subject. You might find the colour palette drab.You might prefer the grittier takes from before. The same goes for the story, i personally feel like it ends much too soon and it can feel like very little happens in the plot at times.I think it's very subjective, i'm not fond on it personally. You will revisit certain locations and it can feel very underwhelming in that department. The side content feels the same way and i have very very little motivation to do it aside from achievements. I'm so tired of people screwing this stuff up, seriously. It shouldn't be shallow content to pad gameplay, it should be just as fun and meaningful as the main game.

Overall i think i'll give it a very disappointing not recommend if you are buying it at full price in 2022. If you're playing through the rest of the games and it's on sale like it was for me. It's still fun for a few hours.

I loved New Order, but this game is messy in design at all levels. There's no direction to the maps and I was backtracking for ten minutes on each level just to figure out where to go. Do I go down this ugly, gray hallway or that ugly gray hallway? Neither! Go out the door that you can't see, because, like a fool, you chose the correct brightness/gamma settings! 

Ammo, health, and armor pickups are damn near impossible to pick up, even while moving slowly and mashing E. I got stuck after meeting the New York Resistance group and couldn't get past holding off the Nazis that broke in because I couldn't grab health or ammo in time. 

The weapons don't auto-switch when you're out of ammo, which is fine but one of the weapons has an inexplicable delay in firing after pressing the fire button. So you can't tell if the game is working as designed or if you're being screwed over and by the time you figure it out, BJ is dead. Also, while dual wielding, if one gun runs out of ammo BJ won't automatically holster it, he just keeps aiming it like an idiot. There's a learning curve, but I'm on the third level, where the hell can I get better?

Weapon switching is clunky and slow, the animations for reloading are confusing and also slow, not a single invulnerability frame during melee kills makes them worthless. I could go on, but I just can't believe anyone would play this game and say they enjoy it.

I'm not like...bad at video games. I like a challenge. But there was no way out of this room for me, because I entered with no ammo in the AR.

I'm upset by the design choices made and have no interest in continuing and I can't sleep at night knowing anyone made money off this purchase. First game ever that I requested a refund for.

Wolfenstein II is fantastic and expands on Wolfenstein The New Order in many ways. But It's not perfect. 

The Level Design is more open and varied. But it seriously neuters stealth gameplay.
The World Building is fresh, being set in the United States rather than Europe. I still find myself preferring the European setting of New Order.
The weapon upgrade system works better, but upgrades to blazko are still unlocked with challenges. 
The Characters are just a lovable as in The New Order, as well as the new faces. But I find the writing to be inconsistent. And many of these new characters don't get much care.
The Graphics are very improved, but not optimised that well (Also don't play on outdated drivers, it kills the performance of Wolf II)
Finally the Story of Blazkowicz is definitely the best part for me. It has many twists and turns and never grows stale. Even with the often inconsistent writing, it's still a fantastic story. 

Wolfenstein II is a fantastic shooter, I recommend it.

Boring, and LOVE the other Wolfenstein games.  The cut scenes are WAY too long (literally 10-15 minute segments sometimes), the story is like a bad file-student movie, the characters are one dimensional, and the game play is just boring - it feels like a major downgrade from the The New Order.

New Colossus is definitely a step-down from New Order. While the same elements that made the previous entry great are still there, they've downgraded them and added a bunch of nonsense that makes the game less fun.
The game is only good for about half the duration, (not to mention it's terribly short too) after which it turns into a poorly designed, repetitive hallway shooter. It beat the campaign in 11 hours, and if it weren't for the boring wandering around the u-boat, it would've been a few hours shorter. Speaking of wasting time, this game has probably the worst navigation and level design I've ever experienced. The levels are sometimes so convoluted you may end up spending 30 minutes just wondering where you're supposed to go next, only to find that the exit was some obscure part of the scenery that is completely random. There are also a ton of empty rooms with zero purpose, which only further throw you off. The latter half of the game is just ridiculously easy, you can camp in corners and take out every enemy one by one. There's not even a final boss to speak of, only a few bigger robots to take out before you get to walk towards General Engel and click her once to initiate a cutscene that takes her out. Wow, what a payoff.
I found the selection of weapons to be rather limiting. Only the maschinenpistole and laserkraftwerk were worth a damn, since the other weapons have terrible damage at longer distances, which wouldn't be a problem if the game didn't have so many hallways where you have to quickly kill nazis from afar.
The story has several of fun moments in it, like Bombate hooking up with Sigrun, or demented Hitler trying to hold auditions for his movie. However, the cutscenes are way longer than in the previous game, and it might not suit everyone to sit 10 minutes watching a single cutscene. They should've opted to shorter and more concise cutscenes like in New Order. Again, this is definitely away from time that could've been spent making more actual gameplay. I think most people don't play Wolfenstein for the plot anyway.
Then there are the technical issues with the PC release. People have reported several issues with the game crashing and not booting up. I had these same issues with my older PC setup. So be prepared, if you don't have the console option. They definitely rushed this PC version.
Overall I can't recommend New Colossus. It's a disappointing mess with less focus and less polish than in New Order. Only pick this one up if it's on sale.

[b]Pros:[/b]

+Visual part. I liked the environments, both from art and level design perspectives.
+ I like how they wrote BJ in the first part of the game. You can feel him trying his best not to literally fall apart while trying to help the cause.
+ Shotgun and Axe.

[b]Cons:[/b]

- I don't like the writing in general. I feel like the devs tried to "sit on two chairs" at the same time. On one hand, they condemn nazis for an inhuman amount of unjustified violence, on the other hand, they glorify the violence too. Yeah, I get it, nazis are the scum of the Earth, but the way that this violence towards them is being glorified gives me the creeps. I guess it's because all of this is being presented as a fun, albeit bloody, comedy.
- Humour is not funny.
- No likable characters that you can sympathize with. Even BJ "worked" for me just for the first part of the game.
- The game doesn't know what it wants to be from the story perspective. Is it a comedy? B-class trash and gorey story? A drama? 
- Game was broken by some patch that probably will never be fixed. Had to drastically lower the settings to be able to play and I still get the error. At least I didn't have crashes like other players. 
- AI. It's not that smart really, and it constantly spawns behind your back. Can't even imagine what it's like to play above normal difficulty (I played with a controller).
- The ending is rather disappointing.

[b]TL;DR[/b]

The message on the surface is good and understandable. But the way it's being told in this game feels like some corpo-dudes tried to cash in on that idea. And that is a real shame.

This is a fair bit more difficult than the previous entry, and is lacking in proper boss fights, but if you enjoyed the first game this is a great continuation.

Since the Golden Age of FPS in the 2000s-early 2010s (multiplayer games like CoD, BF, Halo, CS, L4D2, and story-driven games like HL, BioShock, Borderlands), first-person shooters have been extremely polished in terms of graphics, but the games all feel the same and lacking in flare. They focus more on multiplayer systems with lootboxes and progression systems meant to keep you playing in order to feel a sense of completion, rather than enjoyment. It's rare to find a shooter that even has a campaign these days, let alone one that isn't tacked-on for sales purposes on consoles.

There are thousands of shooters released but so few of them are actually any fun to play for more than a few hours, these days - the new DOOM games, Deus Ex, Metro, Bulletstorm, and Titanfall 2 to name a few. In my opinion, Wolfenstein II blows all of these out of the water. With the exception of Titanfall 2, Wolfenstein II manages to have some of the absolute best gunplay of the past few years, while simultaneously crafting a decent story and characters you actually care about. It looks great and the soundtrack is perfect, and it's one of the few FPS games I actually never ragequit. I highly recommend this series.

Wolfenstein II, The New Colossus. Wow, This game set me back into my seat for the first time in a while. Nothing is off limits in this first person shooter. The saga continues in this sequel with terror-billy being just... broken.  A symbol to the resistance in an alternate past in which Germany has taken over the USA, and a general all 'Merican badass, he nurses his wounds and gets back in the fight. 
  I will be honest: This is the first ever Wolfenstein game I have played.  It was a stark difference to the call of duty style of campaigns that I have become used to. I started out with an open mind, but was quickly reminded of a strong story line present in the franchise that I was unaware of. Not great for newcomers like myself. Blood and violence with a hint of steampunk inspiration made this game great. Bursting through the first few levels, building a sense of dedication to the characters and learning the weapons/gameplay theme when suddenly, PLOT TWIST. Let's kill off a main character in the most gruesome fashion possible, shall we? It was at this point I realized I was in for a strange dreamlike emotional roller-coaster. And it was. 
  Glorious character dialogue and independent styles of thought make the down time on the ship a genuine pleasure. Listening to the arguments, watching the genuine interactions happen, and getting to laugh like a mad man for the sex and toilet jokes. Simply excellent writing on the producers and designers' part. The evolving emotions and character arch for every individual team member is such a pleasure to behold. Good gameplay mechanics and weapon/equipment aids in the combat. Stealth options are a welcome addition to the game, if not difficult to use. 
  BLOOD. Like a level of blood spray and violence that I could nearly smell the metallic tinge through my monitor. I have played and seen some fucked up shit in my years, but DAMN. I actually had to take a break at one point and wonder if this was going to have a lasting effect on me. If this game were any bloodier, I would be sliding it chocolate and tampons under the bathroom door, asking if it needs another Midol.  Regardless, I pushed on to the finale because nazi's don't kill themselves. At a stage late game you are captured and
SPOILER ALERT
you are executed publicly. Then your head is revived and you are brought back to life with a cyborg body. This is about where the game lost me. I continued to play through and give it a decent effort, but all of my care for the characters and plot had been tossed aside. I lost faith in the story.  In the end I finished the game and was indeed happier that I had played it to completion, but I'm not itching to play the next one like I had hoped. The game lost me when it took a sharp left into fantasy land. 
  Do I suggest playing it? Yea, if you've got a stomach for gore and violence. Just don't expect to come out on the other end with a victorious smile and heartwarming feeling.
A true single player game experience, It's a bit like a cool, outrageous movie that you get to play in as well as watch. High production standard indeed and a lot of fun. Great value @steam sale.

Wolfenstein 2 has nice visuals and the gunplay is the best it has been in the series so far. The developer's reliance on cutscenes to move the story along is absolutely exhausting though. You aren't engaging the player with the story if you are repeatedly forcing them into a spectator role. It's not as though the plot requires a ton of exposition either; it's a pretty simple affair about killing Nazis. The cutscene quality itself is quite low and they are all over the place in terms of their tone. At one point, BJ and his pregnant girlfriend are mid conversation about him likely dying from internal organ failure in the next few weeks, when one of the side characters bursts out of the bathroom to derail the scene with a poop joke. The game had been building up to this conversation prior to this with BJ reflecting via monologue on his fears of leaving his girlfriend to be a single parent in a doomed world. I get the game is trying to be irreverent but I think you would need be brain damaged to believe this is effective storytelling. When the storytelling is done this poorly, the cinematics just feel like a chore, something you need to get through so you can go back to killing Nazis. I suppose every game is political in nature but such an overt display of politics seemed a little out of place for a game like this. There are some very questionable death defying turns in the plot, I won't get into spoilers but if you've played it you know what I mean. Hard to be invested in the story if death can be so easily averted. Suffice to say, having been worn down to dust, I skipped a couple cutscenes toward the end. 

The story takes the player to a variety of different locales (ex Nevada desert, Manhattan, New Orleans) but they all feel very much alike, featuring the same assortment of Nazi industrial corridors and crumbling cityscapes. This is a real shame as some of the locations could have been interesting. The combat is decent but becomes a bit stale after awhile. More weapons or a more diverse array of weapon modifications would be welcome. Additionally, the AI is dumb as rocks and it really lowers the game's difficulty.

[b] SPOILER FREE: [/b]
Loved this game. The story wasn't as good as The New Order in my opinion, but gameplay and graphics were far better. I'm glad there weren't any supernatural elements, as although I also loved The Old Blood, it was a spinoff. In the end, this is the same top-quality Id Software release I've come to expect from Wolfenstein or Doom titles. Also, there are tons of collectibles, so completionists could easily spend hundreds of hours with this one. All in all, this game is a blast and in my opinion there's nothing more satisfying than blowing the head off of a Nazi or KKK member with a fully automatic shotgun.

[b] SPOILERS: [/b]
[spoiler] My biggest problem with The New Colossus is the ending. There is no final boss battle, although there is a final level which is very difficult on higher difficulties. Still, it was very unsatisfying. In The New Colossus there was a satisfaction in killing Deathshead after a multi-stage boss fight that was difficult even on the Bring 'Em On difficulty. In this one, you assassinate Frau Engel by ambushing her on a talk show and burying a hatchet in her face and leveraging it to crack open her skull like a coconut. Visually, this is incredibly satisfying, but why couldn't it be after a boss fight where you, for example, fight your way through waves of Nazis she sends at you and make your way to her command station? Maybe the writers wanted to subvert expectations, but the result is an incredibly unsatisfying ending. In fact, as the credits rolled, I believe I audibly said "that's it?" [/spoiler]

[b] POLITICS: [/b]
Okay, this is the point where "Anti-SJW" types should probably stop reading. I'll start by putting my biases out there; I'm a socialist and an anarchist, so the anti-fascist themes here are gonna immediately make me like this game more, so I'll share some of the things I appreciated as a leftist. First of all, similar to how Jimi Hendrix was essentially in The New Order in the form of J, the Black Panther Party is in this game in the form of the Black Revolutionary Front, whose members make a home in the Evas Hammer (essentially your home base). The detail here is outstanding; the members have black berets, brown leather jackets, pins like the Black Power fist and even "Free Huey". Speaking of which, Huey Newton is even in this game under the name Huey Parks, and his character model is strikingly accurate. Next, we get to see Nazi America, which reminds me of the famous quote from James W. Wise, in which he wars that if fascism comes to America, it will not be identified with any shirt movement, nor with an insignia, but wrapped up in the American flag and heralded as a plea for liberty and preservation of the constitution. Now, none of that should offend anyone left of the far-right, but this next thing might. This game is incredibly feminist, with arguably the most moving character being the leader of the BRF, Grace Walker, who is a very complex character. She's a battle-worn and calloused strategist and orator who slowly opens up to the residents of Evas Hammer and becomes an incredible leader. I should also mention that I'm no liberal, and I think the corporate pandering game studios tend to do is annoying and counterproductive, as this pandering usually results in one-dimensional characters who are never wrong and have no flaws. This game has none of that, all the characters are the way they are for a reason. Grace Walker is leader because she's competent and intelligent, but has very obvious flaws that she works through. At one point she's even knocked down a peg and taught a lesson by Sigrun Engel, Frau Engels' daughter, who is a defector who clearly holds no loyalty to the Nazis and is even willing to help in killing her own mother for the greater good. Grace stubbornly calls Sigrun a Nazi, eventually resulting in Sigrun hitting Grace and giving a moving speech that teaches Grace to accept the fact that even Nazis can change and become good people. So no, Grace is no "girlboss" Mary-Sue.

Wolfenstein II new colossus doesn‚Äôt do anything special or unique especially when compared to the last entry in the series. But it is just plain simple fun.

I really don‚Äôt know how to start this review everything in this game feels so average that I have nothing to commend or criticize. I guess the visuals are good enough, both technically and stylistically I love the techno Nazi aesthetic and seeing everyday 60s Americans standing next to high super soldiers (and KKK members) is quite fun to see. The plot of the story isn‚Äôt great you basically just get shoved around a few different set pieces and locations until you end up on national television killing a general. Some of the set pieces are definitely worth experiencing [spoiler] (I really enjoyed the Hitler scene, especially when I got to just randomly kick him although‚Ä¶ why can‚Äôt we actually fight and kill him? Seems a bit like sequel bait) [/spoiler] most of the characters are fun to be around although I dislike the new rebellion leader, she just acts like an arsehole all the time and therefore must be the boss? 

As you might expect the Gameplay is quite fun and frantic, but it lacks a lot of depth. you get a few standard weapons and some rarer heavy weapons which usually aren‚Äôt worth using because they make you so slow. Enemies have a few different varieties but its mainly just upscaling normal dudes with power armour.  there was one big mech which showed up a few times and I literally have now idea if I was meant to kill it or not, it would shoot it for a few minutes then just run past it because nothing stopped me. Dual wielding is fun but its sometimes a hassle to equip. you have to press the key twice to pull out the weapon, the animation is slow and if you do any action, it cancels it. So, if you fail and stealth (oh yeah theirs stealth btw) and need a big gun quick it just isn‚Äôt worth doing. They game is also quite hard on the higher difficulties, but it does not get fairer most enemies have hit scan weapons so as soon as you are in line of sight you are taking damage. Honestly no matter how good at shooter you are just put it on medium its a lot more fun. 
 
Overall if you are bored and just want a quick Nazi shooting fest the Wolfenstein will do the job but don‚Äôt expect any depth or complexity with its systems or story.

A really fun game and a huge step up over New Order. The gameplay is a lot more fast paced, the stealth feels just better. I played both on the highest difficulty available and New Colossus feels infinitely more fair while still being very challenging. It could be compared to Doom 2016 nightmare being absolute dogshit stupid hard and Doom Eternal nightmare being very balanced and a good way to play the game for the first time. The performance also, IdTech 5, the engine that New Order uses, absolutely HATES AMD cards, which is what I use, even on the absolute minimum settings I was getting 10-15 fps average during combat, while here it stays above 60 always even when I max the settings. The story was absolutely phenomenal aswell, might honestly be the only game I didn't instantly skip the cutscenes in, all the characters were well written and just felt... alive, as if they were real people. The music aswell, another FANTASTIC soundtrack by Mick Gordon that perfectly compliments the gameplay, however I'm not sure about him returning for Wolfenstein 3 after the whole Doom Eternal situation.

Overall I'd recommend this game to absolutely anyone who can handle quite a few fucked up things (SPOILERS: [spoiler] Having to choose a friend to get their eyes and brain cut out of them while they're still conscious [/spoiler], [spoiler] Seeing a few beheadings [/spoiler], [spoiler] Having YOUR OWN head cut off[/spoiler]).

[h1]One step forward, two steps back. [/h1]
[b]Flawed combat experience holding on by excellent gunplay.[/b]

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
1. Gunplay feels even more satisfactory thanks to id Tech 6's excellent animation and sound system.
2. Adding three additional abilities(smash,stealth,height) to improve player's combat experience.
3. Amazing graphical fidelity. Eye candy level.
4. Very interesting plot and scenarios, a mixture of black comedy and serious tone, putting a smile on my face with every mission.
5. Solid voice acting.
6. Nazi ruled 1960s America is crazily intriguing.
7. You can kill Space Nazi again. (On Venus this time.) 
8. You've got the chance to kill Hitler himself!

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[b]1. Combat flow is NOT as great as The New Order, and here's why:[/b]

[b]a)Weapons are a downgrade compared to The New Order,[/b] Rocket Launcher attachment(Assault Rifle) now replaced by the Kampftpistole which I don't really care in The Old Blood, AR marksman rifle is now replaced by the Assault Rifle, and it's secondary plasma shot are removed completely. Pistol's burst shot mode is also removed. Grenades no longer explode on impact. Why Machinegames why?!!!!

[b]b)Some weapon upgrades are pretty lame[/b] like the submachine gun's nail rounds, making the bullet much slower(still spray like hell) and doesn't gain the impact effect it deserve like the nail gun in F.E.A.R. Molotov upgrade hurts the player more than the enemy. Overall it's trash.

[b]c)Player's movement system feels so underwhelming [/b]once the super solider and teleportation robot arrived; the super solider can head butt charge into the player so fast that the player's old-school FPS movement system doesn't give you anything to counter that. Same thing goes to the teleportation robot, the player just can't have any initiative against them thanks to the game's uninspired moment system.

[b]d)Enemy(again,the super solider and teleportation robot) doesn't seem to have a visible weak spot[/b], making them a pure bullet sponge to deal with, ruining the combat flow even more when the game decide to throw a lot of them at you at once. 

[b]e)Also since the grenades no longer explode on impact[/b] combined with it's weird physic behavior, using Tesla grenade to stop the mechanized enemy is more like rolling the dice.


2. The three new abilities are a welcome, but there's only one that's actually useful. The other two are simply lame af and didn't add a lot to the gameplay. Some could even make the game harder, like the Battlewalker ability...(Let's ignore all the cover and become a 7 foot tall target by double tap the space key!)

3.  The ending felt so weak compared to the ending of The New Order, there is not a solid conclusion and we never saw the revolution happens.(Actually we will never know if there IS a revolution until The Young Blood....that's lazy af)

4. Limited enemy variety....You will be shooting the same Nazi solider and robots over and over and over in the latter stage.

5. Weak enemy design....they mostly looks the same...felt like Machinegames are running out of ideas. 

6. Weak music compose compared to The New Order. 

7. Venus is super lame compared to the Moon base in The New Order. Everything is so brown and fuzzy...like a base built on diarrhea(COD vibe)....also it adds a cooling meter(something like a oxygen meter), breaking the combat flow even more.

8. Promoting Communism and SJW ideas in a video game all about killing space Nazi.(it's generation Z, so we got to came up something edgy and ridiculous for our audience. Guess Wolfenstein 3 will set in the Meta-verse.)

9. Can add more creativity in player's ability, Iike the ability in Rage 2. Guns„ÄÅMovement„ÄÅCombat flow is all it matters in a FPS game. Story should be the second place.


[h1]Final Verdict:[/h1]
 [b](Buy Now/ [u]Wait for Sale[/u]/ Rent/ Don't Touch)[/b]

[h1]-Wait for Sale (B+)[/h1]

Not only is it my favourite Wolfenstein game, but it overtook Dishonored and became my favourite game to date. A huge difference compared to New Order and Old Blood, but in a good way. My issues with the previous 2 Wolfenstein games were the awkward and unnecessary cut scenes as well as the almost non existence objective marker. However, Wolfenstein 2 was a masterpiece - no more awkward cut scenes and the objective marker is practically a way point now. In terms of customisation, players now get to decide which gun they wish to upgrade with limited attachments unlike the first 2 games where upgrades are fixed based on how the story flows. Game feels more like a semi open world now too and players also can do side missions that are given by NPCs. Seriously, if you haven't played this game, what are you even waiting for?

The New Colossus is more narratively driven and ambitious compared to the other Wolfenstein games. So it understandable why some people may not like this game as much because there could be an argument made about the narrative being tonally inconsistent and breaking up the gameplay pacing, especially if you consider that the Old Blood and the New Order had some pretty emotional and decent stories in them. To a certain extent the narrative/story does have occasional pacing issues and flaws; however, I enjoyed the narrative this game was going for and, gameplay wise, I notice no drastic changes or major difference from the New Order and the Old Blood. If anything, I feel that this game gives more freedom in level approach not forcing players into either all out stealth or guns blazing. Also I feel like this game has more replay value with more stuff to do after beating the main story. Personally, out of all the Wolfenstein games from Bethesda, this one is my favorite.

I loved new order, I quite enjoyed the old blood, but the new colossus turned out to be a major disappointment.  

This one turned into a slog, a grind I didn't even want to finish and the only reason I ever picked it back up to complete it was so I could uninstall it and never look at it again.  Now why is this?  How did this one turn out to be something I didn't like versus my pure enjoyment of the new order?  I think I figured it out - The enigma system.

In the new order you get to run and gun a lot, and it feels fantastic.  On occasion there are radio operators, if alerted they summon a never ending stream of enemies until you hunt them down and kill them off, this forces the occasional bit of stealth gameplay to try and assassinate them so you don't trigger the alarm.  Well in new colossus they added the enigma system where you have to collect codes from the radio operators to use in a minigame to unlock more stuff, which means they littered the game with more of these operators and have encounters with two of them much more frequently slamming the breaks on the incredibly awesome run and gun gameplay I liked so much from the first game.  

The story also feels very much disconnected, they keep trying to have these awesome moments, that just don't fit together as well as the previous games.  That is in addition to a small pile of absurd choices, the use of multiple nukes, and general tone whiplash.  There is still plenty to enjoy, but coming off the last two games I was expecting better than this.

My advice, go play new order and old blood, this one was kind of a miss.

Expanded alot on the first game, the combat is class A and the most fun part of the game. I was glad to see the game still enforcing different, yet viable choices of approaching a situation, without binding you permanently to one playstyle. Blazkowicz can be stealthy, crafty, or a straight up terminator mowing down enemies. The gadgets acquired later on don't hinder this flexibility, and instead enforce a playstyle that you've grown more familiar. However, I do wish that they were changeable, instead of being bound to just one.

The plot of the game was easy to follow, and continued the story well. I liked how the last game's resolution had an actual long lasting effect on our main character, and the first portion of the game really felt like he could collapse at any moment. The later outfit change was a downgrade though. Seriously Blazko, yellow leather jacket? Nothing compared to the rugged looking comfy brown jacket of the previous game. 

The lenght of the game is fine, about 11 hours of the main story. A bit of spoiler here, the game is still playable after the story, to finish some quests and get achievements. However due to the confusing layout of the hub area, and the map, I don't feel like playing these, even when the NPCs can be quite endearing.

I recommend this game to everyone who likes story driven FPS games, but please do play the first one first, to fully appreciate the story, and the changes in gameplay.
