I have a very long review to write for this that I will do elsewhere to explain how much of a joke this game is but for now I keep this to bullet points. After loving Wolfenstein: The New Order when I was younger I am honestly appalled by how bad this game is. I uninstalled the game at the time of writing this, so it is long after the games release and I never quite understood why this game got so many bad and mediocre reviews considering how well the first game was received. Well if the reviewers made any of the same points I have issues with then I finally understand.

Good:
- Graphics - In game is great and cutscenes often look like E3 presentations.
- Performance - runs very well while looking good, didn't notice any stutter at all even when running from my backup hard drive.
- Set pieces - some cool parts and areas
- Theme - Slightly cheating since it already had the universe, but its still a cool setting of a rag tag rebellion taking on an empire of uber nazis.

Bad:
- Story - Relies on unbelievable shock factor and wackiness yet tries to take itself very seriously elsewhere. If you are avert to SJW politics, some of the dialogue can be very jarring and not exactly subtle in what the writer's opinions are but it calmed down after the beginning enough for me to ignore almost entirely for this review (at least up to where I stopped playing).
- Movement - Running, jumping and climbing all rarely work, especially in combat
- Missions - Short and sometimes not even relevant to the story.
- Difficulty - Goes from being spammed in a corner and having grenades snipe you to death to walking through a level without losing any health. No consistency and only difficult due to mentioned broken game mechanics rather than the actual difficulty choices. 
- Stealth - Bare Bones yet arguably forced due to officers that will set off alarms inviting infinite enemies if they are alerted.
- Map - You will get lost all of the time. The map is bad and doesn't allow you to change floors. There is no compass or on screen marker and the objectives are nondescript like "go to character" or "get out". 
- Combat Feedback - the hit indicators for the player are very bad so you will find yourself dying because you didn't even know you were taking a lot of damage. Same goes for grenades that only seem to have an indicator if you are looking at them, which is just as useless and redundant as the game telling you that your eyes are open.
- Controls - Very finicky. Some have double functions that can't be undone such as TAB scrolling the journal menu and melee also throwing an axe which will randomly choose which it wants to do. Another is that it is very temperamental whether it allows you to pick up armour and ammo automatically. So in combat you will try to pick up armour manually because you are dying and the game will refuse to pick it up automatically and accidentally pick up an empty heavy weapon, then die.
- Weapon Swapping - Possibly the worst I've ever seen. Firstly it is very slow not allowing for the on the fly weapon changes that Doom does. But also the duel wielding system is horrific. You will find yourself swapping weapons 4 times before getting the combination that you want. Combine that with the swap speed and you will die to this a lot. Also the weapon wheel is terrible too.
- Music - Its good because its Mick Gordon. I'ts bad because its horribly implemented with full levels having no music and very quiet ambient noises, even in battle. The mixing is pretty bad too considering Doom had a dynamic orchestra that followed the players actions.
- Side Quests - inane nonsense like feeding a pig potatoes, literally.
- Shooting - Sadly it just doesn't feel good. Weapons have no punch to them and feel like BB guns and the ADS covers so much of the screen and wildly shakes it is more of a challenge to use than hip fire. Also the game fluctuates in brightness a lot and at points you won't be able to see enemies at all until you see their muzzle flashes.

When I Stopped Playing: 
Near the end of the New Orleans level. Got charged by an enemy and knocked my heavy weapon out of my hand (annoying mechanic regardless). Spent 10 seconds looking for the gun only giving up since it despawned. Run away and pick up another of the same gun just to be immediately charged again and spammed while I was on the ground due to the slow stand up animation. The enemy wasn't even difficult, the death was purely from looking for a despawned weapon and the enemy spamming me while I couldn't move, a combination of previously mentioned issues. No thanks. I'd just beaten a miniboss by walking away slowly from its awful AI and was feeling that the game was running out of cards to keep me playing.

Rating: 5.9/10       (cant bring myself to give it a 6)
It is playable and can be enjoyable between the mess of game design. But the frustrating issues are so frequent and the variety of problems is so huge that it really isn't worth playing unless you truly don't care for your time or are one of those people that will defend any game that you have spent money on since your souls are monetarily linked no matter how bad the game is. 

Essentially the only thing that this game does well is graphics and performance. Other than that it pretty much fails in all aspects of game design making it a frustrating experience with no actual reward or satisfaction from playing it. I will have to replay Wolfenstein: The New Order to see if I was a stupid child for liking it. But until I am proven wrong, If you want the uber nazi killing experience just play The New Order, or better yet Doom Eternal.

I've played this game twice now. Thought it was really good the first time. Really did not like it the second time. 

Getting the obvious out of the way first, it's pretty buggy, as said by pretty much every other negative review.
At first it really wasn't that bad, but after a while, it really does prevent you from having fun the way you want to, which is kind of a big deal when you consider that this game lets you approach each level in a more open-ended sense. 

The gameplay is fine for the most part. Again, there are bugs, but when your either using a stealth or guns-blazing approach the game does FINE. I thought the weapon upgrade system was actually pretty cool, but I found the contraptions to be pretty underwhelming honestly (except the constrictor, which is actually kind of fun). It feels like they promise WAY more than you can actually get out of them. Additionally, the difficulty ranges between piss easy to borderline ironic (both of my playthroughs were on difficulty 6/7, 7 being hardest). With this in mind, you can pretty much forget realistically beating the game on the hardest difficulty, which is the exact same as the second hardest minus being able to save. Speaking of which, the checkpoint system in this game is pretty disappointing. It works more on a manual save system, so you either cheese the game by saving ALL the time with kind of bad loading times or restart each level on death.

Lastly, the plot. Overall it has its ups and downs. Obviously being able to take down Nazi's is great, but the game presents this idea of a "revolution" but never shows us this "revolution" outside of the submarine (except once, but then those people get in the submarine too). It promotes a grand sense of scale without actually backing it up. There are genuinely cool moments in the plot, and the areas you visit are also pretty cool, but these moments are broken up with some corny and hilariously bad dialogue. Hearing BJ philosophically whine to himself is unintentionally funny in ways I don't think the developers intended. Other than that, there are some seriously shit plot holes, and the ending is not only abrupt, but super disappointing. Even worse, instead of just letting that ending set up a new game, they just give you the aftermath in a serious of PICTURES, and then skip TWENTY YEARS to the plot of the next game (which has its OWN issues, but that's there, not here). All of this makes what you just played feel borderline POINTLESS. It's kind of mind-blowing to be totally honest.

I know people enjoy this game, I know friends who enjoy this game, and that's totally cool, but if you're looking for something more tightly knit, I would genuinely try either one of the newer DOOM games first (same publisher), and even THEN, I'd still recommend something else. This ain't it.

"If you want a vision of the future, imagine a boot stamping on a human face - forever." - George Orwell.

Imagine that quote as a game. That game is the new Wolfenstein series by Machinegames, from 2014 's The New Order onwards. If you like linear story driven first person shooters, please do yourself a favor and play The New Order and its prequel The Old Blood. Pre-Doom 2016 I would have said those were the most visceral, action packed shooters I have ever played.

The New Colossus, a name Wolfenstein 2 shares with the poem at the base of the Statue of Liberty, completely eschews the adage "less is more" in favor of the tongue in cheek "but more is also more". Its a sequel in the truest sense of the word: it takes the foundation laid down by The New Order and refined by The Old Blood, and just dials things up, keeps dialing them up, hits the point where it should probably stop dialing things up, then cranks the dial straight past 11 and keeps going. In some ways, this is a good thing. We don't get a lot of solid linear story driven first person shooters nowadays, and its great to see Machinegames... uh... stick to their guns and just deliver more of what the first game offered.

But where The New Order sort of toyed with the line between style and substance, the macabre and the comedic, while keeping its separate elements in a near perfect harmonious balance The New Colossus suffers from its excesses. Don't misunderstand, the game is actually riotously funny and equal parts dark and gut-wrenching, but rather than delicately holding the line between these two disparate tones the game is almost bi-polar in how poorly it handles switching between the two. This comes to a head near the climax of the game where the schzophrenic tone begins to resonate with the narrative, where even the main character begins to question whether what he in the context of the game is experiencing is real or some sort of twisted dream. As the player, you progress ever forward, more and more with this gut wrenching sensation that the second act of the game does not feel... right. Like a fever dream where there is something just wrong and you cannot quite put your finger on it.

Its possible that Machinegames will pull off a narrative coup de grace in the third act (not Youngbloods, which is more of a side adventure similar to The Old Blood, but a true Wolf 3) by building this tonal dissonance into the story or plot (and part of me suspects they will) but only time will tell.

There was a lot of hooplah and controversy regarding the "SJW" elements of Wolfenstein 2, but like many of these twitter controversies it is overblown and can really only be played up by ignoring any of the subtlety (yes there actually is some of that) between character interactions and sometimes outright ignoring major plot points. Yes, Nazi's are like... super bad. I think we can all get on board with that. Wolfenstein 2 goes through really great pains to make sure you the player see the Nazi's are just people through any number of collectible readables scattered through the maps (postcards to family, friends, loved ones) or through little interactions between NPCs to even having one of your gang of outcasts provide perspective that these are not monsters, just people that do monstrous things.

Nazi's are also predominantly white, protestant, upholding the "Aryan ideal". Naturally, when recruiting a resistance movement against the Nazi's you're going to pick up all the people Nazi's find subhuman, which if it were a ven diagram would likely overlap with what people would consider a "diverse" cast of characters (multi-racial, differently abled, multi-religious, etc) but it makes perfect sense given the actual context of the game. I feel this game does in fact benefit from some distance from the zeitgeist, in 2018, that the game launched into. Bethesda's marketing leaned into it which naturally resulted in a backlash against it, and gamers were obligated to divide into the "pandering to the SJW" camp and the "OMG they're FREAKING NAZIS" camp which seems to taint the conversation surrounding this title to this day.

As for the game itself, it is a damn masterpiece of production. The visuals are stunning, but the game easily pumped out 100+ FPS thanks to its Vulkan renderer. Mick Gordon and company have assembled an absolute gem of a soundtrack. The character voice acting and animation is absolutely superb, some of the best I have ever seen. There is plenty of environment and enemy variation, the locations are rich and varied and although the basic types of enemies don't fundamentally change, their appearance matches the environment. Its just little things that draw you deeper and deeper into the world.

Levels generally follow the same flow of The New Order. You are inserted into a level from a hub world, and have the ability to sneak and silently dispatch enemies. Inevitably, at some point, you will be spotted, an alarm will sound and you drop the charade of sneaking and mow down waves of Nazi's as you beeline for the nearest Nazi Commander to dispatch and end the alarm. Glory kills are present, but unlike Doom 2016, you get no invulnerability during the takedown animation, limiting their utility.

The game does have some other flaws, small but annoying. The game does a poor job telegraphing where you're receiving damage from (or that you're even taking damage) so in a hectic firefight you can think you're doing ok only to suddenly see the screen go red and a few seconds later drop dead from a hail of Nazi gunfire. This combined with some bizarre dificulty spikes (The Courthouse) can result in some staggeringly difficult sections of gameplay. The level design in the first half the game is definitely weaker than the second, and weapon balance (especially after upgrades) can leave something to be desired.

None of the flaws are enough to actually stop me from wholeheartedly recommending this game to literally anyone that will listen. If you've been looking for a solid linear, story driven FPS hit, play all the new Wolfenstein games (excepting Youngblood, which I haven't played but heard handles things quite differently). The New Colossus definitely benefits from playing prior games in the series, although it can certainly hold up on its own. Just be warned that you're getting onto a weirdly melancholic ride for what outwardly presents itself as a meathead shooter. There are more brains on display than one might think at first, its just that the brain is all ****ed up.

Wolfenstein The New Colossus is not a game about shooting nazis. It is a cry for help from some deeply disturbed people who, with wide-eyed, loud, manic glee, INSIST this is just a game about shooting nazis as though it were the only game ever to feature nazis and shooting. If Joker had gotten up on Murray's stage and started telling an aristocrats joke, it would have sounded like this game.

I have been shooting nazis in video games for decades. From Hitler's head exploding cartoonishly in Bionic Commando to countless Medal of Honor games to putting three or four rifle rounds through the Fuhrer's crotch in the various cash-grab Sniper Elite mediocrities, I have a great deal of experience in shooting nazis in video games, and even in the heights of some of the most sadistic displays of hateful violence you could feasibly fit in an WW2 game, Wolf:TNC is absolutely not what it has ever looked like. Wolf:TNC is deeply ugly, aesthetically and spiritually, and manages to make a decades old tradition of heroically shooting nazis in video games into something disgusting, nauseating, and alien. No gamer should ever feel alienated while shooting nazis in video games and it is to Wolf:TNC's great shame that it manages to do so.

The people behind this game have put their myriad psychological issues on display for the world to see here and nothing good can come of indulging them in this. (I saw Wolfenstein Youngblood. Nothing good DID come of supporting this sort of filth.) After forcing you to sit through obnoxious, ugly, pointless nudity or scenes of a father abusing his family that last longer than whole stages of better games, the people behind this will insist loudly, with an elevated uptalk accusatory tone completely devoid of self-awareness, "It is just a game about shooting nazis, just like Indiana Jones! You don't love nazis, do you?" No. It's not like Indiana Jones. Get help. And get away from me.

Please, do not get involved with this game, even and especially if you enjoyed the previous two. Do not embrace this revolting ugliness, this thoughtless tantrum lashing out so viciously, defacing one of gaming's founding franchises. Gaming is absolutely full of countless far better opportunities to blast nazis. There is no excuse for creating something so profoundly ugly.
Would be nice if the developers would fix the frame-rate issues. It's unplayable even when lowering just about everything. Makes no difference.   Refund please!

This game has one of the best appearance you can get and yeah you need some better hardware for it too, mainly GPU with 4GB+ of VRAM. I really don't recommend playing this, if you have below 4GB of VRAM, you will probably get a message, that your graphics driver has ran out of video memory and the game is going to run like shit. I have 4GB of VRAM and when I set graphics preset higher than HIGH, I was getting this and the game was looking blurry and the fps were like max. 60, when there was absolutely no action, but playing on HIGH was okay in my case, except for some places, where I got some little fps drops below 60.

I really like the futuristic looks with the retro theme. As for the story, it's great too. Gameplay has several interesting mechanics with easy and simple control. A little negative thing for me, was that at a little longer distances, the bullet spread was kinda random, especially with pistol, so if you were trying to play stealthy, sometimes it was hard to shoot the enemie's head on the first good.

The game itself can be quite a difficult challenge for you, if you play on higher difficulties and game offers several of them. I have played the second hardest and enemies could sometimes kill you just with two bullets. Once you complete the storyline, you will unlock the toughest challnge of the game. "Mein Leben!" is practically same as "I am death incarnate!" just with one differance and that's one life for the whole game.

I don't know what else to write, so I'll put here a brief review, which is 9/10 for me.
Great graphics, great story, great game play.

Ok so there's the thing. Its a good game. It really is. Its still as fun to shoot nazi's as in the previous game.  I think the weapons are fun and the levels are beautiful. 

But. 
The tone has changed. Its not the grim story we are used to. Instead, they added some humour into the game and tried to adress some serious issues. Some might find it a funny or interesting twist. And although I recognize they are imporant themes; I hate it. I chose the for the wyatt guy to live as I liked his story in the new order. In this game, he becomes some weird vision having, drug using dim wit. They make a point of making him unfit to lead in favour of some chick you have never seen before. From a friend I  heard Fergus gets an uncoperative bionic arm. I mean.. that form of humor just doesn't fit with wat I expected or wanted from this title. BJ starts to have psychological problems. A logical concquence of the things he has been through, but it feels off. The defeatist tone of the hist voicelines rubs me the wrong way. He is the hero, the man who liberates and destroys nazis wherever he goes. I love stories and I play a lot of story heavy games, but something about the cutscenes, the tone and the way the characters are portrayed just ruins the game for me. I realize this is deeply personal but I thought I'd write it down so someone else might find it an usefull perspective. 
Also they changed anya's face drastically :( 

In the end, its a fun game and besides the points outlined above, I mostly have fun :-) So go play! Buy in sale i'd say.

Edit after few more hours of gameplay: Lighting and graphics are awesome. Story doesn't get any better. You end up watching hitler being and old man and a just plain bizzare display of slapstick by him. Farting, vomiting and more. Its supposed to be funny but I didn't think it was. Its way too much and bizzare for me. But then the cutscene was over and I was shooting nazi's again. 
I don't think I'll buy the next game in line though.

Edit after 2 more hours: I got game freezes for some reason. No problems untill now. Changed my review recommendation to 'not recommended'.

Amazing Game

I hate to not recommend a game about killing Nazis... And yet here we are. The game is too short for starters... and I got caught off-guard by the last mission without having most side quests... I just couldn't believe it was already the last mission until I saw the credits roll... and then yes you can complete the side quests afterwards... But it just made me realize why they were there in the first place... Its just filler. Most side quests are reusing the same maps (although sometimes modified) and they just feel boring and repetitive. So much of this game design seems to be built around dragging out the game... Boring side quests in the U-Boat that rely on the fact you will just waste time going from point A to B because it can feel like a maze(at least at first). And tons of Assassination missions that really feel like more of a chore than a pleasure... And also there is a Enigma Code mini-game required to unlock the Assassination missions... Which is practically impossible to fail... At first I was like why the hell did they even put this in here... And then it dawned on me... To drag out the game for an extra 20 minutes... Also even after having finished the game I realized I did not even have enough Enigma Cards to unlock much more than half the Assassination missions... Which would force me to replay levels, assuming I wanted to complete everything... But after doing 5 Assassination missions I just didn't care anymore...  And last but not least ''an alternate timeline'' that you can play by choosing to save a different NPC at the beginning of the game... But the differences are marginal. If you take out the couple side missions I did, the cutscenes and the cinematics... The main story probably took me less than 6 hours to complete. OK so enough about the length of the game and repetitive missions... Gameplay was OK at best. Rather than give you a ton of Nazi Soldiers to mow down... Most of the time you are fighting a couple at a time that are fully armored and even in Mech Suits which at times forces you to use the overpowered and heavy energy weapons in order to take them out... For someone like me, who comes from the original Wolfenstein 3D game this feels so different. I liked the fact that you can dual wield almost anything and the weapon upgrades you can unlock are nice... But that`s the only thing I enjoyed a lot about this game. Everything else was mediocre... And I could have recommended it had the main story been 2-3 hours longer... But this just felt so intentional and lazy... and its a shame because the game looks good visually... Although there are way too many dark tunnels and night time sequences... And the best looking level... Which happens to have a bunch of KKK walking around... You can't even fight in it. I just kept thinking to myself  ''I wish this was a level in Hitman'' so I could assassinate everyone lol. Thank goodness I bought this on sale... Because I would be livid had I paid full price for it.

[h1] Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus - 7.75/10 [/h1]
[b] Playthrough Length - [/b] 7 hours

[b] Plot and Dialogue: [/b] 8/10, 7/10
[b] Setting and Art Design: [/b] 9/10
[b] Soundtrack: [/b] 8/10
[b] Graphics: [/b] 7/10 
[b] Gameplay and Sound Design: [/b] 9.5/10, 8.5/10

[b] Plot and Dialogue: [/b]
The dialogue in this game definitely takes a set back from the previous entry. The characters have good interactions and the new characters are welcome (except one). I didn't like one of the characters as I felt it was pushing a bit too much of a particular agenda which really annoyed me with a game like Wolfenstein. Ultimately, the Wolfenstein plot doesn't matter a helluva lot considering we're focusing on killing Nazis. 

[b] Setting and Art Design: [/b]
The setting continues to excel as we can really see the fusion of American and Nazi architecture. One of the most shocking scenes involves Washington D.C. and Manhattan, which you'll find out later why. The Evas Hammer does feel pretty cool as well, so they did a great job in that regard. 

[b] Soundtrack: [/b]
The soundtrack really gives me DOOM vibes as it really kicks in when you're ruthlessly slaughtering tons of Nazis. Helps to get that blood rushing. 

[b] Graphics: [/b]
This game is a graphics hog. It takes so much VRAM and for the amount of VRAM that is used, it doesn't look that good. It does look good though. Be careful with HDR as when I tried to use that in Wolfenstein, the game dropped to 10 FPS. Not a good look. 

[b] Gameplay and Sound Design: [/b]
The gameplay is the most important aspect of Wolfenstein. It continues to excel in this installment and offers you even more weapons and ways to go about killing the Nazis. Enemy class types are very distinct and provide their own unique challenges which is very good. There is also an additional side mode that allows you to hunt down the higher ups of the Nazis even after the story is complete so you have even more Nazi killing fun. Sound design is also an improvement from the last entry.

[b] Final Notes: [/b]
While not as strong as the first entry, it is still a game that I would highly recommend for all to play.

And of course they throw hints and tid bits of ID's identity and their history all around. For instance. BJ is in fact from Mesquite TX. The very home of the dev studio. 
It's been a great game so far and I'm not even done but I know I will play it again and again every year.

A slog of repetitive missions tied together by a compelling overarching (but crudely paced) plot. Missions have a difficulty mix of overly-easy to sudden shoot-heal/reload-shoot game play, and a few weapons that don't have much uniqueness compared to other shooter games.

I struggle to find reason this game should be bought other than on a good sale ($11 w/ expansion during the thanksgiving 2021 sale). While the plot to the main story is compelling, it's slow and clumsy. This is a game that could be easily compacted down into the space of a movie runtime, but is interrupted with constant battles of grinding the same few types of enemies over and over and over. Grinding being a keyword, because every bout with enemies feels repetitive and samey despite slightly different environments. Additionally, Wolfenstein operates on a very narrow track of what weapons should be used when.

Tight corridors = shotgun (If you run out, go to SMG)
Heavy unit = Grenade launcher (when you run out go the rifle)
Anything else = Rifle (when you run out, SMG)
Stealth = The pistol and SMG, which are the only weapons that can be suppressed. Having a suppressor option feels out of place for the game though, and I almost never chose the stealth route. Enemies act oblivious until they identify you, then behave omniscient once alerted.

Heavy weapons exist (dropped by what are essentially mini-bosses), which early on are absurdly powerful. They do not persist in your inventory, are dropped at the end of levels and when traversing ladders. Around 3/4ths progress through the game though, your core set of inventory weapons are likely upgraded and (conditionally) better, especially when you upgrade the Sturmgewehr (the assault rifle) to have 'Armor Piercing'.

As mentioned, the pistol and SMG have a suppressor option, and the assault rifle has a armor piercing option. This is part of the games upgrade system, where upgrade kits hidden across the levels can be used to improve your weapons. While there aren't many upgrades (3 per weapon, and 6 weapons not including grenades and not including the alternate special weapon you don't get), it becomes very obvious which upgrades you should go for first.

****Spoilers below****

On the story front, little feels accomplished by the end. One of the big baddies is offed, but it felt like I was just grinding through the same enemies to get to that point and it felt like a somewhat hollow victory. As I previously mentioned, I *want* the main cast of characters to be successful and to make progress, but at the same time they're an annoying burden. It feels like it was attempted to have the depth of characters you'd find in 'The Last Of Us' (knowing the story of Joel from pre-clickers to the end of the game), but without any real reason to care for them.

And with minor and major story points, this persisted. The best example being Caroline Becker, (spoiler) she dies early in the game...but I really couldn't care. I played the first game years ago, but she was forgettable to me. Will talks to her through thought/internal dialogue very frequently for the first half of the game, but then due to a situation that essentially boils down to the story not having room to progress and needing a longer run time, Will no longer has a reason to continue this inner dialogue focused on Caroline and shes brushed aside.

This circles back to what I initially said. I find the main plot compelling: Wolfensteins world, *some* of the characters, and where we are story wise in this game. It's just that the points that are interesting could be condensed to little more than three hours and you'd still have the complete picture.

One other aside is that the main baddie feels like a dollar store knock off of a wannabe Joker. You hate the baddie for their actions, they act maniacal and insane, do crazy things, but it just seems weird and lazy from the writing perspective when you step back and look at it as a whole.

It's entertaining at first, interesting and fun at times, but mostly boring and grindy for the rest. Hard to recommend other than on a steep sale and with no other games to play.

Quite the hodge-podge of a game. Honestly it has some great quality of life improvements from the last installation in the series, and yet I feel like the messaging and story are confusing and weak. 

Its hard to relate to BJ Blazkowicz. His whole identity is focused on killing Nazis, and he has little personality outside of that. He is dehumanized in a lot of ways. The end sequence for this game is extremely absurd, his pregnant baby momma being a front line soldier, and his proposal to her over the dead body of his arch nemesis. For someone whose supposd to represent America as a bastion of liberty, he's relatively mindless. 

Definitely worthwhile if you enjoyed the first game, but don't be too hopeful as far as story. 

That being said, the game is fun, and the different stages of the main characters life are interesting. He goes from being in a wheelchair to other circumstances.

NOTHING like the first one.

I gotta be honest, I dragged myself to finish this one, and I like the series. The levels are quite boring, basically your dark corridors, rundown building, sewers. You think you will get to visit interesting locations like Manhattan, New Orleans or even Venus, but that's just for the first minute, the rest is, you guessed it, dark corridors, rundown buildings and sewers. 
Even the gunplay seems like a downgrade from the previous.Everyone is wearing damn armor and are bullet sponges. Your big and imposing weapons feel like bb guns, if you want to deal real damage you have to carry a huge weapon that slows you down to a sloth level. Waves of enemies will swarm you and if you don't take the stealth way chaos will ensue and you will most likely die from something. Did I mention you get knocked down? Yep, knocked down by enemy hitting you, by explosions, by dogs, by the wind. If you are hoping for an engaging firefight get ready to crawl on the floor a lot.
Is there anything positive about this game? I guess. The graphics are better, the music is good, didn't encounter any bugs, so I guess you could say it's competent. The melee kills are nice and rewarding. The cutscenes are interesting and build a compelling but weird story. But all that could not get me to care much about the game, I was too busy running through sewers shooting bullet sponges.

epic nazi killing simulator

!Minor spoilers ahead!

Third installment in the reboot, the core of the game is the same: killing nazi's in all forms and shapes, including some KKK-ers. The game drops all reasonable "what-if" stuff and just goes full fantasy with things such as stitching heads back to bodies or a senile Hitler that hangs out on Venus and wants to make a movie about Terror Billy (you). Oh and half the US gets atom bombed.

You again have 2 ways to kill everyone: Rambo or Sam Fisher. While going stealth is a bit more difficult, its rewarding to finish a district or a section without setting of any alarms. The AI does have some minor quirks so getting spotted happens more often than not. You do have an arsenal of weaponry at your disposal that even can be upgraded along the way.

While the gameplay is fun and some of these 'what-ifs' are funny, the story as a whole feels rushed, incoherent and maybe a tad incomplete, especially towards the end. The final boss fight is relatively difficult but it never felt like a true boss-fight as its just against robots. Actually facing off with the main baddy - Frau Engel - is a fun sequence though.

It also feels short. You don't expect length and depth like in an RPG, but the game setups some elements (like a homebase on Eva's Hammer) that make you expect a longer duration. However, after 10 hours you're pretty much there. There is some artificial lengthening (not like that) in terms of collectibles (toys, tablets, tapes, cousin Niko ...) and killing Ubercommanders. 

The latter is locked behind a non-explained minigame (I actually had to lookup how it works, but that might be me) until relatively late in the game so make sure to pick up Enigma codes along the way. You'll also have to farm some districts (Penthouse is your friend) to get enough of those codes to unlock all Ubercommanders. Its a fun addition to the game - and a reason to revisit certain locations - but it could have been woven more into the main story in my opinion.

All in all, definitely the best of the 3 so far (New Order, Old Blood and this) even if its for the unlocked framerate alone.

Good game, though lacking in some of the areas that I thought New Order did really well in. Shooting still feels nice, but there are gameplay mechanics thrown in there (like the stilts) that are either pointless or simply not fun to use. The game also leans a little more into the "wacky" nature of its alternate-history setting, with more outlandish characters and interactions that lead to a more comedic tone (I was a fan of The New Order's grit, personally). Even still, I'd recommend picking this up on sale as it usually goes for pretty cheap.

This is a decent shooter and nowhere near as short as some would have you believe. Those people are skipping the things that separate this from the crowd.
Mouse input is good. FOV is adjustable to good levels and it's a great looking game that runs very smoothly until ...

... it crashes or freezes.

Unfortunately I can't recommend it. I must have had 40+ crashes and freezes during my play time. I tried multiple variations of settings. Much googling. Nothing worked really. I think towards the end, I may have struck on something by raising the pool size (image streaming in settings) but it still crashed. Crashes exiting levels. Crashes transitioning to cut scenes. Freezes just bloody looking around. Constantly having to end task through task manager. In the end I'd just had enough. I will put my specs for reference. Ymmv but I rarely have games crash on me and I have never had a game crash on me the way this game has. It's in a league of it's own.

Also, although cut scenes are skippable ( ... not immediately mind, as levels have to load .. ), there are in game "events" that may as well be cut scenes (since all you usually do is press one button at the end) that can't be skipped and go on for f****** ages. First time around is bad enough but that second play through, those are gonna be torture.

What I will say is despite all that, I plugged away at it (as you can see from my play time) because it is a very enjoyable shooter when it works.

It won't stop crashing, working at 40 to 80fps, mind that it uses the same engine as Doom 2016 and Doom Eternal, I finished both on the same rig.
This makes no sense, so I'm throwing it under "bad optimization", as always with these newer games... If they pay no mind to the 2GB V-Ram "plebs", I pay no mind to wasting my money, then!
pretty cool ngl

I like it a lot; there's a lot to like - You don't even get to the title until you fight a bunch of Nazis for over ten minutes, so you've earned it.  Whereas the menu and gameplay was pretty much identical in the other two, this one's interface is totally different, including key binding and/or lack of same.  F'rinstince, you can't toggle the crouch command in Colossus - you could in New Order and Old Blood. Toggling it makes it easier - hold down the key 'til you wanna walk upright again, or stand up. It's easier than keeping track of whether you're in a crouch somewhat hidden, or exposed, but able to run much faster.  I find it easier, anyway.  This one's gameflow is different as well - things seem to be just a little more relaxed; you're not always having to hurry up and get to the next checkpoint; you do that often enough, then the game's finished.  I don't like it any less or more, it's just different. What I've seen so far holds a bunch of promise.  I just hope all of the Nazi Assholes end up dying.  They need to, and this is the third strike.  Kill 'em all.     I'm out. Bioman.

First note: probably would help to play the first of this series going in; took awhile to figure out and really feel the impact of what's happening, and can be overwhelming to drop right into (especially w/ how this game begins).

Once you get past that though, while it has flaws, this game is an excellent exercise in making you feel the rightful disgust you should for Nazis, and depending on the difficulty mode you choose you get to either experience a simulacrum of the terror, anger, and frustration fighting these monstrous ideologues would surely bring (higher difficulties), or it can be a perfect vehicle for power fantasies of taking out hoards of them instead as an embodiment of the very thing the worst among them always feared.

Past the symbolic stuff it isn't much more than a sort of action-shooter with some horrifying and suspenseful elements that gives you some optional collectable/completionist options to pursue, but that can be a pretty fun (if not always intellectually stimulating).

The New Colossus is a masterpiece in many ways. The gameplay, story, visuals, and music come together to create an unforgettable experience. The game uses its setting extremely well, exposing fascist ideologies and simultaneously celebrating diversity in a masterful move.

The main storyline takes about 10 hours, with quite a lot more left afterwards as you chase down the "√úberkommando" all over the US. The story does get ridiculous at some points, but never stops being fun. If you like FPSs and hate nazis, this is a must see.

I waited until this was on sale... but it didn't deserve the wait.  
If you're looking for a really good FPS with an amazingly decent story-line (good but not intrusive cut-scenes story-board) and extraordinary immersive play, then buy this game.  
(I don't leave many reviews but this one's worth it.)

I admittedly have yet to finish this game and I plan on powering through it at some point, but I doubt my opinion is going to change. I don't really like it. There's multiple annoyances with the way this game is designed that rubs me the wrong way at every turn, I feel like a moment doesn't go by that I'm not being annoyed by another aspect of the game.

It's going to sound nitpicky as hell, but here are some of the reasons I'm finding it difficult to pick up this game and play it.

-  This game suffers from triple AAA budget syndrome where they're trying to make a cinematic experience alongside a video game, and it sucks. The camera work in the cut-scenes feels meandering. The dialogue is rattled off inorganically as if these characters are reading verbose scripts and not having a conversation. And while I do not subscribe to this idea that this game is "Woke" and therefore it's bad, it does sound kind of preachy at times where it feels like the writers are trying to tell you some kind of message instead of a story. 

- On the subject of the story, the game feels like it's trying to be Inglorius Basterds. But it sucks. Just lean harder on the grind-house violence and make me feel disgusted but justified with what I do to the Nazis and make the story focus on that.

-Blazkowicz is just majorly cringey. You're unfortunately given access to his isolated thoughts and he waxes lament like he's writing lyrics for a country song. He speaks slowly and depressingly to himself at random intervals throughout the game, often about some woman character I've already forgotten. And he's doing this right after he hacked a Nazi's face to pieces with a tomahawk. It's just stupid, unrealistic, and it feels like the developers are elbowing you in the side saying "Hey, you should empathize with this guy, he's not just a blood-crazed nazi killer, he has feelings"

- The Heads Up Display is ugly and it's especially heinous when trying to use the hint system to see where you're supposed to go. The icon that's supposed to highlight your destination is like a transparent off-white diamond that's incredibly small and only stays on the screen for like 2 seconds so you'll miss it if you blink. I mean fuck, I'm 31, I'm not an old man but this game is making me squint like I'm in my 60's. 

- Level design is bad. This goes in tandem with the HUD problem. It's not that the environments don't look good, is just that they're not intuitive to navigate. When you arrive in the ruins of New York City you basically need to keep guessing which direction you're supposed to go because there's no obvious little indications that the pile of rubble over yonder has a trail underneath it that takes you to the next area. When you're in the U-Boat everything is just a labyrinth of hallways and metal catwalks that there's not a single memorable area in the zone.  

- The actual gameplay itself is mediocre at best. It's functional enough for some people to find it fun. It's not quite on the boomer-shooter level of high octane run-and-gun gameplay like Dusk or Doom: Eternal, and it's not slow and methodical like Call of Duty, it's somewhere in the middle. If you were looking for a FPS game with a story, I'd recommend about 10 other games before I ever recommended this one.

And the worst part is that killing nazis should be fun, but this game is a total snooze fest. Play something else.

A mediocre Shooter with some nonsense social justice messaging.
Firstly, we have nothing new here really. The graphics are decent, the gameplay is good, and the story is decent. No more, no less. A fairly limited amount of different weapons and gameplay options make replay unlikely. Some cutscenes shine, while others are uninteresting.
Secondly, the social justice messaging is just juvenile. An overweight nazi is insulted by her mom, then turns sides and has sex with the black resistance fighter. The black panther party are the heroes, and their female leader breastfeeds a child on camera, and acts like an alpha strong personality, while her husband is just a weak cuck. Really? Not impressed by this lazy, pandering writing. I believe the protagonist even says something about "evil white " people. This messaging culminates in a pregnant, topless woman gunning people down and saving the male hero.... Really? What an embarrassment. The messaging is pretty clear, and uninteresting.

A controversial second entry in the new Wolfenstein universe, one that I personally enjoyed immensely, but others had some issues with. Granted, while there are some changes in gameplay and directions in the story that are...questionable, to say the least, if you like wild, extremely fast an dangerous yet rewarding gameplay, wacky and over-the-top characters and a plot about killing Nazis that can go almost anywhere and do almost anything, this is the game for you. BJ Blazkowicz, currently the main protagonist of the series, is humanized beyond my expectations in Wolfenstein II, to my immense delight, as these aspects of the story are much of why I love these games. I have a great deal of attachment to the other characters as well, especially Anya, Fergus, Grace and Horton, and thought they made cutscenes, which I'm normally not a big fan of, more enjoyable. The gameplay is a step above the previous entries, being quicker and deadlier than the previous entries, more akin to the new DOOM games, with the (admittedly clunky) ability to dual-wield different combinations of weapons. Would recommend to people who are not necessarily looking for a grounded experience, but more of a high-flying adventure that will stretch beyond its limits, or those who simply want more new DOOM-style gunplay and action.

Also, Mein Leben difficulty is insane.

Also also, Horton Boone is based.

slowdown and kinda sucks to begin with anyways, its great that they have different enemy types, but for fucks sake give me a clean menu to quickly switch on the fly or give me slowdown in the menu, it isnt fun being killed by a specific enemy because i had to spend a couple crucial seconds fiddling with your weird weapon wheel (i know its unlockable later, it needs to be there from the start). some ledges arent clipped properly or the character just doesnt know how to step over them, i find myself sneaking through a lot of the game and i have to jump or stand up and try to run because my supersoldier chad got stuck on the bottom of a sub door, hangar door, or any step of a staircase, enemies being randomly alerted to your presence even though they have no reason to be, sometimes i even know the reason why they are alerted and its crazy, you mean to tell me that of the 2 guys i just killed, one of them telepathically told everyone that there's a dead body in front of him even though i just john wick'd them both in half a second (this is a mein leben killer on some sections), im sure they get alerted randomly because the ai has wallhacks, seriously they shoot at your position through solid walls, wouldnt be surprised if they see the dead bodies too. some nitpicks are the fact that you can try to speedrun levels after losing them many times for any of the reasons above, and you can hit a barrel at a weird angle while jumping and be thrown off the map because blazkowicz lubes himself up before every mission, vaulting being 50/50 on whether you actually grab the ledge or just slide off of it, enemies shoot you through solid walls sometimes but its kinda rare, although i lost a mein leben run because of a rocket through a wall.. and the cherry on top is that the story is cringeworthy at many points, thanks for coming to my ted talk, this game is a mess

PS, the guy that made so many collect em all achievements needs to die

Overall, I thought this was a worthy successor to The New Order. I didn't think it was quite as memorable as its predecessor, admittedly, though it still has plenty of strengths in its own right. The graphics are gorgeous as ever and the gameplay is fairly smooth. Plenty of your favourite characters from The New Order are back, and some of them get a bit more screen-time than they did the first time around (like Bombate, for example), though some old favourites (like Fergus) take less of a key role in the overarching story. Then there are new members of the cast, such as Grace, Sigrun or Horton. Granted, not all of these new characters get any real development before the game ends, but I still enjoyed them for what they were.

The story of the game is that you're liberating the US from Nazi occupation by linking up various resistance groups. The game does end somewhat abruptly - but I guess it didn't overstay its welcome, so I suppose there's a silver lining to that. Plus, part of the story really revolves around Blazkowicz himself, who learns he is going to be a father - which prompts a bit of exploration into his own backstory.

So yes, I do recommend the game. If you want to see a sample of gameplay before deciding whether to buy, here's a handy link to my Youtube playthrough: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1DlfFIsbBo8&list=PL05Yc3_TEBpO7DvEupeG6y6yP9JfDsF3N

I played this just after the previous two games, back to back. While I've enjoyed the previous installments, this is the only one I take any issue with.

Positives:
-fun to use weapons and tactics
-good to great atmosphere
-immense detail in graphical and audial capabilities
-well delivered lines from voice actors
-fair bit of extra content including side missions, shooting range, collectibles, and Wolfenstein 3D

Negatives:
-heavily stereotyped characters
-overly goofy tone that (while some might enjoy) doesn't at all fit the universe as set up in the previous two 
 titles
-disproportionately large focus on cutscene length for an action/shooter
-mostly hitscan enemies can make the game feel unbalanced on occasion

Ultimately, much of this is personal opinion, and the game was still pretty well made. However, the dragging story filled with so many pointless moments and characters that i found it impossible to be engaged with the plot as in the last two games. I don't really recommend this title unless it goes on supersale and you NEED to play it.

BOTTOM LINE: if you must play this game, you might end up skipping most of the cutscenes

I see abundant graphical artifacts that were not present in id Tech 5 or id Tech 7 and that I don't remember seeing in Doom 2016. Pixelated-purple hair that should be white, for example. On a RTX 2060. Opening cutscenes are awful and not skippable. The actual gunplay feels good, but getting to it involves sitting through some really uncomfortably long plot exposition.

I usually 100% a game before reviewing, especially Wolfenstein but this is gonna be an exception because of and what is the only con for me in this game, crashing. "Could not write crash dump" happens way too often and there's no guaranteed fix for it. There are many possible solutions that seem to be hit or miss. I haven't found one yet although I haven't tried them all yet since it wasn't really happening that often. But often enough if I want to go for Mein Leben run which I definitely do.

Apart from that there was 1 moment in story that kinda ruined it for me but there were still many other positive wtf and very funny moments in the story, all the likable characters come back from New Order and some cool new ones are introduced as all. All that made it even better.

Gameplay wise I think it's a huge improvement as well although I thought weapons were better balanced in TNO and TOB. In this game there's one weapon with specific upgrade that can do it all at all ranges against all enemy types. Not really game breaking but a bit of a shame. Other weapons are still very fun to use at least.

Content wise there's a lot of it in this game. Compared to TOB and TNO, A LOT more. Many more collectibles, actual side missions, "assassin contracts", DLC campaigns, combat challenges from TOB return and there's even an arcade machine with full Wolf3d game. I like this main area, your base where all the characters are and they have little chats, usually very funny, with each other you can listen between missions. Kinda like that hideout in TNO but much bigger and many more characters. All that makes this game the best of the series imo. If you are lucky enough to not get any crashes of course.

This game is a disappointment. They took all the bad things from The New Order and cranked them up to 11. So many characters are just annoying to listen to or be around. There are so many pretentious moments in this game it will drive you insane but I can't really get specific without getting into spoilers. The story is really just a huge step down from the original. It's kind of boring honestly. I almost quit playing it. At least the combat is good though, that's one of the few things about this game I actually like. But without a good story to back it up, the game falls flat. I'll give it 4/10. Below average.

What set this game apart from the rest are the cutscenes. Remember the time when you were rewarded for completing a chapter with something awesome to watch? That really motivated me. It also shows how much you can achieve nowadays with this kind of technical production: powerful, imaginative and dynamic camera movement, engaging performances by good actors excellently motion-capturing memorable characters in far out scenarios and just giving your game that extra little... panache.

As for the gameplay - it's good (not great). The weapons lack a certain punch, there is not a great variety to them or the enemies and the boss encounters are not that special or fun. There's not even a colossus to fight. :( I found it to be a minor improvement from The New Order, though. And people are right if they critizise that our protagonist doesn't carry the same weight as before. Although the Nazis still feel quite menacing the game is way more comedic than it needs to be.

Waw... I loved that episode. Interesting characters and great fights.

- The combat feels better than previous game. 
- The soundtracks are amazing
- The oberkommando missions are just lazy reused levels, and it is bullshit sometimes. The oberkommandos are using kampfpistole. The annoying part comes when you're playing in mayhem way (run and gunning). There's zero checkpoint in oberkommando levels so if you're dead, you're restarting the whole damn level. The oberkommando can kill you with one shot of kampfpistole. So, don't do these missions with mayhem, do them with stealth.
- And no chapter select like the previous games? seriously? 
- The DLCs aren't bad, but overpriced. 
- The dogs are annoying. This isn't an issue with the previous game, but those mutts are just too fast and hard to kill in this game, especially if you're a controller user.
- The game can be hard sometimes, that can be a good thing in a video game, but not this one. The enemies aren't bullet sponge, but you became as weak as a fetus. I've tried the "do or die!" difficulty, everything was fine and not really that challenging. But the real shit begins in one oberkommando mission: the manhattan subway. For some reason I always die in that level. I've beat the court level (the level that everyone has a hard time dealing) with no issue, so why's this one the hardest one?
- the story is amazing and sometimes can be funny. The characters are lovable, but some are introduced too far in the game. For example, Horton and his gang, they're introduced too far, almost reaching the end of the game.
- There's the motherflipper himself, hitler, in the game. You do get an achievement when you kicked him, but they missed an opportunity to have him as a cyborg boss.
- The end boss doesn't feel personal. Just more soldiers and ubersoldatens, and two bigger and harder ubersoldaten. When you kill general engel in the game, it feels satisfying, yes. But you don't feel the satisfactory of killing her in-game. You don't fight her like you fight Deathshead in The New Order. Everything was scripted. 
- They tried to make a "BFG" version of Wolfenstein, the ubergewehr, but it ended up just a weapon that got you killed multiple times. It's slow af and not fun to use.

overall, the combat is superior than it's predecessor, and the game is fine. I've replayed the game three times and it's still fun. But it would be cool if they added the chapter select tho..

This part of the trilogy is significantly worse than the previous two:
1) Almost the entire game BJ has 50hp, at the end they give 100, but they reduce the armor from 200 to 100.
2) The weapon has a huge recoil. Because of this, bursts can only be fired at very close range. At the same time, even the headshots are quite weak, the weakest enemy needs at least two headshots from the most powerful weapon. Usually they need 10-20 headshots. It's boring.
3) Almost all weapons have a very large spread and low dps. Enemies just have to kill with a few clips.
4) Almost all enemies do not react to a hit. Do not stagger. It is not at all clear whether I hit them.
5) The difficulty grows very quickly, if at the first levels I easily scattered everyone at the 5th level of difficulty, then by the end I was able to play only at 2-3 levels.
6) Too many collectible items, and especially texts. I came to shoot! If I wanted to read, I would go to the library.

As a player of the other two (rebooted) Wolfenstein games, I definitely enjoyed it. It has the same fast-paced Nazi killing action that I was used to and the American setting was neat, especially Roswell. I've always enjoyed the alt-history of the Nazis and their crazy technological devices and weapons, which is represented well. I was disappointed that we didn't see more of the Occult side of the house that was so preset in The Old Blood. I really hope we see more of that in the future, much like how the 2009 Wolfenstein story was written. Another disappointment was the abandonment of the enemy codex. This game brought some neat new enemies and I would have loved to read more about them, if only a brief blurb, but this was not included in the game. 

All in all if you enjoyed the two previous titles, you'll enjoy this one.

[list]
[*]Horrible level design.
[*]Visual effects terrible at night, you have no idea what the f@ck you're looking at.
[*]Unintuitive controls for weapon switching.
[*]Game having an anneurism whenever you try to lean left/right and shoot.
[*]Boring visuals, just grey and brown corridors one after the other.
[*]3 useful weapons out of 15 provided.
[*]You will be wondering if anyone playtested this on a real difficulty. Certain sections are meant exclusively for the player to go rambo, without considering the absurd damage received in higher difficulties. It's impossible to beat without save-scamming.
[*]The DLCs are just a waste of money.
[*]SJW propaganda shoved in your face at every available opportunity, and poorly executed at that.
[*]Abrupt, anticlimactic ending.
[*]Writing fitting a cartoon meant for toddlers, especially concerning philosophical concepts of morality and the more action-packed "coolness". Frankly I'd be ashamed if I ever wrote anything as immature as this. [/list]

Great shooter, compelling plot, PC performance excellent.

This game, of course, like everyone said, isn't as good as the new order. A lot of cutscenes, weird (but still very satisfying) shooting and a fuck ton of nazi commanders. 

However, it has its strengths. Many people mention that the writing isn't good in this game, but I find it quite the contrary. Yes, it's not as good as the new order (repeating myself), but it's still damn good. The tension that they manage to create in them is just great.

My favourite part in this whole game doesn't even involve shooting. It's the part, where you are walking around as a fireman in the USA and seeing what the nazis have done to the country. That is really my favourite part about all the Wolfenstein games but in this game it really shines.

So yes, I would recommend it to anyone who likes shooters, movies, wolfenstein or alternate history shit. Peace.

This is by far the best FPS I've played.  The New Colossus returned me to the original Wolfenstein, Quake, and Haven in that the game play is relentlessly in your face. Doom and its competitors wandered off into environmental design and atmospheres and lost what made these original FPSs so great.  The New Colossus adds a good (and pretty funny) storyline with the cutscenes being an opportunity to recover from the last map.

I'm 77 years old. I've been playing FPSs since the original Wolfenstein and Doom.  I was awed by the concept and delivery of Half-Life. And then we got Minerva Metastasis, which was the best FPS up until now (although Black Mesa should get an honorable mention).

Bottom line: I cannot recommend The New Colossus highly enough.  Just don't lose you head.

Spoilers ahead! I have mixed opinions on this game. Sure, it's prettier than its predecessor but that should be expected. I like most of the new characters, even if they sometimes make me cringe. But they do a lot of disservice in this game, particularly to Wyatt spends the whole game high but Blazkowicz doesn't even notice which is disappointing. The same can be said for Sigrun. In the previous game you have Klaus Kreutz, a nazi turned freedom fighter. The team seems to instantly accept him, albeit with some hesitancy from Blazkowicz. It can be argued that Sigrun instantly proves herself to an extreme extend saving the lives of Blazkowicz and Wyatt/Fergus whilst freeing the U-Boat and everyone on it. Everyone walks all over her just like her mother does and it's uncomfortable. Aside from those awkward character moments is the final boss, or lack-there-of. There literally isn't a final boss. You fight two nameless robots and capture the Ausmerzer. Then there is a cutscene where you kill General Engel. That's it. That's the end of the game. Though the story was a bit wild with Blazkowicz's losing his body and gaining a new one, it was good. I just wish they did literally anything else with that ending. 

6.5/10

With over 100 hours sunk into the game, I have to give it a thumbs down. New Colossus is unfortunately lacking, especially when compared to previous games. By no means is it a "bad game" so to speak, especially to players with no prior experience regarding the franchise. What I dislike most is the pacing of the game, the severely abrupt (and lacking) ending, and the fact that it doesn't make you feel anything significant (story-wise) in the third act; It feels very rushed. 

I only found enjoyment whilst going for the Mein Leben difficulty, as it gave that intense feeling that would never really leave you until you beat the game, but that's not a pro for New Colossus, its primarily just thanks to the Wolfenstein formula.

Also; The super forced feminist quips are especially weird in a Wolfenstein game. I personally wouldn't have mind a quip here and there, but its too present and almost feels forced. Really weird choice in this given setting Bethesda, but you do you. Wonder if the next game will have BJ jamming to Dua Lipa while killing Nazis.
The only thing more fun than shooting virtual Nazis is watching real-life ones lose their mind in the comments. Great game.

This was a total chore to play.  I bought this because of the good reviews.  The graphics are good, even now 4 years after its release (if you can ignore the hunch back that all 3D models of the characters have).  The story is, well, ludicrous, but it has a few moments of fun (and lots of utter tastelessness, but that is a matter of taste, in a manner of speaking).  
None of the characters in this story made me root for them, or even only feel sympathetic with.  In fact, the only person I felt remotely I could relate to was the father who was trying to teach his son that he had to stand up for himself.  This part of the story played almost 100 years ago, and back then life was harsh, nothing for the young, soft snowflake generation of current times.  I wonder whether the makers of this game have ever realised how much they placated themselves with the pinnacle of their story - a gory, brutal act of violence far worse than the supposedly heartless father teaching his son a lesson.
The biggest gripe I have is the BORING game play.  All weapons feel the same, all environments look the same, all enemies look identical, and the whole darn thing seems to play as if all movement is done with rubber bands attached.  The action does not nearly make up for that, because, it too is the same throughout.  The worst part is the "Lost at Sea" portion where not even the action is there - all you have to do is endlessly run about the huge U-Boat and look for people and/or run stupid errands that have no meaningful impact on the overall story line.  All of this comes with countless "collectibles" and other side information neither helpful nor immediately relevant to the story, and it is just a pain to look through.  I guess the authors wanted to create "atmosphere" but it simply does not add up.  It does not get better by the mistakes of the German language used, both spoken and written. At least they did have multi-lingual voice talent, such as General Engel, who seems to be native (or close enough) to make her German and English sound natural. 
I had played the 2016 release of Doom only half a year earlier, followed by Doom Eternal.  Both sport an equally strange but engrossing story, both give the player the Doom Guy as a highly enjoyable character to relate to, and both are highly addictive and left me with an urge to move on, to know more, to understand the story.  It is a mystery to me how Wolfenstein II could be such a let-down, coming from Bethesda just like Doom 2016 had.
My recommendation is clearly do not buy.  Even at the bargain of EUR 5.99 it is not worth your time.

TL:DR Sehr gut

An epic sequel to an epic series. Wolfenstein II manages to improve its already impressive predecessors in almost every way - much better visuals, better gunplay, more varied enemies with vastly improved AI, bigger levels, bloodier action, more strategic combat and more. The gameplay is super fun, fast, yet varied with decision making needed on the fly. Just for the action, this game deserves to be played.

When it comes to the story, I think it's very good. Very well written, large in scope, but well fleshed out, with a very large cast of characters that all feel real and alive, with BJ at the center of it all as a very good protagonist. The worldbuilding is also amazing, combining Nazi brutalism, sci-fi dystopia and a hint of hippie 60s America. There's also a bigger dash of humour than before which helps lift the pressure of the high stakes. Now, there is an obvious hint of modern liberal politics and humour but it isn't ham-fisted and doesn't get in the way. If you worry that this game will push political correctness onto you, fear not, it won't.

Also one more thing, something I've never mentioned in a game review before - cinematography. The cutscenes in this game are among the best I've ever seen, with fantastic shot composition, transitions, atmosphere and style, making the experience feel like a high budget action film. In game, the first person perspective and detailed visuals are used in clever ways to create amazing immersion and emotionally moving experiences. Chef's kiss for you Machine Games, you outdid yourselves again. Just, please do something about all the technical issues, it's a shame for a modern AAA game that is otherwise very well made and well polished to have so many bugs that sit unfixed.

In conclusion, the same that I said for the previous Wolfenstein games applies here - one of the best story-driven FPS games ever made, both in terms of its story and its gameplay. Highly recommended.

Playing through Wolfenstein 2 was one of the most incredible experiences I've ever had. So many jaw dropping moments to be had throughout this game. After 3 incredible games you finally feel like you have set the wheels in motion of taking America back from the Nazi's. 

SPOILERS AHEAD:

With incredible moments like the tragic death of Caroline or the dramatic ending of BJ's cruel father. The game constantly keeps you on edge. Especially when you are put before a judge sentenced to death, then out of a fit of rage you break out of your bonds and kill everyone..., and see BJ's mother. But, none of that matters because in reality it was all just and dream and then you see BJ's head get cut off on live TV. An unexpected turn of events to be sure. Especially when you get a brand new body, with a brand new set of abilities. Making your way to confront Hitler himself steal the Odin codes and finally kill Frau Engel.

I'm sure I skipped a couple details here and there but at the end of the day this was one of the best games I have ever played. BJ truly is a monster, patriotic, and god among men. 16/10 game.

Do not buy unless spending multiple hours fixing obscure, game-breaking bugs with even more obscure fixes is your cup of tea. This is the buggiest game I've ever played out of the box.

In case you do buy it, here's a list of fixes that worked for me:
Black screen during cutscenes - turn off steam overlay.
Black screen during explosions - enable motion blur.
Black screen depending on view angle - install nvidia game ready driver 398.46.
Framerate and time slowdown depending on view angle - boot game in safe mode.
Faint grid on screen - none.

I can recommend this game [i] IF [/i] it's on sale.  To elaborate:

The gunplay is fantastic, and it feels so satisfying to shoot and kill the enemies! The sequences where you fight the bosses/big bads are challenging, but not frustratingly so.  The level design feels organic without feeling too linear. However, there were times where I was a little confused on where to go without using the hint key, and that brings us to the main hub. The submarine where the player spends a good portion of time is confusing to navigate even with all the signs it has inside. It was too easy to get turned around in the submarine and have a "where am I?" moment. From my perspective a lot of the submarine just didn't seem to necessary to the game, and detracted from it more than helped it.  

The weapon upgrades and perks for the game, felt largely like an afterthought. I never really got as invested in them as much as I was in the first game. I was also a bit disappointed with the lack of weapon variety. Maybe I missed some weapons during my play though, but there seemed to only be 6 weapons worth using. 

The story is so-so. I didn't really find it compelling or interesting, and I get that wolfenstein has a history of "out there" plot points, but this was [i] really [/i] out there.  The character development, besides the romantic interest, was actually pretty good, and I liked the other characters quite a bit. They all had good dialogue, and it was fun interacting with them.  The voice acting was good, for the most part. Although, some of the dialogue was more than a bit weird even for wolfenstein. 

With all that said the game is short, about 8 or 9 hours if you complete everything. Not that it's necessarily a bad thing, it just is.  Too add to that the gunplay is also sporadic, a player can go 20 to 30 minutes (multiple times) without shooting, which slows down the game. 

All in all, I can recommend it, but only when it's on sale. It isn't quite as good as the first one, or Doom 2016 for that matter. However, it is still worth a play through.

I really like the franchise, but this gets everything wrong. Tries to be a frantic, fast-paced shooter, but it's all just janky and sad. The movements and clipping are poorly matched to the environment. The AI does this stupid ducking sidestep to avoid fire like some burlesque skit in Summerstock. And all the exhausted corridor-shooter tropes apply: AI spawning behind you in cleared areas, AI opening fire before they have line of sight. The game play lacks any strategy, no decent stealth options.  Plus, the game gets wrong all the FPS stuff that has been solved *forever*: pick-ups are a tremendous chore, interaction triggers are 5 pixels wide, the weapons are under-powered, the AI are sponges.  The voice acting and NPC cast is good, but the cut scenes are overwrought. The backstory is somewhat interesting, but it goes nowhere. I only spent 12 bucks, still feel rogered.

A very polarising sequel that will divide fans of the first game. It has a much larger emphasis on story and characters and focuses less on it's gameplay which some may hate but I love. You really end up caring for each of the misfits you have in your crew and is very reminiscent of Oceans 11. The levels are more varied than the first taking you all over the world and they are much more open. Has quite a few really solid twists and turns that I simply did not expect.


Unfortunately aside from the bugs this game has one hugely annoying flaw: The commander mechanic. It seems like every five minutes the game plops you in a level with Commanders. Why is this a big deal you ask? well it severely limits how you play. You can't just run and gun because it will alert the Commanders and then they proceed to spawn waves of enemies unless they are killed. This means you are forced to stealth in and kill them first if you don't want to be swarmed by infinite foot soldiers. Really not sure why they insisted on this mechanic popping up so frequently because it is very annoying. When I think of Terror Billy the last thing that comes to mind is the titular character cowering in the shadows. He's a bad ass who has slaughtered Nazi's in the thousands, not Sam freaking Fisher. 


It's still a strong recco from me. Think Oceans 11 meets Quentin Tarantino and you get The New Colossus.
