Tediously boring unskippable cutscenes bar the user from actually getting to play the game. After 10 minutes I decided to go play a game that actually let me play the game.

Well, that was disappointing.

At first, like you <probably>, I didn't get the reason for the negativity in the reviews for this game. A certain mob of people tried bashing the game for daring to show Anya topless in a rather hilariously bada$$ scene, but it otherwise seemed like more of the same in terms of gameplay. And yes, the level design feels a bit lackluster yet similar compared to the prior entries, the guns don't feel nearly as powerful as they should be until you upgrade them, but the story is truly the bullet to the knee. 

They roped me in at first, with some fairly hardcore setup and a visceral look into our hero's past, but things quickly fall off from there. Without even trying or meaning to, most of the levels in this game are short, direct, and pretty easy overall. You can crank the difficulty up, but that often just leads to getting one-shot in ridiculous ways to the point of needlessly frustrating you at the end of a level. The enemies are primarily just cannon fodder, with visually generic armor and going from being decent in their damage resistance to outright absurd. Tell me, should a grunt magically absorb half a mag from an SMG point-blank before dying? On Normal?

By the time we clear things out and get to a standard, you see what the game is trying to set up: a death march. Make every action count. The characters are lacking in emphasis, they're abrupt while tossing words and """funny, quirky""" events at you to try and give a laugh. In the end, the dialogue just feels forced and phoned in compared to prior entries, with the aforementioned events just feeling shoehorned in with such a tactless approach that they feel more awkward than anything.

But, then we get to meeting the New York resistance, and speaking of lacking tact and subtlety, ho-lee PHUCC, is the intro cutscene bad. In light of events in the past couple of years, you have to tread as if walking through a minefield, so I'll just say this: if they made Grace's dialogue and "personality" with any less subtlety while making it painfully obvious, they might as well have just codenamed her VSD-1, the first virtue-signalling drone that you meet in this game. After seeing this, it's pretty clear when they began the wild swing to left field that would eventually spawn the abomination known as Youngblood.

The gameplay and design quality was lowered, but it was still fun. Then you get to the shoehorned political dogma, and it just kills it. When combined with the game freaking out over technical issues, a horde of crash reports, and continuous spam to buy the expansion when you start the game and get through the 30+ seconds of trigger warnings, it's just not worth it. Stick to New Order or Old Blood, skip this as <even without politics> it's more of the same but to a lesser degree, and don't even waste time with Youngblood.

4/10

if i didn't know any better i would have guessed this game was made by a different developer. everything is pretty much worse. 

ill start with the gameplay first. gameplay and level design wise this game feels like a huge step back. everything felt more claustrophobic (im not sure if this is right word) and every time i got into a firefight i just wanted it to end quickly so i could just move on to the next section. in new order and old blood i would sometimes not stealth right off the bat in a new area because it was fun fighting and the weapons felt good to use, but in new colossus i tried to stealth every single time because i just didn't have fun when i got caught and the alarms went off. none of the weapons felt particularly satisfying to use either which is a huge negative in a fps. my favorite weapon was a heavy weapon that fired a laser beam so i couldnt carry it with me forever. also i get why you have 50 health for like half the game but i think this was a very poor choice.

characters/story wise... holy shit. like obviously if anyone has played new order or old blood you'll know shit is a little ridiculous. old blood had that giant final boss. in new order you went to the moon and hid in submarine missile and came out and hijacked a uboat. you know, ridiculous shit. new colossus breaks the ridiculous meter in a way that makes me feel like it was too much (although i will give it up. when i was about half way through the game i thought about dropping it but then something happens that made me think "okay, this is dumb. but now i have to finish to see what the fuck happens now"). probably the biggest problem i have with the ridiculousness is anya (who is several months pregnant and is showing quite a bit) goes out on the field. you might be thinking, "oh? that's your biggest problem and not the thing that happens in the middle of the game?" the reason the anya business bugs me the most is the scene in the last mission. that was the like the cherry on top of it all and i just mentally checked out. 

i wanna talk about wyatt. apparently people did not like his change to like the hippy/drug tripper. i didn't either but if im being honest i didn't like him at all in new order. the reason i picked the wyatt timeline is because i feel it's the more canonical timeline. so while i do like fergus better, i feel personally if bj were to be a real he would have chose to save wyatt (but that's just me. i was also planning on playing this game a second time for fergus's timeline but i probably wont play this game ever again). the reason i wanted to talk about wyatt specifically is because i thought his speech at the end was incredible. his speech (almost) made it worth it to slog through this game, and for a second i forgot about the issues i had with it.

bug wise, i had an issue constantly when i would be crouching around and would get stuck in door ways. in the epilogue i had to reload my game so many times because i couldnt crouch and get through a section in the stands. there was also a part early in the game where i kept clipping through an elevator. i never had any big/constant issues with new order/old blood so this is upsetting to have so many issues with the third entry.

after playing this and seeing the reception of youngblood i hope machinegames can bounce back but i dont know.

Wolfenstein II The New Colossus was an improvement far and beyond that of its previous game is almost every aspect, and is a must play game for any fan of the series, but also anyone just looking to play the newest games. 

Right away, I was blown away by the graphical improvement and the fluidity of the game. The New Order was locked at 60fps, however I was able to easily reach 120fps at 4K max settings. It seems to be a new engine, which performed amazingly. Some of the things I really liked were the updated, yet familiar game designs, such as recharging your heavy weapons. The characters in this game were way more memorable and distinct to create their own impact on the story. Everyone was a useful addition and the voice acting was superb. I enjoyed the cutscenes before and after each level which gave the characters more room to shine and establish themselves. There were minor adjustments like the ui, and weapon selector which, although not as significant, still stood out as a good improvement to the series. Finally, the story this time felt much better, and had much more satirical moments which actually made me laugh out loud. Each level was memorable. I also really enjoyed how straightforward the game was with certain issues, and didn't shy away from topics like other games would. Having a main hub for the game was also a smart idea since it made sense in terms of the story, but also allowed the player to decide where they wanted to go or do in the universe. 

In terms of things I didn't like, my biggest gripe with this game was that each level felt WAY too short. You could rush through each level in only about 5 minutes just to trigger the cutscene and move on. Additionally, you did not even need to kill, or even fight the bosses. You could run away from them and exit the level while still under fire, and there were no consequences to this. It made the enemies seem pointless at times, which for the final boss, after continuing to die over and over, I finally just learned I could run pass the two big enemies and escape without even firing at them. Very anti-climactic for something which should have had a better pay off. Other than that, there were a few minor bugs in trying to climb through small spaces, but really that was the only issues I ran into. 

Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed every moment of this game, and would highly recommend it. The campaign should have been longer (only marginally longer than the first game) for a sequel, but I would pick it up for about $10 as a reasonable price.

I just beat this game a day ago and here are my thoughts about this game. I would recomended to everybody to buy this game and to play it, however this game has some good and some bad things too.

The good things are :
- Story
- Atmosphere
- Skippable cutscenes and etc.
- No Crashing issues for me and the game still runs good on PC's with lower specs (I have 8gb ram, Nvidia Geforce GTX 960 and intel Core i5 CPU. The game runs perfect on my PC. I can play it on Low Graphic Quality setting and I'm still very happy. For me is just important to play the game and to enjoy the game and graphic setting doesn't really matter. For me it doesn't matter If I can have Graphics on Low or Ultra and for me it's just more important to enjoy the game, enjoy the story and to have fun with the game I'm playing

The bad things are :
- There is no chapter select option in the main menu (In Wolfenstein The New order and The old blood there was an option that when you beat the game, you can just went to chapter select and finish all remaining side quest, collect all collectables and max all perks, but here if I want to do all that stuff and get the achievements I don't know how can I do it, because there isn't any option for chapter select)
- Cracking Enigma Codes (In Wolfenstein the new order , cracking Enigma codes was super easy. you just have to collect all Enigma codes, went into the main menu and crack them, but here you have to use the Enigma machines and play hard minigames to crack them.)
- Mein Leben difficulty (The only thing that is annoying about this difficulty is that this difficulty is permadeath difficulty. They should make a difficulty that is simmilar to uber difficulty in previous two Wolfenstein games games, because the uber difficulty was challenging , but is still enjoyable because you can save and you have checkpoints and in The New Order you can play Uber difficulty through 999 mode which makes it even more easier)

First one was my favorite game of all time.

This one is okay... it feels a bit smaller, a bit less coherent as a story and a lot less focused in its design.

BUT compared to such a well crafted and well done game as the first one of course it's going to pale in comparison. On it's own it is pretty good fun to shoot nazis, pretty horrifying when the nazis you have yet to shoot are allowed to have their way with the world, and the interesting character moments you see along the way.

Though the weird health system you're saddled with at the start is quite frankly a major design flaw, as sometimes I found myself cranking the difficulty all the way down to the lowest level just so I could get past a section without dying over and over again.

Though it might be more flawed than it's predecessor, it still  is a quality peice of gaming that I cannot recomend enough... though with the qualifer that you should probally get the first one first.

Okay, I've finished all achievements after 69 hours (even Mein Leben) and this is my honest review.
DON'T BUY THE SEASON PASS OR DLCs, THEY ARE NOT WORTH IT!
Story wise, this suck and didn't show as much hype as the previous two. However, gameplay is some good shit.

SPOILER:
The story for me has too many plot holes, it wasn't as serious as the first one and in the end it doesn't deliver the hype or having "the final big boss" as the first two. In The New Order, we have a mini boss (which is either Wyatt or Fergus depending on you) that made us furious to kill Deathshead and in Old Blood, we still have the vibe from saving either Annette or Kessler and unveil the final goal of the villain, The New Colossus however didn't have that much of a strong taste.
About the gameplay though, it's an upgrade compared to the other two, it feels smooth even with graphic upgrades. It has few bugs, especially when you bind the key for rifle it usually swap with the SMG and this annoys me. 
And last, DLCs are trashes, both storywise and gameplay (some of the missions should be easier and some should be harder). 

Overall, worth to buy but not as a complete package.

After sinking 25 hours into this game, I totally not recommend it!

Let's start with good stuff first:

- Visually games looks impressive, especially the lightning and particle effects. 
- Voice acting, motion work and cutscenes are fantastic.
- Gameplay is good, if you played the last 2 games, almost the same as before, but still satisfying (with minor issues tho)
- [spoiler] Hitler scene is just hillarious and amazing at the same time. That and courtroom/execution are highlights of the game [/spoiler]
- Few cutscenes and moments in the game which are dark and brutal, I won't spoil, but it's well done.

That's about it, now for the bad stuff:

- Writting. Absolutely terrible, characters are dumb, makes no sense in what they do, dialogue is sometimes cringy and bad. SJW's wet dream to put it correctly.
- Cutscenes. Yes, they are skippable (although not on hardest difficulty, which I still can't fathom why not), but it's a fucking Wolfenstein game! I mean, when compiled together it lasts for 3 hours!!! It took me around 8 hours to complete this game on Death Incarnate (second hardest diffuculty) and I skipped almost all cutscenes, and that's because of me dying over and over on some sections, so I assume this game takes around 5-6 hours to complete when skipping cutscenes. It's damn criminal to have that much cutscenes, especially in a game like this, this is not Metal Gear Solid or some shit...
- Some minor complaints: 
Weapon switching is slow, it should be a bit faster.
Movement over obstacles is janky and sometimes bad, I got stuck A LOT. For example, sometimes I couldn't walk up the stairs, I needed to jump on every step to go up, which is ridiculous. It's weird considering I had no issues at all with the last 2 games.
Game had decent amount of bugs too, cliping textures and all that stuff.
Graphics on highest settings looked weird sometimes, like plastic.
No chapter selection after you complete the game, which is absolutely insane and I don't get why they removed it, last 2 games had them and it was perfect. It just sucks if you are after achievements and you missed some, you need to replay the whole game again, which has some of the cutscenes that are in game and go on for 5+ minutes... Super annoying.
- Crashing. Now I don't know about others, this might be subjective, but what killed the game most for me was constant crashing, which was super frustrating and almost made me quit the game. I stopped to count after 10 times, but I would say easily over 20 times in my whole 25 hours of playthrough, game crashed. That immediatly turns me off to even attempt the Mein Leben difficulty (perma death + no saves + NO skip cutscenes). Imagine getting to the last boss and BOOM, game crashes. Fully up to date drivers, with beffy rig (2070 Super GPU), so no lacking on my part.

I got this game on Steam summer sale recently for 8,99‚Ç¨ and I still feel robbed honestly. I'll never support MG's games anymore, my experience was bad with this game, just because of the constant crashing alone. 
I still recommend it if you are fan of the series and want to experience it (and even then wait for sale, don't buy it for full price), but don't expect anything great as far as writting goes. For other folks, hard pass.

4/10 score.

Edit 8.8.2021:

So Steam summer sale came in and I bought a DLC, just to complete rest of the achievements. 
But first let's talk about Mein Leben run. I did it. After 8 attempts, I did it. It was mostly not that hard, honestly the hardest part is to endure through all the cutscenes... I mean first one takes around 10 minutes, you get a little gameplay and then after that again for the 5+ minutes... It's horrible and mind numbing stuff. WHY NOT ADD THE SKIP BUTTON?! I mean, at least give it for perma death run, for folks who will attempt this A LOT of times.
As for the difficulty itself, the most important thing is to hide in a spot where they can't get you from back and sides. Enemy AI is kinda dumb, but beware, if you allow them to shoot, you're gonna get fu**** most of the times, because they can melt you in half a second, no kidding. Some sections can even be skipped, luckily enemies despawn after you hit next triggers. But yeah, Venus for me was the hardest part, there's lot of tight and smaller areas with tons of enemies, mixed with the hard/big ones. Good luck if you attempt this, you'll need it!

As for the DLC, nothing special, ok at best. You have 3 chapters, each one having 3 volumes. Maybe up to 1 hour max is the duration of each chapter, some even less (stealth ones can be completed in minutes if you know the drill). You play as 3 different characters, that each have their unique abilities (breaking walls, moving through tight vents and the legs that make you taller). As I've said, nothing special, no new weapons or enemies, just basic linear campaign missions.
Aside 3 campaigns, there are sort of like challenges, basically parts of the campaigns, you get points for kills on various ways and you need to progress throught it, just like a mission.

Overall, nothing special, definitely NOT worth the full price, it's barely worth on discount tbh.

A secret cabal of Jews for centuries has built advanced war machines that they've hoarded for themselves and from the shadows influenced world events. Is this in-game Nazi propaganda, you say? No, this is in-game fact. In other words, a game ostensibly about fighting Nazis is based around one of the oldest and most corrosive anti-Semitic tropes there is.

But the game doesn't stop at just simply being nakedly anti-Semitic. It's also openly racist. The game's central African American female character assumes a leadership role over your already-hierarchical ragtag band of fellows from the second you meet her. And why/how does she do this? Because of her great leadership abilities? No, she constantly denigrates and insults her subordinates. Her fierce fighting ability? No, she doesn't fight a single person in the game; delegating 100% of all fighting. So why does she immediately become leader? She assumes leadership simply because of the color of her skin, her gender, and her stereotypical bad attitude. Regardless of a person's skin color or gender, showing someone overcoming adversity, having unique skills, and bringing people together is how a leader is created. Making a character a leader with no journey there whatsoever simply to score woke brownie points is the epitome of bad writing.

The story is borderline incoherent and the characters are awful caricatures of what they were in the prior game with no real personalities, goals, or even shortcomings. On top of this, the plot is just flat-out horrible. You careen from map to map, with little rhyme or reason for how or why. This is clearly a game where they came up with a set of maps and then tried to (badly) shoehorn a story in after-the-fact. There is quite literally a part in the story where you meet Hitler, and for some reason are both forbidden from killing him both before and after the cut scene. You'd think GI Joe would be smart enough to realize maybe killing Hitler would be a more important target than finding whatever stupid document he was after. And let's not forget the abrupt and pointless ending after a mediocre boss battle.

And I haven't even touched on the gameplay yet. The game is extremely easy, with moronic enemy AI that will happily run directly into your line of sight to be mowed down over and over again. Though the game has a (weak) stealth mechanic, there's really no point to using it, as letting alarms go off is barely an inconvenience since mowing down the guards is so trivial anyway. 

The levels are 100% linear cake walks with no thought, strategy, or exploring required at any point. That's modern game design for you. I hope you like the look of "generic Nazi bunker" or "destroyed city", because these two archetypes are repeated over and over again for every single level in the game. The Venus level was the only remotely interesting level in this game, and even then it was claustrophobic, tiny, and linear as pretty much all the levels.

The devs were obviously acutely aware with how short this game is, so they attempted to pad it by giving you in-story missions back to *every single* previous level you've completed, plus tons of useless collectables which have no in-game purpose. Why does collecting Nazi gold have no in-game purpose? Why can't I use it to buy upgrades instead of finding poorly-hidden upgrade containers in every level? It's so frustratingly badly designed. 

By far the worst part of all this padding though, is that through the story most of the maps you've played through are supposed to have been destroyed by the time you're finished. So magically somehow being able to go back there as if nothing has changed ruins any shred of immersion this game was trying to establish. 

I sincerely hope the Wolfenstein franchise remains in stasis until a company that actually cares about making a good game with a good story and intriguing gameplay takes over again.

I was planning to play it to the end before making any judgement but unfortunately I can't manage to do it. From the storytelling perspective, it feels sloppy and tedious. And from the gameplay perspective, if you play with high difficulty, assault rifle perhaps is your only choice since pistol, MP & shotgun are unbelievably weak against armored units(which practically means all of them). Moreover, route guidance in New Colossus is too ambiguous for players to maintain a comfort rhythm. I'm not a person who easily get lost in games, but this game really turns me off. In a word, the game has blood, vengeance and fantastic scenes, but nothing more... I would like to recommend New Colossus to some fourteen-year-old hotheaded boy, but if you consider yourself someone more than that, you should really give up on it.

+Pros+
- The game is a beauty and the art direction did a pretty amazing job. I've found the game slightly to dark in tones at some points, but it is probably the way I've set-up my Alpha.
- Same for audio, everything is sport on from menu interaction to voice over. they did a really, really impressive job.

-Cons-
Where to start.... 

From a general standpoint they really messed up the super strong base they add with new new order and old blood. That is probably one of the rare game I just rushed to the end past mid-game because of the pilling of inconsistencies, poor game design and rushed level design. 

- The combats really felt bland and unbalanced. You either smack opponents way to easily, or get smacked way to easily. Armoured opponents do way to much damage. So if you wanna go head on dualwielding, you need to wait to have a significant amount of upgrades on your weapons. If you want spot-on gunplay and variety, play Metro Exodus.
- Infiltration is not enjoyable due to the randomness of enemy detection, and you are anyway not provided with extra tooling nor level design really taking it into account... 
- Which leads me to the big NO of this game.
Rushed level design: yes Levels look good, as I stated above, art direction did a phenomenal job, but they play bad. Poor spatial indication an readability of the levels. I could be in a level and just don't naturally feel what to do next after cleaning a pile of foes. They really don't stand the comparison with New Order and Old Blood. You can feel as well the "replayability",  where levels keep this generic feel to allow for other activities. I don't like that, but it is just my personal taste.
- Game design is poor, in my opinion. They had really great things to build on, but instead they decided to cut corners. simplifying gunplay, and last but not least creating this absolutely awful narrative. God it is bad. 
- Great heroes and stories are developed by formidable Foes. Foes here are poorly build. As a secondary villain in New Order, Frau Engel had a really deep construction and substance. Here as a main Foe, she just doesn't stand the comparison with Strasse, she does not have this focused madness, this discipline in inhumanity. 
All the cutscenes, and god knows there is a ton of them, doesn't give you insight on character or their motivation really, but many excuses to be dicks and unlikable, that's for sure (hence why I rushed the second half after new York). I am not going to scratch deeper about Narrative anyway... Where you had a real deep sense of desperation and retribution In New Order, with the single purpose to remove the heart of Evil, you have here a single man army of Blasko surrounded by pretty much useless people that screams "Revolution!" and expect the world to follow them. 
Grace is the typical team manager you don't want to have at work: Bully, unapologetic, poor communicant, she just doesn't compare to Caroline. The badassery of Caroline was just second to Blasko. She could plan a mission, shoot hordes of N*** and drive back an helicopter with a broken spine. 
They made Bombate unlikable, unforgivable.
Seth is just a shadow of himself.
They are rude to Max. Like wtf.
Anya turned from operative nurse with a stong maternal symbolism to a pregnant commando with fucked up level of hormones... I mean come on! 
The cynicism and Irony of New Order gets replaced by situation comedy, the poo level one (Literally). It is tiring. You don't want to listen to characters, or whatever they want, you just want to get done with the game and uninstall it.

Unfortunately I found this to be a pretty frustrating experience. 
I think it has some improvements over the original mainly that most of its cutscenes are left for the start or end of a level and that when the game does let you play it focuses on its main FPS mechanics rather than one off concepts.
However, its cutscenes are somehow even longer than the original and you never know if your going to get a short intro to the next level or are about to sit for 10/15 minutes on a small episode of a TV show. Especially near the end it gets up itself with excessively long cutscenes where it suddenly tries to be a comedy which just isnt what I came for and didnt enjoy.
The basic FPS mechanics lead to even more frustration than the original for me. Stealth really feels like an afterthought in terms of level/enemy layouts. There are a few neat additions such as a the tomahawk for more stealthy options but the stealth option is so often undermined by tomahawk throws or bullets just going missing. I set up a clear headshot on someone but something happens to the bullets on the trip so instead of someone dying quietly they start looking in my direction. 
When I did get to shooting it wasnt very good. The guns I thought felt worse than the original and it felt like you could take so few shots even on the middle difficulty. Sometimes it was fine but too often when I really want to go guns out I would walk into the area, immediately take two thirds of my health from one enemy and then have to start running around for health packs. Its really disappointing since The Old Blood was such a fun experience with a great balance of enough health to take advantage of the duel wield but also not so much you didnt have to consider your health.
I cannot recommend playing this. If you really wanted to see the story I think it would honestly be more fun to just watch the cutscenes.

If you liked ‚ÄúThe New Order,‚Äù you'll probably like ‚ÄúThe New Colossus.‚Äù At least from a combat-centric point of view. Gun play is basically unchanged, as are the approaches to combat (a mix of stealth, tactics, and unmitigated aggression). Level design is solid; still plenty of reasons to explore (collectibles, secrets, upgrades, etc), but navigating isn't much of a challenge. There's also not as much variety to levels (or enemies) as you might first believe. If you just wanna bring death and destruction to the Nazi war machine, this will be your cup of tea.

The story on the other hand... That's something else. ‚ÄúColossus‚Äùsuffers from sequel syndrome. Rather then focus on tighter story, character growth, or world building, the focus is instead on revisiting the things that made the previous title great. Like the designers thoughts, which include no awareness of terms like 'gratuitous', went along these lines:

'Can't add too much new stuff. New stuff is untested and might result in diminished sales due to buyer uncertainty. So... make things flashier. Bigger. Current social issues must be inserted wherever possible (regardless of whether or not they actually add any poignancy or depth to the story or characters affected). Awareness/visibility/profile is good, right? Preachy without relevant context isn't cheap, right? You know what? Somehow, let's find a way to add even more blood. To EVERYTHING. 'Cause more blood is more cool, right? RIGHT?! Oh, and add some b**bs. Why? WHY?! THERE IS NO WHY. JUST DO IT! AND COVER THEM WITH BLOOD!!' 

Many plot points, characters, set pieces, and twists/developments were dialed up to 11. ‚ÄúOrder,‚Äù while ludicrously over the top, still managed a relatively cogent narrative structure. Sure, BJ went to the moon in order to deliver his borderline farcical levels of violent deliverance. Yes, that was pretty outlandish, literally and figuratively. It may have strained the bounds of credulity but, and I can't believe I'm about to make this distinction, the lunar base mission was still logically consistent with the shenanigans ‚ÄúOrder‚Äù establishes in terms of both flavor and scale for its mythology. 

‚ÄúColossus,‚Äù however, never finds a way to stick that landing. Going to Venus felt as superfluous and unnecessary as most of the blood in the game is overly gratuitous. It happens simply because it can. Sure, what happens on Venus is humorous, gratifying, and memorable, but it doesn't resonate the same way as the lunar base. There's no tongue-in-cheek, 'ah, of course' moment. BJ goes to Venus only because he'd been to the moon in the previous game, so the new game needs a space mission, as well. Then the designers said, 'well, something absolutely huge needs to happen here,' so having the biggest bad guy of all show up in that level became a given. But not because it made sense. In fact, it had to happen because it didn't make sense. No one would see it coming, so everyone would be surprised. The only real storytelling here was to frame the scene as a film audition.

Honestly, it could have worked. But rather than a message about the universal pervasiveness of impostor syndrome, or the importance of taking a stand against intolerance, or why it's incumbent on every individual to never give up... we get none of those things. We don't even get an exploration of the notion of a scene in the game, which can no doubt be played out a different way, resembling a scene in a film, which can no doubt be played out in a different way. Instead, we get nothing of consequence. Because even if the writers were trying to say all, or any, of those things, it was more important to focus on crazy bad guy doing crazy bad guy things. Don't get the point across, maybe even with a little artistry. No. Make it about all the blood crazy guy caused. And his vomit. What could have been a clever, profound statement instead fell utterly, terrifically flat. So much promise that ends up so... squandered.

Yeah, I'm salty about it. Here was a chance to say some serious things about some serious problems. Perhaps it stings so badly because of how good it could have been.

Definitely one thumb up, but I don't know how to score it numerically. As a tactical FPS, it's at least a 7, maybe an 8. Graphics are an 8. Story, though? That's a 6... maybe a 7. Expect your enthusiasm for the game to end with the campaign and you are less likely to be disappointed. While there is a lot of additional content, in the form of assassination missions, DLC, etc, I'm not convinced it's a good investment of time.

This game is a mess. Story as everyone knows at this point, Its a badly written B-movie that you maybe watch it once or just straight up skip it. 
Game play is not fun. Unpolished game, multiple bugs and some questionable design choices keep wearing your enjoyment for the game the longer you play.

When i first started the game, it bugged and throw me into the Engel head chopping cut scene hence i never played the wheel chair part. You can even check my achievement to see that I finished the game but never unlocked the fergus vs wyatt decision in first chapter.

Lighting in this game is atrocious. Either you barely see anything in the darkness or you get blinded by any light source: 1 simple light, your own muzzle flash, etc. Hell there are some level the devs think its not enough an they make the enemy use spotlight directly to shine your face.

The game is a wolfenstein game with dual wield mechanic, you would think dev designed this game for you  to run and gun blasting nazi. Your ms is fast. Enemy is quiet spongy. HP/armor/ammo scattering around the map.
However, they also made the enemy to be some kind of sharpshooter division in nazi army. They have deadly accuracy and the reaction time that makes you feel like you are playing PvP fps CSGO, Cod, Battlefield. The best way for you to survive is to hide and peek out to shoot enemy. But then your weapons have really bad spread at distance. Best you can do is tapping or burst with your assault rifle.
And because of that, its so hard to use any other fun guns because you will die so quickly. Heavy guns are also out of the question because you are slowed when you use it. and the 1s or 1.5s spin up time to shoot is enough for enemy to burst you down.

Damage indicator is really badly designed. No low hp indicator. 
No actual boss fight. The so called last boss fight of the game is stupid. They just put tough enemy into the closed area, double it so you fight 2 of them at the same time. Add more common soldier to sneak around and flank you to make it hard. 
Why is it hard? because while you using heavy gun to fight the boss, common soldier just sneak around and burst you twice to kill you. Shoot them with the heavy gun? You are at disadvantaged because heavy gun are slow and not too accurate for that, or its explosive and you also blast yourself. Switch to another gun? The switching speed is slow af and the weapon switching system is horrible in the first place.
 The "boss" itself, you fight by hitting it until you break the first layer of armor. Then you keep shooting until it dies. The same way you fight a MMO boss with health bar. Hit it till it dies. Very cool.

Maze liked levels with no minimap, no clear indicator of objective. Lots of time spending on finding the right way or the prompt to advance the story.

First part of the game sucks hard. It is stupidly hard because you are handicapped with 50 HP only. Also your main character, BJ is now a depressing, whining guy in grief. Levels are so uninspired. You run a maze, find the prompt to go to cut scene and then get thrown into another corridor to find your way.
The game only get better at 2nd half when you get more tools to play with. Sometimes it reminds you of Dishonored franchise when you get to pick the upgrade and have multiple ways to approach the level ( Dishonored dev is Arkane studio also worked on Wolf 2). But then its just half ass and never get fleshed out. They mostly just replace a corridor with new way for you to use upgrade. It doesnt really change the game much.

Very disappointing game. Worse than TNO for sure.

Althought not as special as The New Order, Wolfenstein 2 is still an amazing game worthy of playing. Fun, Smart, and Stylish as hell. The SmartAss Cousin of doom. In the best way. Make Wolfenstien 3 AT LEAST EVENTUALLY. Please.

There are some moments of dullness, and one or two levels are extra hard for no reason. I hate replaying a level over and over again even on a medium difficulty. It's great you can lower the difficulty at any point.

I'm giving this one a recommend, but only when on deep sale, and even so, it only barely passes the threshold of recommend status. It is a fun game at its core but is riddled with a slew of problems.

Pros:

1) Great art-design for the characters and the world. Diesel-punk is a unique aesthetic that we don't see used very often.

2) The story is crazy, over-the-top and cheesy; and i love every single part of the tale this game tells.

3) Graphics are great; the light effects and sparks that fly as you tear your way through Nazis look fantastic.

Cons:

1) Wolfenstein 2 really suffers from an identity crisis. It gives you a fast character, and heavy, bombastic guns, but then expects you to play carefully, hiding behind cover wherever you can. The sheer speed with which a full stack of armour and health melts away from your body makes no sense at all.

2) The level design, especially when compared to the previous two entries in the franchise, is quite poor. There are several places where collision issues happen and you character will get inexplicably stuck, forcing you to flail around frantically as you try to set him free.

3) Switching between weapons (using a keyboard and mouse) feels clunky and sluggish. Weapon switching animation is slow and out of place, often forcing you to run and hide, just to switch weapons before emerging again.
Great soundtrack, love the characters, weird story but they make it work. Would definitely recommend as a fun game

Sigh‚Ä¶
The sin of all sequels.

When the first game came out, it presented us with a horizon. A wide and daunting vista of a world where Hitler won. Yes, there are some characters striving in this world, but their main quality is just that ‚Äì strife. How exactly do they return the pressure this ideological apocalypse weighs on them with? When pani Oliwa from the first game says: ‚ÄúNo more resistance, the Nazis rule everything‚Äù, it sounds final and hopeless. It‚Äôs this finality, this apocalyptic hopelessness and the unlikely battle against it that lured people in.

Aaaand now we‚Äôre focusing on the characters. BJ? He‚Äôs not just a hillbilly dreaming of a never-to-happen barbeque on his own back lawn. He‚Äôs a complex character now. Firstly, he‚Äôs a Jew because his mother is a Jew. Okay. There was a tell in the first game, so fine. Also, his father is a bigoted antisemitic arschhole. Okay. Also, he‚Äôs got Oedipus. Okay. Because of the combination of the previous two factors. Oh‚Ä¶

So, yeah, credit where credit is due: [i]New Colossus[/i] doesn‚Äôt just focus on characters for characters‚Äô sake. Instead, it presents us with a new vista. A vista of America where all of its most chauvinistic tendencies have been not only left alone, but cultivated. Thing is‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs a boring vista. A world ruled by Nazis is a fear many people can get behind. A world full of bigotry is just reality. This focus on specifically American societal birth traumas instead of the world overview limits the sight of the player. Plus, some of the threads connecting the characters and the society are liable to transform into something else entirely. Take BJ‚Äôs father, for instance. His last name is Blazkowitcz. And seeing how William speaks a bit of Polish in the first game, we come to the conclusion that his father can‚Äôt really be taken as a classical bigoted American redneck. Especially when you consider the history of Polish nationalism and anti-Semitism (not trying to be antagonistic here, Russia has a lot of same stuff).  Indeed, Joseph Conrad became who he became just to escape his Polish nationalist father and his fight against imperial Russia. Truly, seems that children of Polish nationalists make great New People. Only none of this has anything to really do with America. But do the writers of [i]New Colossus[/i] realize that?

And New People our people are. Where in the first game the Resistance cell felt like dregs of society, the best we could muster, now we wear our eccentricities on our sleeve. Hippie shirts. LSD. Flowery patterns for decoration. It is all fine,but... The hopelessness is gone. We feel like the odds are at the very least equal. 

And then there's the character creep‚Ä¶ Some people die, but many show up and‚Ä¶ Don‚Äôt do too much. Half of them are just quirky and comedic, brought simply for a memorable image, and the other half are Angela Davis. Would be more peculiar if they put Malcolm X in instead. But he would probably refuse to cooperate with BJ in the first place.

Really, bringing historical figures to such game is‚Ä¶ Not a good call. It primitivizes them. Yes, I understand, new [i]Wolfensteins[/i] are camp. But they‚Äôre only part camp. The other part is quite serious, and in this game it‚Äôs a lot more serious than in the previous one. There‚Äôs actually some message here. And when in a single scene you see [spoiler]the F√ºhrer[/spoiler] a)puke b)piss c)mistake [spoiler]Leni Riefenstahl[/spoiler] for his mother d)shoot three people e)curl up like a ball on the carpet‚Ä¶ The message kinda becomes redundant. There‚Äôs no way a player can imagine he has any capacity to become like this man one day. Some people are just evil and deranged. A message for the ages.

And even on the level of characters the game kind of falls flat, because the conflict is no longer as sharp. In the first game everything hinged on Deathshead. So much so he was on every loading screen, BJ and him had William-Wilhelm chemistry, and their face models were somewhat reminiscent of each other. They try to do something like that here too, but eventually fail, because here the antagonist is just a high-seated goon, and not a shot-caller. Plus, the game can‚Äôt quite make up its mind whether the worst thing are the Nazis or the American bigotry.

On the bright side, the direction ‚Äì both of design in general and of cutscenes just skyrocketed. Extremely well done. Also: stealth is better and enemy variety is a bit wider.

Critics loved this game‚Äôs story. Hope they enjoyed [i]Youngblood[/i] which has all the same tendencies, but in a more terminal stage and with smaller budget and poorer cutscenes.

Before I go, just a few short technical questions about the gameplay. Nothing too important.

Why the #$%@ can I simultaneously sprint and reload?
Why the #$%@ do I move as fast while dual-wielding as when I‚Äôm not?
Why the #$%@ leaning up and down has been tampered with?
Why the #$%@ in some arena battles do enemies spawn in when there are no commanders?
Why the #$%@ do I have to be surgically precise to pick up a piece of armor or a medkit when bullets are flying?
Did anybody bother to #$%@&*^ test the courtroom battle on higher difficulties?
What‚Äôs the #$%@&*^ point of augments from the second half of the game?
Why the #$%@ are there no boss battles?

That‚Äôs it. Hope they‚Äôll find the budget and a multiverse loophole out of [i]Youngblood[/i], seeing how [i]Man in the High Castle[/i] tradition allows for it.

New Colossus has a great story, that builds on the events of Wolfenstein New Order. I personally prefer New Order, but New Colossus is very good too. I would describe the story as an emotional rollercoaster.

You know a game is really well done when it gets you to hate an invented character with your whole soul. This woman, fucking Frau Engel, is horrible. And you meet her for the third time. She was in every single game of this series. But all the other characters are well done. They are unique, have their own stories and most of them are interesting and essential.

The detail in this game is amazing. I probably spent about 20 minutes just walking around the submarine base to check out every corner because it was really well done. So many easter eggs, documents and that design‚Ä¶ wow. So good. Also, the city of rosewood was incredibly well done and I appreciated every minute spent there. There are even well designed ‚Äúmovie posters‚Äù around the map. You can see that they spent time and effort to design even such small things as invented Nazi movie posters. Wolfenstein New Colossus is a futuristic sci-fi shooter, with lots of action. Nevertheless, a quick disclaimer: This game is not for people that are new to video games. Before playing this game, many of the reviews I'd read led me to believe it was a lukewarm, slightly-above-average shooter with fun gameplay. Having now completed the game, I could not disagree more with those assessments. It is so much better and so much more than what I was expecting. 

This is a fascinating game - it has starkly memorable characters that exchange well-written and interesting dialogue, fun and slick gameplay, an extremely lived-in world chock full of thoughtfully placed details, a consistent tone tastefully punctuated with story detours both humorous and dark, and a surprising amount of tenderness. More than anything, this game has a story that was clearly crafted by writers who genuinely love these characters and want you to love them too. 

At first blush, "A New Colossus" may seem like a superficially dumb meathead shoot-em-up. However, anyone who has played its predecessor, "A New Order", might correctly expect some surprising layers underneath the adrenaline-filled action. The story is poignant and self-aware, and invites you to explore a myriad of themes and ideas. Like other great games, "The New Colossus" doesn't just hand you everything that the devs prepared for you. It doesn't cram every poignant character interaction down your throat - if you want a lean, short experience that only focuses on blowing up Nazis with no reflection, then you can have that. But there are *so* many interesting moments, waiting patiently for you to discover and engage with. 

The central "hub world" of the game isn't just pretty to look at - it is full of scripted interactions that are *worth* witnessing. One of my favorite moments of the game was a tender, quiet moment between two relatively minor named NPCs in the hub world. It wasn't just dialogue between two static characters, either - it involved one NPC standing up, taking the other by the hand, and walking them across the ship to show them something. And all of that was just a moment in the ship, entirely independent of the protagonist's participation. 

The story progresses at a steady clip, and takes place in a variety of locations. Personally, I think the writing team knew when to be lean and concise, and when to slow down to allow the player to really take in certain story beats. There are a few fascinating, stand-out moments and missions that really feel inspired and unique. Some of the most memorable are quiet interludes involving Blascowicz's past, and one in particular I will remember for a long while. 

Tonally, the game shares a lot of DNA with "The New Order". William "BJ" Blascowicz's heavy, thousand-yard-stare in-game narration makes a return, and establishes a mainline mood that is weary, war-torn, and depressed. That central tone, however, is often deviated from - this is much less of a war campaign than "The New Order". Other characters bring colorful personalities and joy into the story, and you can almost feel the effect they have on elevating Blascowicz's own spirits and mood. 

I think that overall, it creates a consistent mood: the characters are shining beacons of hope that live in a terrible world, where the worst of the worst wield absolute authority. Though they all have different and well-realized personalities, the main cast of allied characters do share one trait: they have a molar-grinding determination and discipline not to give in to the seeming hopelessness of their situation. They choose to fight and resist, and all without becoming grizzled piss-and-vinegar caricatures of resistance fighters. Your band of rebels aren't all tropey "insert badass with five o'clock shadow" characters. Instead, the rebels you meet include a pregnant woman, academics, musicians, etc. They're people first, rebels second. 

Naturally, it is often said that stories like these are only as good as their villains. Luckily, a deliciously detestable villain stars opposite the heroes in this game. Irene Engel was one of the more memorable characters in "A New Order" and her return as the primary antagonist of this game works to great effect. She is formidable, incredibly hateable, and commands a chilling presence both in and outside her scenes in the game. I think she is a stronger villain than the series' preceding main antagonist, General Deathshead. 

I could say more about how surprisingly good I felt the characters and writing were, but I'll just sum it up by reiterating this: I think that the writers are talented craftspeople who genuinely love these characters, poured passion and talent into creating them, and are inviting you to love these characters too. I cared way more than I thought I would. 

The gameplay is very engaging. The guns are crisp, loud, and each has a distinct use and personality. The gun upgrades and customization can also actually significantly impact play, as well - instead of leaning into the assault rifle's capabilities as a full-auto weapon of destruction, I slapped a precision scope on each of mine and ran around duel wielding them in single fire (the scope changes the reticle even when not ADS). Enemy types feel varied and dangerous, and also just look really good. The weapon design, enemy design, and general environments are all aesthetically interesting (or at least I thought they were). 

I feel like overall, this game was created with a very cogent, consistent vision. It wasn't designed to maximize milking your money. To use an incredibly overrused cliche (but one that I think fits), it feels like this game was made with love by a team that was genuinely passionate about bringing their vision of these characters and their struggles to life. 

I strongly recommend. Would definitely step into Terror-Billy's shoes again to bash Nazis and feel a surprising amount of fondness for him and his found family of misfits.

I am so conflicted with this game. I sort of regret buying it (on sale), and was considering refunding it, but decided to keep playing. The story is just pretty bad in this Wolfenstein. I absolutely loved the other two, The New Order and The Old Blood. There was so much virtue signaling that was super lame. Really ruined a lot of the game for me.

Stuff I liked about the game:
-The shooting mechanics, they are very good in all the Wolfenstein games
-Some of the level design was pretty creative
-The voice acting was pretty good for the most part
-There were some good weapons and they were fun to use, although wish there would have been a few more
-I really like how there are two story lines like in The New Order, that is awesome

Stuff I didnt like about the game:
-The virtue signaling, probably the worst part of the game
-The starting and pause menus are so blank and boring compared to the other two games, literally just a white screen with black text, couldnt have put at least a tiny bit of work into it? Kinda lame.
-Same with the Item icons that appear on screen, blank and boring
-BJ, (and most NPCs) look way worse in this game, i didnt like how they looked at all, their teeth and eyes were awful
-The beginning level you start off in a wheel chair, was pretty boring they should have made some sort of short normal level before that, I didnt like the wheelchair level one bit.
-Anya also looks awful, Same with Wyatt
-A couple of the soldiers didnt even have German accents or anything, though it was only like 2
-Music not as good as the other two games
-BJ is ALWAYS talking about Caraline that got really old really fast
-The resistance in the game, is just a bunch of hipsters, kind of stupid
-99 percent of the characters in the game are totally unlikable
-Couple of references to BJ that he totally would not have gotten
-A lot of man hating, which is weird for a game that mostly men are going to play
-They like try to make this game a love story, which is just pretty awful for Wolfenstein
-Stupid tasks between missions
-Ridiculous plot holes
-The HORRIBLE song cover at the end, WHY couldnt you just get the original song? lol

If there wasnt so much virtue signaling, and more like-able characters, and less plot holes I would recommend this game, but how it is, I cant. Only get it on sale if you have already played the other two games, and just want more Wolfenstein to play, but dont expect it to be as good as the other two. If you can just avoid it all together, I kinda wish that I would have.

I'd give this game a 4/10, mainly because of the writing.

The gameplay is great, even better than the last one thanks to weapon upgrades and contraptions. But gameplay can only do so much to make up for bad writing, and that's why I wouldn't recommend this game.

*spoilers ahead*

It's stated in this game that with the death of Deathshead, the nazi's R&D is crippled. Yet every weapon and enemy is bigger, badder, and more advanced than ever. Despite it only being 5 months after TNO, nearly every design for enemies, weapons, and environments has all changed. My biggest gripe is with the U-Boat. It tripled in size since TNO and it has a secret section with a single hidden entrance that seems to take up half the ship. It's also where all of the nuclear warheads are found, apparently, and yet for 5 months not a single person wondered why they couldn't find any more nukes.

Moving on, the Ubercommando missions have no impact on the story whatsoever, and the ending is so abrupt it feels like a large chunk of the game is missing. There's an artifact BJ gives to Set that makes him go nuts on 3 occasions, and that goes absolutely nowhere. One mission is basically a copy of the Moon mission from TNO. Just lots of dead ends, weird, awkward, and uninteresting characters, a boring story, etc etc.

It's a shame because the game is beautiful and fun to play, but I have no desire to replay it because of the terrible writing.

Having played through The New Order and The Old Blood just prior to this, I was initially a bit disappointed, as in terms of purity of the shooter experience this game is far behind its predecessors. Perhaps the biggest reason are the advanced visuals and very high contrast, which often make enemies and objects difficult to spot (not in the good-difficult way, but in the unnecessary-annoying way). However, the combat is still by and large enjoyable, with reasonably well-balanced mechanics and decent weaponry (aside from the questionable decision to remove the option to toggle aiming down sights).

What truly convinced me to this game though, is the absolutely brilliant production throughout. From world design, through dialogues and lip sync, all the way to cut-scenes, the game is very immersive, and made me enjoy the experience of playing it tremendously, even if I didn't enjoy the combat itself as much as in TNO. Some of the cut-scenes were really long, but they were so well-produced that they felt like genuine scenes from a movie! I think they worked perfectly in combination with the gameplay though; thankfully they didn't go overboard and make it into a full-blown movie.

And a final shout-out goes to performance optimisation, which is maybe the best I've seen. Despite the game looking fucking gorgeous, I got stable 160+ fps on max settings and 1080p on a GTX 1070. I genuinely can't remember a game where I'd get such high and stable fps throughout, let alone such a modern one.

When it comes to the DLC (The Freedom Chronicles), I think a lot of the criticism is deserved, as they don't really add anything new to the experience, other than a little more volume. And, given the length (3-4h if you're rushing, 8-9h completionist), it's certainly not worth its full price. I don't think there's anything terrible about it as such, but the levels are pretty repetitive in terms of enemies and loot, the stories are rather bland, and there are no new mechanics whatsoever. Despite that though, the stories were a reasonable amount of fun to play through, as they mostly maintained the still solid combat experience of the main game.

I think someone at Machine Games saw that Wolfenstein and Doom 2016 were both hits, and tried to capture the best aspects of both in one game. Despite their conceptual similarity, they're not compatible.

Gunplay is smooth and fast-paced, but frustrating in parts. There are places where you have to make split-second decisions based on things you won't know until you've died at least once. People praise the level design, but it leads to some trial-and-error gameplay, because a good stealth level isn't a good arena and vice versa. You can now dual-wield two different types of guns, but the dual weapons wheel is so clunky I didn't want to risk using it in combat. Even for switching single weapons. So that was one step forward, two steps backwards. There are lots of new weapons, but they have so much functional overlap that there's no reason to switch unless you run out of ammo or need a silencer. And in place of the second half of the story, we get a bunch of sidequests on reused maps. Between the unnecessary upgrade system, the grindy perk system, and the hub world with side-quest filler, I felt like I was playing a Ubisoft game. Ugh.

The story was... interesting. The New Order ended on a low note, so continuing from there felt a bit forced. The tone is inconsistent and keeps the more serious moments from really landing. It's also short, but I was either bored or frustrated most of the time, so I wasn't disappointed to reach the end earlier than I expected. There are too many new characters in too short a story, so I never got attached. MG really tried to weave together a narrative from the dangling threads of the last game, but Order wasn't written with a sequel in mind, and there just weren't enough loose ends to work with. A lot of the major plot points in Colossus are recycled from Order, but dialed up to twelve (Order was already at eleven.) What *is* new feels as contrived as the intro, and there's no tension when people you don't care about die and resurrect at the writer's convenience. Colossus paradoxically lowers the stakes as the scale grandiosifies.

TNC's biggest problem is that it's a sequel that no one needed. It doesn't have anything new to say and it could only top its predecessor by increasing the scale and lowering the emotional stakes. But while it's unnecessary, it's competently made and might appeal to fans of DOOM '16. Just don't go into it expecting a sequel to Wolfenstein: The New Order.

Side note: some of the voice acting was pretty bad. I caught the schizophrenic French bartender pronouncing voiced initial "TH" as "D", "Z", and correctly as "TH", all in one sentence. I'm thinking that VA has never even met a French person. A bit disappointing, considering the first game used native speakers for the voice roles.

One would like to think that years after the release of this game that Bethesda would read all the comments attesting to its poor stability, but I guess we're left playing this thing on a wing and a prayer.

The game had potential, but falls short of the New Order in a few ways.

-environment design. At a few points in the game I had difficulty in telling where to go or what to do. This could have been abated by clever coloring and texturing, but most of the palate is just some variation of dark and or grey. This makes it difficult to tell where enemies are, since they also blend into the environment since they use the same color palate

-general handling. the dual wielding is a bit clunky, and for some reason only your right weapons gets reloaded, which really messed up the flow of combat. It is also very time consuming to switch out of dual wielding to another dual or single weapon. The stealth system also needed some flushing out, as enemies can see you when peaking around corners, for example.

-overall structure. BJ spends the first half of the game partially crippled (hilarious early part rolling around in a wheelchair shooting Nazis though), but the first half of the game throws too much at you to justify this half health restriction it imposes and just is frustrating after a while.

-confusing rules for the player. Maybe this is because I have been playing Doom Eternal, but I just can't figure out what the game wanted the players to do. Should I be running and gunning around to pick up health packs or hiding around a corner to funnel the enemies into a killzone? It does not help that enemies seem to appear out of nowhere behind you, and you end up dying quite quickly.

-overall balance. I found the heavy weapons dropped by supersoldaten mostly useless by the end. dual wielding certain upgraded standard weapons offered far better odds, compared to the movement restriction imposed by the heavy weapons, especially because BJ seems so fragile in this game. Just an indication that the individual parts of this game were not put together very well in the end.

Like I said at the beginning. It is worth 10 bucks and a single play through, but I do not see much beyond that. It definitely has some of the charm that the New Order had, but it seems to be trying to take things too seriously in some places.

The lack of removing headbobbing makes me carsick under extended play.... still going to complete it.

This game is great. Combat is fun and the stealth is powerful enough to stealth most missions. I honestly reccomend most players play on a lower difficulty for the best experience as damage felt inconsistent and random at times. Mitigating that issue, by lowering the difficulty, can really give you the ability to stand up and shoot your way out, mix things up a little. 

However, coming from The New Order it is a bit lackluster in pacing and storytelling compared to the juggernaut that game was. However, asides from sub-optimal storytelling the themes and game play still shine. Themes of social justice, critical dialogue, dehumanization, exploitation, etc. are all present but not as well rehearsed as the previous game. As another player mentioned, outside of the levels there is a distinct lack of threat in the story that seemed to permeate throughout the TNO. Otherwise, most of my problems with the game lie in a lack of optimization meaning you should definitely wait to play this on a slight beefier computer. Finally, you get to rip and tear nazis, which is always a plus.

READ BEFORE BUY!

So I love this game, its one of my favorites but this game needs a serious optimization fix. I've done the whole search around for this games hot fixes and what not on youtube. The fixes very. But buy at your own risk. It always crashes for me when I die, black loading screens causing a force shutdown of the application. Its not a bad game at all and looks amazing on PC but feels abandoned on PC by the developers who don't seem to care about it. Its filled with errors that will never be fixed. In the wise words of loltyler1: "FIX THE GAME"
new order is better but this is still good

One of the worst shooting mechanics, uninspired gameplay, forced stealth and the dumbest AI. Never thought someone could beat Naughty Dog at making the era defining bad AI. But the developer of this game does. It tries to capture the oldskool no minimap navigating style of Half life games. But Half Life games had good level designing. The level design in this game is confusing clusterfcuk of props and game assets with poorly executed pathways for gameplay variation (game forces you to play stealth which is atrociously unrewarding and stale with 0 skill requirement). On higher diffliculty, enemies are bullet sponge. They have no real depth or substance.  They stand, they shoot, they die. Story is well....this is how a procrastinator writes a short story. Compilation of various ideas lacking good foundations. This reflects on the characters we are introduced to. One dimensional cardboard.
 In the end, this game tries desperately not to be like DOOM 2016.

The game looks good and continues the alternate 1960s vibe. But the game engine has a fatal flaw that just ruins the game experience. It is very easy to get stuck behind things when exploring the levels. To have this in a game now adays is just shoddy programming nad incompetent level design. There simply is no excuse for it. 

If you like frustration and endless reloads as you lose progress when getting stuck behind chairs, boxes and other usually movable objects, or if you think a good game requires you to hit fast save every few seconds then this is the game for you! Otherwise you might be happier with the technically better previous games in the series. 

I am deeply disapointed in this entry into the franchise. When released it was not a finished game, but hey! why care about the players? They only fork over their money right?

If I could describe Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus in one word it would be: Solid.

There are great things and not so great things about this game that make it a solid 85/100 for me.

The most appealing factor to this game for people is undoubtedly its unique take on Alternate WWII history mixed together with phenomenal gunplay. 

Let's get to the important stuff before the more nit-picky details that I had problems with..

How is the Gunplay/Core Gameplay?

The most obvious feature this game has is its emphasis on intense close quarters engagements, however there is another side to this coin. You can approach combat in any way you want, or not at all in some situations.
The rpg elements this game has are progressed in accordance with what weapons you use, or how you take down Nazis. There is no overall leveling system that you expend points earned on perks. Instead, the devs used a more hands-off system to enact their rpg perk elements, which I appreciate. We know this game is first and foremost a shooter, the hands-off "unlock as you use system" is refreshing over an outright RPG leveling system and in my eyes keeps the action-shooter in the front supported by a serviceable perk system that add the appropriate amount of depth to the gameplay. 

Further in to the game you unlock a "new suit" that adds little to the actual gameplay other than, I guess, roleplay purposes? This mechanic being added in about midway through the game is purely optional to use in actual gameplay and, in my eyes, is a wasted opportunity to have a more fleshed out system than what it is.. a gimmick.

You are presented with a choice of three suits all three clearly having distinct playstyles in mind. Guns blazing, stealth, and tactical. 
Something about this system just seems so unnecessary, you can do everything in this game without the mechanic better. It feels bloated and a square piece for a circle hole. This requires further explanation.

The first one is a ram ability that activates when you sprint. okay, but what if you play on higher difficulties to where you die in five shots with max health and armor? The mechanic is negated.

The second is a compression vest for your torso allowing you to fit in smaller spaces for a limited time before dying from oxygen loss. The thing is these smaller compression zones are few and far inbetween and seem to be where the enemy is patrolling. Okay so you take an extra couple of minutes to get behind the guard and stab him from behind rather than just peek a corner and pop him in the head once with your suppressed pistol which is much faster. Its negated. There are far more efficient ways to play this game without the risk of 10 guards seeing you try and maneuver to shank this guy from behind. Defeating the purpose.

The third are these long legs, similar to stilts. I play my games on the highest difficulty I can. The reason I do this is two fold. The first reason is that it creates much more satisfying gameplay moments. The second is that it forces you to maximize efficiency and use every system the game offers to achieve your goal, experiencing everything the game has to offer. The purpose of these long legs is that you can get a more "tactical" view of the area. I get the idea, you can peek over tall cover and smoke a bunch of Nazis from above right? Wrong. You're dead in five shots, and the Nazi scum has Annie Oakley accuracy up close. Negated. Before you can fire a couple of shots you're swarmed because your position is exposed and the enemies fire on sight, duh.

Overall, I think the gunfights, the stealth and even the gun niches are enjoyable. The best part of the game hands down. Some gun/grenade upgrades are useless and very situational and some are so important that you almost are forced to take them. It really does suck to not see such a balanced gun upgrade system. Because it should add, not just be there and be forgotten about.

So, what does all this really mean? It means there are great aspects to this game and there are super forgettable ones as well.
Moving on..

How's this game sound?

It sounds brilliant. This game's combat music takes inspiration from Doom's phenomenal soundtrack as well as elements from The New Order, which in my opinion is slept on. 
Guns sound punchy and the impact of weapons sound gory and brutal. Grenades are generic grenade explosion sounds with nothing of note. The laser weapons are distinctive, effective, and the sound of disintegrating Nazis is always satisfying. The heavy weapons sound and feel so good you'll wanna slow yourself down on purpose just to drag them around. Love em. The sound of the world around, the ambiance, is calming compared to the brutalistic nature of this game. A nice dichotomy that I think highlights the absurdity and perversion of nature that is the Nazi ideology. Maybe I'm reading too much into it who knows.

How are the Levels?

While I think the New Order's level design is superior to this installment, I do still like it. Most environments are open enough for you to have tactical leeway without it feeling you're on rails. And some times you do. Some chapters feel like you're doing nothing but going room to room clearing Nazis just to do an action that opens a new area, then clear more rooms. This was revolutionary 25 years ago. It is not now in current year. However; the weapons and intensity of the firefights keep you engaged and all that feeling doesn't wash over until you're looking around for collectibles in each area. It really does feel like a cage match at times, albeit a fun one. 

What's the world like? How about the lore? Is the Story any good?

The World of New Colossus is far more fleshed out than the New Order and adds to the already great ambiance and setting of the series. Finding all the collectibles reveals a lot about the world that didn't make it into the dialogue/cutscenes of the game. The world building is obviously fantasy as to how the Nazis won WWII with them essentially stealing technology from a secret society and using it for their own gains. This game really does hammer in the point that Nazis are evil by the way, and that you are the underdog good guys. I agree Nazi man bad. HOWEVER; a lot of people don't understand that historically the Nazis drafted people against their own free will into their war machine, and I'll bet my bottom dollar a lot of germans didn't agree with Nazi propaganda. Watch interviews of german veterans of the war and citizens. To paint the picture that every single soldier of the Reich is nothing but a mindless drone takes away, rather than adds. I remember a cutscene from the New Order about the horrors of war BJ was discussing with Bombate. If the game wants to blatantly talk about the "horrors of war" then at least mention in a cutscene rather than a discarded letter that those soldiers were boys drafted by a monster to do the bidding of an empire they didn't believe in. The world is more than just 2Dimentional boogeymen who kill anyone they don't like at any given time of the day. Shallow to say the least.

Overall, I think the story is next to derailed by obvious token characters whose personalities are entitlement, greed, and outright narcissism. The comedic relief characters are there to service the token characters and it really is insulting to the legacy characters we had in the original. I do not want a lecture when playing my games whether I agree with the agenda or not. Almost ruined the game for me because I have so much love for Fergus, Anya, BJ, Max, Bombate, and Caroline.. most of these characters are dragged through the mud for no reason other than servicing these new token characters. 

The story is in the end satisfying because for me its about the journey, not the destination. 

Lasty how does this game look and run?
To run this game at 60 FPS on Medium settings you're looking at a decent rig..
I play max settings and the game looks great! Beautiful to look at truly.

The guns, gunplay, and sneaking around is still as fun as the first two instalments. The gameplay is more polished and the final fight didn't involve some annoying static boss and was actually quite fun. Overall recommended if you liked the gameplay of the first two games.

Blazo, however, continues to be an enjoyable protagonist to play as. He's got some interesting monologue and is deeper than the "Terror Billy" moniker he's given.

Wolfenstein II is a beast of a game. It has the same foundation as the previous entries, but incredibly shaken up and crazier stuff is happening. It still feels consistent with the tones of the previous games as well, but the writing is pretty nuts, and some interesting choices by the writing team (some good, some bad) will stick with you for sure. It's much, much less linear than the previous games as well, and the ways you can choose to progress are pretty neat. This is definitely a sequel worth getting, it's just a shame that things went downhill after this entry. Hopefully Wolfenstein III can fix things properly.

The tone definitely changed in this game when compared to The New Order. Whether you like it or not, depends entirely on you. 

I personally enjoyed playing this game a lot! The soundtrack was amazing, and the gunplay is so much better. The guns sound and feel great to use, and close quarter takedowns are very satisfying (although, it does suck that you can still take damage when you‚Äôre performing one, making it not worth doing on higher difficulties). 

The difficulty in this game is alot different from what it used to be back in the prequels, TNC/TOB. [b] I AM DEATH INCARNATE! [/b]from those games are more in line with [b] I Am Terror Billy [/b] than with the one in this game. You die REALLY fast, and are forced into playing stealthy, which sucks, because the gunplay is so good in this game. If it gets difficult for you, I recommend lowering the difficulty. I started on [b] Terror Billy [/b], and went down to [b] Do or Die! [/b]. Play with what you‚Äôre most comfortable with. 

All in all, it‚Äôs a game I‚Äôd recommend getting, especially on sale (the collection, while you‚Äôre at it). 

BJ‚Äôs narration is still top notch. I love the VA.

We need more games like this!

While i have few gripes with the game, in the end what matters is that it was fun.

gripes: 
Played on I am death incarnate, the difficulty felt at times incredibly luck-based - like getting randomly oneshot by an enemy. Came into a T-junction and looked in the wrong direction first? Fuck you, you are dead. And the AI definitely felt smarter in New Order, many of the harder fights are possible to cheese due to dumb AI.

Heavy weapons are kinda useless, the slow movement and slow spool-up means death. Probably worst offender is the Ubergewehr (BFG), i literally only used it twice effectively and that was when you come across it for the first time - where the area is literally designed for it to be effective to try it out. 

The SJW propaganda was also pretty heavy-handed, i doubt other games would get away with it if you weren't fighting literal nazis. [spoiler] Is it just me, or Caroline was killed off just so they could introduce Grace - the strong black woman leader? [/spoiler]

Collectibles in games lately really piss me off. It is not a fun experience to look for them at all, yet it still creates the feeling of leaving the game unfinished if you don't. Probably my brain is just broken.

While the game is passable and mostly fun, the game is riddled with game-breaking bugs that can ruin your experience. The game is largely abandoned, so I don't expect these bugs to be fixed. Use caution when using manual saves as they may become corrupted and prevent you from finishing mission without crashing. The levels are also not very well designed when it comes to collision boxes. At multiple points in game I had to adjust camera and character very precisely to walk through what looks like a completely clear passage. It may seem you are not supposed to go a certain direction, but the collision boxes simply prevent you from going where you need to.

Overall story and game-play is enjoyable, but be prepared for many crashes and headaches. Pickup on discount.

This game fights itself over being a hardcore burly American adventure, and a soap opera. The mood that the lore of the game sets for itself through the majority of the game matches with the setting, but not in a good way. The game tries to explain BJ's past as a sad, depressing one full of pain while simultaneously putting on a depressing lore for the present. Thinking about BJ's hardships as a kid and depressing circumstances as an adult which the game doesn't let you forget does not put me in the mood to blast Nazis into smithereens.

Combat is good though.

As a shooting game, it's fine. The game has got some great action packed moments and fairly well balanced mechanics, though nothing truly stands out. It's in reality as a narrative experience that Wolfenstein II shines. The writing, the performances, the music, the cinematic vision, and the way that it all comes together, makes for a convincingly confident and self-aware narrative that's really truly remarkable.
If you easily find yourself offended by videogames making political statements or attempting to lecture you, or if you simply play games for escapism free of story breaks requiring attention, Wolfenstein II probably isn't for you. But if you enjoy strong, uncompromising storytelling that isn't afraid to challenge you, I'd say you owe it to yourself to experience this thrilling roller coaster ride!
