Such a fascinating game. I've played the previous one twice and it was fantastic, hence i got 2nd version too. I always wanted to get into Wolfenstein games and now i can finally say that i've played half of the franchise.

Gameplay:
Compared to the last version there is not much difference, they are both very alike. Graphics are way better obviously and quite a few things have changed. Variety of guns, characters, areas, enemies and so on. Wheel, from where you are able to change guns, also feels way smoother and you can choose which gun you want to hold. You can have a pistol and a shotgun in another hand. Movement feels similar, shooting as well. It has 2 endings, but nothing really changes. It is possible to upgrade your guns and there are "skill tree" sort of things, basically you have to kill enemies and you level up, which makes your character strong. However, its not exactly skill tree, things just upgrade on their own as you kill nazis.

Story:
I actually enjoyed the cutscenes way more than actual gameplay. Frankly, it was quite boring and got repetitive quickly, however the story itself was amazing. I'd love to just watch them instead of playing. William moves to New Mexico, USA, and starts a revolution against nazis. In the meantime he gets a lot of new friends who help him riot against them. In the USA William finds a village, where he used to live. He starts to reminisce about his mom, different race(d) girl and a dog. Unfortunately, his dad was a d1ckhead and excessively strict. He used to beat him and tried to teach him how to be a man. The dad makes William to kill his own dog (you can make the choice as a player whether you shot it or not). I, personally, did not kill it, but dad did anyway. I wont take anything from him though, because he was a strict one yet nice at times. Once William could not sleep, because he was scared of basement monsters, therefore the dad came up to the child, gave him a gun and they both went to the basement to find demons (with the mom). Keep in mind the year, everything happens in 20th century where racial discrimination is a thing, thats the reason why his dad did not like the girl (William's friend) with different skin color. Blazkowicz's mother is a jew and as its already known nazis did not like them. His dad sets her up and gives her to nazis. However, William did not know anything about it, untill he went back to the village (as mentioned). After he is done reminiscing about his childhood, he enters his parent's room and sees his father. They have conversation about personal subjects, but after Blazkowicz finds out that he, basically, sold his wife William gets mad and murders him, but the dad was close to nazis, therefore he had called them in advance, hence they knew William's location. This is basically the sum up, but there were a lot of things i did not mention.

The story is not all about Blazkowicz's childhood, but it surely is interesting. I dont wanna spoil much, but revolutionaries somehow got themselves a huge USS Nautilus sort of thing (you can google that, i did not know either). Sadly, they did not check every room on the ship, therefore some nazis that were still on board hiding, they were sending the revolutionaries' location to nazi nation. However William finds them and murders them all. After they have cleaned the ship then they head to New mexico. Let me cut the chase and tell you the best scene in the game, where you meet Hitler the F√ºhrer himself. I wanted to see him in game and i was excited to observe what he was capable of and let me tell you, he did not disappoint. He lives on mars, i think, because that was the safest location. In order to get to Hitler, William had to change his "body" basically and became an actor, because Hitler was planning to set up a theater about killing Blazkowicz, so he needed people. I wont keep on going, you must see everything yourself, not to mention i am bad at telling stories so!

Things i did not like:
Game being repetitive. The fact that it does not have replayability, even though it has 2 endings, but not different from each other one person replaces another. and same times of enemies, I did say it has variety, which is true, but after some times they were all the same and it just got boring. Other than these it was amazing.
Go play RealRTCW mod instead.

I really didn't like the quality of this one, especially after how amazing New Order was. The intro to this one was extremely deep, and really does play with your emotion, but all of that foundation gets lost with really bizarre, forced silliness later. I did find it really humorous at first, but that effect is just lost because it tries far too hard to be funny and unique, and forces it far too often. Not to mention the really repetitive combat and level design as you get into the game. It'll crash too, and is really badly polished for a game that's been out for four years. Really, it's amazing at first, but just halfway through reveals it had no more up tricks up its sleeve, and by the end I was just hoping it'd be over already. Really disappointed

Wow, this game is a super underrated gem. IMO it's one of the best single player fps games of the 2010s, up there with DOOM, and other great games. Its a sequel, and it could be played without playing the first game and the spinoff, but those games are really good too, I recommend picking up A new order, the old blood, and this all on sale. 

First of all I want to talk about the protagonist, P.J. Blazkowicz, perhaps the most badass protagonist in any videogame, rivaling masterchief and DOOMguy. He falls into that category of unkillable badasses, and he really makes you just want to kill nazis. He was a good character in the first game, but not great. However in this game he is outstanding, they give us a great backstory, and he is amazing.

The game itself has amazing graphics, music, super fun gameplay, where the dual wielding system lets you make tons of combinations. movement is good, everything you could want is good. My only complaint is that it is only 7 hours long, but those 7 hours are amazing. 

The campaign has a good story, and the cutscenes feel like a movie, but the best stuff is how gruesome it is, there are multiple cutscenes, especially early on that are just horrible, but even in some of them you start cracking up from how hilarious this game is, its so goddamn funny. There are other normal cutscenes that are just hilarious.

after you finish the great campaign, theres the side missions to do, I havent done them yet, but Ill edit this saying how worth it they were.

you can also play through all combat sections for points and a time in the main menu

Please just buy this game on sale, its easily one of the best single player games of all time

Wolfenstein 2: The New Colossus, isn't a bad game by any means, but it was a major letdown after playing The New Order.  

First of all, the game goes waaaaay overboard on the cut scenes.  Other people who've played this have done the math and apparently half of the game consists of cutscenes.  I don't know if this is true, but it sure felt that way because every other level seemed to involve me wandering around the much larger hub (a stolen U-Boat called Eva's Hammer) listening to numerous conversations and doing various fetch quests. 

Don't get me wrong, some of the cutscenes were extremely funny such as the one involving Hitler and the milkshake scene in Roswell, but there were a lot of times when I just wanted to get to the action.  

Speaking of action, the gameplay wasn't as fun as The New Order, either.  For starters, you play a good chunk  of the game with half health, which means you have to rely much more heavily on stealth and cover shooting instead of mostly doing whatever you wanted like in the first game.  Second, I hated the weapon switching mechanics.  Perhaps it's easier to use on a controller, but it was cumbersome with the keyboard/mouse.  

The levels didn't have as many interesting features, either.  Sure, you get to go to Venus this time, but it didn't feel like a space station and there wasn't much to see outside the windows, though I did laugh when I saw that on Venus they eat the nutrient cubes from the original Star Trek series.  The Roswell levels, though, were the game's high point since you get to see what Nazi America would be like as well as travel through a speeding rocket train.

Enemy variety seemed to be missing as well.  I missed the different uniforms that the Nazis in the New Order wore depending on their location, and they seemed to carry a greater variety of weapons in the first game.  There aren't any truly massive robots, either.  Indeed, I wouldn't even say there is a final boss fight unless you count two extra tough versions of the supersoldiers you've been fighting throughout the game.   Thus, the final enemy you dispatch was a bit of a let down even though it was enjoyable to finally put an end to her.  

As for the story, well it's not as tight as the first game's, though it has some good moments.  They managed to create an even more ridiculous plot, to the point where it was a bit difficult to suspend disbelief even for a Wolfenstein game, but overall it was okay.  The new characters were a bit of a mixed bag.  Most of them are forgettable since so many of them end up in your hub, and a few like Grace are downright obnoxious, but some like Sigrun were pretty funny.  The returning characters, however, were more interesting overall. 

Lastly, I had a lot more technical problems with this game.  For some reason, it liked to crash during loading screens somewhat frequently.  I tried a few fixes but none of them worked.  I'm not sure if other people will experience the same problems, however.  

Overall, I'd say that Wolfenstein 2: The New Colossus is worth getting if you really need to see how the story continues, but otherwise I would stick with The New Order.

Wolfenstein II delivers the ideal experience for a first person shooter just like its predecessor, The New Order. Blazkowicz is badass as always and dual-wielding is joyful as ever it is. Especially cinematic narrative and gameplay continues well in this sequel. But unlike The New Order, The New Colossus gives us a crazier story and settings like Venus. Blazkowicz is faster and stronger now. Some of us will not like all of these changes but this is Wolfenstein, everyone can find something to like. There is one thing I should say, our crew could be made much interactable. There isn't much activity to do in our submarine. I can't stop thinking about what if we could have Metro Exodus's train atmosphere with these characters. Wouldn't be great? 8 out of 10.

This game is fantastic. Following one of the best stories in recent FPS games, and adding a lot of flavour on top of it. There's a few things I'd have done differently, but I still love it. It's filled with nice little touches, like the bass guitars being all left handed, because you know, the fantasy nazi Beatles are the biggest band in the world, and nazi Paul McCartney is nazi left handed.

The base game is genius, however the DLC are very maligned. Now I don't think they're as bad as people make them, but they're very lazy, and just a reuse of assets. I don't blame the developers, this looks like some contractual obligation with the Publisher, that they just had to fill. Don't bother, watch the cutscenes on Youtube, and you'll get the best part of them all, 'cause the characters are actually ok.

Honest review

Game is amazing looking, effects, you may get odd error where weapons are near silent and everything else is loud. 

Gameplay tuned up and good from first 2, nice selection of games and neat upgrades to each weapon.

gunfights can be fun, I say can be. Why?

Poorest execution of a certain trope 
[spoiler] Character is slowly dying on first half [/spoiler] at start of game you are stuck at 50hp in one of the most frustrating, poorly executed mechanic for tension. 

Armor, might as well be wearing paper because thats how it feels like, running to 2-3 soldiers will shred you like it.

Problems due to 50hp

YOU WILL DIE A TON and for BS reasons. If you have the odd quiet gun sounds problem, you will miss being shot from the back.

Certain level areas are constant death traps as you struggle to stay alive with bad armor and 50hp.

And it doesnt get better with 100hp with poor armor  and enemy dps just destroying you.

A lot of weapons feel poor. Pistol? eh only if you want to stealth but game is setup to eventually set off alarms.

SMG, pretty good once upgraded, AR also, and shotgun 3x shot, is you're best one

nade pistol nah skip it, you'll find others are better.

laser: best one once upgraded fully.

Other heavy weapons, good but major draw backs

BFG like weapon, I swear the way they put this one into levels is non viable. Why?

Unless you're shooting normal soldiers directly its good. Shooting at mechs, heavily armored power suited ones? Ha they just charge at you so you lose the secondary dmg explosion. Charges slow so get shot and die, travels slower than grandma on sand. Get ready to miss unless you plan out spawn areas.

It just feels like wasted potential. Especially on Air ship battle, ready yourself for frustration. Drop it and use fully upgraded weapons instead.

Overall

Gameplay 7/10

I knock down points for super poor execution on HP at start and weapons viability. 

But story is good, still worth a buy at sale.

Take everything good about Wolfenstein: The New Order (2014) and throw it out the window. 

Alternate reality / alternate history games can be amazing fun and a great trip down the "what if" rabbit hole, this is not one of those games. The writers seemed more concerned with how much shock value they could throw in without the ESRB damning them to hell and the game is filled with characters that to be honest, you'd rather shoot in the head then suffer through one more of their cut scenes or one liners. 

The plot feels extremely unfinished and more of a "wouldn't this be cool to do" brainstorming session than anything that should have been a finished game. Sure this is a game, in a fictional alt history setting, but there's no way in hell a pregnant lady is going to be running around in a warzone, jumping and rolling around, flinging herself through the air and landing on her stomach every two seconds. A lot of the wordage used in the dialogues was just plain unnecessary, there were tons of different ways to get across the point that his father was racist without resorting to using the N word, but again it's all about shock value and not substance.

As far as the actual gameplay, every Nazi either is heavily armored or even when they aren't it still takes a good deal of ammo to bring them down even when you have your weapons upgraded. A headshot doesn't feel like a headshot, etc. for example. They rely far too much on enemies dropping from the ceiling, etc. things like that to bring enemies in rather than having them patrolling the larger areas, everything is very contained. 

Overall: Wolfenstein 2 feels like they took the original team, fired them, and then scraped the bottom of the barrel to put together a team that would have been more suited to a Duke Nuke'em game. It's lazy in every way, uninspired, more annoying than enjoying, and hopefully if there's another game made after this, it's from a different developer.

[h1] A great leap forward from the New Order, but with small issues [/h1]

[b] Spoiler free Review by an average gamer. Game beaten on "Bring em on"/Normal difficulty [/b]

[u] Things I enjoyed [/u]
- Obviously, stunning graphics and a great artstyle. Machines, Buildings, uniforms and many other aspects are designed stunningly
- And unexpectedly amazing story (for a shooter) that actually entertained me, no more whining and bo hooing like in TNO, just sheer dedication to fight the Nazis
- A point that I pointed out in TNO already and I'm happy to do it again: Stealth is 100% optional = no "you have to retry mission if spotted" no, if you are spotted you will just have to fight head on. Stealth makes things easier, but it's not required
- Even further, the game extends into that fact by letting you customise even more into the 3 playstyles "Stealth, Mayhem and Tactical)
- Weapons feel beefy and impactful. Even on strong enemies you notice that your weapons do in fact hurt them. (Except for the MP, that one feels weak unless used in stabbing range akimbo)
- Damage model. In combination with the above, enemies get damage depending on the weapon you killed them with (chunks of flesh are missing if shot with the shotgun)
- Akimbo is possible, just like in TNO, but this time you can select two DIFFERENT weapons for each hand
- A comparable arsenal to TNO, some weapons have been "merged" (The STG61 now serves as assault and, on switch, as a sniper rifle with a flip-up scope) in order to make room for a few new weapons. Especially the heavy weapon-pick ups are glorious
- After the Knive from TNO and the Pipe from TOB we now have a fire axe as melee weapon
- Old senile Hitler

[u] Things that could've been better, but were okay/avoidable [/u]

- most interaction scenes are too slow/clunky to be fluently integrated into the combat. I had to avoid melee takedowns because BJ would always take his time on the kill, so the other two enemies had plenty of time to get me from full health AND armor down to zero

- The Laserkraftwerk, which was a signature weapon in TNO, constantly being upgraded and growing with the player, is now rather "unimportant" like its just another weapon in your arsenal

- Your max health is limited to 50HP for the first half of the game

[u] Things I did not enjoy [/u]

- The Dogs and the miniature version of the mecha dogs. If you play without headphones and due to their small size you have almost no chance to hear or see them coming, and then you suddenly get pinned down to the ground to be annihilated by other enemies with guns
- Venus, I almost enjoyed not a single bit of it. 
- Tampers, absoluetly annoying enemies
-Very poor feedback for incoming damage. I often died all of a sudden because I literlly did not notice being hit
-Like in TNO I could write an entire essay of why I did not enjoy the finale. Too hard, no explanation given. Which would be no problem as bosses are supposed to have a tactic you need to discover BUT you have NO time to find out about it as you are under constant fire that shreds you once you are out of cover and while you ARE in cover there are endless standart enemies that use the chance to swarm you

[u] Conclusion [/u]

I overall enjoyed Wolfenstein 2, more than The New Order or The Old Blood. It improved on some weaknesses, but also created a few new ones.

8/10

I had to pause the game mid-cutscene and write this review. Wolfenstein II is the worst attempt at storytelling I have recently experienced. That is not normally a problem, however, you CANNOT SKIP THE IN-GAME CUTSCENES. IN A GAME FROM 2017. Making this game almost unplayable. You can't even alt tab since the game auto-pauses on loss of focus, with no option to adjust this. And while you can skip the rendered cutscenes, anything performed within the game engine itself is unskippable. 

Let me waste my time and tell you why the writing deserves this hatred:

The writer committed the awful sin of attempting to tackle extremely mature themes and ideas, while obviously lacking any of the skill or talent required to do so. The style poorly emulates the ironic tone of Rockstar's GTA 5 and perhaps a little bit of Half Life-esque first person narrative, also done in a merely emulative fashion. A number of the characters are walking punchlines (Fat Nazi, Walt the Hippie who took LSD and haha he's so loopy) or shallow caricatures (your dumb cardboard wife, or the main fucking character being a chadlord mcgee). These characters spend their time completely ignoring the context of this brutally racist (albeit futuristic and campy) Nazi Germany and, for the love of god, why is everyone having fucking babies? I cannot recommend this game at all, because the writing is essentially trying to be so bad it's good, and you can't DO that! Not intentionally, at least. 

Spoilers:
In the second fucking cutscene you are forced to endure ridiculous and cheesy depictions of childhood abuse, including the murder of your pet dog. In a game about campy nazi shooting... they felt this was a solid theme to explore in the OPENING OF THE GAME. Unskippable nonsense. And before you think there is some larger story to explore here, well, later on in the game you return to your childhood home and I guess murder your father? With the same cold, distant method by which you murder like 10,000 nazi soldiers, you 'Press Middle Mouse Button to Murder your Father'. And that serves as a 'story arc' or something. It's like they copy pasted the wiki article on character development. lol what a fucking joke

The rest of the game was fun in a vague way, though the level design was mostly just a re-hashing of the various levels from the Half Life games. ultimately it was uninventive compared to the first in this reboot series. The guns were enjoyable to learn. 

Hire some new writers, or don't give them the tools to direct in-game cutscenes, or.. just drop the pretense a game like this needs a story full of characters. This review has nothing to do with having a diverse cast, which I felt was welcome and made sense in a story about fighting classic racist types, you know, Nazis. However, the universe of Wolfenstein II is not conducive to interesting character development, and regardless of your rendered setpieces or wacky deus ex machinas, the story was ultimately just really fucking boring. zzzzzzzzzzzzzz

I haven't been more divided with a game than I have been with Wolfenstein II The New Colossus. There are so many things Wolf 2 gets right, but the things this game does wrong, can ruin the whole experience for some people. Machine Games are clearly a very talented studio who love what they do, and love Wolfenstein. Even with the issues I have with this game, I am still excited for what they will do next, and this title gets a strong 6 to a light 7, but more on the 7 side on my non existent numerical rating system. 

The part Wolf 2 had the most effort put into was definitely the story, which I actually think is really good. Most people may scoff at the fact that the game is 60% story, 40% shooting, but at least the story is really well done that I am interested in watching the beautifully animated cut scenes with incredible voice acting. Wolf 2 is a mid point between the spark that was Wolfenstein The New Order and what hopefully will be the bombastic finish that will be Wolfenstein 3. Focusing on the softer side of BJ Blaszkowicz journey, Wolf 2 shows that even the strongest of FPS protagonists are still made of flesh and bone. I also love how Nu-Wolfenstein blends really serious characters and dreadful situations based on real horrors of facism and Nazis, is blended with this Tarantino-esque, or Matthew Vaughn style pulpy, blatantly video game plot that only a Wolfenstein game can get away with. If you want a more thorough examination of the story of Wolf 2 with spoilers, I really suggest watching the video by Errant Signal because almost everything he says I agree with. But being as vauge as possible, Wolf 2 has one of the better written stories in the Half Life clone genre of action FPS games, and I am glued to the screen whenever a cut scene occurs or a character is speaking to me.

However, most people come to Wolfenstein for tearing Nazis to Heinz Ketchup, and unfortunately this is where the game really stumbles. Lets get the positives out of the way first. The weapons feel and sound great, and when every thing is working just as I expect it to, I am having the time of my life. Nazis fall apart with ease from dual wielding shotguns, or shredding them with dual assault rifles. The action in Wolf 2, when it is working is even better than what The New Order had and then some. My issues with this game all stem from the controls and the level design which potentially can ruin all the positives above. Being built on ID Software's at the time latest ID Tech Engine, a lot of traits relating to controls carried over to Wolf 2 from the acclaimed Doom 2016, specifically the character speed. When sprinting and even when walking, BJ moves at Super Sonic Speed, in really cramped levels. You will stumble on things you do not see because of how fast you move in these tight levels, which only offers close quarters combat situations. Okay, not off to a great start. Next, one thing I did not expect with the movement itself is that it feels really slippery and wonky. Because BJ is a full body character now, which really impressed me as an animator, as a responsive FPS character, something about the movement feels really off. Its almost if, BJ has butter on his shoes, but when he runs into a pebble, he stops. Because of your frustrating controls and really cramped level design, you will die really fast, even on lower difficulties. BJ's health drops at the drop of a hat even with maximum health or armor because the damage model is completely off. All of this, in addition to a wonky mixed dual wielding weapon system where you can now equip two different weapons at once, Wolf 2 has some of the most frustrating controls and level design in an FPS game I have played as of late, which is a darn shame because the weapons are fun to use when the level design opens up a bit.

As far as presentation goes, I also had some issues. The game performs really well on my 980ti, 4790k system running at 1440p,  but I had some weird game breaking crashes where some saves were unusable upon reloading my save. Thankfully this was early in my 3rd play through so it wasn't that painful, but your mileage may vary. The game looks really great with many graphical effects like global illumination, physically based rendering and really satisfying gore effects. The texture work is top notch and the character models and animations again are really well done. I especially love the way the game renders eye balls, they look so good in these Nu-Wolfenstein games. The soundtrack by Mick Gordon and Martin Stig Andersen is obviously really great, Mick Gordon providing the fist pumping industrial combat music, and Andersen serving some really creepy dark ambient pieces, reminiscent of his work on Playdead games. The sound design is also awesome with beefy weapon sounds, nice ambient sound effects, and some of the best voice acting I have heard in an FPS. Overall, the presentation when it is working is even better than The New Order, but the technical issues may get in the way of enjoying this title.

Wolfenstein II The New Colossus gets most things right as far as presentation and story goes, but the game play is a step backwards for the most unexpected reasons. All of these problems I think could have been fixed with a fan patch or some quick number swapping on the damage values for enemies and your weapons, but unfortunately Wolf 2 stumbles on what I expect from a Wolfenstein game, sending Nazis back to Hell where they belong. There is a wonderful game here, I can see it through the too tight level design, but it just doesn't work all the time. That is why it gets the lightest 7 out of 10 for me, just because when the game is firing on all cylinders, It is better than The New Colossus, but most of the time, when the game is not showing a beautiful cut scene, its a frustrating mess.

This game is, in many ways, a mockery of what Wolf. New Order was. 
The art direction (apart from the casting on Venus) is uninspired and generic
The gunplay and combat physics are less smooth
The new characters are annoying however the old characters are expanded on and actually are likable (like Set Roth)

Finally the story;
It is a joke, and not in a good way. New Order tied the snippets of gameplay and story together extremely well and immersed you as being part of a resistance in a dominated world. Things made sense.
New Colossus takes that to an absurd level, where the Kreisau is essentially invincible and manages to complete feats that don't make any sense whatsoever.
For brevity, I will take the example of the moon in New Order. The buildup took time, and created suspense until you manage to reach the base. It felt powerful because it bloody was. Meanwhile Old Blood takes something that is EVEN MORE IMPRESSIVE AND AMAZING and makes you appear there with nothing to it.

I wanted to like this game, force myself even, as New Order is one of my favourite games of all time, but I simply cannot. And with Youngblood apparently being even worse than this, I don't think I will return to this franchise again. RIP Wolf, time to wait for another sci-fi Notsee game

The most annoying part of all of it is that your right gun will randomly switch, it would make sense if it is an AI preemptively switching your gun to better suit the situation but they don't. I've never seen a game try so hard to be "edgy." The end result is a weird amalgamation of what appears to be social justice messaging and clumsily racist tropes, which really distract from what should have been a fun action game. The main character's internal monologue in the first few chapters is the cringiest thing I've ever heard in any game ever.

Gameplay-wise, they kinda tried to introduce a stealth mechanic, but it doesn't work very well. You can dual-wield weapons, but there doesn't seem to be much benefit to doing so. There are some gadgets that allow slightly different ways to traverse levels, but those aren't all that interesting either. It's a pretty run of the mill FPS. It feels shorter and all-around "less" than I remember New Order being, but I admit it's been a while since I played that one.

Graphics and story wise has improved greatly compared to the first two.However game play wise it feels like a step down with forced stealth mechanics and clunky gun menu.Still great shooting mechanics regardless and a solid game.

Honestly, I was expecting a bit more with this game. Don't get me wrong, the cut scenes are sometimes absolutely hilarious and the jokes are on point, but that's really all that's great about this game. Overall, if a comedic story game is what you are looking for, then this game could be it, but if you care about anything else, I wouldn't recommend this game at all. 

The combat/gunplay feel clunky at best and just downright not fun at other times. Selecting your weapon is a very annoying process as using the weapon select system leads to many frustrations of accidentally choosing the wrong weapon. The dual wielding concept is interesting at first, but it just feels extremely clunky especially when shooting. Switching weapons with duel wielding is very time consuming as if I wanted to use a longer range weapon I'd need to switch off duel-wielding, then switch to that desired weapon. Whilst you could use Q (or whatever keybind for switch to last used weapon) and that would solve this problem, I've personally encountered many times where I forgot that the last used weapon wasn't the long range weapon I desired and just switched to a gun/guns that I didn't want in that situation. 

Level design wise, I think they are okay, no complaints for the most part, but nothing stunning/spectacular. In the beginning of the game, it explains that you can try to stealth some levels but honestly, you can easily tell that this isn't a stealth game. Not only are most level just not made for stealth, the enemy detection system is straight up garbage. After playing through the entire game I'm still not sure what/how the enemy detection system works. In most stealth games you have either a indicator that an enemy has seen you and while sometimes there is a verbal cue that enemies may have heard or seen you, I've been caught hiding behind boxes while others times I've looked straight at an enemy and they just don't see me. That aside, another gripe I have with the level design it is sometimes difficult to know where you need to go as there is no obvious signage/visual cue as to know where to go. If not for the helpful "tell me where to go" button, I would have been completely lost. The map is legit useless as I've never found it useful whenever I got lost. 

Besides the jokes I really would have liked getting more story/background on the characters. They feel almost robotic sometimes and you just can't/don't get attached to these characters at all. Maybe this is due to the comedic nature of the story, but it's just hard to convey a serious idea. Death is treated almost like a joke and while that isn't an issue, the reaction I get when they kill a character is "Oh, Unfortunate". The lack of character development paired up with the type of story telling just doesn't pair up well and leads to characters/npcs that I just don't really care about. 

This has been a pretty long review I must say, but if you only can take one piece of information from this review, then that point would be that this game is not meant for those looking for a fun shooting game, nor is it a game for stealth and strategy. It is a loud n proud shoot em up type game with honestly an unamusing gunplay and mediocre story telling aside from the jokes.

I really, really wanted to like this game.

Wolfenstein II still knows how to let you have fun tearing apart the scum of the Earth, also known as Nazis. It continues the franchise's proud tradition of over-the-top baddies and over-the-top violence. Released in an era when it seemed that you couldn't call Nazis Nazis without receiving a bunch of idiotic blowback, it could have been the middle finger to modern Nazis that we needed.

If only it worked. If only it hadn't crash-landed the ending. I don't just mean the closing scene that, if you haven't been spoiled on yet, good for you. No, before that is a final boss fight that does not announce itself as a final boss fight like a proper game should. Worse, at that point you can't go back to the sub and get the brute-force upgrades that will actually help you in this fight, not the stealth upgrades that amount to very little here. And if you beat that fight, get ready for a penultimate cutscene that is one of the most ridiculous, gratuitous scenes ever released in a video game.

Besides that, there is an annoying Enigma Machine and a clunky mechanism to pick up weapons and armor. Most of the characters in the storyline don't resonate; Sigrun's and Grace's story arcs in particular were letdowns. On top of that, all that Wolfenstein II seemed to say about resistance to Naziism is that its cause was for "freedom." Freedom? That's all Bethesda wants us to think the Nazis took away? Come on. The most satisfying part of the game to me was Wolfstone, which is nearly the original Wolfenstein 3D with mostly minor changes. Sidequests should not be more fun than the main storyline! Bethesda, you can try harder than that.

You might find the game worth it just to advance the franchise if you can get it on sale. Don't waste your money on a full-price purchase. It's not worth it.

The New Colossus is a continuation of the story in The New Order. It definitely feels like Machinegames hit their groove with this game. The combat is spastic, bloody and fun while offering a story that sees the development of its characters. Enemies can be relentless, but each can be taken down with tactics and patience. The enemy scaling is linear, which means that there isn't such a massive difference between the average Nazi foot soldier and the supersoldiers. To use an analogy, compare the supersoldiers in Wolfenstein to Halo's Brutes, where Halo 2's were like bullet sponges and Halo 3's were more like facing an Elite. You have to be smart about using cover and the right weapon and watching your ammo counter, but you won't feel like the game is throwing you into a gauntlet every time a supersoldier comes your way. And believe me, the supersoldiers are small potatoes compared to the bigger and badder enemies The New Colossus has in store for you! It's a fair change. 

Eva's Hammer becomes your base of operations and as you progress through the story, you get to see your fellow teammates interact with each other in meaningful ways and often quite hilariously. Wyatt has a pretty good character arc if you've chosen him instead of Fergus as the one to be spared from Deathshead's experiment. Sigrun also has a pretty good character arc. B.J. himself is struggling to keep going while on the verge of death and with the thought of Anya having to raise their kids herself and the death of a former comrade both lingering heavily in his mind. I love his narration so so much. I've gotta address an elephant in the room here. You've probably noticed that other players have complained about Grace and taking a dislike to her outspoken opinions as well as her group's association with Communism. Listen: this game takes place in 1961, in a timeline where the Civil Rights Movement is almost non-existent because the country is under the control of white supremacists and fucking Nazis. But just like how early Civil Rights Activists sided with Communists, so too do people of color like Grace. If you know your history, you'd know Southern Capitalists didn't give a damn about black people. What's the enemy of my enemy? Just like in real life, in this game's universe the enemy of the enemy of black activists, including the Black Revolutionary Front, is going to be Communists. And we all know Communism failed (and where it exists, continues to fail) because it probably cares even LESS about liberating people than Capitalism, so enough with the hand-wringing and pearl-clutching about Machinegames perverting this game into cOmMuNiSt pRoPaGaNdA. Stop that. You sound so stupid when you treat everything that pays even the littlest bit of attention to historical detail and fact as some kind of America-hating liberal conspiracy. Alright? Grace was a former member of the Black Revolutionary Front (which was a black nationalist group), so excuse her for having certain opinions that are going to be pretty disagreeable. Even Malcolm X distanced himself from black nationalist groups. Get over it. Don't be obtuse. Not YOU, though. You're not buying into that nonsense, which is why you're still reading this review. Good for you! You're one of the good ones. I apologize if I sounded accusatory. Grace is a great character. You will learn to love to her and her fucking brilliant/hilarious plan of stowing a nuke in a fire extinguisher and dressing up B.J. as a firefighter so he and her crazy lawyer/amateur-ufologist hubby Super Spesh can smuggle it deep into Nazi/KKK territory. Goddamnit, I love this game so much.

Besides the main story, there are also plenty of items to collect, including kits to improve your weapons. After finishing the main story (and witnessing a spectacular end to the most evil bitch in Wolfenstein history), you can crack codes to discover the location of high-ranking Nazi officers and systematically send them straight to hell. Also don't forget that you can also play a Nazi-twisted version of Wolfenstein 3D, where you play as Terror Billy playing an arcade game where he's Nazi soldier whose mission is to search and terminate...Terror Billy. Trippy. This game has no right to be as good as it is. It's one for the books. Buy it. Play it. Love it.

The New Order was a solidly built and reasonably enjoyable game, but in between a fairly impressive field in 2014 and a huge lack of personality ultimately faded into the background a little.

What Machine did with TNC though is something most AAA studios could stand to learn from - not only did they refine the design, gameplay and visuals to the point of making one of the most genuinely immersive (and genuinely fun) gaming experiences of 2017, but they gave it enough nuance and pathos to reach a level of genuine emotional affect a good chunk of its competition can only aspire to - which pairs beautifully with the tension and release of the new and improved gameplay like a fifteen hundred dollar glass of Bordeaux with the ratatouille they made in Ratatouille (2007).

It's not bad, but it's incredibly bland and average. It would have worked as an expansion for the first game, as it does not iterate on anything. 

- Level design is bland, and not particularly intuitive. Game takes about 7 to 8 hours. Difficult darts all over the place, I found myself dying in early sections, and steamrolling the game in later levels, then getting to a part where I would just restart all the time. The final airship fight, you basically have to cheese the AI.

- Gunplay is functional, but the dual wield seems to serve little purpose. I found myself only using the assault rifle throughout the game as the rest of the guns don't really seem to have much going for them.

- Characters and dialogue are cringe, and seem to be all stereotypes. Not exactly sure what the Hitler scene where he's shitting and pissing and farting was about, but whatevs.

- Story is just confusing. BJ, go and get this magguffin, now collect these people who do nothing for the plot, now go and get this magguffin. 

- Graphics are decent though, so that's a winner.

So story is a no-go for me. This plays more like a coin-up arcade shooter with really cool guns. It is nice looking I give them that. I'm still amazed that we should feel immersed in the world by picking up "star cards", gold (yeah let me carry three gold bars here for fun) or in-game concept art? The spread out books and leaflets are of course a way to build meta-story and proven to work but placement and frequency is just weird here.

I'm going to be honest this: this game blows. There is so much wrong with it, that I hardly even know where to begin my rant ...

Let's begin with the best thing in the game: the gameplay. It's OK. It's basically exactly the same as Wolfenstein The New Order. More or less the same enemies, the same weapons, the same mechanics. The problem is also: there is nothing new and exciting.

There is a severe lack of variety and nothing is memorable. A lot of levels look the same: you have the inside of a military base, ruins, more ruins, more military base, yet more ruins and a foreign, red planet (with a military base, what did you expect) Because the previous game also took it to space of course!

Level design is boring, not to mention confusing because it all looks the same: endless boring corridor after endless boring corridor filled with the same after same after same after bloody god damn same fucking enemy.

I finished the game and hardly any level in particular stands out in a good way. Looking back at the game, my memories are more like: New York, oh yeah that level was terrible. Roswell ... Roswell ... Roswell ... wait, was Roswell in the game? Ah yeah, I remember the non-combat intro. Hollywood ... hmm, did I really go to Hollywood?

The difficulty is fairly high so you are encouraged to make use of the stealth system (lifted straight from the previous games). Stealth is hard as well, but often just boils down to relentlessly reloading which pads out the game's length nicely. The alternative is playing it as a cover based shooter, also unnecessarily lengthening combat.

Once you get the hang of the stealth mechanics you can complete fights just fine. The only really difficult parts are when swarms of enemies are thrown at you in arena style, but there are just so many health packs and ammo lying around that it ends up an exercise in taking care of everyone in the optimal order rather than actual playing skill.

Also, the game is fairly short if you take away all the padding and cutscenes. It tries to lengthen the playtime with "enigma levels", but those are nothing more than replaying previous levels and could not really interest me.

Oh yeah: the RPG-ish perks that you can level up are back again as well. They are even more uninspired and pointless now.

So sameish combat in boring levels. The gameplay is mildly entertaining mostly because its just copy/pasted from the better Wolfenstein games. Those were the "good" things I have to say ...

Up to the bad stuff:

First of all, a special mention must be made of the writing. The writing is terrible, it's just plain horrible. The script is mind-numbingly bad: not "so campy bad it's good", but just plain stupid, riddled with plot holes, eye-watering awful dialogue and retarded developments in the plot.

An example: your team just witnessed the horror of a nuclear explosion onto a mostly inhabited city, big emphasis on the word "horror". First reaction: "Hey, how about we make a nuke of our own go boom, on a populated American city?" WTF? I mean: WTF? Who the hell comes up with this sort of stuff?

The cutscenes are boring and overly long. And the attempts at humor fall flat on their face.

Seriously, there were cutscenes where I said out loud "What?" thinking I misheard. I never, ever talked to my computer before. I can only assume that, to keep in the spirit of the "everyone is special" doctrine (lots more on that below), they outsourced the writing to a team of mentally disabled 9-year olds. And the Bethesda peeps then took out the most clever and best bit from that unholy retarded storyboard and presented it as their own. That would explain how come everyone in this game, including the main character, acts like a retard.

(I admit that was not a very political correct thing of me to say. Maybe I should apologize and say that I didn't mean it ... but I'm a bad liar so I won‚Äôt be doing that.)

Speaking about politically correct ...

This game is so overly politically correct that it is cringy. It actually hurts the game, as if the developers decided to move everything aside if it would make the result even more PC.

And that result is an utterly predictable and forgettable stereotype of a game. All colours and kinds of people are living in perfect harmony like a big happy family, talking about feelings and sipping herb tea and shedding tears together over memories lost. Of course a strong black female leader pops up out of nowhere, hoodrats turn out the most clever computer operators, women are all strong and independent (unless they‚Äôre Nazi‚Äôs), interracial relationships are promoted and everyone who is white is pictured as a coward (that is literally said in the game by the way). The "good" white guys on your team are on the other hand depicted as either (drug-addicted) lunatics, or a guy that worships a toilet. He literally kneels and prays to a toilet! I actually feel more stupid after some of the cutscenes in this game.

Yes indeed, the game is so politically correct that the game is actually racist. No joke: our protagonist screams out lines like: "White ass Nazi facist".

Yes, Nazi's that are also fascists! Someone flunked history 101.

Yet at the same time ... the game goes completely out of its way to portrait this perfect multicultural team as a bunch of incompetent cowards and lazy slobs. They barely do anything except talking hippie-bull crap, while leaving it up to you to solve their problems. Another example: they have a massive nuclear submarine at their disposal. The only thing they do with this powerhouse is making a massive mess of it while you're away.

Sigh.

I mean: if you sacrifice the entire story, dialogues and cutscenes of your game in order to show that stereotypes are bad, then I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôre not supposed to play it out in a way that only confirms the traditional stereotypes, m‚Äôkay?

Oh ... oh ... oh ... I still need to bring out my love-hate (well, actually only hate) relationship with the protagonist. He is the most annoying and uninteresting character on a submarine full of uninteresting characters.

For the first half of the game, BJ is an annoying crybaby who sputters sad one-liners just because a Nazi looked at him disapprovingly, there wasn't enough milk in his cereal that morning or he put on his skirt back-ways or whatever. And even in the second half, when BJ gets the courage to exchange his purse for an extra rocket launcher, he still behaves like a spineless doormat.

‚ÄúAnya grant me your wings!‚Äù Hey, it's like I'm playing May Payne 3 all over again.

You know what BJ? I don't care about your emo mumbo-jumbo, I don't care about your socio-politic views, I don't care about your kid and I don't fucking care about your dog. All I want to do is shoot some Nazi's in fun and creative (preferably also very very gory) ways. How the hell you you screw up a game like Wolfenstein???? This is Wolfenstein, this is the grandfather of shooters, why did they try to make it into a high-school soap opera?

You know what: the entire game I thought that the final sequence would be: "Blastowicz wakes up from having passed out at the end of Wolfenstein The New Order. Phew, he things to himself, it was all just a bad dream." No dice.

PRESS E TO WIN FINALE??????? God-bloody-damned! Why, God, just why?
